From "server raids", when a group of users joins a server at same time to cause chaos, to "grief trolling", when someone attempts to make jokes degrades deceased their next of kin, this type of negative behavior is rooted in disruption harassment, is not tolerated on our platform -- no matter how harmless instigators may think it is. aI hate saying asticks stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me,a because words hurt,a said Patricia Noel, Discordas mental health policy manager who is a licensed social worker has a background in youth mental health. She collaborates cross-functionally within Discord with external partners, such as Crisis Text Line, with goal of providing tools resources to teens who may be experiencing mental health challenges. Why education is as important as enforcement Part of enforcement strategy for bullying harassment is to include a series of warnings, with escalating enforcement actions aimed at educating users, namely teens, that certain behaviors are not OK on Discord. a aThis generation is really empathetic. But I also know that there are people who go online just for sake of going online being a troll,a Noel said. aThose might be very same folks who are having problems at home, who are dealing with their own mental health well being issues. They might not immediately recognize that they are doing harm to someone else.a Understanding that young people are going to make mistakes is reflected in how new warning system handles suspensions. For lower harm violations falling under Bullying Harassment policy, Discord will test suspensions rather than permanent bans. idea here is that some teens may need a long pause before coming back to platform, given how much growth development occurs during each year of adolescence. while there will always be a zero-tolerance policy for most serious violations, Discord will focus on remediation, when appropriate, for topics like bullying harassment. This is so teens can have an opportunity to pause, acknowledge that they did something wrong, hopefully change their behavior. challenge is that behavior is so wide-ranging, said Ben Shanken, Discordas Vice President of Product. He pointed to a recent analysis by Discord that looked at reports of bullying in large, discoverable servers. aIf you put these examples on an SAT test asked, aIs this bullying? Many people probably would answer questions incorrectly,a he said, noting how Discordas large teen user base is inclined to atroll-ya behavior. In one example, Shanken shared how teens were trolling each other by deceptively reporting their friends to Discord for supposedly being underage when in fact they were not. Itas trolling. While itas not nice, itas also part of how teens joke around. But, instead of simply banning offender, we build in an opportunity where they can learn from their mistake. aIf we ban a person, they don't know what they did wrong, they likely won't change their behavior,a said Shanken. aGiving them a warning saying, here's what you did wrong, flips script in a more constructive way. At its core, Discord is a place where people can come together to build genuine friendships. Educating users, especially young people, through our warning system is one part of Discordas holistic strategy to cultivate safe spaces where users can make meaningful connections. nature of being a teenager navigating relationships can be tricky. There are going to be situations where you hurt people's feelings. There may be moments where users lose their cool say something really mean even vaguely threatening,a Riggio said. aWe want to build in more of a runway for them to make mistakes online but also learn from them.a Remediation: Why you canat ban your way to a safe platform Discordas remediation philosophy Our approach to remediation is inspired by restorative justice, a concept from criminal justice that prioritizes repairing harm over punishment. Discordas Community Guidelines exist to keep people communities safe, itas important to make sure everyone knows how why to follow them. still, when people break rules, most of time they deserve a chance to correct themselves show that theyave learned. When users break an online platformas rules, they donat always do so intentionally. Consider how many different platforms someone might use in a day, each with their own rules expectations. Discord needs to enforce its own Community Guidelines, while understanding that a user who violates Guidelines might not even know they had broken a rule in first place. aA lot of users have their own aterms of servicea that may be different from ours,a said Jenna Passmore, Discordas senior staff product designer for safety. Admins moderators set rules, norms, expectations for their own servers on top of Discordas Community Guidelines Terms of Service, users may not know when theyare breaching rules of a server platform. aIf there's a mismatch there, itas not a severe violation, we don't want to kick them off platform.a Instead, Discord wants to teach people how to stay in bounds keep themselves, their friends, their communities safe fun for everyone. And, to be clear, when it comes to most severe violationsasuch as those involving violent extremism anything that endangers exploits childrenaDiscord will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy. Putting users in charge of outcomes In most cases, breaking Discordas Community Guidelines triggers a series of events that are aimed at returning user to their community with a better understanding of how they should behave. Education comes first. When Discord spots a violation, it lets a user know what specific thing they did wrong. Theyare prompted to learn more, in plain language, about that rule why it matters. Nobody expects someone to memorize full Community Guidelines Terms of Service, but this is best moment to help them learn what they need to know. Consequences come next. Any penalties we impose are transparent match severity of violation. A first-time, low-level violation, for example, could prompt a warning, removal of offending content, a cooling-off period with temporary restrictions on account activity. When action Discord takes to enforce its Community Guidelines takes proper measure of violation provides users a path back to good standing, users can often return to their community with a greater understanding of rules need to change their own behavior. If users stay on good terms, similar violations in future will play out roughly same way. If they continue to break rules frequently, violations stack up, so do consequences. idea is to provide users an opportunity to learn from their mistakes, change their behavior, therefore stay in communities they know trust on Discord, rather than pushing users who violate Discordas Community Guidelines off platform to other spaces that tolerate encourage bad behavior. aWe want users to feel like they have some agency over what's going to happen next,a Passmore said. aWe want an avenue for folks to see our line of thinking: You violated this policy, this is what we're doing to your account. Learn more about this policy, please don't do this again. If you do it again, here's what's going to happen to your account.a Banning is reserved for most extreme cases, highest-harm violations result in immediate bans. Otherwise, if someone repeatedly demonstrates that they wonat play by rules, consequences become more severe, from losing access to their account for a month, to a year, eventuallyaif they continue to violate Community Guidelinesafor good. Everyone knows where they stand Remediation depends on users who are able to learn change their behavior being able to return to good standing. Discordas account standing meter lets users see how their past activity affects what theyare able to do on platform. standing meter has five levels: good, limited, very limited, at risk, banned. aFor most folks, it will always be agooda,a Passmore said. When itas not, hope is that someone will act more thoughtfully so they can return to that good status stay there. She compared it to road signs that show risk level for wildfires. aIt changes your behavior when youare driving through a national park you see that thereas a moderate fire risk,a she said. Discordas internal policies outline severity of each type of violation, appropriate consequence, how one type of violation compares to others. These policies help ensure that employees who review violations of Discordas Community Guidelines enforce rules fairly consistently. That means when someone breaks rules, employees arenat deciding punishment on an ad hoc basis. Instead, outcome is determined by severity number of violations. aOur goal is to help people act better,a said Ben Shanken, Discordas vice president of product, who oversees teams that work on growth, safety, user experience. aPeople don't always know that they're doing bad things, giving them a warning can help them to improve.a Ultimately, we believe that guiding users toward better behavioraand giving them tools they need to learnaresults in a better experience for everyone. Bringing Policies to Life Discordas policy team invests time resources into understanding dynamics of type of behavior theyare writing policies about. aThe team does a significant amount of research to understand: What is phenomenon? What does this issue look like on other platforms? What does issue look like in society?a said Bri Riggio, senior platform policy manager who oversees this process. policy team reviews scholarly research, data, nonprofit industry guidance, among other resources. They bring in external subject matter experts from around globe, like academics who study online behavior legal scholars who focus on sexual harassment. They also do internal research. They interviewed Discordas Trust & Safety teamathe ones who review content for violationsato see examples of what they consider bullying harassment.A One thing policy team keeps in mind during this stage is how this research pertains to teens. aTeens are at forefront of my researchathinking about how we protect young people who are online making sure they feel safe comfortable using Discord,a said Edith Gonzalez, a platform policy specialist. She added that she looks for research that addresses parents' concerns when it comes to issues such as cyberbullying. At heart of each policy, Riggio her team start by asking question: What is problem that we are trying to solve on Discord? She calls this idea aspirita of policy. aIf we are trying to stop users from feeling psychological emotional harm from other users, if we want them to have a good experience, then we write policy to try drive towards that north star,a she said. aIt can be a guiding force for us, especially when we get escalations edge cases where policy may not be so clear cut.a For example, if Trust & Safety team gets a report of content that was flagged for bullying, but content falls somewhere in a gray area itas not clear if content was intentional, team discusses if taking action under policy is actually going to solve problem not. Another way of putting it: Does it go against spirit of policy? These discussions inform how policy team can sharpen better articulate policies over time. Policy specialists like Gonzalez begin listing all different behaviors that describe issue. For bullying harassment, examples might include: sexual harassment, server raids, sending shock content, mocking a person's death. aOnce I write down all criteria, I expand each behavior,a said Gonzalez. aHow do you define a violent tragedy? How do you define mocking? How do you define unwanted sexual harassment? Slowly, policy starts off as a list, then I keep expanding it.a For this policy, we define bullying as unwanted behavior purposefully conducted by an individual group of people to cause distress intimidate, harassment as abusive behavior towards an individual group of people that contributes to psychological reputational harm that continues over time. Riggio points out significance of sustained behavior. Itas an acknowledgment that context matters. For example, what may be friendly banter joking between individuals could be misconstrued as harassment, not taking into account that friends sometimes joke around with each other. aWe would be potentially over-enforcing policy with users who are just having fun with each other.a Research experience tell us that people donat always know rules, when appropriate, they need an opportunity to learn from their mistakes. Discord built a warning system that helps educate users, especially teens. (Important note: warning system does not apply to illegal more harmful violations, such as violent extremism endangering children. Discord has a zero-tolerance policy against those activities.) aThere's a perception that teens will roll their eyes at a rule, they don't like rules, but reality is, teens really like it when there are clear rules that resonate with them,a said Liz Hegarty, Discordas global teen safety policy manager. Once they learn rule, they might slip up again, so policy team built in several opportunities to educate teens that bullying isnat allowed. These show up in form of a series of time-outs, versus a flat-out ban after a few strikes, as is common on other platforms. aItas teen-centered,a said Hegarty. aIt's this idea of: how can you educate as opposed to just punishing teenagers when they're making mistakes?a This, too, reflects spirit of Bullying Harassment policy, because ultimately, Discord wants to empower people to build meaningful relationships on platform. aThe spirit is intended to get at various behaviors that we know make users feel uncomfortable,a said Riggio. aThatas behavior that impacts feelings of safety culture of a community.a Our Approach to Content Moderation Moderation across Discord All users have ability to report behavior to Discord. User reports are processed by our Safety team for violative behavior so we can take enforcement actions where appropriate. Discord also works hard to proactively identify harmful content conduct so we can remove it therefore expose fewer users to it. We work to prioritize highest harm issues such as child safety violent extremism. We use a variety of techniques technology to identify this behavior, including: In larger communities, we may use automated means to proactively identify harmful content on platform enforce our Terms of Service Community Guidelines.A If we identify a violation, we then determine appropriate intervention based on content conduct take action such as removing content suspending a user account. result of our actions are conveyed to users through our Warning System. Creating a safe teen experience In addition to all measures we've outlined above, we add layers of protection for teen users. Our proactive approach for teens has additional layers of safe keeping because we believe in protecting most vulnerable populations on Discord. For teens, we may monitor content activity associated with teen accounts to identify possible situations of unwanted messages through Teen Safety Assist. For example, if we detect potentially unwanted DM activity directed at a teen account, we may send a safety alert in chat to give teen account information about how they might handle situation. (For messages between adults, we do not proactively scan read content by default.) Together we are building a safer place for everyone to hang out. To stay up to date on our latest policies check out our Policy Hub. Culture of Safety What do we mean by safety? When we talk about protecting users, weare talking about preventing them from anything that could cause harm. That includes things like harassment, hateful conduct, unwanted interactions from others, inappropriate contact, violent abusive imagery, violent extremism, misinformation, spam, fraud, scams, other illegal behavior. Itas a broad set of experiences, but each of them can affect someoneas life negatively in real ways. They also degrade overall experience of community where they happen. In addition to keeping users safe, we also need them to feel safe. Thatas why we talk openly about our work, publish safety metrics each quarter, give everyone access to resources in our Safety Center. A culture of safety starts with people building technology Discordas commitment to safety is reflected in its staff way we build our products. Over 15% of our staff works directly on team that ensures our users have a safe experience. We invest time resources here because keeping users safe is a core responsibility: Itas central to our mission to create best place to hang out online talk to friends. Our safety work includes experts from all parts of company, with a wide range of backgrounds. These experts are engineers, product managers, designers, legal experts, policy experts, more. Some have worked in technology, but also social work, teen media, human rights, international law. Building a diverse team like this helps ensure we get a 360-degree view on threats risks, best ways to protect against them. We also invest in proactively detecting removing harmful content before it is viewed experienced by others. During fourth quarter of 2023, 94% of all servers that were removed were removed proactively. Weave built specialized teams, formed external partnerships with industry experts, integrated advanced technology machine learning to keep us at cutting edge of providing a safe experience for users. Getting users engaged in safety While rules technical capabilities lay foundation, users play a central part in making servers safe for themselves others. Our Community Guidelines clearly communicate what activities arenat allowed on Discord. We warn, restrict, even ban users servers if they violate those rules. But we donat want to spend our days chastising punishing people, we donat want people to worry that theyare always at risk of being reported. Thatas no way to have fun with friends. Instead, we help users understand when theyave done something wrong nudge them to change their behavior. When people internalize rules that way, they recognize when they, someone else, might be breaking them. They discuss rules organically, in process build a shared sense of what keeps their community safe in good standing. This has a multiplier effect on our work to build safer spaces: Users act with greater intention they more proactively moderate themselves their communities against unsafe actions. When communities have this shared commitment to rules, theyare also more likely to report harmful activity that could put an otherwise healthy community at risk. Changing safety narrative Itas sometimes said in technology that a platform canat really reduce harm block bad actors from doing bad things. Instead, those actions have to be addressed after they happen, when theyare reported detected. At Discord, we have loftier goals than that. We actually want to reduce harm. We want to make it so hard for bad actors to use our platform that they donat even try. For everyone else, we want to build products provide guidance that make safety not just a technical accomplishment, but a cultural value throughout our company communities we support. How Do aTeensa Rightsa Show Up in Discordas Enforcement Policies? What is a teensa rights approach? A teensa rights approach honors young peopleas experience, including areas where they could use a little helpasay, when they push boundaries just a little too far succumb to peer pressure engage in inappropriate behavior online. idea comes from United Nationsa guidance on impact of digital technologies on young peopleas lives. For report, committee members consulted with governments, child experts, other human rights organizations to formulate a set of principles designed to aprotect fulfill childrenas rightsa in online spaces. committee also engaged those at center of reportayoung people themselves. UNas guidance was not only rooted in research, it treated teens with respect. It listened to them. It's this kind of holistic human rights approach that makes this body of work so influential, especially for child rights advocates. But itas also become a guiding force for Discord. aTeens are going to try things out, figure out who they are, make mistakes online. Discord is focused on guiding them through that process without being overly punitive cutting them off from their support networks their friends,a said Laney Cloyd, a senior product policy specialist. Cloyd her colleagues set out to construct a new warning system for when a teen breaks Discordas rules. They started with idea that young people are going to do regrettable things, like send their friend a link that says, aFortnite cheats herea aCute kitten picsa itas really an IP grabber. They may think it's funny not harmful, but itas still against rules. aWe can't be super punitive on first violation, because they don't know. We have to teach them,a said Cloyd. Of course, when someone violates rules, there should be consequences. But a teensa rights approach considers a personas potential to changeacall it a teachable moment. Teens need extra opportunities to figure out what boundaries are. Itas true when theyare at home with their parents, when theyare at school with their teachers, when theyare on platforms like Discord with its own set of community guidelines. Parents, teachers, coaches are there to tell young people whatas what. Discord saw an opportunity to play that role online: We built interactive educational moments that explain to a person what they did wrong. aAs opposed to just saying, ayou're kicked off, go read our guidelines,a we offer more guidance so they can do better,a said Liz Hegarty, Discordas global teen policy manager. Hegarty pointed to research that shows teens really aren't given great advice about how to handle themselves online. Platforms have a role to play in helping teens build their digital citizenship skills. All of this is part of Discordas philosophy for designing policies that hangs on belief that people are capable of change if you give them a chance, especially when those people are young still learning. They need a chance at rehabilitation. (An important caveat is that some violations are more serious than others, Discord takes appropriate action depending on severity of violation. For example, we have will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy towards violent extremism content that sexualizes children.) It might sound odd that a tech company would borrow ideas from preeminent human rights organization. But consider most foundational tenet of human rights: right to live freely safely. Platforms like Discord are most successful when they enable people to be themselves, have fun, make meaningful connectionsaall without fear threats to their safety well-being. How do teensa rights actually show up on Discord? To illustrate how teensa rights are woven into our warning system, take for example Discordas updated approach to enforcing our Bullying Harassment policy. First, itas helpful to understand that bullying is broken down into a number of different dimensions. One of those includes imminent threats of physical harmafor example, extortion a death threat. For violations of that severity, there are no second chances. Users donat get to do that on Discord. But for non-imminent non-physical threats, Discord has built in more opportunities for teens to get message that bullying isnat allowed. These show up in form of a series of time-outs. Say a teen has been flagged for harassing a useramaybe theyare degrading mocking someone. For their first violation, they would get a notice Discord would remove content. Then second time, theyall get a notice, content will get removed, teen will be placed in aread onlya mode for a set number of hours. If it keeps happening, Discord will apply longer longer time outs. Ultimately if teen doesnat change their behavior continues to engage in harassment sustained bullying, they can receive a yearas suspension. This approach is in contrast to a traditional athree strikes youare outa rule, where most violations, no matter how severe, would count against you, then after three dings, youare banned for good. Discordas more rehabilitative approach takes into account too-real probability that teens are going to make mistakes. aImagine a 14-year-old who falls in with a bad crowd engages in a bunch of bullying gets suspended for a year,a said Cloyd. aIf they return, a 15 year old is going to be a different person in a lot of fundamental ways.a new warning system is also geared toward addressing specific thing a teen did wrong. For example, letas say a teen posts an image that violates Discordas rules. An appropriate measure would be to turn off their ability to post images for a while, but they can still talk to their friends, join voice chats, play games. aWe're taking very targeted interventions not just slamming a big ban hammer down,a said Cloyd. aBecause you posted one wrong image you didn't know was wrong, wead block you out of app forever? That's not fair. That's not a learning experience.a Why do teens need special rights in digital spaces? aWe intuitively recognize that as children get a little bit older, they are autonomous humans. They have agency,a said Hegarty. aThey have right to access online spaces safely.a This goes back to UN document, which Hegarty first encountered before she came to Discord when she worked for a childrenas digital advocacy organization. aThe whole world is fairly new to thinking about how we handle teens in online spaces, especially when more more of their lives are taking place online. It has an impact across everything from telemedicine to education,a said Hegarty. Teens are at a transformative exciting stage of life. They get to explore world in new ways. They use platforms like Discord to find themselves make meaningful connections, but that can't be separated from potential that they'll make mistakes along way. Recognizing thataand helping them grow from itahelps keep everyone safer. Teachable Moments Hidden in Plain Sight Using research to help teens build their 'safety muscle' To do that, Discord works with organizations like Digital Wellness Lab at Boston Childrenas Hospital National PTA to understand needs of one of our largest user bases. aWe are experts in technology, not experts in teenagers. So we need to make sure we are pulling in expert research when we're thinking about what it means to be a safe, healthy ultimately, empowering place for young people,a said Liz Hegarty, Discordas global teen safety policy manager.A A Hegarty her colleagues are guided by research, which is empathetic to teens' lived experiences cautions against being overly paternalistic. For example, Digital Wellness Lab advises parents to resist urge to step in solve every problem for their teen, online off. Instead, they recommend asking probing questions talking through decision-making process. This can clear way to have more conversations about digital boundaries. aThese conversations can help teens build their safety musclea, said Hegarty. We built our Family Center with this idea in mind. Launched in 2023, Family Center is an opt-in tool that enables guardians, trusted adults, teens to alinka their accounts. While it allows parents to know who their teen is connected with, tool does not allow adults to see contents of their teenas conversations with friends. aThe key is to find balance between respecting teen autonomy agency while also giving parents ways to check in with their teensa, said Savannah Badalich, Discordas senior director of policy. aParents trusted adults in a teen's life are here to coach them,a said Badalich, who leads team responsible for key safety areas, such as teen safety mental health. aLet them explore themselves, let them find who they are. But give them parameters in which to do so.a There is a risk that a teen may choose not to talk at all if they feel they are being constantly monitored. This is why it's important to follow research. aLeading experts say that sort of parental surveillance does not always help generate safety create a trustworthy environment for teens to talk to their caregivers,a Hegarty said. Hegarty notes that when building Family Center tool, Discord decided to add an additional layer of support. As a teen connects with their parents, Discord surfaces information for Crisis Text Line (note that this is for users in U.S. only). This is a support line that provides free, 24/7 mental health support via text, WhatsApp, web chat. idea is to provide available resources to teens to encourage them to seek help if they need it. Itas another way we embed subtle lessons throughout experience. Weaving in teachable moments Discordas Teen Safety Assist includes two recently released safety features: one for when a teen receives a direct message (DM) from a user for first time, another that blurs potentially sensitive content in DMs group DMs with friends. When an alert is triggered, teen might see a pop-up that says, Unwanted message? If you donat want to chat with this person, you can block mute them.A They can then click to alearn more,a see a message that prompts aUnwanted message?a, as well as provides a set of tips for handling situation.a a aIt's this idea of educating as opposed to just punishing teenagers when they make mistakes,a said Hegarty. aIn moment, itas important to give teens resources, autonomy, agency, help.a Hegarty points to research about how teens are nervous to block other people. They're worried if person finds out they're blocked, teen is going to look uncool. Meanwhile, if they report, they arenat sure what will happen next. They are anxious about getting somebody in trouble. Research from Thorn, a leading child welfare nonprofit, also suggests that when teens encounter a potentially harmful experience online, they are less likely to seek support offline, such as talking to a trusted adult. So Discord is trying to meet teens where they are. aIt's not a paternalistic approach that protects teens from everything. Being overly restrictive risks them lacking necessary skills to move within world once they turn 18,a said Badalich. aInstead, let's educate them throughout their experience. Let's give them tools to control their experience.a Giving teens opportunities to learn Risk-taking is part of growing up. Itas part of being a teenager. aBecause their brain is still developing, they need options, time education,a said Badalich, whose team is also working to sharpen Discordas enforcement system with teens in mind. When it comes to developing policies rules that govern platform, Badalich her team are rethinking what that looks like, with understanding that teens need extra opportunities to learn. aKeep up, take down, ban have been main levers. we're continuing to explore even more ways to take necessary action,a said Badalich. For example, aWhen you think about someone talking about self-harm, do we really want to penalize them? do we want to figure out some other form of intervention?a To be clear, when it comes to most severe violationsasuch as those involving violent extremism content that sexualizes childrenaDiscord will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy. But when it comes to building out more nuanced, research-driven policies, policy team looks to lessons from restorative justice, a concept that recognizes that people are capable of change. aInstead of just being purely punitive all of time,a said Badalich, aDiscord wants to move in direction of where we are giving people opportunities to change, grow, learn.a Building a Safer Place for Teens to Hang Out Choose what you see who you want to hang with Introducing our new Teen Safety Assist initiative: Teen Safety Assist is focused on further protecting teens by introducing a new series of features, including multiple safety alerts sensitive content filters that will be default enabled for teen users. Starting next week, weare excited to release first two features of Teen Safety Assist initiative. Teens have shared that they like tools that help them avoid unwanted direct messages (DMs) media. To support this, weare rolling out safety alerts on senders sensitive content filters that automatically blur media that may be sensitive a even if sender doesnat initially blur it with a spoiler tag.A a Weave partnered with technology non-profit Thorn to design these features together based on their guidance on teen online safety behaviors what works best to help protect teens. Our partnership has focused on empowering teens to take control over safety how best to guide teens to helpful tips resources. Weare grateful for support of Thorn to ensure we build right protections empower teens with tools resources they need to have a safer online experience. first two features of Teen Safety initiative will start rolling out globally in November 2023 will be turned on by default for teen users. Stay tuned for many more features from this initiative as we look ahead to next year. Work together to keep each other safe We know mistakes happen rules are accidentally broken. Our new Warning System includes multiple touchpoints so users can easily understand rule violations consequences. These touchpoints provide more transparency into Discord interventions, letting users know how their violation may impact their overall account standing gives information for them to do better in future. We built this system so users can learn how to do better in future help keep all hangouts safe.A Some violations are more serious than others, weall take appropriate action depending on severity of violation. For example, we have will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy towards violent extremism content that sexualizes children. Warning System is built based on our teen-centric policies. This is a multi-year, focused effort to invest more deeply holistically into our teen safety efforts. We incorporate teen-centric philosophies in how we enforce our policies, assess risks of new products with Safety by Design, communicate our policies in an age-appropriate manner. For Warning System, this means that we consider how teens are growing, learning, taking age-appropriate risks as they mature, we give them more opportunities to learn from mistakes rather than punish them harshly. Warning System starts rolling out today in select regions. Stay tuned for many more updates to our Warning System in future. a For our server moderators admins, weave recently expanded their safety toolkit with new features that allow them to proactively identify potentially unsafe activity, such as server raids DM spam, take swift actions as needed.A We began rolling these tools in September to Community Servers, now weare rolling them out to all servers. You choose what stays private While you might be an open book with your friends, having your personal business out there for everyone to see can feel a bit weird. Thatas why you get to decide, from server to server, how much you want to share how easy it is to contact you. With Server Profiles, you can adjust to how you present yourself in different spaces, allowing you to be as much of real ayoua as you feel comfortable being in any particular group.A You can also always try turning on Message Requests: a feature that sends any DM from someone new into a separate inbox requires your approval before that user can DM you again. Or, go extra mile turn off DMs entirely from server members unless youave explicitly added them to your friends list. Weave got you PHEW, okaya that was a lot. Thanks for stickina around jamming through our most recent updates with us. Everything you could ever want to know about safety privacy on Discord, even more if youare learning type of person, lives in our Safety Library a check it out for more tips on making Discord safe comfortable for you. a This article was first published on 10/24/2023. Navigating Online Boundaries With Your Teen Weare committed to making Discord a safe place for teens to hang out with their friends online. While theyare doing their thing weare doing our part to keep them safe, sometimes itas hard for parents to know whatas actually going on in their teensa online lives. Teens navigate online world with a level of expertise that is often underestimated by adults in their lives. For parents, it may be a hard lesson to fathomathat their teens know best. But why wouldnat they? Every teen is their own leading expert in their life experiences (as we all are!). But growing up online, this generation is particularly adept at what it means to make new friends, find community, express their authentic selves, test boundariesaall online. But that doesnat mean teens donat need adultsa help when it comes to setting healthy digital boundaries. it doesnat mean parents canat be a guide for cultivating safe, age-appropriate spaces. Itas about finding right balance between giving teens agency while creating right moments to check in with them. One of best ways to do that is to encourage more regular, open honest conversations with your teen about staying safe online. Here at Discord, weave developed tools to help that process, like our Family Center: an opt-in program that makes it easy for parents guardians to be informed about their teenas Discord activity while respecting their autonomy. Here are a few more ways to kick off online safety discussions. If a teen feels like they could get in trouble for something, they wonat be honest with you. So go into these conversations from a place of curiosity first, rather than judgment. Here are a few conversation-starters: Teens will be less likely to share if they feel like parents just donat get it, so asking open questions like these will foster more conversation. Questions rooted in blame can also backfire: teen may not be as forthcoming because they feel like adult is already gearing up to punish them. Read more helpful prompts for talking with your teen about online safety in our Discord Safety Center. Our goal at Discord is to make it a place where teens can talk hang out with their friends in a safe, fun way. Itas a place where teens have power agency, where they get to feel like they own something. Just because your teen is having fun online doesn't mean you have to give up your parental role. Parents trusted adults in a teenas life are here to coach guide them, enabling them to explore themselves find out who they areawhile giving them parameters by which to do so. On Discord, some of those boundaries could include: Using Discordas Family Center feature so you can be more informed involved in your teensa online life without prying. At Discord, weave created several tools to help parents stay informed in touch with their teens online, including this Parentas Guide to Discord Family Center. In spirit of meeting teens where they are, weave also introduced a lighthearted way to spur conversations through a set of digital safety tarot cards. Popular with Gen Z, tarot cards are a fun way for teens to self-reflect find meaning in a world that can feel out of control. messages shown in cards encourage teens to be kind to use their intuition trust their instincts. They remind teens to fire up their empathy, while also reminding them itas OK to block those who bring you down. no, these cards will (unfortunately) not tell you your future! But theyare a fun way to initiate discussions about online safety establish a neutral, welcoming space for your teen to share their concerns. They encourage teens to share real-life experiences stories of online encounters, both positive negative. idea is to get young people talking, parents listening. Sometimes, even as adults, it's easy to get in over your head online. Through our research with parents teens, we found that while 30% of parents said their Gen Zeras emotional mental health had taken a turn for worse in past few years, 55% of Gen Z said it. while some teens acknowledged that being extremely online can contribute to that, more reported that online communications platforms, including social media, play a positive role in their life through providing meaningful community connection. Understanding healthy digital boundaries how they can impact mental wellbeing is important, no matter if youare a teen, parent, any age in-between. When it comes to addressing unique safety needs of each individual, there are resources, such as Crisis Text Line. Trained volunteer Crisis Counselors are available to support anyone in their time of need 24/7. Just text DISCORD to 741741 to receive free confidential mental health support in English Spanish. How To Report Content To Discord Submitting a Report to Discord a next screen will allow you to further specify specific abuse thatas occurring. You can always click back change your first answer, so you can select most relevant category. Alternatively, you may select aDelete Message,a which, as a mod will enable you to report message to our Safety team as well, while removing content from your server. What to do if you receive a violent threat, someone is at risk of Self-harm If a credible threat of violence has been made you someone else are in immediate danger, if someone is considering self-harm is in immediate danger, please contact your local law enforcement agency. Additionally, if you are in United States, you can contact Crisis Text Line to speak with a volunteer crisis counselor to help you a friend through any mental health crisis by texting DISCORD to 741741. A You can learn more about Discordas partnership with Crisis Text line here. You can find more resources about mental health here. What Happens After I Submit a Report? When we become aware of content that violates our Community Guidelines Terms of Service, our Safety team reviews takes necessary enforcement actions, including: disabling accounts, removing servers, when appropriate, engaging with proper authorities. We may not review your report manually respond to you directly, but weall use your report to improve Discord. You can read more about reports we receive actions we take on violations of our Community Guidelines Terms of Service in our quarterly Transparency Report. a Developing Moderator Guidelines Lead by Example moderators are people that your community members look to, not just for enforcement of server rules maintaining peace, but also as role models for what behavior is appropriate for server. If your users see moderators ignoring bending certain rules, they will learn that that is ok for them to do so also, they will call you out if you attempt to hypocritically enforce rules against them. As such, moderators should hold themselves to a higher standard than other users, especially in regards to civility more subjective rules such as what is considered NSFW content. This also applies also for private interactions among mod team. For example, if a moderator is talking in chat shares a suggestive picture, users will understand that other pictures that are equally as suggestive are ok to post. Not only will this encourage borderline rule-breaking behavior, it makes it more difficult for moderators to peacefully moderate NSFW content because users will say aWell, you posted this picture picture I posted is basically same.a same holds true in way moderators respond to questions. If someone asks for help on something moderators respond to them rudely condescendingly others will treat new users same way create a hostile environment. Thatas not to say that moderators canat have fun, of course. Moderators can should participate in chat regularly engage with members as normal users. If a moderator entering chat is disruptive in of itself, it usually means that moderators are not active enough in server. Ultimately, moderators should strive to be seen fondly by server members, yet respected in their positions of authority. Moderators that fail to enforce rules will be seen as unprofessional apushoversa by server members, while moderators that enforce rules too strictly and/or do not participate in chat will be seen as aloof, aggressive, out of touch. Spirit of Rules One of things you may often hear is that aspirit of rulesa is more important than aletter.a In other words, it is more important that people follow intent of rules, rather than adhering to a literal technical definition. As a result, moderators should focus on managing problems of chat, including addressing unhealthy behavior that may not directly break a rule. It is appropriate to moderate people that are deliberately toeing line to see what they can get away with (i.e., trolling), but what many moderator teams also forget is that rules are not infallible, moderators should use their judgment to enforce rules only when it makes sense, not blindly following letter of law. There may be instances where wording specifics of rules end up disallowing behavior that, in practice, does not go against main principle of moderation. In these cases, moderators should refrain from warning user without consulting rest of their mod team also seriously consider modifying rules to more accurately reflect expectations of mod team in regards to server conduct. For example: letas say you have a rule that prevents users from cropping images to focus on sexual body parts in order to prevent NSFW conversations from occurring in chat. However, someone ends up cropping an image of an in game character to focus on her skirt from behind, discussing outfit. In this case, it may not be appropriate to warn user since they are using this image to start an appropriate conversation, even if it technically breaks rule about cropping pictures. So, mod team should discuss ways that rule can be rewritten to cover scenarios like these, rather than resign themselves to warning user abecause rules say so.a Remember: rules exist to serve community, not other way around. Moderators should conduct themselves in accordance with rules, potentially even better, but they ultimately have power to change them for better of server if need be. Treat your rules as a living document remember that they are there to improve your community, not stunt it. When to Forgo Progressive Discipline While certain rules readily offer an ainstant bana option (such as doxxing) in some cases, a useras conduct may reveal that they are only in chat to troll otherwise cause trouble in a way that does not break one of instant ban rules. Just as rules exist to serve community, so too does progressive discipline system. purpose of progressive discipline system is to allow your members to understand their bad behavior rectify it in future without unduly punishing them for occasional small mistakes. Conversely, this means that users that are clearly acting in bad faith on server may not be afforded same leniency should be muted banned depending on circumstances especially if user in question does not have any previously normal chat history. While users that instantly break rules without message history could all be potentially banned, some behavior you may want to consider in particular includes: Itas important that disruptive users be addressed quickly before they sour mood of other server members (which could lead to additional infractions from users that were incited by original bad behavior in first place). Just as moderators should not use rules to punish users that donat practically deserve it, moderators should also be sure not to allow disruptive users to remain on principle of following policy. Other Considerations While principles above are most generally important moderation principles, there may be other things you want to include in your moderator guidelines channel as well such as Always keep in mind any peculiarities of your server questions your moderators might have so that you can proactively address them before they become issues. Summary A moderation guidelines channel is an important channel for helping your moderators get acquainted with both procedural aspects of moderation more subjective aspects. Moderators should be aware that they are leading by example hold themselves to a higher standard so that other users will be encouraged to follow their example. This will help them perform their duties smoothly as well as allow them to readily de-escalate conflicts before they become an issue, encouraging a positive server culture. Finally, by encouraging your moderators to evaluate situations critically, you have mods that can understand both when users should be swiftly punished as well as when rules may need to be adjusted clarified to allow greater flexibility. If youare interested in seeing example moderation guidelines, you can check out link here. Hopefully these help you in developing your own moderation guidelines. Happy moderating! Using XP Systems What Are XP Systems How Do They Work? One of most important factors of keeping a community alive healthy is activity. To maintain activity, moderators can use a few different methods which generally can be separated into two groups: active passive. Active methods are those which require presence active participation of a moderator. Passive methods, on other hand, do not require a constant presence from an individual are often automated by using bots. Keep in mind that even passive methods will require occasional maintenance from a moderator. One of more popular passive methods are XP systems. XP systems, otherwise known as experience leveling systems, grant users experience points (XP) levels based on their activity in a server. Their main purpose is to reward member activity in community. These systems exist in form of bots. Usually they are just one function of multi-purpose bots, but there are cases where sole function of bot is leveling system. basic way these systems work is: These four steps are only a simplification of process, there are many options to consider while using these systems. Depending on bot you choose to use, you can get various options for configuration but there are several that are commonly available on most bots. Some of these options are: Usage of XP Systems main function of XP systems is to reward user activity. Their ability to passively lead users towards being active allows moderators to occasionally take a moment to step back from their usual activities of engaging with their community. existence of a leaderboard appeals to competitive nature of humans pulls them to be more active. Rewards additionally add to this appeal. This is applicable in small, medium some large communities. Alternatively, XP systems can be used as a measure of security. By locking certain permissions behind levels, you can make sure that inactive malicious users are prevented from committing certain offenses. This is mostly applicable in very large servers. Both of these routes will require utilization of roles. There are two main reasons for this: Regulation of Activity As goal of XP systems is to boost activity, it is important to note that they will also lure in users who believe any type of activity is acceptable. This is not case. While problem of spam is already resolved by cooldown ability of most XP systems, there are still behavioral issues that need to be addressed. Members need to be aware that rules still exist in community they cannot simply do as they please. It is important to moderate those who blatantly misbehave in order to level up. Other contributions to community, which are not measured with activity in text voice chat, should also be rewarded, such as artworks, stories, etc. Furthermore, activity that comes from channels which encourage spam-like behavior, such as bot channels, should not count towards total. For that reason, XP gain should be disabled in channels of that sort. Types of XP Systems Knowing that we have ability to reset XP in server, we can use this option to create different types of XP systems. We can divide XP systems into three different types: cyclical, permanent combined. Cyclical systems reset XP points in a regular cycle. Cycle duration should be set based on activity, though it is not advisable to use this system in communities with very low activity. constant resets in leaderboard allow new members to climb charts quickly, but this only lets system be used for rewards. It is common to give out special rewards to most active users at end of cycle, such as custom roles for duration of following cycle, which encourages continued activity to retain their rewards. This also gives moderators opportunity to post announcements regularly at ends of cycles. biggest downside of this system is that not all bots have ability to also remove leveling roles when cycle ends. Permanent systems do not reset at any point in time. Occasionally, users that are banned have left are removed from leaderboards. They give a good look into who most active dedicated users in community are. Permanent systems can be used both for rewards security. Their biggest downside is that they are not very friendly towards new members, especially in older communities. Combined systems are a combination of cyclical permanent systems. They usually require usage of 2 separate bots to keep track of rankings on both leaderboards. They take best aspects of both systems, meaning they can be used both for rewards, which would be connected to cyclical system, security, which would be connected to permanent one. This also allows for cyclical leaderboard to help involve new users more, while still giving good insight of who most active members of all time are with permanent one. only big downside that remains is issue of removing roles from a large number of members. Negative Aspects As with any system, there are several negative aspects to consider when it comes to using XP systems. All of these should be taken into consideration before you make a decision on whether you want to use one. Some of most commonly voiced concerns would be following: fact that these systems encourage sending a larger number of messages automatically leads to idea of spam. Since spam is considered a violation of rules, as well as a ToS violation, this would become a huge problem. issue is easily resolvable, thanks to built in anti-spam measures XP systems have, primarily message cooldown. This, in combination with good moderation would make it certain that no spam is generated by presence of system. Since most XP systems require utilization of roles for truly fulfilling their usage, issue of role bloating comes to mind. It is important to manage space leveled roles properly in order to avoid creating an excessive number of roles with no real use in your server. It is believed that when it comes to rewarding members, rewards should be granted manually through qualitative judgement of content, rather than quantitative. Itas a fact that bots cannot themselves tell quality of messages sent. fact that all types of conversations allow users to gain XP means that there is no meter on what quality of conversation is. Granting privileges as a result of such conversations sends wrong idea of what sort of activity is encouraged. Only humans can truly judge content subjectively to determine quality. By combining proper moderation, for handling judgement of quality, built-in preventive mechanisms of XP systems for quantity control, this issue can be held down to a minimal level. This would be one of most difficult problems of system to resolve. Many members, with intent of increasing their XP count level, will attempt to hold conversation in community. This part of it is perfectly fine. problem arises when they start forcing conversation at any point in time solely to increase their message count. result would be communication that is completely unnatural unhealthy. This type of abuse of system canat really be stopped with cooldown system since most of time it is not spam. only real way to prevent this is to use No XP role, but difficulty of telling organic inorganic communication apart raises question: Was there really any violation of system? Not in every case is an XP system useful for a community. In many cases moderators canat figure out how they can add this sort of system make it seem like a natural part of server, how it can fit theme of community. Considering theme purpose of your server is an important part of making decision of adding a leveling system to your server. Before you make decision, ask yourself: How can I make this system a natural part of my community? Which Bot Do I Use? In following section, several publicly available bots will be presented as options for what you can use for an XP System in your server. following bots have been chosen based on data collected from a survey of various moderators, administrators owners in Discord communities. This list is not exhaustive. There are plenty of alternatives available online. All of listed bots are free public. Some features may be limited to paid additions private versions of bots. content of this article is not endorsed by any bot company related to bots. Gaius Play is an entertainment bot that also hosts an XP system. It takes both text voice chat activity into account. basic version comes with a preset configuration for XP gain leveling, as well as commands for adding rewards up to 6 roles, fully customizing toggling level-up messages, manually controlling XP, ignoring activity in certain channels ability to boost XP gain within certain parameters (roles, channels, time periods). It also has ability to remove leveled roles from all users, making it ideal for use in a cyclical system. Additionally, there are several premium features, such as unlimited reward roles a tree leveling system. Users can also reset their own reward roles in order to change paths on tree leveling system. Amari is a bot that is solely focused on leveling systems. It only looks at activity in text channels. This is a very simple bot, containing commands for setting rewards, manually controlling XP, customizing toggling level-up messages, as well as ignoring activity in some channels. It has ability to have 2 leaderboards active at same time, both of which can be reset at any point. Donor features allow for modification of cooldown between messages, as well as modification of XP gain per message. Nadeko is a multi-purpose bot with a leveling system module. It detects activity exclusively from text chat has a preset configuration for XP gain. It contains commands for setting up reward roles, toggling level-up messages, ignoring activity in channels manually controlling XP. A big upside of this bot is that you have option to host it yourself. This also adds ability to set up in-bot currency rewards, as well as better overall control of bot. Tatsu is another multi-purpose bot with an XP system module. It has several basic commands, allowing creation of reward roles, toggling level-up announcements, modifying XP gain per message cooldown, manual XP control ignoring channel activity. It also features a dashboard a global leaderboard alongside local one. Summary With available selection of bots documentation explaining setup of XP systems, using leveling modules is simpler than ever. configuration options that exist on these modules allow for creative usage of leveling systems with goal of passively increasing activity within community. Naturally, you have to consider several factors prior to deciding on using XP systems. If you are considering using one, think of how you can best integrate it into your community. In which way will you use it? Which type of system would suit your community best? Which bot would be best for task? Of course, there are negative aspects to consider as well, meaning youad have to figure out how to control minimize them. Carefully weigh all pros cons prior to making a final decision. Creating Moderation Team Channels Moderation Channel Setup Once confident in channel permissions that lock access to your private moderation channels, itas important to think about what you want your moderation channels to look like. larger server more channels you may need to accommodate everything. An important rule of thumb is to make sure that your moderation channels are an exception to any auto-moderated actions your moderation bot may be taking, that automoderator is configured not to act on messages from moderators. No blacklists should be in effect in these channels to ensure proper discussion of punishments happenings in server can be discussed truthfully respectfully. Itas also important to ensure that any message logging is configured to ignore channels that not all moderators have access to. For example, if all of your moderators can see a general action log channel, but you have a separate channel for a lead chat, deleted edited messages from that channel should not be logged for privacy reasons. More about this can be found below. Structurally, it is recommended to have informational channels at top of your moderation channel category to make sure everyone sees them. Anything that should be easily viewable by team follows, such as an update channel moderation/action logging based channels. Channels restricted to smaller groups of moderators should be closer to bottom as less people have access to these, partnership channels meant to maintain relations as opposed to direct moderation connections can be on bottom. A sample of a large staff channelset can be found below. a a Weall now begin to outline a variety of channels that are often useful for moderation purposes. below list is for your consideration when building your own moderation channel category, but by no means should you feel obligated to add every channel discussed below to your server. This is all about recognizing your needs making sure they are met! Every moderation team should have a developed moderation handbook that is easily accessible to all team members updated regularly. However, some moderation teams like to have an overview channel for rule enforcement for quick referencing. This channel can contain information such as how you categorize punishments, an overview of popular commands for easy referencing after returning from a moderation break, links to all guidelines moderation forms for easy coordination. We recommend that this channel is viewable to all moderators, but Send Message permissions for informational channels like this should be limited to server owner administrators to ensure only important select information is fed into channel. Additionally, denying Manage Message permissions to everyone but administrators is also recommended to ensure that these informational messages arenat deleted. Action logs are most important moderation channels out there, but also busiest. Moderation action logs exist for a variety of purposes, you can configure them however you see fit. Some recommended actioning channels include, but are not limited to: Like your server, your moderation team can have a general channel. While it is important for your moderators to moderate, itas also important for your team to bond. This is best achieved by having a space that is not dedicated to moderation. It exists to talk to each other, get to know each other, build rapport in your team environment. Moderation can be stressful, this is where you can go to take a break with your teammates. However, it is important to maintain same set of moderation expectations here as you would in public channels. An occasional vent is understood acceptable, but you should avoid speaking negatively of server members that can taint a moderation experience. While itas important to bond with your teammates, it is also important to bond with your server members as well. Chatting in server itself is just as encouraged as getting to know your fellow moderators. If you enable community server option for your server, youall have updates fed to a chosen channel. As these will be major community-based updates for moderation purposes, it is often recommended to have them feed to a moderation update memo based channel for ease of viewing. Channels that serve this purpose can be used for a variety of reasons including announcing extended absences from team for vacations mental health purposes to avoid burnout, taking team-wide votes, making announcements for moderator removals, departures, promotions, initiatives team is pursuing. Many servers use a single channel as a catch-all update arena as it serves a very specific purpose will not be used daily. Although there are a variety of ways to organize your team hierarchy, in addition to regular moderators most mod teams also have administrators who are responsible for overseeing regular moderators. Some mod teams also make a distinction between regular moderators moderators-in-training, who may have different permissions compared to regular moderators otherwise be subject to additional scrutiny during their training period. If these distinctions exist within your own mod team, it may be wise to create separate administrator channels training channels. Administrator Channels - An administrator chat is necessary to speak about private matters on team. This is to judge general moderation performance, handle punishments for problematic actions internally, it also serves as a place to handle any reports against moderators to ensure privacy. Please remember, it is important that these messages are not caught up in bot logging so moderators are not made aware of fact that they are being discussed privately before leads connect with them. Training Channels - General permissions granted to all moderators will not yet be accessible to moderator trainees, thus some teams consider locking their access to select channels. There will need to be a space for all moderators leads to privately discuss growth of trainees without them gaining access even after promotion. Some teams may go as far as to establish a unique action log channel used during training periods before giving them access to full history of moderation team once they prove their ability to be unbiased moderators. Again, it is important to ensure that discussion channels for trainees are exceptions to basic bot logging to avoid awkward occurrences with trainees seeing commentary about them that they should not see yet. There are a plethora of moderation channels that can benefit a team in unique circumstances that donat fit into above categories. Consider following when thinking about what fits best for how your community is run: If your community is linked to an external community such as Reddit Twitch, it would be useful to have separate moderation channels dedicated to this external community in addition to your Discord moderation channels. Reddit moderation channels specifically can be created by utilizing webhooks. Reddit moderation spaces housed on Discord often have r/modnews updates feeding into a special update area channel sets unique to their external community needs. You can also have new posts comments logged into a designated Reddit action log for easy reference without opening Reddit. Teams that have a separate Reddit Twitch moderation team in addition to their Discord moderation team may have designated hangout spaces for all teams to get to know each other casually. But, most importantly, they may have shared moderation spaces to discuss troublemakers that can span multiple platforms to flag problematic users for other team. Easy specialized communication across teams will help to keep all facets of your community safe! Conclusion There is no right wrong way to set up a moderation channel category outside of ensuring you utilize correct permissions. Itas important to consider needs of your community how their needs translate to needs of your team when creating your moderation space. Having flexibility a willingness to grow as your server grows requires change is imperative. While action logs are most useful kind of moderation channels from a punishment perspective, hangout spaces are important to establishing team cohesion rapport. Identifying needs of your team making sure they are adequately met will help you create strongest moderation environment as possible. Schools X Discord Benefits of Using Discord in Classrooms Lots of new opportunities are created for schools who make use of a private Discord server. One of biggest opportunities is presented in a cultural shift away from formality closer to general bonding. Gone are days of formal communications over e-mail instead we have open chat discussions with teachers, fellow classmates, group project members, even private one-on-oneas (similar to office hours!) when necessary. In this section we seek to discuss many ways that Discord can help virtual learning. Discord can function as a virtual classroom setting in ways that can generate new opportunities for continued reliable teamwork while enabling new exciting ways for students to connect with each other. Utilizing Discord as a Virtual Classroom While certain permissions are essential to creating an environment that separates teachers student private chats subjects, a classroom environment acts as overall hub for everything necessary from a full school, to a specific classroom, to separate groups working on projects, even a variation of subjects being taught. Simultaneously, a server can be set up to serve a variety of school-related functions including, but not limited to: Discord naturally lends itself to communication in ways that allow students to help each other. If one student is stuck on an assignment, any student can answer their question perhaps join them in a study session to work out problem together. Schoolwork can feel less solitary, there is less of a reliance on teachers aids, students who may be taking same subject in different classes can meet each other help each other out. This also allows teachers to monitor such a space to gain insight as to where their students are struggling so they can adjust their lesson plans accordingly. Interaction with each other doesnat have to be limited to just typing in designated channels. Students can interact with each other teachers while using subject specific audio and/or video channels as well, allowing them to have more personal interactions cater to different learning styles. However, if you are using these channels to broadcast a lesson not promote group work, make sure that you disable voice activity for students to avoid accidental noise from being broadcasted throughout your online classroom. This helps create a controlled environment for all involved in virtual classroom space. An example about how to do this is below. Discordas Easy to Use Interface Will Make Students Feel at Home Discord was created for housing online communities which sets it apart from other routes taken for e-learning platforms. Your students staff will feel at home in Discord user interface because it is easy to use made for quick adaptation. natural familiarity that many students may bring from their personal usage of platform even other similar platforms will reduce friction of adopting into new virtual learning atmospheres more easily help transition Discord into their daily educational routines. A common complaint in larger classroom settings, both in person virtually, is that environment is impersonal. In a sea of many faces, it is understandable that a student may feel like just another number on attendance roster. However, Discordas premise of providing an easily built space meant for easy informal communication can reduce this lack of personal connection instead help students feel welcome, including, easily engaged. a There is Always Fun to be Had in a Healthy Community When creating your virtual classroom it is important to keep in mind what you want purpose of your server to be. A server for a specific math classroom taught by Mr. Wumpus at noon everyday is going to be geared entirely towards education, whereas a more open-concept Algebra server that welcomes all students currently enrolled in course under various teachers to have a more common meeting space while also being split into their respective virtual classrooms via permissions allows for antics in addition to education. Educational settings can also be fun if you choose to build them that way. There is always fun to be had in a healthy community when school day finishes, providing this hang out space for students will allow them to not only bond but associate positive feelings with school. There can be spaces designated to help students study together in after school hours perhaps come together to take a study break to play one of their favorite games. A music bot can be used to listen to music in an essay-writing sprint, a leveling system can be used to reward students for participation. Community feelings lead to happiness, which can impact mental health grading. Discord is an Extension of your Physical Campus Discord also brings many advantages to educational arenas outside of classroom. A server can be viewed as an extension of your physical campus to Internet in an e-learning environment. Similar to a real-life campus, Discord is a meeting place for students staff to chat, get to know each other, build a stronger community in places they feel safe. Shy students may even find it easier to bond better in an online environment than a physical one which can lead to generating new friendships while also improving pre-existing ones. Students who perceive a welcoming environment have positive feelings about their school community will often get better grades because of higher motivations levels. Interestingly, a further extension of a physical campus would be to an alumni association. While school related Discord servers are often for study tools virtual classrooms, they can also serve as special places for alumni to connect after graduation. They can not only catch up with their old classmates, but they can mentor current students as well. Such a situation can be brought about via unique ideas like career fairs oriented towards advising current students about future career options by making use of a schoolsa alumni network. Disadvantages of Using Discord as a School Platform As mentioned above, Discordas widespread usage for personal gaming easy to use interface means that a lot of students could already use Discord in their free time begin to adopt it into their lives after being introduced to it in a classroom setting. person someone may present themselves as online can differ from who they are in real life. When given opportunity to use a profile picture, set usernames nicknames, even statuses, things can get out of hand quickly. It may even be difficult for some teachers to identify which student is behind certain accounts if these expectations arenat established immediately upon server creation. With likely change that a student might not want to use a picture of themself as their profile picture, it is important to establish server guidelines about what is appropriate to be in that photo. While some users may not be comfortable using their full name even their first name in their username, set expectation that everyone has to change their nickname in your private school-related Discord servers to their real name. On a related note, if a user is subscribed to Discord Nitro, they may also change their profile picture on an individual server basis. However, it's not required in order to use Discord on whole. Our recommendation if a student is uncomfortable with using their real picture for their platform-wide account is to tell them to make a secondary account specifically for school where they can use a photo of themselves. With Discord's account switcher feature having a second account for this purpose is less of hassle. Finally, when students first enter server, we recommend enabling Developer Mode to privately connect each individual User ID to a student should someone alter change their identity/account information in future. This could be done through schools information management system, just by using a spreadsheet. It is also imperative to reiterate boundary that you expect everything present in virtual school ecosystem to be school appropriate. Features like profile pictures, username, status are platform-wide features that appear in all servers a user is in. What is appropriate in some spaces may not be appropriate in school. Consider this ahead of time to establish rules around this also punishments should this not be respected. It is important to keep in mind that Discord does have strict Terms of Service Community Guidelines that state users arenat allowed to use NSFW content other forms of illegal content as their username, profile picture, and/or status. This will partly make sure content on their profiles is acceptable to a degree. However, you may not be comfortable if a student is cursing in your virtual classroom that can be dealt with accordingly by you. Conclusion Discordas very purpose is to foster communication by bringing users an easy to understand interface that is adaptable to a variety of needs, thus making it a really useful modern tool for e-learning virtual classrooms. With right permissions, students can be brought into environments where they can not only learn, but also have fun in a virtual extension of their physical campus. Through utilization of a variety of ways to teach classrooms communicate amongst groups, Discord naturally fosters teamwork open forum discussions between students teachers alike. However, Discord is still a platform with millions of users exploring a variety of interests. Itas important to enter Discord prepared to handle students who may be using inappropriate media for school via platform-wide features like profile pictures, statues, usernames because they are appropriate elsewhere. If you consider logistics of creating a safe, school-appropriate environment set expectations guidelines upon entry, Discord is a great tool for your future educational needs! Confidentiality in Moderation Considerations Regarding Leadership Whichever moderation roles a server may have, there should always be an authority role that can make calls at their discretion if they believe it is best thing for community. A good example on how to do just that can be found here. Moderation administrators, leaders, managers, etc. should always be prepared ready to make judgment calls on information provided to them, whether by mods users. A very common misconception among moderation teams is that they should share all information amongst team for transparency. This can be a double-edged sword in sense that disclosing private information that is not essential for a moderator can open more routes for that information to have unauthorized distribution. If this occurs, it will compromise privacy trust of users that information applies to. In sensitive situations containing very volatile information, consider if it may be beneficial to have it handled directly by a team leader even owner of community. Personally identifiable information (or PII) is any information that can identify a user, such as an email address, full name, phone number, IP address, exact location, even their Discord user ID username. People should never disclose someoneas personal information except their own in an appropriate environment, as disclosing othersa info can be treated as doxxing, which is a disclosure of personal info by a third party (for example, someone posting another useras address), can, in some instances, be actioned on by Trust Safety as it may violate Discordas Terms of Service/Community Guidelines.
