This is an integral part of establishing a healthy environment for your moderators solid internal relationships. creation of specific mental health-related guidelines ensure that users remain respectful of each other that conversations are within designated guidelines of your community. Some suggestions for creating these guidelines include: Escalation protocols are another important foundation for when mental health discussions take place. Some ideas to consider when implementing them: a Moderation of mental health channels can be a touchy subject. On one hand, moderators should be firm in removing harassers users who are disrespecting others. On other hand, moderators should try their best not to over-moderate. There must be a balance to ensure that these channels that have very sensitive subject matters within them are moderated with care. Some ways to do this are: a There are an incredible amount of resources available for mental health supportaeverything from emergency phone numbers to suicide hotlines LGBTQ+ helplines. Find a Helpline resource consists of a list of global helplines hotlines. We also recommend looking at TWLOHA resource, which is a non-profit movement dedicated to presenting hope finding help for people struggling with their mental health. Discord has also partnered with Crisis Text Line, a non-profit that provides text-based volunteer support for people in crisis. You can learn more about our integration partnership how to use it on Discord here. Some more examples of support sites include: Not all communities are prepared to host a mental health channel thread, there is a lot to consider before adding one to your server. While allowing talk about mental health can be incredibly beneficial, it is just as important to realize that moderators arenat professionals should not be put in those positions if they arenat comfortable with it. Thatas why we advise that you carefully consider your current environment, your communityas purpose, implications that might occur if you choose to add one. Whatever you decide is best for your community, we believe that education is key. It may be helpful to think about adding a channel post that gives people access to professional support lines, such as FindaHelpline TWLOHA resource, as well as other resources laid out in this article. Generally, facilitating a healthy discussion around important topics of any kind is essential in helping to develop stronger communities online. Make sure that your community is a safe space for everyone that chooses to call it home! Twitch X Discord Is Discord for Twitch Necessary? At some point during their Twitch careers, most streamers will ask question, aIs having a Discord for my community necessary?a. Most streamers are already struggling enough with configuring their overlays, cultivating relationships with other streamers, taking time to edit design future content. Will working with yet-another platform really help move my streaming career forward, is it just another item on endless list of distractions? Most of streamers who ask this question fail to understand how Discord fits into their high-level plan for scaling their brand community. One of biggest misconceptions is that Twitch can be used for every step of growing your channel, brand, community. Twitch is only one of many platforms required for success. While Twitch is well-known for engaging monetizing your active community base, it struggles with content discovery, data collection, long term retention. Twitch should instead be viewed as a tool to engage connect with an already-existing community. image above categorizes content platforms into 3 primary groups; Discovery, Engagement, Activation. Content platforms that focus on Discovery are specifically designed to spread new, persistent content that can be viewed later. These platforms are ideal for finding new community members fans to engage with by inviting them to join another more personalized platform, such as a fansite, email list, Discord community. It is through this persistent community that you can advertise ways to support engage directly with primary content creators by supporting through Patreon viewing/subscribing on Twitch. platforms above can obviously be used for different purposes, but theyare segmented as such because of how their primary business models work. Discovery platforms run on ads focus on getting you to consume more content. Engagement platforms are more personalized, with content not designed for larger audiences frequently encourage users to take action. Activation platforms are designed to have monthly direct recurring payment models that provide an enhanced personalized version of Engagement content. Going Live Back Again With a better understanding of primary purposes of each platform, you can begin to design your user experience in a way that provides new community members an easy direct way to participate in show dedication to community. Regardless of how your Twitch viewers discover your channel content, directing them to a centralized community hub will allow them to share their appreciation with others, go from being an individual fan to being part of a community. To get most out of Discord encourage members to join your stream, spend time with your community before after each livestream. Before each stream, spend 15 minutes chatting with your active Discord members to ask them about their day receive feedback about your content. As you begin your stream, post announcements on your social media platforms use a bot to alert your Discord community that youave gone live. Moderators should continue to oversee discussions in your Discord, but encourage members to watch livestream as it occurs. Bots scripts can also be used to remind users to join Discord community if they havenat already, as well as following on social media for updates alerts. Finally, as your stream is ending, remind community that youall be available in Discord for a short time to discuss stream answer any questions. Some streamers will also include special events for high-ranking members subscribers, which can help encourage collaboration active use of server. Playing with Viewers via Discord One of most effective ways to engage directly with your community is to create content with them. This can either be done while livestreaming, else as a scheduled event that community can participate in. Events need not necessarily be games, but can also include Q&A sessions discussions about a topic of interest. Special precautions must be made while playing with viewers as youare live to prevent astream snipinga, where community members will attempt to disrupt your stream game while youare live. Moderators should take note be ready to handle disruptions while engaging directly with community, but most situations can be prevented by assigning restrictions requirements to be on stream with host. For example, being a subscriber to community requiring participants to apply for a spot if game has a limited number of participants can help ensure everybody understands follows rules. Discord for Twitch Checklist As you grow your Discord community, members will have different expectations of what your server offers, how itas managed what server is used for. For example, a community with 500 members may not be expected to have a full events calendar, but they would definitely expect that roles have been properly configured so that subscribers appear as a different username color with more permissions access to restricted channels. Below is a simple checklist for functionality your server should have: Conclusion We hope these guidelines have helped you to determine if creating a Discord server for your Twitch audience is right fit for you. most essential thing to keep in mind is that your Discord server is not just an appendix to your Twitch presence. It serves as its own entity community that needs to be fostered with same, if not more, personal attention care in order for it to blossom. With right mindset efforts, your Discord community can bolster your Twitch presence bring your community closer together, for longer Application of Metaphors in Moderation Five Types of Community Moderation Approaches An academic study interviewed dozens of moderators across multiple platforms grouped moderation approaches into five different categories: a Being able to understand perspective behind each of these approaches then applying them to your own community as needed is a powerful ability as a community manager. This article will discuss in more detail what these five categories mean how you can apply them within your own communities. Nurturing Supporting Communities Moderators that nurture support communities (nurturing-type moderators) focus on shaping community conversations that occur in server among members to match their vision. foundation for their moderation actions stem from their desire to keep community positive welcoming for everyone, not just long-time members. They seek to create a community with a good understanding of rules that can then develop itself in a positive way over time. These types of moderators may implement pre-screening of members content in their communities by implementing a verification gate using an automoderator to filter out low quality members content curate conversations of server to be better suited to their vision. Although this passive behind-the-scenes guidance is one type of nurturing moderator, these types of moderators also often actively engage with community as a aregular member.a For nurturing-type moderators, this engagement isnat meant specifically to provide an example of rule-following behavior, but rather to encourage high-quality conversations on server where members will naturally enjoy engaging with each other moderators as equals. They are leading by example. Overseeing Facilitating Communities While nurturing- supporting-type moderators operate based upon their long-term vision for a community, moderators that are focused on overseeing facilitating communities focus on short-term needs day-to-day interactions of community members. They are often involved in handling difficult scenarios fostering a healthy community. For example, these types of moderators will step in when there is conflict within community attempt to mediate between parties to resolve any misunderstandings restore A friendliness to server. Depending on issue, they may also refer to specific rules community knowledge to assign validity to one viewpoint to respectfully discredit behavior of another. In both situations, moderators will attempt to elicit agreement from those involved about their judgment resolve conflict to earn respect of their community members restore order to server. Those in overseeing facilitating communities category may also take less involved approaches towards maintaining healthy day-to-day interaction among members, such as quickly making decisions to mute, kick, ban someone that is causing an excessive amount of trouble rather than attempting to talk them down. They may also watch for bad behavior report it to other moderators to step in handle, allow community to self-regulate when possible rather than attempting to directly influence conversation. Fighting for Communities Where overseeing facilitating community moderators emphasize interactive communicative approaches to solving situations with community members, moderators who see themselves as fighting for communities heavily emphasize taking action content removal rather than moderating via a two-way interaction. They may see advocating for their community members as part of their job A want to defend community from those who would try to harm it. Oftentimes, moderators themselves may have been on receiving end of problematic behavior in past desire to keep others in their community from having to deal with same thing. This attitude is often driver behind their A no-nonsense approach to moderation while strictly enforcing communityas rules values, quickly working to remove hateful content users acting in bad faith. Moderators in this category are similar to subset of moderators that view moderation from overseeing facilitating communities, specifically ones that quickly remove those who are causing trouble. However, compared to perspective that misbehavior stems from immaturity, moderators that fight for communities have a stronger focus on content being posted in community, rather than intent behind it. In contrast to moderators in overseeing facilitating communities category, these moderators take a firmer stance in their moderation style do not worry about complaints from users who have broken rules. Instead they accept that pushback on difficult decisions they make is part of moderation process. Governing Regulating Communities Those that see themselves as governing regulating communities see moderation team as a form of governance place great emphasis on appropriate desirable application of community rules, often seeing process for making moderation decisions as similar to a court system making decisions based on a set of community alaws.a They may also see themselves as representatives of community moderation team emphasize need to create policies enforce rules that benefit community as a whole Moderators in this category may consciously run community according to specific government principles, such as having a vote on community changes. However, they may also achieve consensus within team about changes to server without involving community at large even have one moderator make final determination about community changes. This afinal decisiona power is usually exercised in terms of vetoing a proposed policy issuing a ruling on an issue that is particularly contentious within mod team community. Very rarely would a form of decision-making be exercised, it would be granted to very specific members of a team hierarchy such as server owner administrative lead. Even so, moderators in this category find following procedure to be important tend to involve others to some extent in making decisions about community rather than acting on their own. This tendency is also seen in way that they approach rule enforcement. Moderators that see themselves as governing regulating communities view rules as if they were laws of a country. They meticulously review situations that involve moderator intervention to determine which rule was broken how it was broken while referring to similar past cases to see how those were handled. These moderators also tend to interpret rules more strictly, according to aletter of law,a attempt to leave no room for argument while building their acasea against potential offending users. Managing Communities Moderators that see themselves as managing communities view moderation as a second job to be approached in a professional way. They pay particular attention to way they interact with other members of community moderation team as well as moderation teams of other communities, strive to represent team positively to their community members. This type of moderator may appear more often as communities become very large as there becomes a need for clearer, standard processes division of responsibility between moderators in order to handle workload. Though this metaphor focuses more on moderator team dynamics than relationships between moderators users, it can also shape way moderators approach interactions with users. Managing-type moderators are more likely to be able to point users toward written rules, guidelines, processes when they have questions. Managing-type moderators are also much less likely to make aon-the-flya decisions about new issues that come up. Instead, they will document issue post about it in proper place, such as a private moderator channel, so it can be discussed a new process can be created if needed. This approach also makes it easier to be transparent with users about decision making. When there are established, consistent processes in place for handling issues, users are less likely to feel that decisions are random arbitrary. Another strength of this approach is evident in efficient on-boarding processes. When a community has clear processes for documenting, discussing, handling different situations, adding new moderators to team is much easier because there is already a set of written instructions for how they should do their job. This professional approach to moderation can also help moderators when they are attempting to form partnerships make connections with other servers. An organized moderation team is much more likely to make a good impression with potential partners. If you want to learn more about managing moderation teams, click here. Conclusion As you read through this article, you may have found that some moderation category descriptions resonated with you more than others. more experience you have moderating, wider variety of moderation approaches youall implement. Rather than trying to find a single abesta approach from among these categories, itas better to consider your overall balance in using them how often you consider moderation issues from each perspective. For example, you can nurture support a community by controlling how members arrive at your server curating content of your informational channels to guide conversation, while also managing overseeing interactions of honest, well-intentioned community members quickly banning those who seek to actively harm your community. Itas perfectly natural that each person on your moderation team will have an approach that comes easier to them than others no category is superior to another. Making sure all moderation categories are represented in your moderation team helps to ensure a well-rounded staff that values differing opinions. Even just understanding each of these frameworks is an important component of maintaining a successful community. Now that you understand these different approaches, you can consciously apply them as needed so that your community can continue to thrive! Internationalization of a Community Expanding from one Language Which languages to choose entirely depend on type of server you run. For a community server, it is recommended to adjust it to communityas needs. Usually, most commonly featured languages outside of English are German, French, Spanish, Turkish Russian. You can determine your featured language by community analysis, server insights (if your server has them), demand. What nationalities are represented most in your server? Which users struggle most with English upon joining server if theyare struggling, what language do they usually communicate in? In addition to that, you can consider starting a survey every time you your staff feel ready to expand into a new language. On other hand, if you make a server for a brand company, it is recommended to go by your target audience. Introducing features like internationalization needs carefully planned, but steady steps. If your server was originally English only, itas not recommended to expand into too many languages at once for a variety of reasons. Agree on one language (preferably most popular one in your server) slowly add on from there, if need presents itself. Once you figure out a pattern a stable structure on how to approach expansion, you can add more sections for different languages. Server Design As your server grows, so does Discord. It is vital to keep in mind that your server can get a lot of incoming users who have never really used Discord before- so make sure your serveras design is user-friendly, easily accessible, has a clear structure. Also, remember that more languages you feature on your server, more text-and voice channels will appear for your staff. It is recommended to hoist most important text-channels at top of your server. That may include announcements, server-info, rules, optionally giveaways more. To ensure global accessibility, translate important parts like rules server information in every language you feature alongside your main language. Additionally, you can add a server guide for easier coordination. Both new users your staff will benefit from that. It should cover a list of accessible text voice channels as well as a short but detailed description of each. Furthermore, try to integrate every additional language in a way that utilizes it to its utmost potential. You can do so in form of a feedback suggestion channel in each languageas category. This lets you hear directly from users that would benefit from that additional language chat most. Consider having staff that are dedicated to interacting with each section instead of focusing all their attention on global chat. Having these additional language chats makes it so that your international users donat feel less validated only because they donat want to canat communicate in global chat. You can implement that same line of thinking when organizing server events. Consider alternating between server-wide international events as demand allows. For latter, analyze your serveras activity for each region host it at time with most community engagement for those users for best results. You can apply same system to voice channels by creating a few global voice chats then adding language specific channels. Your staff should only allow one common language to be spoken in global chats redirect every other language into their appropriate voice channels. Creating a Server with One More Languages From Scratch If you want to feature multiple languages with equal amounts, you can effectively combine multiple Discord servers in one. For first half, it will be same as before: Have at least one international general-chat before you split server into each language. That way every user is able to communicate with entirety of server instead of just their language-specific section. Let users choose their language via a reaction verification with option to opt-out change regions. You can summarise most important aspects in a common text-channel, text being translated into every featured language. simplest way to manage split server is by having same channels categories, but in different languages. This will heavily depend on type of server you moderate, but recommended channels for every section are ones you would usually include in a monolingual server. These channels should include things like rules, announcements, general-chat, bot-commands, media, optionally a looking-for-game channel, more. Take care to ensure you have appropriate translation for each channel. Moreover, community events can be a lot more diverse. You can host a variety of events for each language as well as let all of them participate in shared events. Take time to analyze each nationas activity also take holidays national days into account. Staff Arrangement Internationalizing your server may mean that your moderation team grows to be larger than expected, so to make it easy for users to contact appropriate staff you can separate moderators by nicknames, colors, role hoist. Nicknames: If you want to have moderation team equally displayed throughout server, you can arrange moderators by nicknames. Simply add language they moderate at beginning of their nickname so they are alphabetically sorted below each other. Users will have an easier time recognizing appropriate moderators, but with a large staff, this might end up looking a little busy. Some moderators tend to change their nicknames frequently may not be big fans of having tag in front of their name, either. Colors: It is advised to have colors of each moderator role in same shade with a slight but still visible difference. This helps to differentiate moderators regular users will be able to tell difference immediately. Remember that newer users might not check each role just contact first seemingly online moderator they see. Role hoist: If you display only accompanying moderator role for each language, ensure that you have a common, not displayed role for all moderators so one team is not less validated than other. Users should definitely be able to contact appropriate staff ping correct moderators to help them out with issues in chat. but, when displaying a lot of teams with many members each, some of them might be pushed off screen. You run risk that some moderators that are displayed below other teams seem less aimportant validateda to community, but shared staff role should fix that problem easily. Moderation While moderating a multilingual server it is crucial to have moderators that are native speakers at least fluent in each language that you decide to expand to. Having moderators that are native speakers makes it so that they not only understand textbook definitions of what is being said but understand cultural contexts that may come with international chats. However, these moderators should also be accomplished capable with other responsibilities of being a mod that lie outside of just being fluent. While community moderators should follow basic tasks (moderate chat, be accessible for questions, guide users), things in multilingual servers can be a bit more advanced. Moderators need to identify address inappropriate behavior towards other cultures in an authoritative, but instructive way. Furthermore, they need to free chat from toxic behavior control discussions about sensitive topics. In addition to that, they have to be open for cultural questions of users who chose a language they are not fluent in yet. Both user staff need to work their way around language barriers together. Theyall be required to help users, as well as resolve disputes, often at same time. For that, theyall have to rely on their communication skills in order to succeed in resolving both situations any other issue that may require it. Without good communication skills, users won't understand what you're trying to convey to them, which should be assertive but tolerant. Moderators can under no circumstances be discriminating towards users of other cultures beliefs. It is their responsibility to create a civil, welcoming comfortable environment for all users. While you are always entitled to your own opinion, make sure to keep a neutral output in public part of server try not to let it cloud your judgement. Managing several moderators from all around world can turn out to be quite tricky. Organizing meetings waiting for everyoneas approval for one date may be a real challenge to deal with. Getting majority of team on board could take days, especially with difference in time zones. One simple solution is to delegate some captains representative moderators for each team. They will gather feedback, opinions suggestions from rest of staff team discuss them with rest of staff during meeting. That way itas easier to organize staff meetings, but they can also directly inform rest of their team who could not make it due to time conflicts. Depending on size of staff teams, you can appoint more than one moderator for that position. When creating more than one staff role, make sure that everyone is comfortable with their position their responsibilities. Misalignment can lead to misunderstanding later on, it might create needless tension amongst staff. Consider appointing one representative in each region that your server is branching out to. That will open possibility to have regional staff meetings where language culture specific issues suggestions can be discussed without need for an international meeting with whole team. While not every moderator will get chance to get to know every other moderator from different regions in these larger moderation rosters, it is important that team feels united regardless. Donat leave it up to one team to tackle an issue- let them know that they can always ask for help from rest of staff. Global Accessibility: Make sure that you have bots available for every part of your server. That could either mean that you include them in global section of your server, you translate commands definitions in every language featured. Moderation: Since not all moderators will be able to understand every single language, using bots turn out to be very helpful for auto-moderation. Inform your fellow moderators about inappropriate words phrases ensure that you added them into bot filter for easier moderation. Banned filtered words should contain common slurs in not only English, but also in commonly banned words for every language that you offer. Language Barriers: It may occur that users message ModMail in poor English in their native language. Find out user's nationality reply with a message in their native language that lets them know their request is being routed to appropriately fluent mod. To save these messages, simply create an extra text-channel in ModMail server let moderators translate important phrases that might come in handy. Cultural Awareness It's easy for people to underestimate impact cultural differences can have. Culture influences values, rules, thought patterns, perception. That means that events happening in other countries may be viewed differently in each nation. News social media don't always portray truth which lets misinformation spread easily. Make sure to have your staff updated about current situations so they have it easier to deal with discussions about sensitive topics trolls. Communication is key users of server will massively benefit from it. While people are entitled to have their own opinion ask for further information, make sure to let it happen in a calm civil atmosphere under a moderatoras watch. If you as a moderator find that youare ill equipped to talk about topic, you should refrain from publicly voicing your opinion until youare better informed. Conversely, you may want to refrain from allowing contentious topics like current events politics to occur in your server at all, which is something you should decide with your moderation team as a whole. Final Words Making a server internationally available is a great idea can be a boon to your communityas retention. It can be utilized for both communities companies alike. But you have to be careful with your approach- Internationalization is a deliberate complicated process it should be treated as such. If itas gone about in wrong way, left uncompleted rushed, these international spaces could backfire. It may result in negative feedback, a disappointed community staff deserted channels. Make sure to inform your staff community about every step youare about to take, give them a chance to voice their input. Feedback suggestions from both your mods your community will be essential to making sure this is right fit for your server. Internationalization requires a lot of effort prioritization in order to properly take care of many factors simultaneously, but if done right, itas an unparalleled way to enrich your community. Training Onboarding New Moderators Training Methods Each server has to decide for themselves what most effective training method looks like. This article will present explain some recommended methods that can simplify moderation training. aBuddy Systema approach describes working in pairs groups, in which two more abuddiesa work together on one task. Requiring newer moderators to work with each other even an assigned team member allows you to better monitor progress for aid to come when required. It promotes active communication trust between moderators also allows them to keep an objective view on everything. Having multiple opinions about certain matters receiving assistance from a reliable source prevents moderators from feeling pressured with moderation tasks can even open your eyes to new viewpoints. Additionally, it allows its members to effectively share their moderation skills with each other. It also aids in terms of personal safety: if a moderator feels personally attacked by a user, they get immediate support from their abuddiesa without feeling need to tackle issue alone. A Using this system allows less experienced moderators to quickly effectively catch up to moderation standards as they learn how to deal with specific matters first hand. It is important to remind more experienced moderators on your team to allow new moderators to learn instead of wanting to quickly handle every task themselves. With time, certain actions will also become second nature for newer moderators, too! This approach is most commonly used when onboarding new moderators. Here experienced moderators head of staff introduce each new member of team personally guide them through most important aspects. difference between this system aBuddy Systema is that each new moderator will be acquainted with moderation tasks responsibilities by a higher up, usually only once. After walkthrough most recruits are expected to manage certain moderation duties on their own while being supervised. It is crucial to support reassure them so they are able to grow confident in their actions. Recruits can display appropriately train their soft skills be informed about moderation standards in a controlled environment without fear causing too much irreparable damage. Another method of efficiently training both experienced inexperienced moderators is by letting them regularly test their knowledge. This involves designing exemplary situations of some everyday issues happening within your Discord server to let trial moderators explain how they would handle them. Such instances can include how to handle issues in audio channels, user disputes, DM Discord invitations, off topic discussion in incorrect channel, potential issues that may be encountered with bots. At end you should provide some sort of amodela aexamplea answer to let recruits know where they need to improve. One negative effect of this system could be fear of failure that some inexperienced moderators might be exposed to. Reassure them that making mistakes is okay as long as you take responsibility for your actions are willing to learn from them. Moderation is an ever-shifting learned art, mistakes are not to be punished when they happen every once in a while.It may be tempting to conduct these regular exercises incognito (aka acting up on an alt to see how they do) test them without warning- while this may yield more aeverydaya unbiased results, it has a high probability of backfiring. Blindsiding your moderation team with tests exercises has potential to do more harm than good, especially in terms of team trust morale. Itas recommended that you donat do this instead, practice transparency when conducting regular exercises in order to avoid a potentially inequitable situation. Another form of training is to demonstrate how situations scenarios are handled in your community via presentation an actual demonstrative walk-through with moderation alt accounts. This is very useful for training where moderators have to use a wide range of commands, such as explaining moderation Modmail bots. Ideally, this should take place in an audio channel group call where you can share your screen. Not everyone is able comfortable joining a voice chat unmuting themselves, which is something to be considered beforehand. Training Program Content An essential part of onboarding new moderators is to have an easily accessible document outlining basic responsibilities details on moderator tasks different moderation teams. Such documents need to be designed for each server individually, but they usually contain general rules for staff, conduct expectations, a punishment outline to set a standard unity for moderation actions. Recommended additions to such a moderation handbook are: Be sure to recognize anything that is prevalent in your moderation culture community that is also worth mentioning here! more thorough guidelines, easier document is to refer back to for any questions. For example, gaming servers should have a brief description of featured gaming companyas Terms of Service discussion about how to handle cheaters users mentioning account sharing/selling in accordance with those rules. Another example would be for bot support servers where a brief description of commonly encountered issues how to solve them as well as an FAQ section to help users with simpler answers. Another important topic new moderators should have easy access to are commands for moderation bots. Having a simple guide in a separate text channel with a quick guide of botsa prefix format (command, user-id, [time], reason) will aid moderators in quickly responding to ongoing issues on server. It lets them react fast without having to pause to look up necessary command. Try to use same prefix for mainly used moderation bot to not cause unnecessary confusion, particularly for users who are new to moderating. Each server uses a differently designed service to assist moderators with helping out users. Bigger servers tend to rely on a ticket Modmail system, so properly introducing them with sample conversations problematic matters is essential for both recruit future user. Confident moderators are more willing to aid users in need than those who are still unsure of how system works. This kind of training should include commonly used commands procedures. There should be conversation about how to redirect users to higher staff closing tickets appropriately so they donat stack up cause confusion. As long as a ticket system remains organization those guidelines organizations are established across full team this will prove to be an easy to use communication system that is much less daunting than it may seem! Staff Safety No user should ever feel unsafe threatened on a Discord server. Staff members are often exposed to harmful disrespectful messages, some of them targeted at some moderators directly. An important aspect of onboarding moderators therefore is to make them aware of how to react in such situations. They need to be able to create an environment in which it is comfortable for them to work in not be afraid to ask for help if they feel threatened by users or, in extreme cases, other staff members. Staff members supporting each other being able to communicate in such moments is crucial for an effectively working team. Creating Managing a Training Program Effective management promotes a feeling of professionalism simplifies process of training new moderators by a lot. Important aspects that should always be covered when creating a training program are time management, deciding on which staff are involved in training why, effective communication, detailed content, flexibility. Choosing an appropriate approach. How do you want to introduce new members? What system did you conclude will work best for your server staff team? Never be afraid to evolve an already existing plan into something that suits better for your current situation. Deciding what topics to cover. What topics do you prioritize over others think require more time investment than others? How are you moderators handling learning process? Might there be anything in need of adjustment? Selecting voluntary participants. Having a reliable team behind you to assist you in training is of most importance. Everyone involved should be aware of what exactly they need to teach how to approach training within a reasonable time frame. Developing a timetable. Find common ground between everyone involved, including both mentors trainees, settle on when to teach what topic. Recommend tools to easily manage bigger teams are Google Docs similar, but bots self made timetables will suffice, too. Try to keep it simple easily accessible for everyone involved. Communication. Who responds to whom? Decide on how when mentors report to head of staff other higher ups. Documenting helps with ensuring everyone is aware of their part planning how to proceed further. Flexibility. No matter how carefully you plan everything out, it can always happen that something doesnat work according to plan. In such situations you need to be able to react spontaneously be flexible, such as pitching in for someone who is unable to attend due to a last minute shift in schedule. How to Deliver Effective Training Before conducting training, you should evaluate what can make your training most effective. Below you will find some best practices to set up a training program be able to atrain trainersa. Planning When you are giving a training, it is important to properly plan your training. What are most important topics to cover? What do you want new moderators to know after conducting training? How much time are you planning to spend on training? Some people struggle to focus for a longer period of time, so if your training takes over two hours, you should consider breaking your training up into multiple sessions of shorter duration. Make sure to accommodate for any accessibility issues notes for those who were unable to be present. Goals Each training should have objectives. You can create an outline of your training where you write down topics you will cover objective of that topic. For example, if you are training moderators to use Modmail, your objective is that new moderators are able to handle Modmail tickets use commands available to them. For each topic, also write down how you want to give this training: are you going to give a demonstration? Will you use illustrations? Will you offer new moderators to practice during your training get hands-on experience? Publicly sharing this with trainees can help keep you on topic allow them to come prepared with questions Practice After creating your training, make sure to practice it at least once. First, go through entire training yourself to see if everything is covered that you think is important. You can then give your training to someone on your team, in case you missed something important to check whether not your estimated time is accurate. If it is possible, go through material with someone who is unfamiliar with moderation. Adjust your training appropriately you are good to go! Interaction For every training session, it is very important to have interaction with your trainees. People lose their attention after 15-30 minutes, so your training should include a discussion, practice, some sort of interaction. Some of these interactive sessions are covered down below. Interaction with your trainees is also important because it acts as a way for you to verify whether not your objectives are properly conveyed. Make sure there is a break once every one to two hours so trainees can focus on your training without feeling overwhelmed. Methods Every training can consist of a combination of different training methods. These include, but are not limited to, lectures, quick exercises, group discussions, practice runs, quizzes, videos, demonstrations, more. When planning your training, you can write down what method would work best to convey objectives to your trainees. A group discussion will be better applicable to discuss moderation cases, where a demonstration practice would work better to demonstrate how Modmail bots work. Try mixing up multiple methods within a training to keep it fresh keep people from losing their attention. Preparation Preparation is key when you are giving any sort of training. Have quick notes ready with keywords that you are going to use during your training, so you do not lose track of where you are what objective you are trying to convey. If you need any material such as a presentation, paper pencil, example cases such, prepare them beforehand so you do not lose time during your training setting these up. If you use any material, test them beforehand. Donat forget to clear your schedule beforehand have some water ready if your training is mostly conducted over a voice chat call. It is important to sleep well night before feel confident. This will let you remain focused have an uninterrupted training session. Make sure you are ready at least five minutes before training starts to welcome arriving trainees as a final check whether not everything is ready good to go. If your training takes place in a voice chat call, test your microphone if you have a wireless headset, make sure it is charged up beforehand! Wrapping up your training When your training is done, finish with an exercise, group discussion, something else that is interactive fun to do. Ideally, this should summarize entire training. Have some room at end to answer any questions your trainees might have. Donat forget to thank everyone who participated for their active contributions! Evaluation After each training, write down what went well what could be improved. You can ask your trainees after they have had some experience as a moderator, what they missed during training that they think should be covered next time, as well as asking what information they did not find useful. You can then adjust your training for next time! Summary Having a training onboarding process in place is very important to have new moderators get accustomed with moderation culture, using bot commands, server rules, your moderation guidelines. There are several training methods that include buddy mentor systems as well as exercises demonstrations. A training document should outline most important information new moderators need, but prevent them from being overwhelmed with information they are unable to comprehend. To have efficient training in place, there are some very important aspects to consider, such as your preparation, goals, how you will carry out training of your new moderators, planning. Considering all of these things when creating your training process will make onboarding as informational effective as possible for you your new recruits! Reddit X Discord Does Your Subreddit Need a Discord? Discord communities are distinct from subreddits attract different audiences. While there are often overlaps between those audiences, it will not always be case, itas important to determine whether your community will benefit from having a Discord before you attempt to start one. Successful Discord communities revolve around human connections conversations not just content. For a Reddit community to translate well into a Discord community, it should be centered around a topic its members are passionate about are highly engaged with. To start, ask yourself following questions: If you believe answers to those questions would be negative about your community, it might be helpful to take a step back reconsider whether a Discord server would benefit it. Moderation Teams Typically, itas best to keep Reddit Discord moderation teams separate. Your Discord is a separate ecosystem with its own needs - itas important to find users from within it that will help you develop maintain it, make it flourish. When starting off, adding your existing subreddit moderator team usually works. However, itas important to note that those mods might not always be as dedicated to this new platform as they are to one that they came from. Looking into future for your Discord server, things might change subreddit mods that helped it in early days might end up having to take a backseat in favor of users who are brought in from within server. owner of server should be a dedicated mod from subreddit who knows both community inner-workings of Discord. Decisions made by owner will be critical to development of your server, so take a moment to review all of potential candidates within your team to choose best one for task. Make sure to bring in at least one user subreddit mod who is also as knowledgeable with Discord ecosystem familiar with your existing community to help with setup administration of server early on. You now have a bunch of mods! Mods on your subreddit, mods dedicated to your Discord server, mods that are both. But what do you do with all these mods, how do you tell them apart, what perms should they have? Communication between your different teams is key to success of both of your communities. Outside of owner, you should ideally have at least two other moderators that are present on both teams. These shared mods will be able to efficiently relay information between teams, coordinate collaborations between Reddit Discord communities, be able to take action in emergency situations, mediate conflicts if they occur. A Here are a few best practices: Itas important to be upfront to your community about fact that your subreddit Discord server are run moderated by completely separate mod teams after server starts taking shape. Set up escalation paths for both of your teams to direct issues related to your subreddit to Reddit modmail, vice-versa, direct users experiencing issues within server to its team. A All staff positions (except owner lead admins) should be independent of useras status on different moderation teams, you should remind your staff team that it is not a given to be modded elsewhere if you become a mod on either platform. Mods that participate in multiple teams must still uphold your activity requirements, meet all of your expectations similarly to rest of your team. Hosting Events Cross Promotions While your communities are linked together, theyare separate entities with different groups of regular visitors contributors. When considering cross platform promotions, assess their relevance to each of your audiences, determine whether they will find it helpful. A few best practices around this topic are: Closing notes Creating a Discord server can be a great way to broaden your subreddit-based community's horizons, giving your users a whole new way to interact with each other. However, it's important to remember that maintaining a Discord community can be a whole lot of work that some of your existing team members might not be interested in taking. Finding right person to lead your Discord ensuring your community's new outpost is in good hands early on will ensure a lasting smooth relationship between your subreddit Discord, to everyoneas benefit. Securing Your Discord Account Account Security first step towards securing server you moderate is securing your own Discord account. Your first line of defense is a strong unique password. Some characteristics of strong passwords include: You can also use a random password generator a password manager to create a completely random password that will be nearly impossible to guess, but difficult to remember. Another option is to combine several random words together. key, though, is that words need to be completely random. Using a tool to help select words at random from dictionary is a good way to help ensure their randomness. Once you have a strong password, you should also enable two-factor authentication, also known as 2FA. 2FA ensures that even if someone manages to guess your password, they wonat be able to get into your account without access to device where 2FA app is. You can also enable 2FA via SMS receive your authentication code via text message. However, SMS 2FA is less secure than application-based 2FA because text messages can be intercepted your phone number could be stolen. Although chance of this is still low, you should still avoid enabling SMS backup for this reason if possible. You also need to make sure devices where your Discord account is logged in device that has your 2FA app are physically secure. Make sure your computer is password protected locked when you are physically away from it. If you use a public computer, make sure that you use incognito mode on web browser to ensure that your Discord information is removed when you close browser. For a phone tablet, require a PIN code to unlock it so that it canat be used by strangers. Now that your account is nice secure, there is one more thing you must closely monitor to ensure it doesnat fall into wrong hands: yourself. Avoiding Social Engineering Attacks weakest link in any cybersecurity system is usually a human, security of your Discord account is no exception. Social engineering is use of deception to manipulate individuals into divulging confidential personal information that may be used for fraudulent purposes. People attempting to gain access to your Discord account may attempt to get you to log into a fake site, download a malicious file, click on a suspicious link. Being able to identify these actions avoiding potential pitfalls is an important part of keeping your account (and servers you moderate) safe. One of most common dangerous scams on Discord is a user a bot sending out a direct message with a QR code saying that you should scan QR code with Discordas QR code scanner for free nitro. This will generally be combined with instructions on how to access use Discordas QR code scanner. However, it is important to remember that Discord's QR code scanner is only used to log in to Discord. Scanning given QR code will allow that attacker to directly log into your account, bypassing your password any 2FA you may have configured. If you accidentally scan a suspicious QR code, you should immediately change your password as this will invalidate your current account token log you out of all devices.You can also report any such scams directly to Discord Trust Safety for further action. For more information on making reports, check out this article. Another common attack is to encourage you to click on a link that redirects to a fake Discord website. Before clicking on any links from a user, ask yourself following questions: If you find that answer to many of above questions is ayesa, you should avoid performing whatever action they are requesting. You can also check any suspicious-looking URLs with various URL checkers, such as this one. If user is specifically asking you to click on a link that prompts you to log in to Discord, another option you have is to navigate directly to https://discord.com in your web browser log in from there. If clicking on useras link still takes you to a login page, double check URL of website. One thing youall want to check is if website starts with https:// instead of http:, that there is a lock next to beginning of URL. Although some fake sites may still have an https:// designation, many of them will not. Other signs may be slight misspellings of URL visual tricks such as diiscrd.com dlscord.com with a lowercase ala instead of an aia. If you notice any of these signs, it is highly likely that it is not actually Discordas website instead a fake website intended to trick you into entering your login credentials so that it can steal your account. a Conclusion Creating a strong password, enabling 2FA, following best practices for physical device security are first steps towards keeping your Discord account secure. However, there may be people that try to trick you into giving access to your Discord account through various scams other social engineering attacks. Being able to spot suspicious messages users being cautious when encountering strange links files is another important part of keeping your account safe. Of course, anyone that is able to illicitly gain access to a moderator account on your server still has potential to do great harm, such as banning users deleting messages, channels, roles. Be sure to share this information with other moderators on your server so that you can each do your part to keep your community safe by keeping your accounts secure. Parasocial Relationships Definition A parasocial relationship describes a one-sided relationship between a spectator who develops a personal attachment through various influences to a performer who is not aware of existence of spectator. It is strengthened by continuous positive exposure to its source, which mainly happens on social platforms. Process In this section weall take a look at how parasocial relationships are developed how to establish severity of level of parasocial relationships you are encountering from a moderation standpoint. Development of Parasocial Relationships establishment of parasocial relationships can be portrayed as such: User A, in this example a popular content creator, uploads regular content on a big platform. User B, who takes position as a member of User Aas audience, takes an interest in their content. User B reacts to User Aas content observes them. While User A may know that people are enjoying their content, they are unlikely to be aware of every viewersa existence. This total awareness becomes more unlikely bigger audience gets. User B on other hand is regularly exposed to User Aas content takes a liking to them. interest is usually defined by User Aas online persona: content, visual appeal, likeability, even their voice can all be influencing aspects. User B perceives User A as very relatable through common interests behaviors starts to develop a feeling of loyalty, even responsibility, during that phase of one-sided bonding. This behavior can be attributed to personal reflection in User A, as well as psychological facts like loneliness, empathy, even low self-esteem. As a consequence, User B can easily be influenced by User A. At this point User B might feel like they understand User A in a way nobody else does may even begin to view them on a personal level as some sort of friend close relative. They see this individual every day, hear their voice on a regular basis, believe that they are connecting to them on a deep level. They develop an emotional attachment, stronger parasocial relationship gets, more attention User B pays to User Aas behavior mannerisms. While User A most likely doesnat know User B personally, User B will seek out interaction with recognition from User A. That behavior is typically represented through donations on stream, where User A either reads out their personal message name publishes a athank youa message on certain websites. Additionally, User B tries to follow engage with their idol on as many platforms as possible aside from their main source of content creation. These social media platforms are usually Instagram Twitter, but can also include User Aas Discord server. Levels of Parasocial Relationships While that type of relationship is natural sometimes even desired, it is important to define level of parasocial relationships differ between its intensity for safety of community, staff members, performer. In their article in Psychology focused academic journal aThe Psychologista, researchers Giles Maltby designed three levels of severity of parasocial relationships based on Celebrity Attitude Scale. aFans are attracted to a favourite celebrity because of their perceived ability to entertain to become a source of social interaction gossip. Items include aMy friends I like to discuss what my favourite celebrity has donea aLearning life story of my favourite celebrity is a lot of funa.a least harmful level is general public social presence. targeted celebrity is subjected to gossip mostly provides a source of entertainment. Their presence is mostly found in talks with friends, talk shows, on magazine covers, similar public-facing media. Discord users on this level usually interact with community in a relaxed, harmless way. next level is parasocial interaction. characteristics of this level are development of an emotional attachment of a spectator with a performer, resulting in intense feelings. This behavior is characterized by spectator wanting to get to know performer, followed by desire to be part of their life as well as considering them as part of their own life. A result of that can be addictive even obsessive behavior, which can be noticed in Discord servers, too. aThe intense-personal aspect of celebrity worship reflects intensive compulsive feelings about celebrity, akin to obsessional tendencies of fans often referred to in literature. Items include aMy favourite celebrity is practically perfect in every waya aI consider my favourite celebrity to be my soulmatea.a Spectators of that level usually ping performer message them privately in an attempt to be recognized. While that behavior is natural, anything that endangers safe interactions between themselves, community, performer needs to be supervised carefully. Unrestrained abusive behavior, which can be found in unwanted intimate, borderline NSFW questions comments, needs to be addressed corrected accordingly. final level is considered most intense level also most dangerous. It contains severe, harmful obsessions that can extend all way to stalking real-world consequences. Parasocial relationships to this degree will rarely be found on Discord, but have to immediately be reported if present. aThis dimension is typified by uncontrollable behaviours fantasies about their celebrities. Items include aI would gladly die in order to save life of my favourite celebritya aIf I walked through door of my favourite celebrityas house she he would be happy to see mea.a vast majority of users wonat reach level past seeing performer as a source of entertainment, but moderators should be aware of potential consequences of anything beyond that as they can be harmful to both spectator, performer, safe environment you are working to upkeep for all. Parasocial Relationships on Discord Parasocial relationships on Discord can pertain to anyone who is perceived as being popular influential, making them acelebritiesa of Discord. Some examples of parasocial relationships on Discord can be found between a user a moderator, a user a content creator you are moderating for, even a member of your moderation team content creator you are working for. But what does all that mean for you, mod? While Discord moderators are not nearly as popular influential as big content creators celebrities, they are still observed by Discord users. While being a moderator puts you into a position of power responsibility over wellbeing of server, some users perceive it as you climbing social ladder in Discord server. In their eyes, becoming a moderator changes your overall social status within your Discord community. Being hoisted higher in serversa hierarchy results in members quickly recognizing you potentially treating you differently due to your influence, even becoming afansa of you as a person. Some users will soak up any information they can get about you, especially if they realize that you have common interests. This may lead to development of a parasocial relationship between users you. Users you have never interacted with before might see you as a person they would get along with seek out your attention, leading to a one-sided relationship on their part. Having such an audience can be overwhelming at first. People will start to look up to you, younger users especially can easily be influenced by online personas. They might adapt to your behavior even copy your mannerisms. Knowing that, you should always be self-aware of your actions etiquette in public to promote a healthy, sustainable relationship with users. Receiving special attention from users can quickly influence spiral into developing an arrogant, entitled attitude. There is nothing wrong with being proud of your position accomplishments, but being overtly arrogant will influence a membersa behavior towards you. mindset of one user deciding a moderator is not being responsible can spread through community in negative ways. They might belittle you in front of new members give them feeling that you wonat be there to help them might not inform you of ongoing problems on server during a temporary absence of moderators in chat. A healthy user-moderator relationship is important to prevent stop ongoing raids as well as make moderators aware of a user misbehaving in chat. Additionally, itas important to be mindful that your perceived fame does not start to negatively influence your judgment. For example, you may find yourself giving special attention to those who seem to appreciate you while treating users that are indifferent towards your position as a moderator more harshly. It also causes dynamics within staff team to change as fellow moderators might start to perceive you differently if you begin to allow bias to seep into moderation. They may start to second guess your decisions, feel need to check up on your moderator actions, even lose trust in your capabilities. If you ever notice that you experience said effect, notice one of your fellow moderators is experiencing it letting it consume them, be supportive sort out negative changes. When confronting another moderator about it, make sure to do it through constructive criticism that doesnat seem like a personal attack. In spite of that, effects of parasocial relationships donat always have to be negative in nature. If users manage to build such a connection to a moderation team, general server atmosphere can grow positively. Users know what moderators like donat enjoy, which will lead them to behave in a way that appeals to staff usually abides by server rules. They will also be able to predict a moderatorsa reaction to certain behavior messages new people might use. As a result, they will attempt to correct users that are mildly misbehaving themselves without getting staff involved immediately in hopes of receiving positive feedback from staff. Naturally, moderators wonat be able to know of every single person that tries to appeal to them through those actions, but once they are aware that such things happen in certain text channels, it will give them opportunity to focus on other channels provide their assistance there. As mentioned before: In case of content creators who frequently upload videos, streams, other forms of media for their followers, chance of a parasocial phenomenon being developed can be even greater. This will only intensify by joining a creatorsa Discord server. This can be done under false assumption that there will be a higher chance of their messages being read noticed. Your responsibility as a moderator is to neither weaken that bond nor encourage it while providing security for users, staff, content creator. Let users interact in a controlled environment while maintaining privacy of content creator. Some users might even feel like content creator owes them some sort of recognition after long-term support, both through engagement donations. Such a demand can be intensified when theyare shown as ahighera in hierarchy through dedicated Discord roles, such as Patreon/Donator simple activity roles. In case of multiple people building a parasocial relationship with same content creator experiencing that phenomenon, they may see other active users even moderators as arivals.a They see content creator as a close friend in their eyes feel threatened that others, especially those that financially support content creator, perceive them same think they are even closer to them. During such moments, it is recommended to keep peace between users let them know that content creator appreciates every fan they have. While ones providing financial support are appreciated, every viewer is what makes creator as big as they are played a part in getting them to where they are today. Maybe it wonat only be user that feels closer to them by joining server. Many beginner moderators may also find themselves feeling as though they are above rest of community because their idol has entrusted them with power on their server. Being closer to them than most of users can easily fog your judgement; it is essential to prioritize being friendly respectful to users over these personal convictions. When adding moderators to your moderation team, it is important to keep an eye out for this kind of behavior to combat it, to hold your teammates accountable should you see this behavior begin to exhibit in one of your teammates. Making sure your entire team is on same page regarding your duties standing in community is essential to maintaining a healthy moderation environment. As a moderator for a Content Creator, this individual you may admire deeply has put their trust in you to keep their community safe. Falling into machinations of developing an unhealthy parasocial relationship with them directly interferes with your ability to do that, failing not only community but creator. In Conclusion Despite potential dangers from parasocial relationships, fact that they develop at all may indicate that you are doing a good job as a moderator. While positive attention appreciation are key factors to a healthy development, not everyone may like that sort of attention it is completely acceptable to tell your fellow moderators even users themselves about it. At one point you might feel like you reached your limit need a break from moderation managing parasocial relationships aimed at you those around you. Moderator burnout is very real, you should not hesitate to take a break when you need it. Users will view you, as a moderator, as a leader that helps guide your designated Discord server in right direction. As such, you will be a target for rude comments by users that have personal issues with server while simultaneously getting showered with affection by other users who are thankful for what you do for server. Never be afraid to ask for help rely on moderation team if things go too far for your personal boundaries comfort level, even if you are an experienced moderator. Establishing a healthy relationship with community is important, but being able to trust your fellow staff members is even more so. Nobody expects you to build an intimate relationship with every member, but knowing you can count on them their support is essential for team to function correctly. Transparency in Moderation Pros Cons of Transparency While there are certain abest practicesa when it comes to moderation transparency, there is no single system that is right for everyone. amount of transparency you need for your moderation system ultimately depends on your server rules, culture, vision. This article will explain pros cons of transparency ways that you can apply transparency to your moderation system. Though idea of moderation transparency is generally considered to be a good thing, it is important to understand that there are both pros cons to transparency in moderation. Some of these pros cons are described below. To help you understand how pros cons apply to transparency, consider an example in which a moderator publicly warns another user not to call someone a aretarda because it violates an existing aNo Slurs Alloweda rule. Moderation System Now that you are aware of some of pros cons of transparency in moderation, you must next understand components of moderation system so that you can consider ways in which these components can be made more less transparent. Broadly speaking, a moderation system can be split into following components: Transparency communication go hand-in-hand. more you communicate these components to relevant users server as a whole, more transparent your moderation system is. Implementing Transparency There are several ways to implement transparency in each of these components, each with their own pros cons. Each section here will establish ways in which a component can be made more less transparent a recommendation of appropriate level of transparency for each. However, please keep in mind that every serveras needs are different some of pros cons discussed may not apply to your server. It is always important to consider your specific community when it comes to implementing transparency. Your server rules are backbone of your moderation system. They describe how your members should conduct themselves what happens if they donat meet those expectations. In general though, your rules should be specific enough to ensure comprehension compliance without being overly wordy attempting to provide an exhaustive description of prohibited behaviors. For example, giving a couple of examples of NSFW content for a ano NSFW content rulea may help people understand what you interpret as being NSFW, compared to other servers Discord itself. However, too many examples may make list seem fully comprehensive, people will assume that items not on list are fair game. Disclaiming that examples of rule-breaking content are non-exhaustive that moderators have final say in interpreting if someone is breaking rules can help to address users that are interested in testing limits of rules being rules lawyers to escape punishment on a technicality. Developing moderator guidelines is another important part of your moderation system. Similar to your rules guiding conduct of your server members, your moderator guidelines help guide conduct of your moderators. Keeping your moderator guidelines visible to rest of server will encourage compliance from members, enable them to defuse incidents without moderator intervention. Furthermore, providing basic standards of moderator conduct will help users know when itas appropriate to report moderators to server owner for misconduct hold them accountable. However, you should avoid putting too much of your moderator guidelines out in public in order to avoid rules lawyers deliberately misinterpreting spirit of guidelines to their advantage. After developing your moderator guidelines, balancing these pros cons will help you determine how much of your guidelines you should present to public. Logging user infractions is key to ensuring that entire moderation team has same understanding of how often a user has broken rules. Transparency between mod team user in question is important for user to understand when they have received a warning that brings them closer to being banned from server. Informing user of which moderator warned them is important for holding moderators accountable to warnings they issue, but may leave moderators open to harassment by warned users. Having a procedure to deal with harassment that stems from this, is one way to achieve accountability while still protecting your moderators from bad actors in your server. Although communication of infractions is vital to ensure understanding among your server members, it may be prudent to withhold information about exactly how close a user is to being banned so that they do not attempt to toe line by staying just under threshold for being banned. Furthermore, even though a public infraction log may be a good way to promote cohesion transparency by showing examples of unacceptable behavior to rest of server fostering discussion between mod team community, others may think that such a log infringes on user privacy that these logs may constitute a awitch hunt.a It may also leave mods users open to harassment over warnings given received. If you want to encourage a sense of community understanding without taking away user privacy inadvertently encouraging harassment, a better option may be to encourage users to bring up criticisms of rules enforcement in a feedback channel if they wish to. Provided that mod team ensures these conversations remain constructive civil, creating a public medium for these conversations will help others understand how mod team operates allow them to provide feedback on how server is run. Everyone makes mistakes, moderators are no exception. It is important to have a process for users to appeal their warnings punishments if they feel that they were issued unfairly. If you decide to have a public infractions log, you may receive appeals on behalf of warned users from people who were uninvolved in situation if they feel warning was issued unfairly. While this can help with accountability if a user is too nervous to try to appeal their warning, it can also waste time of your mod team by involving someone that does not have a complete understanding of situation. In general, it is better to keep appeal process private between moderation team punished user, primarily via mediums such as direct messages with an administrator through a mod mail bot. During appeal process, it is best to ensure that you clearly calmly walk through situation with appealing user to help them better understand rules while maintaining moderator accountability. Summary In end, there is not a single acorrecta way to manage transparency in your moderation system. appropriate level of transparency will vary based on size of server rules that you implement. However, walking through steps of your moderation system one by one considering various pros cons of transparency will help you determine for yourself how to incorporate transparency into your moderation system. This will help you build trust between moderators non-moderators while preventing abuse on both ends of system. Auto Moderation in Discord Why is Auto Moderation important? Auto Moderation is integral to many communities on Discord, especially those of any notable size. There are many valid reasons for this, some of which you may find apply to your community as well. security that auto moderation can provide can give your users a much better experience in your community, make lives of your moderators easier prevent malicious users from doing damage to your community even joining your community. If youare a well established community, youall likely have a moderation team in place. You may wonder, why should I use auto moderation? I already have moderators! Auto moderation isnat a replacement for manual moderation, rather, it serves to enrich it. Your moderation team can continue to make informed decisions within your community while auto moderation serves to make that process easier for them by responding to common issues at any time more quickly than a real-life moderator can. Different communities will warrant varying levels of auto moderation. Itas important to be able to classify your community consider what level of auto moderation is most suitable to your communityas needs. Keep in mind that Discord does impose some additional guidelines depending on how you designate your community. Below are different kinds of communities their recommended auto moderation systems: If you run a Discord community with limited invites where every new member is known, auto moderation wonat be a critical function unless you have a significantly larger member count. Itas recommended to have at least some auto moderation however, namely text filters, anti-spam, Discordas AutoMod keyword filters. If you run a Discord community that is Discoverable has public invites where new members can come from just about anywhere, itas strongly recommended to have anti-spam text filters Discordas AutoMod keyword filters in place. Additionally, you should be implementing some level of member verification to facilitate server onboarding process. If your community is large, with several thousand members, anti-raid functionality may become necessary. Remember, auto moderation is configurable to your rules, as strict loose as they may be, so keep this principle in mind when deciding what level of automation works best for you. If your Discord community is Verified Partnered, you will need to adhere to additional guidelines to maintain that status. Auto moderation is recommended for these communities in order to feel confident that you can succinctly effectively enforce these guidelines at all times so consider using anti-spam text filters Discordas AutoMod keyword filters. If you have a Vanity URL your community is Discoverable, anti-raid is a must-have in order to protect your community from malicious actors. Built-in moderation features Some of most powerful tools in auto moderation come with your community are built directly into Discord. Located under Server Settings tab, you will find Moderation settings. This page houses some of strongest safety features that Discord has to natively offer. These settings can help secure your Discord community without elaborate setup of a third party bot involved. individual settings will be detailed below.
