AutoMod AutoMod is a new content moderation feature as of 2022, allowing those with aManage Servera aAdministratora permissions to set up keyword spam filters that can automatically trigger moderation actions such as blocking messages that contain specific keywords spam from being posted, logging flagged messages as alerts for you to review. This feature has a wide variety of uses within realm of auto moderation, allowing mods to automatically log malicious messages protect community members from harm exposure to undesirable spam words like slurs severe profanity. AutoModas abilities also extend to messages within threads, text-in-voice channels, Forum channels giving moderation teams peace of mind that they have AutoModas coverage across these message surfaces without having to worry about adding more manual moderation work by enabling these valuable features. Setting up AutoMod is very straightforward. First, make sure your server has Communities enabled. Then, navigate to your serveras settings click AutoMod tab. From there, youall find AutoMod can start setting up keyword spam filters.a Keyword Filtersa Keyword filters allow you to flag block messages containing specific words, characters, symbols from being posted. You can set up one aCommonly Flagged Wordsa filter, along with up to 3 custom keyword filters that allow you to enter a maximum of 1,000 keywords each, for a total of four keyword filters. When inserting keywords, you should separate each word with a comma like so: Bad, words, go, here. Matches for keywords are exact aware of whitespace. For example, keyword aTest Filtera will be triggered by atest filtera but not atestfiltera atesta. Do note that keywords also ignore capitalisation. To have AutoMod filter messages containing words that partially match your keywords, which is helpful for preventing users from circumventing your filters, you can modify your keywords with asterisk (*) wildcard character. This works as follows: Be careful with wildcards so as to not have AutoMod incorrectly flag words that are acceptable commonly used! AutoModas Commonly Flagged Words keyword filter comes equipped with three predefined wordlists that provide communities with convenient protection against commonly flagged words. There are three predefined categories of words available: Insults Slurs, Sexual Content, Severe Profanity. These wordlists will all share one rule, meaning theyall all have same response configured. These lists are maintained by Discord can help keep conversations in your Community consistent with Discord's Community Guidelines. This can be particularly helpful for Partnered Verified communities. a Both AutoModas commonly flagged word filters custom filters allow for exemptions in form of roles channels, with commonly flagged word filter also allowing for exemption of words from Discordas predefined wordlists. Anyone with these defined roles, sending messages within defined channels containing keywords from Discordas wordlists, will not trigger responses from AutoMod.This is notably useful for allowing moderators to bypass filters, allowing higher trusted users to send more unrestricted messages, tailoring commonly flagged wordlists to your communityas needs. As an example, you could prevent new users from sending Discord invites with a keyword filter of: *discord.gg/*, *discord.com/invites/* then give an exemption to moderators users who have a certain role, allowing them to send Discord invites. This could also be used to only allow sharing Discord invites in a specific channel. Thereas a lot of potential use cases for exemptions! Members with Manage Server Administrator permissions will always be exempt from all AutoMod filters. Bots webhooks are also exempt. Spam, by definition, is irrelevant unsolicited messages. AutoMod comes equipped with two spam filters that allow you to flag messages containing mention spam content spam. Mention spam is when users post messages containing excessive mentions for purpose of disrupting your server unnecessarily pinging others. AutoModas mention spam filter lets you flag block messages containing an excessive number of unique @role @user mentions. You define what is aexcessivea by setting a limit on number of unique mentions that a message may contain, up to 50. It is recommended to select "Block message" as an AutoMod response when it detects a message containing excessive mentions as this prevents notifications from being sent out to tagged users roles. This helps prevent your channels from being clogged up by disruptive messages containing mention spam during mass mention attempts mention raids, saves your members from annoyance of getting unnecessary notifications ghost pings. a This filter identifies spam at large by using a model that has been trained by messages that users have reported as spam to Discord. Enabling this filter is an effective way to block out a variety of messages that resemble spammy content reported by Discord users, identify spammers in your community that should be weeded out. However, this filter isnat perfect might not catch all forms of spam, such as DM spam, copy/pasta repeat messages. You can configure AutoModas keyword spam filters with following automatic responses when a message is flagged: This response will prevent a message containing a keyword spam from being sent entirely. Users will be notified with an ephemeral message when this happens, informing them community has blocked message from being sent. Discord will seamlessly block all messages containing matching keywords, spam content, excessive mentions from your filters from being sent entirely regardless of volume of messages, making this response especially effective for preventing de-escalating raids where raiders try to spam your channels with repeated messages excessive mentions. This response will send an alert containing who-what-where information of a flagged message to a logging channel of your choice. This message will preview what full caught message wouldave looked like, including full content. It also shows a pair of buttons at bottom of message, a Actions Report Issues. Thes action buttons will bring up a user context menu, allowing you to use any permissions you have to kick, ban time out member. message also displays channel message was attempted to be sent in filter that was triggered by message. In future, some auto-moderation bots may be able to detect these messages action users accordingly. a This response will automatically apply a time out penalty to a user, preventing them from interacting in server for duration of penalty. Affected users are unable to send messages, react to messages, join voice channels video calls during their timeout period. Keep in mind that they are able to see messages being sent during this period. To remove a timeout penalty, Moderators Admins can right-click on any offending useras name to bring up their Profile Context Menu select aRemove Timeout.a AutoMod is a very powerful tool that you can set up easily to reduce moderation work keep your community's channels conversations clean welcoming during all hours of day. For example, you may want to use three keyword filters; one to just block messages, one to just send alerts for messages, one to do both. Overall, it's recommended to have AutoMod block messages you wouldn't want community members to see. For example, high harm keywords such as slurs other extreme language should have AutoModas ablock messagea asend alertsa responses enabled. This will allow your moderation team to take action against undesirable messages users behind them while preventing rest of your community from exposure. Low harm keywords commonly spammed phrases can also have AutoModas aBlock messagea response enabled without need to set up alerts. This will still prevent undesirable messages from being sent without spamming your logs with alerts. You can also quickly configure AutoModas keyword spam filters in real-time to prevent de-escalate raids by adding spammed keywords - adjusting your mention limit in event of a mention raid - to prevent raids from causing lasting damage. It's also recommended to have AutoMod send you alerts for more subjective content that requires a closer look from your moderation team, rather than having them being blocked entirely. This will allow your moderation team to investigate flagged messages with additional context to ensure thereas nothing malicious going on. This is useful for keywords that can be commonly misrepresented, sent in a non-malicious context. a Verification Level None - This turns off verification for your community, meaning anyone can join immediately interact with your community. This is typically not recommended for public communities as anyone with malicious intent can immediately join wreak havoc. Low - This requires people joining your community to have a verified email which can help protect your community from laziest of malicious users while keeping everything simple for well-meaning users. This would be a good setting for a small, private community. Medium - This requires user to have a verified email address for their account to be at least 5 minutes old. This further protects your community by introducing a blocker for people creating accounts solely to cause problems. This would be a good setting for a moderately sized community small public community. High - This includes same protections as both medium low verification levels but also adds a 10 minute barrier between someone joining your community being able to interact. This can give you anyone else responsible for keeping things clean in your community time to respond to araidsa, large numbers of malicious users joining at once. For legitimate users, you can encourage them to do something with this 10 minute time period such as read rules familiarize themselves with informational channels to pass time until waiting period is over. This would be a good setting for a large public community. Highest - This requires a joining user to have a verified phone number in addition to above requirements. This setting can be bypassed by robust araidersa, but it takes additional effort. This would be a good setting for a private community where security is tantamount, a public community with custom verification. This requirement is one many normal Discord users wonat fill, by choice inability. Itas worth noting that Discordas phone verification disallows VoIP numbers to be abused. Explicit media content filter Not everyone on internet is sharing content with best intentions in mind. Discord provides a robust system to scan images embeds to make sure inappropriate images donat end up in your community. There are varying levels of scrutiny to explicit media content filter which are: Donat scan any media content - Nothing sent in your community will go through Discordas automagical image filter. This would be a good setting for a small, private community where only people you trust can post images, videos etc. Scan media content from users without a role - Self explanatory, this works well to stop new users from filling your community with unsavoury imagery. When combined with proper verification methods, this would be a good setting for a moderately sized private public community. Scan media content from all members - This setting makes sure everyone, regardless of their roles, isnat posting unsavoury things in your community. In general, we recommend this setting for ALL public facing communities. Once youave decided on base level of auto moderation you want for your community, itas time to look at extra levels of auto moderation bots can bring to table! next few sections are going to detail ways in which a bot can moderate. Bot-controlled Auto Moderation If you want to keep your chats clean clear of certain words, phrases, spam, mentions everything else that can be misused by malicious users youare going to need a little help from a robotic friend two. Examples of bots that are freely available are referenced below. If you decide to use several bots, you may need to juggle several moderation systems. When choosing a bot for auto moderation, you should also consider their capabilities for manual moderation (things like managing mutes, warns etc.). Find a bot with an infraction/punishment system you rest of your moderator team find to be most appropriate. All of bots listed in this article have a manual moderation system. main most pivotal forms of auto moderation are: Each of these subsets of auto moderation will be detailed below along with recommended configurations depending on your community. Itas important your auto moderation bot(s) of choice are adopting cutting edge of Discord API features, as this will allow them to provide better capabilities integrate more powerfully with Discord. Slash commands are especially important as youare able to configure which commands are usable on which bot on a case by case basis for each slash command. This will allow you to maintain very detailed moderation permissions for your moderation team. Bots that support more recent API features are generally also considered to be more actively developed, thus more reliable in regards to reacting to new threat vectors as well as able to adapt to new features on Discord. A severely outdated bot could react insufficiently to a high-harm situation. a As mentioned above, one of more recent features is Slash Commands. Slash commands are configurable per-command, per-role, per-channel. This allows you to designate moderation commands solely to your moderation team without relying on permissions on botas side to work perfectly. This is relevant because there have been documented examples in past of permissions being bypassed on a moderation botas permission checking, allowing normal users to execute moderation commands. a One of most common forms of auto moderation is anti-spam, a type of filter that can detect prevent various kinds of spam. Depending on what bot(s) youare using, this comes with various levels of configurability. One of most common forms of auto moderation is anti-spam, a type of filter that can detect prevent various kinds of spam. Depending on what bot(s) youare using, this comes with various levels of configurability. Anti-spam is integral to running a large private community, a public community. There are multiple types of spam a user can engage in, with some of most common forms listed in table above. These types of spam messages are also very typical of raids, especially Fast Messages Repeated Text. While spam can largely be defined as irrelevant unsolicited messages, nature of spam can vary greatly. However, vast majority of instances involve a user users sending lots of messages with same content with intent of disrupting your community. There are subsets of this spam that many anti-spam filters will be able to catch. For example, if any of following: Mentions, Links, Invites, Emoji Newline Text are spammed repeatedly in one message, spammed repeatedly across several messages, they will provoke most Repeated Text Fast Messages filters appropriately. Subset filters are still a good thing for your anti-spam filter to have as you may wish to punish more less harshly depending on spam. Notably, Emoji Links may warrant separate punishments. Spamming 10 links in a single message is inherently worse than having 10 emoji in a message. Anti-spam will only act on these things contextually, usually in an X in Y fashion where if a user sends, for example, ten links in five seconds, they will be punished to some degree. This could be ten links in one message, one link in ten messages. In this respect, some anti-spam filters can act simultaneously as Fast Messages Repeated Text filters. Sometimes, spam may happen too quickly a bot can fall behind. There are rate limits in place to stop bots from harming communities that can prevent deletion of individual messages if those messages are being sent too quickly. This can often happen in raids. As such, Fast Messages filters should prevent offenders from sending messages; this can be done via a mute, kick ban. If you want to protect your community from raids, please read on to Anti-Raid section of this article. Text filters allow you to control types of words and/or links that people are allowed to put in your community. Different bots will provide various ways to filter these things, keeping your chat nice clean. A text filter is a must for a well moderated community. Itas strongly recommended you use a bot that can filter text based on a banlist. A Banned words filter can catch links invites provided http:// https:// are added to word banlist (for all links) specific full site URLs to block individual websites. In addition, discord.gg can be added to a banlist to block ALL Discord invites. A Banned Words filter is integral to running a public community, especially for Partnered, Community, Verified servers who have additional content guidelines they must meet that a Banned Words filter can help with. Before configuring a filter, itas a good idea to work out what is isnat ok to say in your community, regardless of context. For example, racial slurs are generally unacceptable in almost all communities, regardless of context. Banned word filters often wonat account for context with an explicit banlist. For this reason, itas also important that a robust filter contains allowlisting options. For example, if you add acata to your filter someone says acatcha, they could get in trouble for using an otherwise acceptable word. Filter immunity may also be important to your community as there may be individuals who need to discuss use of banned words, namely members of a moderation team. There may also be channels that allow usage of otherwise banned words. For example, a serious channel dedicated to discussion of real world issues may require discussions about slurs other demeaning language, in this exception channel based Immunity is integral to allowing those conversations. Link filtering is important to communities where sharing links in agenerala chats isnat allowed, where there are specific channels dedicated to sharing that content. This can allow a community to remove links with an appropriate reprimand without treating that misstep with same gravity one would someone who used a slur. Allow/ban-listing templates for links are also a good idea to have. While many communities will use catch-all filters to make sure links stay in specific channels, some links will always be inherently unsavory. Being able to filter specific links is a good feature- with preset filters (like google filter provided by YAGPDB) coming in very handy for protecting your user base without requiring intricate setup on your behalf. However, it is recommended you configure a custom filter as a supplement, to ensure specific slurs, words, etc. that break rules of your community, arenat being said. Invite filtering is equally important in large public communities where users will attempt to raid, scam otherwise assault your community with links with intention of manipulating your user base where unsolicited self-promotion is potentially fruitful. Filtering allows these invites to be recognized instantly dealt with more harshly. Some bots may also allow by-community white/banlisting allowing you to control which communities are approved to share invites to which arenat. A good example of invite filtering usage would be something like a partners channel, where invites to other, closely linked, communities are shared. These communities should be added to an invite allowlist to prevent their deletion. Discord also implements a native filter on links files, though this filter is entirely client-side doesnat prevent malicious links files being sent. It does, however, warn users who attempt to click suspicious links download suspicious files (executables, archives etc.) prevents known malicious links from being clicked at all. While this doesnat remove offending content, shouldnat be relied on as auto moderation, it does prevent some cracks in your auto moderation from harming users. Raids, as defined earlier in this article, are mass-joins of users (often selfbots) with intent of damaging your community. Protecting your community from these raids can come in various forms. One method involves gating your server using a method detailed elsewhere in DMA. Raid detection means a bot can detect large number of users joining thatas typical of a raid, usually in an X in Y format. This feature is usually chained with Raid Prevention Damage Prevention to prevent detected raid from being effective, wherein raiding users will typically spam channels with unsavory messages. Raid-user detection is a system designed to detect users who are likely to be participating in a raid independently of quantity of frequency of new user joins. These systems typically look for users that were created recently have no profile picture, among other triggers depending on how elaborate system is. Raid prevention stops a raid from happening, either by Raid detection Raid-user detection. These countermeasures stop participants of a raid specifically from harming your community by preventing raiding users from accessing your community in first place, such as through kicks, bans, mutes of users that triggered detection. Damage prevention stops raiding users from causing any disruption via spam to your community by closing off certain aspects of it either from all new users, from everyone. These functions usually prevent messages from being sent read in public channels that new users will have access to. This differs from Raid Prevention as it doesnat specifically target remove new users in community. Raid anti-spam is an anti-spam system robust enough to prevent raiding usersa messages from disrupting channels via typical spam found in a raid. For an anti-spam system to fit this dynamic, it should be able to prevent Fast Messages Repeated Text. This is a subset of Damage Prevention. Raid cleanup commands are typically mass-message removal commands to clean up channels affected by spam as part of a raid, often aliased to aPurgea aPrunea.Built-in anti-raid It should be noted that Discord features built-in raid user bot detection, which is rather effective at preventing raids as before they happen. If you are logging member joins leaves, you can infer that Discord has taken action against shady accounts if time difference between join leave times is extremely small (such as between 0-5 seconds). However, you shouldnat rely solely on these systems if you run a large public community. Messages arenat only way potential evildoers can introduce unwanted content to your community. They can also manipulate their Discord username Nickname to be abusive. There are a few different ways a username can be abusive different bots offer different filters to prevent this. Username filtering is less important than other forms of auto moderation. When choosing which bot(s) to use for your auto moderation needs, this should typically be a later priority, since users with malicious usernames can just be nicknamed in order to hide their actual username. Specialized Auto Moderation Bots So far, weave covered general auto moderation bots with a wide toolset. However, there are some specialized bots that only cover one specific facet of auto moderation execute it especially well. A few examples descriptions are below: This bot detects raids as they happen globally, banning raiders from your community. This is especially notable as itall ban detected raiders from raids in other communities itas in as they join your community, making it significantly more effective than other anti-raid solutions that only pay attention to your community. Fish is designed to counter scamming links accounts, targeting patterns in joining users to prevent DM raids (Like normal raids, but members are directly messaged instead). These DM raids are typically phishing scams, which Fish also filters, deleting known phishing sites. Both of these bots are highly specialized link file moderation bots, effectively filtering adult sites, scamming sites other categories of sites as defined by your moderation team. Which bot do I use? When choosing a bot for auto moderation you should ensure it has an infraction/punishment system you your mod team are comfortable with as well as its features being whatas best suited for your community. Consider testing out several bots their compatibility with Discordas built-in auto moderation features to find what works best for your serveras needs. You should also keep in mind that list of bots in this article is not comprehensive - you can consider bots not listed here. world of Discord moderation bots is vast fascinating, we encourage you to do your own research! For largest of communities, itas recommended you employ everything Discord has to offer. You should use High Highest Verification level, all of Discordas AutoMod keyword filters a robust moderation bot like Gearbot Gaius. You should seriously consider additional bots like Fish, Beemo Safelink/Crosslink to aid in keeping your users safe have detailed Content Moderation filters. At this scale, you should seriously consider premium, self hosted, custom moderation bots to meet unique demands of your community. Itas recommended you use a bot with a robust diverse toolset, while simultaneously utilizing AutoModas commonly flagged word filters. You should use High Verification level to aid in preventing raids. If raiding isnat a large concern for your community, Gearbot Giselle are viable options. Your largest concerns in a community of this size is going to be anti-spam text filters meaning robust keyword filters are also highly recommended, with user filters as a good bonus. Beemo is generally recommended for any servers of this size. At this scale a self hosted, custom, premium bot may also be a viable option, but such bots arenat covered in this article. Itas recommended you use Fire, Gearbot, Bulbbot, AutoModerator Giselle. Mee6 Dyno are also viable options, however as theyare very large bots have been known to experience outages, leaving your community unprotected for large amounts of time. At this community size, youare likely not going to be largely concerned about anti-raid with anti-spam text filters being your main focus. Youall likely be able to get by just using AutoModas keyword filters commonly flagged words lists provided by Discord. User filters, at this size, are largely unneeded your Verification Level shouldnat need to be any higher than Medium. If your community is small private, likelihood of malicious users joining to wreak havoc is rather low. As such, you can choose a bot with general moderation features you like most use that for auto moderation. Any of bots listed in this article should serve this purpose. At this scale, you should be able to rely solely on AutoModas keyword filters. Your Verification Level is largely up to you at this scale depending on where you anticipate member growth coming from, with Medium being default recommended. Then, look at its documentation (https://gearbot.rocks/docs) for full details on how to configure auto moderation for your community. Using Webhooks Embeds What is a Webhook? A webhook is sort of a areverse APIa: rather than an application you own (like a bot) calling another application to receive data when it wants it, a webhook is something you can give to someone else's application to send data to you directly as soon as thereas something to share. This makes process very convenient efficient for both providers users. Now letas apply this definition to a more tangible example. Letas say you arenat around to reply to new e-mails for a while. Through power of webhooks you could have a setup that replies automatically! When an event happens on a service (like receiving an email), that service activates your webhook sends you data relevant to event that happened. That way, you have exactly information you need to automatically reply to each new e-mail you receive. So what does this mean for your server? Basically, Discord provides you with ability to have a webhook that sends a message to your server when itas activated, with option to send message to any channel along with having a cool name avatar of your choice.For example, letas say youare waiting for latest chapter of your favorite webcomic series to release. You can set up a webhook thatas connected with an RSS feed. feed will activate webhook when chapter is released a message will be posted on your server to notify you about it. This can be applied to many different things - potential is limitless! If service is capable of sending JSON Webhooks, Discord can often use these to create visually appealing embeds when it sends a message out. However, it can also accept raw text messages to pass along as well. Usage of Webhooks Webhooks are a great tool for services that have events that youare interested in latching onto. This can be incredibly useful for Content Creator communities where their latest YouTube videos Twitter posts can be funneled into channels for followers to have easy viewing access in your Discord community. You could also use this for a community thatas oriented towards an open-source technology by having events from GitHub be submitted directly to your server for people to keep track of. There are a lot of platforms out there that provide you with ability to handle everything by yourself- from creating Webhook through your Discord Server Settings to plugging it into platform you want updates from. However, this often requires you to be more familiar with at least some level of programming as many of these platforms require developer accounts. There can be a few hoops to jump through to get everything set up just right. This can often turn people off from using these types of webhooks. However, times are changing barrier to entry when dabbling into world of webhooks is much lower. These days, multiple third-party services exist that have handled all hard techy stuff for you. They can interface with platforms that would normally require you to do extra work to get data you want. IFTTT Zapier are two such services that lets you plug-and-play several useful platforms directly into your Discord server through a clean web interface that allows you to customize type of data your webhook receives, thus what messages are sent to your server. Just keep in mind that some services have restrictions on how many events can be sent to one webhook, so you may have to create multiple distinct webhooks for multiple functionalities. Note that these options restrictions are entirely platform-dependent. Discord has no problems handling whatever data is thrown at its webhooks when activated, even if itas from different sources. Thereas another use-case for Webhooks that is more unique. While theyare very useful for automated messages, theyare also great for one-off embed messages that have a very polished look! You have ability to customize name avatar of webhook, but if youare technologically-inclined you can create your own JSON data to activate webhook with. This allows you to fully define aesthetics of an embed in your message, giving a clean look to whatever information youare sending. One possible application is nice formatting for your server rules information, rather than just sending multiple plain text messages.Of course, there are other possible uses, only limit is your creativity! If youare not too keen on developing JSON data by hand, have no idea what a aJSONa is, services like Discohook also make it easy for anyone to take advantage of this use case. As a note, websites linked here are not endorsed by Discord are only a suggestion from authors of article. How do I set up a webhook? process of setting up webhooks can be roughly explained in five simple steps! Step 1: In your Discord server, you will need to create a webhook copy webhook URL. This URL is path for your webhook to receive an HTTP POST request from a service when an event occurs. Step 2: From this menu, you have ability to style your webhook with a name avatar. We recommend at least a name to distinguish its purpose. Step 3: If youare using a third-party service to handle events send messages, plug your webhook URL into service configure type of events that service should trigger for. Step 4: If your third-party service allows you to, configure additional options that will change look content of your message to way you like. Step 5: Now that youave created connection, when event happens, data will be sent directly to Discord your webhook will post a message in your preferred channel! What is an Embed? Weave been talking about embeds a lot, but we havenat quite explained what they are yet! In simple terms, embedding refers to integration of links, images, GIFs, videos other forms of content into messages on social media. An embed itself is a part of message that visually represents content in order to increase engagement. As a user of Discord, you have probably seen embeds more than a few times. They often are created automatically by Discord when a user sends a link, such as allowing you to view a YouTube video within Discord when a YouTube URL is shared. But did you know that Discord Bots Webhooks can create their own embeds with all kinds of data? Theyare pretty flexible! They can have colored borders, images, text fields, other kinds of fancy properties. If you're a developer, options available to you to create a good-looking embed are powerful versatile. For non-developers, platforms may give you visualizations that help you plug-and-play data into a website for customization purposes. There are also online tools to help you do this too! Here are several of those properties that can be modified in an embed in order to style it, to give you an idea of whatas possible when you have ability to style your messages: Markdown is also supported in an embed. Here is an image to showcase an example of these properties: Example image to showcase elements of an embedAn important thing to note is that embeds also have their limitations, which are set by API. Here are some of most important ones you need to know:An important thing to note is that embeds also have their limitations, which are set by API. Here are some of most important ones you need to know: If you feel like experimenting even further you should take a look at full list of limitations provided by Discord here.Itas very important to keep in mind that when you are writing an embed, it should be in JSON format. Some bots even provide an embed visualizer within their dashboards. You can also use this embed visualizer tool which provides visualization for bot webhook embeds. a Benefits of using Webhooks There are several benefits to using webhooks in your community including simplicity, versatility, automation, customization, accessibility. Simplicity. Webhooks are straightforward lacking in complexity. They have a single function, which is to send a designated message when they are activated. Versatility. Webhooks have many different use cases, all stemming from being able to send a message upon activation. This allows for many types of automation powered by other services, allows you to send clean looking messages manually. Both of these setups have their own various uses ranging from posting updates logging to posting custom messages for an aesthetic purpose. Automation. With webhooks, there isnat a need to constantly look for updates post them yourself. Once set up, a webhook will automatically post any updates you need. Customization. Each webhook can have a unique name avatar, each message it sends can be unique as well. You can have multiple webhooks with different looks in different channels use each of them however you like. Accessibility. Once you create a webhook, all you need is its URL a website that will push messages. Since these webhooks are hosted on Discord, they donat need to be hosted like a normal bot, often saving moderation teams from encountering a financial investment to use them, making them more easily available to all users. Webhooks vs. Bots Webhooks bots, while having slight similarities, are actually very different from each other. There are several aspects we have to look at when comparing two: a Even though this comparison is important for better understanding of both bots webhooks, it does not mean you should limit yourself to only picking one other. Sometimes, bots webhooks work their best when working together. Itas not uncommon for bots to use webhooks for logging purposes to distinguish notable messages with a custom avatar name for that message. Both tools are essential for a server to function properly make for a powerful combination. a Even though this comparison is important for better understanding of both bots webhooks, it does not mean you should limit yourself to only picking one other. Sometimes, bots webhooks work their best when working together. Itas not uncommon for bots to use webhooks for logging purposes to distinguish notable messages with a custom avatar name for that message. Both tools are essential for a server to function properly make for a powerful combination. Summary Thanks to their simplicity accessibility, webhooks have become a staple in many communities. Despite their limitations lack of functions compared to bots, theyare still very useful A play an important role in automation decoration of your server. Overall, webhooks are a great tool for pushing various messages, with limitless customization opportunities. Ultimately, choice of using them depends solely on your needs preferences. Internal Conflict Resolution Causes of Internal Conflicts There can be many causes for conflicts between your moderators, some of which occur more often than others. Some of these can easily be prevented, while others might need a more intentful thought process to stop them from escalating to a conflict. Personality Clashes Differences main reason for conflicts to arise is a difference in personalities amongst your team. Everyone perceives, analyzes responds differently to certain situations. While this should be a learning opportunity for everyone involved, it can lead to arguments when moderators can not get along. While emphasizing there are different approaches to same issue, you should teach moderators to learn from each other instead of disagreements ending in a conflict. When a moderator constantly disagrees with someone else, ends up in a personal argument, try taking them aside let them know that they should be working on their personal issues. You can help them as an objective observer - it can be very valuable to let members of your team know that you understand their individual perspectives are working to balance them. Try to avoid aHalo/Horns effecta as much as possible. This is a type of cognitive bias where your view of someoneas actions can influence how you think feel about that person in general, both positively as well as negatively. Poor Communication Misunderstandings between your moderators can lead to a conflict as well, especially when there is a different understanding of how a situation should be handled. Having transparent, consistent communication where everyone is on same page is very important in an online setting such as Discord. Text is often perceived differently than talking over voice even in person. Oftentimes a language barrier can lead to misinterpreting a message as well. Try to prevent misunderstandings from happening with clear communication when misunderstandings happen, step in where possible explain how situation should be handled. Foster a culture where it is not only allowed but encouraged to ask for clarification on someoneas statement if you have any doubts about what their intent was. Bullying Harassment Making jokes is beneficial for maintaining a healthy welcoming environment even a way to deal with tough situations moderators may face. However, it is important to make sure that jokes donat push boundaries of what is appropriate lead to perceived bullying of server members behind closed doors, even other members of your own team.What is perceived to be a harmless in-joke in context could out of context seem like a malicious unwarranted comment. When it is clear someone is not comfortable with certain jokes feels targeted, you need to step in clear situation by telling moderators involved that you want a positive atmosphere where everyone feels welcomed comfortable while clearly identifying what line was crossed so it does not happen again. Thatas not to say that all close knit groups trend towards exclusionary jokes, but it is something that can happen without a team even being cognizant that itas a problem. Hence why itas pertinent to keep inclusivity good faith intent in mind with situations like this. Unfair Treatment A main cause for conflicts is unfair treatment amongst members of your team. This might be because there is a lack of equal opportunities, because there are unrealistic expectations. Make sure that everyone on your team is treated equally as everyone deserves same treatment, regardless of your personal relationships. This also means you other moderators should have reasonable expectations of each other. Moderators often volunteer to help out in your community, so donat expect them to be available at all times; they might have other responsibilities as well. Any mod teamas north star should be that areal life comes firsta, to be lenient amongst themselves in face of that. Unclear Responsibilities Sometimes it is not clear what responsibilities everyone has on team. This can lead to misunderstandings eventually to conflicts. Make sure everyone on team receives adequate training information on what different roles positions should be doing. You might want to divide different responsibilities amongst members of your team between different roles, such as moderators administrators. Be as transparent clear as possible on what everyone should be doing. Competition Sometimes moderators feel that they are competing against each other, especially if there are statistics promotions available. You should always be clear that moderation is not about competition, it is about helping your community in best way possible. Not every moderator has same time available to help, so naturally there are going to be differences amongst your team. Moderation is not about quantity but quality - if this negatively skewed competitive atmosphere is a frequent issue, it may be worth looking at whether there are mechanisms within your community that encourage competition conflicts that could be removed revised, such as quotas, public moderation statistics, leaderboards. Different Values Standards Moderators usually come from all over world might have different values. Sometimes, these might result in a conflict. Remind your moderators that they should always respect each other's values, regardless of their own opinion. Moderators should be able to explain why they feel a certain way in order for others to be more understanding of situation. When someone has values that do not align with serveras moderation philosophy, you might need to remove them from your team. Unresolved Underlying Issues It is not always possible to immediately see a reason for a conflict, this might be due to unresolved underlying issues. It is very hard to know these without having a conversation with everyone involved. There can be many more causes for a dispute to arise, but it is always important to find underlying issue which causes a conflict, only then are you able to resolve it. Preventing Internal Conflicts To minimize prevent conflicts from happening, try as best as you can to get a comprehensive view of why how conflicts occur in your server. It is very important to develop interpersonal relationships with all of your moderators value their contributions to server. Encourage moderators to take initiative in projects they are enthusiastic about, especially in collaboration with other moderators. Just as moderators set a positive example in your community, you as leader of your moderation team should set a positive example within your team. When you propose major changes to server, listen to your teamas viewpoints before deploying explain why a decision was made. Good communication is very important within a team, not only to prevent conflicts, but also to keep all moderators on same page. All moderators should feel involved informed when you are making major changes. You can give your moderators regular feedback on how they are doing what they can improve. Make sure moderators always feel welcome to provide feedback constructively positively to each other that they can always contact you someone in charge in case a conflict does arise. Try to discourage gossip within your team, both internal external. When moderators start to talk about each other behind their backs, it becomes personal can distort relationship your moderators have how they see themselves within server. Instead, encourage moderators to form friendships with each other by organizing social events for your staff. During those events, you can learn about different personalities in your team. Last, but not least; you shouldnat lash out over mistakes.Give feedback where it is appropriate move on. Be quick to forgive forget. You should always prevent belittling your moderators while also creating a culture of de-escalating situations in private. Resolving an Internal Conflict There are many ways to resolve conflict internally most of these will depend on what cause is for conflict. A good way of resolving conflicts is using Thomas-Kilmann model. It should be stated that conflicts are not necessarily bad shouldnat be avoided at all costs. When you are working in a team, it is important to be able to challenge status quo question each other, to keep everyone on aligned up to date. In Thomas-Kilmann model, there are two dimensions when you are choosing a course of action: assertiveness cooperativeness. Assertiveness is degree to which you try to satisfy your own needs where cooperativeness is degree to which you try satisfy other person's concerns. Based on these dimensions, there are five ways to handle a conflict: All these different ways to handle a conflict are your intention to solve them: Sometimes situations occur differently than you expect at first. Donat jump to conclusions when you are dealing with a conflict, as reasons for conflicts are often more complex than they first appear. A Everyone tends to resolve conflicts in a certain way, so try to balance them so you donat end up overwhelmed overwhelm others. first step is to identify cause for conflict. You might already know this based on previously sent messages, but sometimes you need to contact everyone involved separately in private to determine cause of conflict. It is your responsibility to determine how to handle a situation. While collaborating together to resolve a conflict might look most appealing, this will not always be possible. Try not to completely avoid a conflict: if you feel uneasy dealing with conflicts donat want to give moderators feedback, you might not want to be in a leading position. If you need to resolve a conflict, choose a neutral place to work it out. This might be a separate server a private group. None of people involved in conflict should have power over others, so you someone else should act as an objective observer. If conflict is between other moderators, you should offer guidance, but donat offer solutions: ultimately it is up to others to resolve their conflicts, you are not taking sides. Remember that not all conflicts require consequences. Most conflicts are sparked by passion of your moderators who are simply in disagreement on how to deal with situations. Try to turn a conflict into a learning opportunity for everyone involved. Let them explain how they view situation how they would have handled it behaved differently. Afterwards, you should be able to identify specific disagreements that you can solve. Listen to everyone involved give everyone an equal opportunity to express themselves. Remind everyone to stay respectful at all times, even if they disagree with each other. Giving Receiving Feedback As said before, you should discourage gossip within your team encourage each other to give constructive feedback. It is important that everyone knows how to give receive feedback to prevent a conflict from happening in future situations. Giving Feedback When you notice a moderator that displays behavior takes action that can be improved, you should give them feedback on how to improve this in future. Donat rush in giving your feedback, everyone needs time to process. When a situation becomes heated, it will not be best time to give feedback. Remember to always give feedback in private! If you are in doubt as to whether not you should give feedback, see if you can recognize a pattern in their behavior actions. Everyone makes mistakes that is perfectly fine as mistakes serve as a learning opportunity you should only give them feedback if it becomes a pattern. Additionally, itas recommended that you ask for consent to give feedback. While this may seem a little counterintuitive to helping moderator improve change, blindsiding someone when theyare not ready can result in backlash rather than progress. When you do decide to give someone feedback, donat focus on person who made a mistake: focus on their behavior action instead.By making feedback personal equating it to an issue with individual rather than their choices, you can come off as argumentative unconstructive biased. Never exaggerate their behavior, be sure that you are clear specific . When you make generalized vague comments about someone, they will not be able to improve their behavior. Feedback should be actionable- there should be a suggestion a change that individual can work on as a result of feedback. Otherwise itas just airing your grievances, which is unproductive for all parties involved. next time you see someone doing something good when you have given them feedback in past, give them a compliment! Positive, specific feedback is especially effective in encouraging repeating said good actions. Giving each other positive feedback is just as important as giving each other constructive corrective feedback. Remember to always treat others as you would like to be treated yourself. It is proven that negative feedback is given mostly when people are experiencing negative emotions like hunger, anger, loneliness, tiredness. This negative feedback method is referred to as HALT-mode, it is important to try to avoid situations where you are giving feedback when you find yourself in one of these states. Receiving Feedback When someone is giving you feedback, it is very important to listen to what they have to say. Donat jump to conclusions, react defensively, disagree immediately. Take a moment to summarize feedback as you understand it to make sure you have understood their feedback correctly. You should always thank someone for giving them feedback, even if you disagree. It has to be clear you are welcoming feedback to improve. If you do not thank them, they might not give you valuable feedback in future. Ideally feedback is very clear specific, in which case you can end conversation by thanking them for their feedback reflect back what you are going to do with feedback in future. Other times it might not be understandable to you as a result, it is unclear what you should do differently in future. In this case you should ask questions to understand their feedback better. To have a better understanding of what they want to achieve with their feedback, it is a good idea to ask other person how they would have handled situation how they would have behaved. After this you should thank them reflect back on what you are going to do with their feedback. It is okay to let someone know why you disagree with their feedback, but remember to stay respectful at all times explain clearly why you disagree. Everyone should feel heard, even if you are not acting on their feedback. Handling Demotions There are many reasons why you might want to remove a moderator from your team, including internal conflicts you are unable to resolve. Removing demoting a moderator is not easy to do, but can be a necessary evil. Removing someone from your team should be in best interest of your community team can often be in best interest of that person as well. Be sure to give someone an opportunity to learn from their mistakes before removing them. Give a warning first have a conversation in private with them, following principles of giving receiving feedback outlined above. While it is not easy to deliver bad news, here are some tips to keep in mind when you do want to remove someone from your team. Donat delay conversation Once you have made decision to remove someone from your team, donat hesitate wait for conversation to take place. When someone is causing more issues than they are solving, they will need to be removed sooner than later, but make sure that someone has had enough opportunities to fix their mistakes resolve their issues. Please make sure you have this conversation in private, for example in direct messages a voice call. Keep it short clear When you are talking to someone you are removing, it is important to keep your message short clear. Tell them they are being removed from team, why you have made this decision, when this will take effect. Be transparent in what reasons you have for removing them, but do not go into too much detail with specific examples. This may result in a conversation where you are arguing about these examples rather than informing them of their removal. A Youare aiming for polite dismissal, not a lambasting of their character. Stick to your decision Despite your message being short, clear, transparent, you might still receive counter arguments as to why they should not be removed to give them another chance. It is important they can express themselves, but it should be clear at all times that decision to remove them has already been made is not up for debate. Always listen carefully to what someone has to say appreciate their feedback, but unless someone has substantial evidence a mistake was made, repeat your decision make it clear that your decision is final. Be helpful compassionate Even though you are delivering bad news, you should take a supportive approach in conversation. Remember that while it might be difficult for you to deliver bad news, it most definitely is difficult to be on receiving end. Show empathy for them especially when they have done a good job in past. In some cases, moderator youare removing may wish to receive feedback on what they can improve - giving this feedback in a constructive fashion is important, will help them to avoid future problems. This feedback should include reflecting on positive contributions they made to team, helping them understand what causes of conflict might have been while they were on your team, simply trying to give them something positive to take forward work on as a result of your conversation. This conversation shouldnat reflect a reversal of your decision, but can be a useful point of reference if they want to join other servers work on improving their skills down line, perhaps even re-apply to join team in future. Inform your team When someone has been removed from your team, make sure to inform team of this decision. It is up to you whether not you want to share reason for their removal, but refrain from sharing details as these are confidential, especially when these could be potentially harmful to someone. You also want to prevent anyone, including yourself, from talking bad about them, as this sets a wrong precedent for your team. As with your decision, you should be straightforward clear to your team, an example of this could be: aToday we have decided to remove Sarah from our team. I will not go into too much detail why this decision was made, but we believe it is best decision for community entire team.a In case someone was removed because of misbehavior, you might want to include that in message, as this gives team assurance you are not removing someone because of a personal conflict, it shows a strong message about how you want moderators to conduct themselves. Wrapping Up In every group, eventually a conflict dispute will arise which needs to be resolved. There are common causes, such as personality clashes differences, poor communication, unclear responsibilities, harassment. To minimize prevent conflicts from happening, try understand as much as possible why conflicts occur in your server. It is very important to develop interpersonal relationships with all of your moderators value their contributions to server. Try to discourage gossip within your team. When moderators start to talk about each other behind their backs, it becomes personal can distort relationship your moderators have how they see themselves within server. You can resolve conflicts using Thomas-Kilmann model. It is important to know conflicts are not necessarily bad shouldnat be avoided at all costs. When you are working in a team, it is important to be able to challenge status quo question each other, to keep everyone on same page sharp. When you want to give feedback to someone, talk to them in private be clear specific. Prevent giving feedback when you feel hungry, angry, lonely, tired. Focus on their behavior action instead never exaggerate their behavior. Oppositely, when someone is giving you feedback, it is very important to listen to what they have to say to avoid jumping to conclusions, reacting defensively, disagreeing immediately. Take a moment to summarize feedback to make sure you have understood their feedback correctly. Sometimes you need to remove someone from your staff team. Donat delay this conversation, keep it short clear, stick to your decision. When conversation is taking place, be helpful compassionate do not forget to inform your team as well, but make it clear that certain things remain private for safety privacy of those involved. Keeping all of those points in mind when managing a team environment will be integral to maintaining a healthy atmosphere full of various viewpoints that are united in shared desire to keep your community safe. Using Modmail Bots What are Modmail Bots? Before we discuss how to use a modmail bot, we should explore what they are what purpose they serve. Simply put, modmail bots are bots that allow users to contact moderators of a server via a direct message with bot. bot then relays these messages to entire moderation team by creating a private channel on server visible only to server moderators (also referred to as a aticketa). Moderators can then use this private channel to have bot relay their own messages back to original user, all while keeping a record of entire conversation within server. Moderators can even discuss ticket together in that channel without user seeing since it requires usage of a specific command to send a message to user. There are numerous modmail bots online, each with their own styles features. Some modmail bots can be self-hosted, while others are hosted publicly online! Here are some examples of modmail bots you can use: a It is important to do research into readily available bots to understand what your server needs to choose whichever one best meets those needs. Please note, content of this article is not endorsed by any developer company related to bots. What Can Modmail Contribute to my Server? Before adding a modmail bot into your server, you should determine if you need one by considering benefits drawbacks of modmail bots. Letas review pros cons of modmail bots to help with this decision. One of biggest benefits of having a modmail bot is better organization. Anytime a user opens a ticket, be it a question concern about server, instead of trying to figure out which moderator is online available, a user can quickly DM modmail bot get in contact with entire moderation team while also notifying active moderators online. This also eliminates over usage of pinging entire moderation team in public channels. a next benefit of modmail bots is team discussions. In above example, weare using ModMail bot by CHamburr. As you can see, a user has opened up a ticket that can be viewed by entire moderation team. team can then decide who wants to respond to ticket, as well as discuss ticket in question among themselves more efficiently handle issue. Team discussions are great for trickier questions that not everyone on team might know answer to. In image below, you can see an example of what moderators see from their side. team can split their focus knock out tickets depending on their priority, urgency, even work together to pick up a ticket if another mod has signed off. ability to read through moderator discussions work together is a great team building exercise for moderator teams! a a next benefit of modmail bots are information logs. Most modmail bots have a modmail log that shows all of modmail tickets that have been opened closed along with useful receipts of conversations that happened in channels. This is great for administrators/lead moderators who want to see how cases were handled want to catch up on what theyave missed while offline. This also helps moderators look back on reporting history if an old report is continued at a different period of time if they suspect someone is abusing modmail. Another benefit of having a modmail bot is anonymity. Some modmail bots allow you to reply to user anonymously which can decrease chances of someone harassing a moderator, other unpleasant situations that may come from having to action someone. Users can sometimes get upset want to seek revenge after being banned, muted, kicked from a server, so being able to communicate with someone action them without revealing your identity is extremely valuable. Moderators no longer need to act as amiddlemana between a user rest of team. moderator can speak on behalf of team use language such as awea instead of aIa which can communicate to user that it isnat just one person handling their case, but rather entire team while keeping their identity safe. a a Something that you will notice when moderating is that there are usually some questions concerns that come up frequently. Having a modmail bot can help you better understand what your community needs are better visualize what most frequent moderator tickets are about. With this knowledge, you can create custom quick-replies that you your team can use to more efficiently resolve tickets! Having same response to a scam DM that is used by all moderators on your server makes responding to those types of tickets quick, easy, consistent. Moderators can copy paste replies, use custom commands to reply with pre-made messages. Once you have set up quick replies, you can answer many tickets without needing to think of how to reply, making your replies consistent no matter who is responding to a ticket. Here are a few examples of situations you can make tailored custom-replies for ease, speed, consistency: It is important to know limitations drawbacks of modmail bots before deciding if your community needs one. Letas explore some of ways these bots can be abused, as well as other negatives you should know about. Please keep in mind that every modmail bot is different, so you can work to choose, even code, a modmail bot that may eliminate some of these drawbacks if you are concerned about them. Modmail bots are vulnerable to spam since anyone on server can DM bot to open up a ticket. Be it a targeted spam attack multiple users reporting same thing. Some modmail bots allow you to block a member from opening up future tickets. Depending on what kind of modmail bot you use, one drawback is that some modmail bots might not save conversations between you user who made ticket, only showing reason ticket was closed. Some modmail bots will save conversation, but not any comments made by other moderators regarding inquiry inside ticket channel which can erase a lot of discussion context from replies that are made. If you want to be able to track actions, you have to prioritize a bot that does save information logs. Another drawback is learning curve from using a new bot. Members that are new to Discord that arenat familiar with modmail bots can have trouble interacting using bot to report issues. Almost all modmail bots require a user to DM bot, which can go against initial instincts be challenging to new users. Some users have their DMs turned off which makes using a modmail bot more complicated if user canat receive DM replies from bot. One solution to this is to ping user in a public channel asking for them to change their DM settings so bot can communicate with them.Members figuring out a modmail bot for first time can lead to atesta messages which will spam your modmail tickets. While these arenat a big concern are mostly harmless, depending on size of your server, multiple users atestinga how bot works can lead to a lot of time cleaning up tickets. Similarly to how a modmail bot can be a learning curve for your members, a modmail bot can also be a learning curve for your moderation team. Learning how a modmail bot works can take some time to get used to if your team has never used one before. Depending on how familiar your team is with using bots, onboarding time may vary, so be sure to set aside time for learning teaching how to use a modmail bot. We have an article on Training Onboarding New Moderators that should help with this! Uses for Modmail Bots Modmail bots can be used in a variety of ways. They not only serve as a way to communicate with moderators, but also help with organization structure can be used for other purposes. Letas look at different uses of a modmail bot, how it can make life on server easier. aQuestions. Modmail bots help users who might have questions that they donat feel comfortable asking in public. This can be questions related to server, more private sensitive matters. By using a modmail bot, moderation team can efficiently answer question depending on who knows answer, user gets a sense of privacy by not having to ask in public. As mentioned previously, having a set of quick-replies to frequently asked questions makes responding to questions a breeze. Some modmail bots even have custom command replies where you can create commands to reply with a specific text, depending on command. For example, replying with command a=helloa can reply to ticket with a premade message meant to greet user open a conversation, such as: aHello. Thank you for contacting moderation team. How can we help you today?a aBug Reports. You can implement a modmail bot in a support server that deals with bug reports. Some larger communities have two serversaone for main community, one for support, depending on community product. Organizing bug reports using a modmail bot is an easy way to keep track of issues in one place. With ability to give a closing reason, you can later search modmail logs to look back at what sort of bugs were reported by different users. aBan Appeals. Anonymity is important when dealing with troublemakers online. One way to use a modmail bot is to have a ban appeal server for users who would like to re-enter your community after being banned. With this setup appeals go through modmail system so that banned users canat talk in any channels can only interact with staff team through bot. Moderators can then review appeal together reply to banned user anonymously through bot. Community Reports. Sometimes a member of your community needs to report something to moderators that isnat rule breaking has information regarding another user that is important for team to know. A modmail bot is great for relaying these types of reports to team so everyone is notified at same time without having to utilize an emergency ping. Server Feedback. Members of your server can provide feedback using a modmail bot. Using modmail for feedback removes need for a feedback channel guarantees that team will see feedback when it is sent. Staff Applications. There are different ways you can have staff applications for a server. Depending on who needs to see evaluate application, it can make sense to use a modmail bot to receive server staff applications in smaller arenas. When an application is made, a modmail ticket will open conveniently for moderators admins to look at. You can even comment within ticket to evaluate each application, case by case! Keep in mind that there are a limited number of channels (in this case, tickets) that can be made in a channel category so this will only work for smaller servers.The above list are just some of many common ways that modmail bots can be used to strengthen communication with your server. use cases for a modmail bot is limited only by your imagination type of bot youare using! Modmail Best Practices When using a modmail bot, it is important that your moderation team is on same page. Make sure there are clear protocols of how to handle tickets. An easy way to ensure that end-user doesnat get messages sent by multiple moderators is to have a moderator say that they will handle ticket inside ticket channel itself. This way, moderators arenat stepping on each otheras toes ticket can be handled efficiently. In image below, weare using a modmail bot that sends all messages sent in ticket to user, unless it has a specific command. Other modmail bots might only send a message to user if a reply command is used, so be sure to read bot documentation to know how your modmail bot handles communication between moderators user sending a ticket. a a Another good practice is to close any old resolved tickets as quickly as possible. If user has no further questions, it can be helpful to send a final message stating that if there are no further questions, ticket will be closed soon. This way, you reduce amount of open tickets maintain a clean organized modmail.As mentioned before, anonymity in responding to tickets can help reduce amount of harassment you your moderators may receive from rule-breakers. When using a modmail bot you can use discretion when deciding whether to respond anonymously with a more personalized response, depending on situation. Here are a few scenarios where itas okay to respond regularly: In most cases, however, it is better to respond anonymously especially when dealing with any modmail tickets related to actioning punishing another user. This applies to handling ban appeals if you have such a system set up. It isnat a big deal if you reply to a question without showing your name. same is not true if you show your name to someone who has been punished on your server.Each server has its own tone style when it comes to moderation. Some servers are more formal may have an official tone, while others might have a more relaxed easygoing tone. It is important to keep this in mind when responding to modmail tickets so that your tone in modmail responses is consistent with tone set by server. This article has explored ways modmail bots can strengthen how your team communicates with your community as well as direct advantages disadvantages that exist when introducing such a bot to your server. In some ways moderation becomes significantly easier, but in other ways, negatives like spam from these bots can be overwhelming introduce new problems to solve. Moderating a server can involve a lot of different moving parts it is important to analyze your communityas needs as it grows, taking into consideration whether a modmail bot is included in that growth. Use what youave learned in this article to make a decision thatas right for you your community.If you decide that a modmail bot isnat a good fit for your community, but you still want some bot help on your server, check out our Auto Moderation on Discord article! Managing Moderation Teams Getting to Know Your Team Above all else, foundation of a good moderation team is familiarity. By knowing your fellow moderators better, what they do, where they live, youall relate to them better. Youall get to know peopleas strengths weaknesses, learn to understand them better, get a feeling for when they need help, vice versa. Though you all may be in different time zones have diverse backgrounds youare all working towards same goal which is keeping community you all care for safe. Who knows- you might find that you share a lot of same interests along way, make great new friends, deepen existing friendships during your time together as moderators. Here are a few basic things you should do to familiarize with each other: Allocating Resources A moderation team needs a clear structure a unified understanding of server moderation, which has already been covered in Developing moderator guidelines. Now weare going to expand on how to utilize each every single moderator's abilities further. A moderation team can range from a few members in a small server to a huge team with 30 more staff depending on server size. bigger your community gets more team needs to be organized. While they are all moderators, it doesnat mean they all do same job. Some of your moderators, especially experienced moderators, are likely to be in more administrative positions. They usually stay further away from general day-to-day channel moderation while newer moderators are focused on watching conversations enforcing server rules. If you do have one of these larger mod teams, consider delegating certain moderators to tasks responsibilities that theyad be best suited for, rather than having a jack of all trades, master of none situation. This allows to divide team into smaller sub-teams that talk to each other more frequently in designated channels regarding their specific mod duties. Here are a few examples of sub-teams that are common within larger communities: Moderators that primarily contribute to community by enforcing rules, watching conversations, engaging members, solving member to member conflicts showing moderation presence. same type of moderators could also exist for Voice Channels, but that is mostly for very large communities. Moderators that are extremely familiar with permissions, bots, programming, etc. Ideally, they arenat just able to operate bots youare using, but also maintain them. A custom bot tailored to your community is always something to consider. Having a bot hosted ain-housea by a moderator within your team adds an additional layer of security. Bot Team is very valuable in making new creative ideas possible especially in automating day-to-day processes. Most servers host events, from community run events to events run by staff members. Event Supervisors watch over community members hosting events, watching out for new events, while being general point of communication in hosting announcing them. These are ways of how moderators can be utilized better by giving them a designated job depending on your team's size, also giving them ability to dive into certain topics of moderation more in-depth within your community, which overall makes managing coordinating a team as a whole easier. Decision Making As server size number of moderators increases, harder it becomes to hear every voice opinion. As a team, decisions need to be made together, they need to be consistent, equitable, take into account as many different opinions as possible. Itas important to establish a system, especially when making big decisions. Often, there are decisions that need to be done right at very moment. For example, when someone posts offensive content. In most cases, a moderator will act on their perception of rules punish offenders accordingly. At that very moment, offending content has to be removed, leaving little to no time to gather a few staff members make a decision together. This is where consistency comes into play. more your moderators share equal knowledge same mindset, more consistent moderation actions get. This is why itas important to have moderator guidelines a clear structure. Itas very important to give every moderator freedom so they donat have to ask every time before they can take action, but itas also important to hear out as many opinions on any major server changes as possible, if time allows it. Growth Over time, a moderation team grows. They grow in many ways, in their abilities, in number of moderators, but also grow together as a team. Every new moderation team will face challenges they need to overcome together every already established team will face new situations that they have to adapt to deal with. Itas important to give a moderator something to work towards. Mods should look forward to opportunities that will strengthen their capabilities as a moderator strengthen teamas performance as a whole. You should let moderators know that they have potential for growth in their future as a moderator. It can be something like specializing into specific topics of moderation, like introducing them into managing setting up bots. Perhaps over time they will progress to a senior moderator focus more on administrative side of things. Discord Mod Academy can be a valuable resource in encouraging moderator growth as well. While they may be familiar with some of concepts in Discord Moderation Academy, no moderator can know everything these articles have potential to further refine their moderation knowledge enhance their abilities. Professionalism Moderators are direct representatives of your community as such should be a reflection of what an ideal community member looks like. Many things tie into showing this professionalism, ranging from how moderators chat with members in public to consistency in moderator actions. presence of a moderator should never make people uncomfortable - there needs to be a fine line between aI can chat with this moderator like with any other membera aThis is a moderator I need to take what they're saying seriouslya. Here are a few attributes in what makes a moderation team look be professional: Your team should share positivity, engage conversation, show respect for others maintain a professional look. Make it clear to your moderation team that they are a highly visible perhaps incredibly scrutinized group within your community- to conduct themselves appropriately with those aspects in mind. Problem Solving As with all group efforts, there is a possibility for friction to occur within a moderation team. This is undoubtedly something that youare all going to have to address at some point in your mod teamas lifespan. Itas very important to deal with these situations as soon as they come up. Many people don't feel comfortable dealing with conflict directly as it can be uncomfortable. However, getting to any potential problems before they become serious can prevent more severe issues from cropping up in future. goal of a problem-solving process is to make a moderation team more conflict-friendly. As a general problem solving process, you should: With that in mind, there are also situations where youad want to exercise more discretion. Something that might prompt this is when a moderator makes a mistake. It can be both uncomfortable embarrassing to be acalled outa for something, so often enough best option is to speak to someone privately if you think theyave made a mistake. After moderator understands situation acknowledges mistake, problem can be talked about with rest of team, mainly to prevent situations like these in future.
