About Discord Discord is a voice, video, text communication app used by over two hundred million people to hang out play games with their friends. Discord Story Discord was made to solve one problem: how to easily talk with friends while playing online games together. But much like protagonists of our favorite game stories, all journeys have their humble beginningsa April 2012 Jason Citron establishes a new studio, Phoenix Guild, to help bring people together around games. Jason soon starts work on studioas first project, Fates Forever, a MOBA built specifically for mobile.A A APRIL 2013 Stanislav Vishnevskiy joins Jason as they continue working together on their upcoming mobile game. Summer 2014 Phoenix Guild, now named Hammer & Chisel, launches Fates Forever to critical acclaim. Some of gameas features, such as built-in voice chat, text chat forums, help lay groundwork for whatas nexta May 2015 Jason & Stan loved playing games but couldnat find a reliable way to talk while playing online. Utilizing what they learned from building Fates Forever, two release first version of a new project: a gaming-focused chat app for desktop mobile called "Discord." Spring 2016 Discord launches an in-game overlay for PC, letting players interact with their friends without leaving their game, adds a friends list to let people talk outside of servers. Discordas official API launches for first time, eventually powering hundreds of thousands of apps. Summer 2016 Discord brings power to voice call friends directly in DMs Group DMs, unleashes to world one of its most popular features of all time: ability to upload use custom emoji in servers. Early 2017 Discord introduces Discord Nitro, letting people support Discord get some slick perks in return, including power to use a serveras custom emoji anywhere set an animated avatar. Fall 2017 Discord, after long-awaited excitement hype, releases video chat screen share features to all users in DMs Group DMs. Discordas Rich Presence API releases, letting players display what theyare doing in-game, directly on Discord. Summer 2019 Discord releases Go Live, letting players stream their favorite games to their server friends in just a few clicks. Plus, Server Boosting lets members come together to help unlock extra perks for their community. Spring 2021 Discord teams up with PlayStation for account linking support, allowing people on Discord to show off what theyare playing on their PlayStation 5 console. Spring 2023 Discord introduces voice chat support for PS5 consoles reveals Activities, a way to play games directly in Discord. Plus, two audio-centric features are released: Soundboard, letting users play sound clips during voice calls, power to send Voice Messages from mobile devices. Spring 2024 Discord doubles-down on its mission to be best place to hang out before, during, after playing games. Soon after, App Launcher releases, letting people enjoy their favorite Activities anywhere on Discord. Winter 2024 Discord starts powering in-game text voice chat of games directly, with two games being first to support Discord chat: Pax Dei Omega Strikers. 2025 on... Weare continuing to make Discord best, most reliable platform to talk play for players on PC, mobile, console. Perhaps some intergalactic domination on side, who knows? In Numbers Global Monthly Active Users Hours of Gaming of Users Play Games Our founders Jason Citron, CEO Stanislav Vishnevskiy, CTO Hear FROM OUR FOUNDERS Check out some recent interviews that feature Jason Stan. How Discord Became a Developer Platform Jason Citron alongside Anjney Midha shares insights on shift from gamer to developer more. a16z Podcast Case for a Smaller, More Private Internet For teens gamers, Discord has become their entire online social lives. Co-founder Jason Citron thinks internet is headed more in that direction. Verge Creating a 'Third Space' for Togetherness James Vincent talks with Jason Citron about safety, togetherness, how we can use good AI to battle bad AI. Fast Company: Leaders in Innovation How I Built this with Guy Raz Jason Citron Guy Raz talk about Jason's early career how Discord grew to become platform it is today. How I Built this with Guy Raz Our office Shape Future of Gaming withA us Weare building Discord to be perfect place to talk while playing games on any platform, no matter what device you play on.

Discord Privacy Policy Welcome! This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, store, protect, share your personal information through our services. If you reside in European Economic Area (aEEAa) United Kingdom, Discord Netherlands BV is adata controllera of your personal information collected through services (as defined in our Terms of Service). For everyone else, Discord Inc. is data controller. Itas important that you read this entire policy, but hereas a summary to get you started: Discord is best place to talk, hang out have fun with friends online We created Discord to be best place to talk, hang out have fun with friends online. Whether youare part of a club, gaming group, just a handful of friends that want to spend time together, Discord makes it easy to connect with friends. Our aservicesa has same meaning as defined in Terms of Service. They include Discord app, which can be accessed on mobile, web, desktop, console, even a connected home applianceaany device with a web browser internet connection. We also have a website, blog, support center, we may collect your information through other means like surveys, emails, social media. If we build another product, our services include that too. As explained in our Terms of Service, we allow users to add content to services in a number of different ways, including via direct messages in smaller larger spaces. If you share content within larger spaces, that content may be accessed by many people, including people you do not know. For example, some servers are available in Server Discovery section of app do not require an invite link to join. Other server owners may publish their server invite link on public websites. Anyone can access these servers, you should be aware that server owners admins set these permissions, like size of a server, permissions may change over time. We may also use content posted in larger spaces to help us develop, improve power our services, including features that help you catch up on conversations safety features that identify harmful content on services support enforcement of our Terms of Service Community Guidelines. These things are important to us, we believe they will make Discord even better for our users. We will always try to let you know type of space you are in (although we donat control where invite links are shared permissions for that server). You can limit extent to which your content is used for these purposes as described in aHow to control your privacya section below. You can learn more about our approach to safety content moderation, including how we use your information for these purposes, in our Safety Center. You should take all of this into account when you are using our services, choose spaces, features, settings that are most appropriate for your content. We make money from paid subscriptions sale of digital (and sometimes physical) goods, not from selling your personal information to third parties. information we collect We collect certain information when you use Discord. This includes information you provide to us, information we collect automatically, information we receive from other sources. We also collect information automatically from you when you use Discord. This includes: We may receive information from cookies (small text files placed on your computer device) similar technologies. You can find out more about Discordas cookie usage how you can manage your cookie permissions in our Cookie Policy. We may receive information about you from other sources, including from other users third parties, combine that information with other information we have about you. For example, if you interact with our social media account on another platform, we may receive certain information about you like your username on that platform. How we use your information Under certain data protection laws like GDPR, companies must have a alegal basisaaa valid reasonato process personal information. Discord relies on different legal bases to process your information for purposes described in this Privacy Policy. We use Information We CollectaAccount information, Content you create, Payment information, Information from actions you take, Information used to enable optional features, Other information you provide directly to us, Information about your device, Information about your use of apps websites, other information that we collect automatically, Information we receive from other sourcesafor following reasons according to these legal bases. For each reason, we describe why we process your information how we process your information to achieve each purpose. aTo fulfill our contract with you For our legitimate business interests To comply with our legal obligations We retain use your information in connection with potential legal claims when necessary for compliance, regulatory, auditing purposes. For example, we retain information where we are required by law if we are compelled to do so by a court order regulatory body. Also, when you exercise any of your applicable legal rights to access, amend, delete your personal information, we may request additional information from you for purpose of confirming your identity. aWith your consent aWe may also collect use personal information with your consent, such as to send you marketing communications where legally required. You can revoke your consent at any time (mostly through our services directly), though note that you might not be able to use any service feature that requires collection use of that personal information. aTo protect someoneas vital interests We may collect share personal data if we think someoneas life is in dangerafor example, to help resolve an urgent medical situation. How we disclose your information Data retention We retain personal information until we determine it is no longer needed for processing purposes for which we collected retain it for legal compliance. You can learn more about data retention periods in our data retention policy. How we protect your information We take a number of steps to help protect your information. All information sent within our services is encrypted both in transit at rest. For example, we use Transport Layer Security (aTLSa) to encrypt text images in transit. We also enforce technical administrative access controls to limit which of our employees contractors have access to nonpublic personal information. You can help maintain security of your account by configuring two-factor authentication. How to control your privacy We believe that users should be able to tailor their Discord experience to their preferences, including privacy. while local laws may require different things, we believe that our users should have at least same basic ability to shape their experience no matter where they are in world. Hereas how you can control how we process your information, how to delete correct certain information, how to request access to your information. Users in certain places may have specific rights under their local laws. You can learn more about these in relevant sections below. aBe aware of Discord spaces you choose to participate in You can choose what spaces to participate in what information you add to our services. You can choose what messages to send post, who to engage with (e.g., one more particular users a potentially unlimited group of users), what information to include in your profile, whether to connect any third party services to your Discord account, more. For example, if you share content in certain spaces, such as servers listed in Server Discovery with public invite links, your content may be accessed by anyone.A aCustomize your personal Discord settings We offer a number of settings that allow you to tailor your experience within Discord. Some of these relate to specific features: for example, you can choose whether to display your current activity (like game you are playing music you are listening to) in your status in your User Settings page (this is gear icon next to your username). You can also access other privacy-related settings in your User Settings. For example, you can decide whether to filter potentially explicit content, who can add you as a friend, more. This is also where you can limit certain types of processing of your information: You can learn more about these other privacy-related settings in our Help Center. default availability of some of these settings may be different depending on factors like your age location. Disable delete your account You can disable delete your account via User Settings menu. Disabling your account stops processing of new data, but allows you to reactivate your account without interruption to you. Deleting your account permanently deletes identifying information anonymizes other data as described in our data retention policy. You can learn more about how to delete your account in this Help Center article how to disable your account in this Help Center article. Manage your content servers You may edit delete specific pieces of information within services: Content may be retained by Discord for use as described elsewhere in this policy in our data retention policy. Also, in limited circumstances, we may have a legal obligation to retain certain information, even if you delete information your account. Access your information If you want to see what information we have collected about you, you can request a copy of your data in Privacy & Safety section of your User Settings. You should receive your data packet within 30 days. Data is delivered in common digital formats including CSV, JSON, any other file format you used when uploading attachments to services. You can learn more about how to access your information in our Help Center. International data transfers We are based in United States, we process store information on servers located in United States. We may also store information on servers equipment in other countries depending on a variety of factors, including locations of our users service providers. These data transfers allow us to provide our services to you. By accessing using our services otherwise providing information to us, you understand that your information will be processed, transferred, stored in U.S. other countries, where different data protection standards may apply and/or you may not have same rights as you do under local law. When transferring data outside EEA, we use standard contract clauses (Module 1 Module 2), we rely on European Commission's adequacy decisions about certain countries, as applicable, other legally compliant mechanisms conditions for such data transfer. Discord its U.S. entities/subsidiaries (Backgammon Merger Sub II, LLC, Brazos Games, LLC, Discord International, Inc, Flames Sub LLC, Sentropy Technologies Inc.) also comply with EU-U.S. Swiss-U.S. Data Privacy Frameworks, as well as UK Extension to EU-U.S. Data Privacy Framework. If you have questions complaints regarding our compliance with Data Privacy Framework principles, please reach out to us at privacy@discord.com. If we do not resolve your complaint, you may submit your complaint free of charge to JAMS. Under certain conditions specified by Data Privacy Framework principles, you may also be able to invoke binding arbitration to resolve your complaint. We are subject to investigatory enforcement powers of U.S. Federal Trade Commission. In certain circumstances, we may be liable for transfer of personal data from EU, Switzerland, UK to a third party outside those countries. If there is any conflict between terms in our privacy policy EU-U.S. DPF Principles and/or Swiss-U.S. DPF Principles, Principles shall govern. For more information about Data Privacy Framework principles to view our certification, please visit U.S. Department of Commerceas Data Privacy Framework site. Services offered by third parties We allow third party developers to build certain features other services offer them within Discord services. For example, server administrators can add abotsa created by third party developers that provide features like content moderation interactive games. Similarly, you may have access to games activities built by third parties within services. These third-party services need to follow all policies that apply to them (including often our Developer Terms of Service Developer Policy). As part of these policies, we require developers to have a privacy policy that makes clear what they do with your information. Please review these privacy policies, as they describe what bots apps may do with your information. We also require that certain popular bots apply for access to certain data. But because these services are operated by third parties, we donat control them what information they collect. Itas up to you whether to participate in a server that uses bots, whether to engage with third-party services in general. Data Protection Officer You can contact Discord Netherlands BVas Data Protection Officer at dpo@discord.com. Weave appointed VeraSafe as Discordas representative in United Kingdom for data protection matters, pursuant to Article 27 of UK General Data Protection Regulation. See section aContact Usa below. You can contact VeraSafe only on matters related to processing of personal data. Information about local privacy laws Certain local laws, such as European Unionas General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), Brazilas Lei Geral de ProteAAo de Dados (LGPD), Californiaas Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), require services to provide information about information they collect, how they use it, lawful basis for processing it. Weave described most of that already in earlier portions of this Policy, but you can find state region specific information disclosures here. aExercising your rights: As described in aHow to control your privacya section above, all our users have control over their information can directly edit delete information from their account limit what data we process. If you are located in certain regions, including European Union, you may have additional rights such as those listed below, as outlined in state region specific information disclosures that you can exercise through Discord app directly by contacting us: If you have any questions about these rights wish to exercise control over your information, please reach out to privacy@discord.com. Changes to this Privacy Policy We will update this Privacy Policy from time to time. We always indicate date last changes were published, if changes are significant, weall provide a more prominent notice as required by law, such as by emailing you highlighting changes within services. Contact us Email us at privacy@discord.com with any questions about this Privacy Policy how we process your information. Weall be happy to help. To contact Discordas Data Protection Officer, please email dpo@discord.com. You can also reach us by mail if you want. If you reside in EEA United Kingdom, you can contact us at:A Discord Netherlands BVA ATTN: Privacy PolicyA Schiphol Boulevard 195 1118 BG Schiphol, Netherlands If you reside anywhere else, you can contact us at:A Discord Inc.A ATTN: Privacy PolicyA 444 De Haro Street #200A San Francisco, CA 94107, USA. If you reside in United Kingdom, you can also contact VeraSafe, Discordas appointed representative for data protection matters related to processing of personal data, using this contact form: https://verasafe.com/public-resources/contact-data-protection-representative via telephone at +420 228 881 031. VeraSafeas mailing address is: VeraSafe United Kingdom Ltd.A 37 Albert EmbankmentA London SE1 7TL United Kingdom

All code authors, representatives of companies they work for, have signed affidavits dedicating their contributions to public domain originals of those signed affidavits are stored in a firesafe at main offices of Hwaci. Anyone is free to copy, modify, publish, use, compile, sell, distribute original SQLite code, either in source code form as a compiled binary, for any purpose, commercial non-commercial, by any means. previous paragraph applies to deliverable code documentation in SQLite - those parts of SQLite library that you actually bundle ship with a larger application. Some scripts used as part of build process (for example "configure" scripts generated by autoconf) might fall under other open-source licenses. Nothing from these build scripts ever reaches final deliverable SQLite library, however, so licenses associated with those scripts should not be a factor in assessing your rights to copy use SQLite library. All of deliverable code in SQLite has been written from scratch. No code has been taken from other projects from open internet. Every line of code can be traced back to its original author, all of those authors have public domain dedications on file. So SQLite code base is clean is uncontaminated with licensed code from other projects. Open-Source, not Open-Contribution SQLite is open-source, meaning that you can make as many copies of it as you want do whatever you want with those copies, without limitation. But SQLite is not open-contribution. project does not accept patches. Only 27 individuals have ever contributed any code to SQLite, of those only 16 still have traces in latest release. Only 3 developers have contributed non-comment changes within previous five years 96.4% of latest release code was written by just two people. (The statistics in this paragraph were gathered on 2018-02-05.) Furthermore, all of code in SQLite is original, having been written specifically for use by SQLite. No code has been copied from unknown sources on internet. Many people associated "open-source" software with software that has grown organically through contributions from countless individuals. And, indeed, there is some open-source software that works that way. But not SQLite. SQLite uses cathedral development philosopy not bazaar approach. All of SQLite code has been written by people who are well known to each other. Warranty of Title SQLite is in public domain does not require a license. Even so, some organizations want legal proof of their right to use SQLite. Circumstances where this occurs include following: Your company desires indemnity against claims of copyright infringement. You are using SQLite in a jurisdiction that does not recognize public domain. You are using SQLite in a jurisdiction that does not recognize right of an author to dedicate their work to public domain. You want to hold a tangible legal document as evidence that you have legal right to use distribute SQLite. Your legal department tells you that you have to purchase a license. If any of above circumstances apply to you, Hwaci, company that employs all developers of SQLite, will sell you a Warranty of Title for SQLite. A Warranty of Title is a legal document that asserts that claimed authors of SQLite are true authors, that authors have legal right to dedicate SQLite to public domain, that Hwaci will vigorously defend against challenges to those claims. All proceeds from sale of SQLite Warranties of Title are used to fund continuing improvement support of SQLite. Contributed Code In order to keep SQLite completely free unencumbered by copyright, project does not accept patches. If you would like to make a suggested change, include a patch as a proof-of-concept, that would be great. However please do not be offended if we rewrite your patch from scratch. pugixml This library is available to anybody free of charge, under terms of MIT License: Copyright (c) 2006-2018 Arseny Kapoulkine Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy of this software associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal in Software without restriction, including without limitation rights to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell copies of Software, to permit persons to whom Software is furnished to do so, subject to following conditions: above copyright notice this permission notice shall be included in all copies substantial portions of Software. QUESTS NOOB GUIDE ins outs to Quests everything in between. Quests are our new ad format designed to engage players on Discord. Players can earn rewards like in-game items Discord avatar decorations by completing Quest requirements, which may include watching a video, playing streaming a game on Discord for a specific amount of time. With Quests, players can discover exciting new games content, get rewarded for engaging. Quests appear natively across Discord on multiple surfaces. Most users will find Quests through Quest Bar, which appears at top of user activity console at bottom of mobile app. Quests also appear in social activity panels if a friend is participating in a Quest. Finally, all ongoing Quests can be found in Quests Home, located in Discover section. Quests can be launched in all regions where Discord is available around world. You can tailor your audience to specific countries based on your campaign goals. We currently have 2 Quests formats: Video Quests: Users must watch a video in order to unlock a reward. Video Quests are 100% viewable, are ideal for trailers, a new season launch, product video, anything in-between. Play Quests: Designed to get players back into your game, playing for first time. We'll show your ad to former prospective players, they'll be rewarded for playing. Quest rewards are incentives given to Discord players upon completing a Quest. These rewards can include valuable in-game items items from Discord Shop, such as Avatar Decorations. Our Sales team will advise advertisers on most effective type of reward for their campaign goals. All active Quests can be found on Quest Home (Discover > Quests). Our Sales team can discuss Quest campaign costs with you, price will depend on variables like campaign reach, geographies, more. You can get in touch with our team by completing this form. At moment, weare focusing on customers in Gaming Media & Entertainment industries. Sign up for updates to stay informed as we evolve expand our offerings to more industries companies. QUESTS SUCCESS STORIES LAUNCH YOUR QUEST

Discord parent hub Learn more about what weare doing to help your teen stay safer on our platform, explore our Family Center tool, download our Parent's Guide to Discord. A Guardianas Guide to Discord If youare a parent guardian seeking a Discord overview, youare in luck! Guardianas Guide is a centralized asset that helps adults who are raising teens understand latest highlights of how Discord works, information on how their teen might spend time on Discord, shares tips resources to talk to teens about keeping their online experiences comfortable. How Your Teen Uses Discord Discord is about hanging out with friends in real time. It's a place where people can be themselves spend time with others who share their interests hobbies. Keep reading to learn how your teen can use Discord to talk hang out with their communities friends. Chatting with Friends Teens use Discord to talk about all sorts of things, ranging from their favorite artists sports teams to homework more. It's a home for communities of any size, but it's most widely used by small active groups of people. These small groups include group chats other groups, called servers, made by interest-based communities friend groups. Discord servers are organized into topic-based channels where you can collaborate, share, just talk about your day without clogging up a group chat. vast majority of servers are small invitation-only, so your teen can choose to be a part of servers they want to be in, if your teen is a server owner, they control who gets to be part of their community. Hopping into Channels Communication on Discord isn't just about text! Discord servers are organized into text voice channels, which are usually dedicated to specific topics. In text channels, users can post messages, upload files, share images for others to see at any time. Teens hop into a voice channel connect through a voice video call in real time, can share their screen with their friends. Exploring Interest-based Communities From gaming, to music, to learning, Discord is home for people wanting to create a community around a special interest a hobby. Your teen may also join public communities that are built around shared interests from language learning, to origami, to their favorite TV shows, to houseplants. More Resources for Parents Educators Safer Internet Day 2023 Discord's commitment to a safe trusted experience Helping your teen stay safe on Discord Answering parents' educators' top questions Talking about online safety with your teen If your teen encounters an issue What is Discord? Talking about online safety with your teen Discord's commitment to a safe trusted experience Safer Internet Day 2023 Discord's commitment to a safe trusted experience Helping your teen stay safe on Discord Answering parents' educators' top questions Talking about online safety with your teen If your teen encounters an issue What is Discord? Our Approach to Content Moderation We currently employ three levers to moderate user content on Discord, while mindful of user privacy. User Controls Our product architecture provides each user with fundamental control over their experience on Discord including who they communicate with, what content they see, what communities they join create. Platform Moderation Our universal Community Guidelines apply to all content every interaction on platform. These fundamental rules are enforced by Discord on an ongoing basis through a mix of proactive reactive work. In Community Servers larger than 200 members, we take a more proactive automated approach to safety as described in our Terms of Service Privacy Policy. We may use automated means to detect violations of our policies. Community Moderation Server owners volunteer community moderators define enforce norms of behavior for their communities that can go beyond Discord Community Guidelines. We enable our community moderators with technology (tools like AutoMod) as well as training peer support (Discord Admin Community). Reporting on Discord Learn how to report content other users on Discord help support your teen in feeling confident comfortable when reporting issues themselves. It's important to have a conversation about what is isn't considered proper online behavior.. For example, only accept friend requests from people you know. If something doesnat seem right, tell a trusted adult. Behavior thatas not okay at school is also not okay online. However, if something does come up, please know that you your teen can easily report it to Discord for our Safety team to investigate take appropriate action. Submitting a Report If your teen encounters an issue on Discord, here's how they can report it to us. First, select message they wish to report. If they're on mobile, hold down on Message, on desktop, "right click." Then, select "Report Message."For parents, you too can submit a report by following instructions in this article. Describe Issue Once they've hit "Report Message" button, they can choose which category of violation they're seeing. More details can be provided in next screen, to further allow them to specify what it is they're encountering.Our Safety team takes action when we become aware of content that violates our Community Guidelines policies, including disabling accounts, removing servers, engaging with authorities as appropriate. Get Help from a Moderator Discord communities, especially large public ones, often have moderators there to help address issues. If violation happened in a server with a moderator, your teen can also reach out to serveras moderators, who may be able to respond immediately help resolve their concerns. In addition, remind your teen that they have ability to block any users they donat want to interact with. Family Center Parentas Guide to Discord Our friends at NationalPTA, ConnectSafely, Thorn have leveraged their expertise working with families to create their own parent guides to Discord. Consider checking them out for another view on how your teen uses Discord, our safety tools, ways to start conversations about online safety.

Discord Safety News Hub Latest in Safety Our Work With Lantern, First Child Safety Cross-Platform Signal Sharing Program Upholding Our Commitment to Safety in 2023 Beyond How We Leverage Machine Learning to Fight Child Sexual Abuse Material Safer Internet Day 2025 Addressing Harmful off Platform Behavior An Update on our Mental Health & Belonging Work Crisis Text Line Partnership Mental wellness is important for everyone. Discord is partnering with Crisis Text Line, a nonprofit that provides 24/7 text-based mental health support crisis intervention via trained volunteer Crisis Counselors.If you report a message for self-harm within Discord mobile app, you will be presented with information on how to connect with a Crisis Text Line volunteer Crisis Counselor. You can also text aDISCORDa to 741741 to reach Crisis Text Line counselors available 24/7 to help you a friend through any mental health crisis. Our goal is to enable users to get help they need for themselves, empower others to get help, as quickly as possible. Crisis Text Line is available to those in United States is offered in both English Spanish. Supporting Youth Digital Wellness Weare constantly improving expanding our approach to teen safety wellbeing on Discord. Thatas why weare proud to support Digital Wellness Lab at Boston Childrenas Hospital to help ground our approach to teen safety belonging in latest scientific research best practices. Digital Wellness Lab at Boston Childrenas Hospital convenes leaders in technology, scientific research, healthcare, child development, media, entertainment, education to deepen understanding address future of how young people can engage healthily with media technology. Weare excited to work with Digital Wellness Lab to help develop ways to better support teen mental health, both online off. Empowering Teens Families to Build Belonging Back-to-school season is a great time for families to rethink reset their relationship with technology. To help out, Discord is rolling out a new program with National PTA to help families educators discuss ways to foster positive relationships build belonging in our digital world. Defending Your Online Spaces Editor's Note: On July 1 2024, Supreme Court reaffirmed that moderation decisions are protected by First Amendment of U.S. Constitution. You can read our response to this ruling here. Today, Discord filed an amicus brief with Supreme Court in support of our ongoing efforts to create online communities of shared interests that are safe, welcoming, inclusive. cases at issue (Moody v. NetChoice, et al. NetChoice et al. v. Paxton) challenge constitutionality of two new laws in Texas Florida. You may have heard of them: these laws would significantly restrict ability of online services to remove content that is objectionableA to their users force them to keep a wide range of alawful but awfula content on their sites. Discord is not a traditional social media service, but whether intended not, laws are broad enough to likely impact services like ours. Itas hard to overstate potential impact if these laws are allowed to go into effect: they would fundamentally change how services like Discord operate, with that, experiences we deliver to you. Thereas no doubt that outcome here is hugely important to us as a company, but that alone is not why we are taking a stand. Ultimately, we filed this brief because important context was missing from official record: you all vibrant communities youave built on Discord. Taking a step back, Discord has invested heavily in creating safe fun online spaces. Our Community Guidelines set rules for how we all engage on Discord, we put a lot of effort into enforcing them: around 15% of company works on safety, including content moderation. This includes Trust Safety agents who enforce Discordas rules, engineers who develop moderation tools for both Discord its users, many more dedicated individuals across our company. We do this work so that you can create those online spaces where you can find foster genuine connection. But in order to bring this world to life, Discord needs to be able to prevent, detect, remove harmful speech conduct. Barring companies like Discord from moderating content is a little like barring garbage collection in a city: every individual block would have to devote its own resources to hauling its own garbage, diverting those limited resources from more productive activities individualized curation that makes each neighborhood unique. So, while our rules content moderation efforts certainly reflect our own values speech about kind of services we want to offer, we really do it for you allawe work to take care of hard stuff so you all can focus on creating communities you want. Thatas why we decided to take such a strong position in these cases: we want to make sure Supreme Court understands how these laws would impact your speech your communities. Fortunately, First Amendment has a lot to say about thisait protects your association rights, which make it possible for you to come together around your shared interests see content that is relevant helpful, not harmful.A Keeping your communities fun safe by not allowing harmful content is a top priority for us. We wouldnat be doing what we do without all of you, we will keep working to make sure you can create online spaces you want.A A Discordas Commitment to Teen Child Safety Our Policies You can read an overview of following policies here. Teen Self-Endangerment Policy Teen self-endangerment is a nuanced issue that we do not take lightly. We want our teen users to be able to express themselves freely on Discord while also taking steps to ensure these users donat engage in risky behaviors that might endanger their safety well-being. In order to help our teenage users stay safe, our policies state that users under age of 18 are not allowed to send access any sexually explicit content. Even when this kind of content is shared consensually between teens, there is a risk that self-generated sexual media can be saved shared outside of their private conversations. We want to help our users avoid finding themselves in these situations. In this context, we also believe that dating online can result in self-endangerment. Under this policy, teen dating servers are prohibited on Discord we will take action against users who are engaging in this behavior. Additionally, older teens engaging in grooming of a younger teen will be reviewed actioned under our Inappropriate Sexual Conduct with Children Grooming Policy. Through our thorough work partnership with a prominent child safety organization, we determined that we will, when possible, warn teens who have engaged in sexually explicit behavior before moving to a full ban. An example of this includes teens sharing explicit content with each other that is not their own content. Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM) Child Sexualization Policy Discord has a zero-tolerance policy for child sexual abuse, which does not have a place on ourA platform a anywhere in society. We do not allow CSAM on Discord, including AI-generated photorealistic CSAM. When such imagery is found, imagery is reported to National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC). This ensures that sexualization of children in any context is not normalized by bad actors. Inappropriate Sexual Conduct with Teens Grooming Policy Discord has a zero-tolerance policy for inappropriate sexual conduct with children grooming. Grooming is inappropriate sexual contact between adults teens on platform, with special attention given to predatory behaviors such as online enticement sexual extortion of children, commonly referred to as asextortion.a When we become aware of these types of incidents, we take appropriate action, including banning accounts of offending adult users reporting them to NCMEC, which subsequently works with local law enforcement.A How We Work to Keep Our Younger Users Safe Our Safety team works hard to find remove abhorrent, harmful content, take action including banning users responsible engaging with proper authorities. Discordas Safety by Design practice includes a risk assessment process during product development cycle that helps identify mitigate potential risks to user safety. We recognize that teens have unique vulnerabilities in online settings this process allows us to better safeguard their experience. Through this process, we think carefully about how product features might disproportionately impact teens consider whether product facilitates more teen-to-adult interactions and/or any unintended harm. Our teams identify strategize ways to mitigate safety risks with internal safety technology solutions during this process through getting insight recommendations from external partners. Discord uses a mix of proactive reactive tools to remove content that violates our policies, from use of advanced technology like machine learning models PhotoDNA image hashing to partnering with community moderators to uphold our policies providing in-platform reporting mechanisms to surface violations. Our Terms of Service require people to be over a minimum age (13, unless local legislation mandates an older age) to access our website. We use an age gate that asks users to provide their date of birth upon creating an account. If a user is reported as being under 13, we delete their account. Users can only appeal to restore their account by providing an official ID document to verify their age.A Additionally, we require that all age-restricted content is placed in a channel clearly labeled as age-restricted, which triggers an age gate, preventing users under 18 from accessing that content. newest launches of safety products are focused on helping to safeguard teen experience with our safety alerts on senders that educate teens on ways they can control their experience limit unwanted contact. Additionally, sensitive content filters provide additional controls for teens to blur block unwanted content. Rather than assigning prescriptive solutions for teens, we aim to empower teens with respect for their agency, privacy, decision-making power. Additionally, we are expanding our own Trusted Reporter Network in collaboration with INHOPE for direct communication with expert third parties, including researchers, industry peers, journalists for intelligence sharing. Our Technology Solutions Machine learning has proven to be an essential component of safety solutions at Discord. Since our acquisition of Sentropy, a leader in AI-powered moderation systems, we have continued to balance technology with judgment contextual assessment of highly trained employees, along with continuing to maintain our strong stance on user privacy. Below is an overview of some of our key investments in technology: Teen Safety Assist: Teen Safety Assist is focused on further protecting teens by introducing a new series of features, including multiple safety alerts sensitive content filters that will be default-enabled for teen users. Safety Rules Engine: Safety Rules Engine allows our teams to evaluate user activities on platform, including registrations, server joins, other metadata. We then analyze patterns of problematic behavior to make informed decisions take uniform actions like user challenges bans. AutoMod: Automod is a powerful tool for community moderators to automatically filter unwanted messages with certain keywords, block profiles that may be impersonating a server admin appear harmful to their server, detect harmful messages using machine learning. This technology empowers community moderators to keep their communities safe without having to spend long hours manually reviewing removing unwanted content on their servers. Visual safety platform: Discord has continued to invest in improving image classifiers for content such as sexual, gore, violent media. With these, our machine learning models are being improved to reach higher precision detection rates with lower error rates decrease teen exposure to potentially inappropriate mature content. We proactively scan images uploaded to our platform using PhotoDNA to detect child sexual abuse material (CSAM) report any CSAM content perpetrators to NCMEC, who subsequently work with local law enforcement to take appropriate action. Investing in technological advancements tools to proactively detect CSAM grooming is a key priority for us, we have a dedicated team to handle related content. In Q2 2023, we proactively removed 99% of servers found to be hosting CSAM. You can find more information in Discordas latest Transparency Report. There is constant innovation taking place within beyond Discord to improve how companies can effectively scale deliver content moderation. Our approach will continue to evolve as time goes on, as weare constantly finding new ways to do better for our users. Evolving our Policies to Keep You Safe Threats, Hate Speech, Violent Extremism Hate harm targeted at individuals communities is not tolerated on Discord in any way, combating this behavior content is a top priority for us. We evolved our Threats Policy to address threats of harm to others. Under this policy, we will take action against direct indirect threats, veiled threats, those who encourage this behavior, conditional statements to cause harm. We also refined our Hate Speech Policy with input from a group of experts who study identity intersectionality came from a variety of different identities backgrounds themselves. Under this policy, we define ahate speecha as any form of expression that denigrates, vilifies, dehumanizes; promotes intense, irrational feelings of enmity hatred; incites harm against people based on protected characteristics. In addition, weave expanded our list of protected characteristics to go beyond what most hate speech laws cover to include following: age; caste; color; disability; ethnicity; family responsibilities; gender; gender identity; housing status; national origin; race; refugee immigration status; religious affiliation; serious illness; sex; sexual orientation; socioeconomic class status; source of income; status as a victim of domestic violence, sexual violence, stalking; and, weight size. A Last year, we wrote about how we address Violent Extremism on Discord. We are deeply committed to our work in this space have updated our Violent Extremism Policy to prohibit any kind of support, promotion, organization of violent extremist groups ideologies. We worked closely with a violent extremism subject-matter expert to update this policy will continue to work with third-party organizations like Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism European Union Internet Forum to ensure it is enforced properly. Financial Scams, Fraud Services, Malicious Conduct During 2022, we invested significantly in how we combat criminal activity on Discord. In February, we released two blogs to help users identify protect themselves against scams on Discord. Alongside these, we developed a Financial Scams Policy which prohibits three types of common scams: identity scams, investment scams, financial scams. We will take action against users who scam others use Discord to coordinate scamming operations. In case of users who have been victim of fraudulent activity, we recommend they report activity to Discord contact law enforcement, who will be able to follow up with us for more information if it helps their investigation. Under our new Fraud Services Policy, we've expanded our definitions of what constitutes fraudulent behavior. We will take action against users who engage in reselling stolen ill-gotten digital goods are involved in coordinated efforts to defraud businesses engage in price gouging, forgery, money laundering. We also do not allow any kind of activity that could damage compromise security of an account, computer network, system under our updated Malicious Conduct Policy. We will take action against users who use Discord to host distribute malware, carry out phishing attempts denial-of-service attacks against others. How Discord Prevents Removes Spam We invested a substantial amount of time resources into combating spam in 2022, disabling 141,087,602 accounts for spam spam-related offenses, with a proactive removal rate of 99%, before we receive a user report. We observed a significant increase in number of accounts disabled during third quarter of 2022, leading to an elevated but lower fourth quarter, then to a substantial decrease in first quarter of 2023. These trends can be attributed to both increased ongoing investments in our anti-spam team a shift in our approach to reducing number of disabled accounts by placing greater confidence in our proactive spam mitigations avoiding false positives. As a result, only .004% of accounts disabled submitted an appeal during past quarter. Spammers are constantly evolving adapting to new technologies methods of detection, moving to use new parts of platform to target users. Combating spam requires a multi-faceted approach that employs new tools technologies, while also remaining vigilant adaptable to changing trends. We're constantly updating our approach to remove spam, as our proactive efforts have increased, we've observed a steady decline in number of reports we receive for spam. a above trends were made possible over past year due to a number of technological advances in both back-end front-end features, products, tools to help prevent remove spam from Discord. Discord is committed to combating spam building a safer environment for people to find belonging. We've grown our teams, shipped new features, products, tools, continue to listen closely to users about how spam impacts their experience on Discord. We're constantly updating our approach to remove spam remain vigilant adaptable to changing trends. We will continue to prioritize safety work hard to combat spam in order to help make Discord best place for people communities to hang out online. How We Leverage Machine Learning to Fight Child Sexual Abuse Material Weare bridging a key gap in CSAM detection To understand how tech industry is working to solve these challenges, itas helpful to understand technology itself. industry standard for CSAM detection is a tool called PhotoDNA, which was developed by Microsoft donated to National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC)athe nationally recognized hub for reporting suspected online child sexual exploitation in US. When imagery depicting child sexual abuse is reported to NCMEC, PhotoDNA is used to create a unique digital signature (or ahasha) of that image. That hashaand not illegal imagery itselfais stored in a database that serves as a reference point for online detection efforts. At Discord, we proactively scan images using hashing algorithms (including PhotoDNA) to detect known CSAM. For example, if someone uploads an image that matches against known CSAM that has been previously reported, we automatically detect it, remove it, flag it for internal review. When we confirm that someone attempted to share illegal imagery, we remove content, permanently ban them from our platform, report them to NCMEC, who subsequently works with law enforcement.A There are more than 6.3 million hashes of CSAM in NCMECas hash database more than 29 million hashes of CSAM contained in databases from around world. That gives tech industry a strong foundation for stopping spread of this harmful material on our platforms. But thereas one key limitation: it only detects exact similar copies of images that are already logged in database. This means that predatory actors will try to exploit this weakness with unknown CSAM that has yet to be seen logged, indicating that there is either a likelihood of active abuse, images were synthetically generated using AI. Machine learning helps us stop CSAM at scale Unknown CSAM has continually plagued our industry our team felt it was important to advance our own detection capabilities. We started with an open-source model that can analyze images to understand what they are depicting. Our engineers experimented found that we could use this model to not only determine how similar one image is to another, but due to semantic understanding of model, it also demonstrated promising results for novel CSAM detection. When we find a match, we follow same process that we use for PhotoDNA matches: A human reviews it to verify if it is an instance of CSAM. If it is, itas reported to NCMEC added to PhotoDNA database. From that point, newly verified image can be detected automatically across platforms. This speeds up review process, expands database of known CSAM, makes everyone better faster at blocking CSAM over time. This is a major advancement in effort to detect, report, stop spread of CSAM. At a recent Tech Coalition hackathon, engineers from Discord other tech companies collaborated on ways we can work together to identify new forms of CSAM that evade existing detection methods. During this collaboration, we were able to work to make AI-powered detection mechanism we built open-source. At Discord, we believe safety shouldnat be proprietary a competitive advantage. Our hope is that by making this technology open source, we can bring new capabilities protections to all tech platforms, especially newer companies that donat yet have established trust safety teams. This is part of our work alongside Lantern program, which is committed to stopping people from evading CSAM detection across platforms. Together, weare working to increase prevention detection methods, accelerate identification processes, share information on predatory tactics, strengthen our collective reporting to authorities. Ultimately, this is an ideal use of machine learning technology. Itas important to note, though, that human expertise judgment is still involved. Our expert staff continues to review anything thatas not an exact match with PhotoDNA, because stakes are high we need to get it right. What matters most is that combined efforts of machine learning human expertise are making it harder than ever for predatory actors to evade detection. Weare working to build a safer internet. Itas in our DNA. Safety is a top priority at Discord. Itas reflected in our personnel: roughly 15% of our staff is dedicated to safety. These teams work to ensure our platform, features, policies result in a positive safe place for our users to hang out build community. Weare stronger together safety landscape is continually shifting. There are always new challenges emerging, no single entity can tackle them alone. Our industry can lead by sharing tools, intelligence, best practices. We also need to work collaboratively with policymakers, advocacy groups, academics to fully understand emerging threats respond to them. Initiatives like Lantern organizations like Tech Coalition represent kind of collaborative efforts that make it possible for us all to better stay ahead of bad actors work together towards a universally safe online experience for everyone. How We Put Safety at Center of Everything We Build What it means to start with safety As soon as we start building something new, we assess risks that might come from it. By starting at concept phase, we can factor safety into everything we do as we design, build, launch, manage a new product. Throughout process, our teams weigh in with specialized knowledge in their domains, including teen safety, counter-extremism, cybercrime, security, privacy, spam. Functionally, this is how we pinpoint any gaps that may exist as we build products features that make Discord a fun, safe place to hang out with friends. Four key questions for building safer products Any time we build something, we prioritize four key questions to determine our approach to building safer products: There are some things we consider with each product. Weall look, for instance, at our data to learn more about most common kinds of violations that are related to what weare building. That can help us understand most harmful most abundant violations we know about today. But our products donat all have same behaviors content, so we canat just copy-paste our work from one tool to another. Think of Family Center voice messages, for example. They have unique purposes functions, so we needed different answers to each of questions above as we built them. By starting with these questions on day one, we were able to make right decisions for each tool at each step of process maximize our approach to safety in end. By following this approach, everyone involved in making our products has a clear-eyed honest understanding of risks that could potentially arise from our work. We make intentional decisions to minimize those risks commit to only releasing something if it meets our high standard of safety. What starting with safety looks like in practice Letas look a little deeper at voice messages, feature that lets you record audio on your phone easily send it to your friends. Hereas a brief rundown of how we incorporated safety conversations into every aspect of bringing this fun tool to life. At earliest stage, product team drew up preliminary specifications consulted with trust safety subject matter experts on staff. product manager shared specs with individuals from policy legal teams, with a focus on flagging any concerns discrepancies regarding Discordas own policies. Once initial feedback was incorporated, product manager created an action plan, bringing on engineers who began building feature. Even during this stage, safety experts were part of process. In fact, it was here that members of safety team called for an additional requirementaa way for us to handle large amounts of audio messages. Just as users can report written messages, they also can report audio messages for content that violates our policies. Our safety teams needed to ensure we had a way to review those reports effectively as they flow in. In this instance, team had to figure out how audio review process would even work. Would reviewers have to sit listen to hours of reported messages each day? That didnat seem viable, so core team decided to use existing text tools that could transcribe reported messages. Now reviewers can evaluate text quickly, review audio for additional context. Once again, product manager engineers worked closely with safety team to include building in this additional layer of safety. Just because our voice messages feature is live doesnat mean our safety job is complete. We need to understand how effective our methods are, so weave developed metrics that track safety give us insight into impacts of decisions weave made. We track, for instance, if we have unusual rates of flagged content appeals on decisions, as well as breakdown of various violations on our platform. We summarize these metrics in our quarterly Transparency Reports. What it doesnat look like To better understand our safety-centric approach, consider alternative. A different platform could start with an innovative idea best intentions. It could build product it thinks would be most exciting for users, review risk safety implications when itas ready to go live. If company identifies risks at a late stage, it has to decide what to address before releasing product to world. This can happen is flawed. If youare already at finish line when you notice risks youave created, you might realize you have to start over to do it right. Building a product this way is risky, users are ones most exposed to those risks. How Discord starts with safety At Discord, we understand that we have to think about safety growth holistically. Discord is built differently from other platforms. We don't chase virality impressions. Discord makes money by providing users a great experience through premium subscriptions. Under this model, we can focus on our users have more freedom to prioritize safety. Put simply, weare only interested in growing a platform thatas safe. Weare here to help people forge genuine friendships, we know that can only happen when people feel safe connecting with one another. How Weare Fighting Spammers on Discord Important Policy Updates Important Policy Updates Joining Forces to Create a Safer Internet Recognizing Safer Internet Day Safer Internet Day was created by advocacy organizations as a way to raise awareness around online safety. It has since expanded into an opportunity for industry, government, civil society to come together to share online safety digital well-being best practices. Making internet a better, safer place for everyone is a tall task a we know we canat do it alone. Last year, as part of our ongoing partnership with National Parent Teacher Association, we co-hosted an event featuring some of our teen moderators talking about belonging mental health in online spaces. Weave continued this partnership with PTA Connected: Build up Belong Program. Weave gathered these resources to help give you a head start: Making your hangouts on Discord more private secure Weare excited to announce that starting today, weare rolling out passwordless login with biometric passkeys to streamline safeguard your sign-in experience as well as default end-to-end encryption for audio video (E2EE A/V) calls. Read on to see how these two features will help make your time on Discord safer, for both you your friends on call! Passwordless Login Passwords are annoying to remember are not most secure (yes, that includes awumpu2-1s-c00la). We provide various forms of multi-factor authentication (MFA) to protect your account, but we wanted to continue to prioritize security with a more seamless experience. Now, you can register a passkey to your Discord account, secured by on-device biometric features such as Face ID Touch ID, to sign in with just one easy step. Discord canat access your biometric data, helps ensure that nobody but you can use your passkey to sign into your account. Your passkey lives on your device, allowing you to seamlessly sign into Discord on any device that has access to that passkey. Thatas a win-win-win for privacy, security, a seamless user experience. Passwordless login with a passkey keeps your account as protected as possible. You can learn more about setting up a biometric passkey how to then log in with that passkey here. End-to-End Encryption for Audio & Video (E2EE A/V) Last summer we began experimenting with encryption protocols technologies for audio video calls, we are excited to announce roll out of our E2EE A/V protocol. Today, weall start automatically migrating audio video calls in DMs, Group DMs, voice channels, Go Live streams to a new system that utilizes E2EE A/V. Youall also be able to verify your end-to-end encrypted call identity of other members in it, giving you peace of mind no one else can listen in. When we consider adding new privacy features like E2EE A/V, we do not do so in isolation from safety. That is why safety is integrated across our product policies, why messages on Discord are unencrypted. Messages will still be subject to our content moderation approach, allowing us to continue offering additional safety protections.A Privacy is an essential part of feeling secure, we want to be transparent about security technology we use. Thatas why weave also published a technical blog to provide more insight into work, how we got here, our design implementation goals, technical overview of how we built our E2EE A/V protocol. You can also see how weave worked closely with external experts to assess risks develop robust safeguards to build our protocol. Discord is a place where you can be authentic should feel safe when talking with your friends - this includes maintaining account security protecting your privacy. Passwordless login makes sure no baddies can worm their way into your Discord account, end-to-end encryption has arrived to help keep audio video calls between you your friends private. To enable passwordless login, just head into User Settings > Account find section called aSecurity Keysa to get started! E2EE A/V is on by default for up-to-date Discord clients on desktop mobile, support for other clients such as web consoles will roll out next year. You can head here to learn how to verify your E2EE A/V calls are truly end-to-end encrypted.A Obsessed with security privacy? So are we aweall continue to prioritize build products that respect both. Navigating Online Boundaries With Your Teen Weare committed to making Discord a safe place for teens to hang out with their friends online. While theyare doing their thing weare doing our part to keep them safe, sometimes itas hard for parents to know whatas actually going on in their teensa online lives. Teens navigate online world with a level of expertise that is often underestimated by adults in their lives. For parents, it may be a hard lesson to fathomathat their teens know best. But why wouldnat they? Every teen is their own leading expert in their life experiences (as we all are!). But growing up online, this generation is particularly adept at what it means to make new friends, find community, express their authentic selves, test boundariesaall online. But that doesnat mean teens donat need adultsa help when it comes to setting healthy digital boundaries. it doesnat mean parents canat be a guide for cultivating safe, age-appropriate spaces. Itas about finding right balance between giving teens agency while creating right moments to check in with them. One of best ways to do that is to encourage more regular, open honest conversations with your teen about staying safe online. Here at Discord, weave developed tools to help that process, like our Family Center: an opt-in program that makes it easy for parents guardians to be informed about their teenas Discord activity while respecting their autonomy. Here are a few more ways to kick off online safety discussions. If a teen feels like they could get in trouble for something, they wonat be honest with you. So go into these conversations from a place of curiosity first, rather than judgment. Here are a few conversation-starters: Teens will be less likely to share if they feel like parents just donat get it, so asking open questions like these will foster more conversation. Questions rooted in blame can also backfire: teen may not be as forthcoming because they feel like adult is already gearing up to punish them. Read more helpful prompts for talking with your teen about online safety in our Discord Safety Center. Our goal at Discord is to make it a place where teens can talk hang out with their friends in a safe, fun way. Itas a place where teens have power agency, where they get to feel like they own something. Just because your teen is having fun online doesn't mean you have to give up your parental role. Parents trusted adults in a teenas life are here to coach guide them, enabling them to explore themselves find out who they areawhile giving them parameters by which to do so. On Discord, some of those boundaries could include: Using Discordas Family Center feature so you can be more informed involved in your teensa online life without prying. They remind teens to fire up their empathy, while also reminding them itas OK to block those who bring you down. no, these cards will (unfortunately) not tell you your future! They encourage teens to share real-life experiences stories of online encounters, both positive negative. idea is to get young people talking, parents listening. Sometimes, even as adults, it's easy to get in over your head online. Our Response to Pentagon Leaks Summary of Current Situation Because investigations are ongoing, we can only share limited details. What we can say is that alleged documents were initially shared in a small, invite-only server on Discord. original server has been deleted, but materials have since appeared in several additional servers. Our Terms of Service expressly prohibit using Discord for illegal criminal purposes. This includes sharing of documents that may be verifiably classified. Unlike overwhelming majority of people who find community on Discord, this group departed from norms, broke our rules, did so in apparent violation of law. Our mission is for Discord to be place to hang out with friends online. With that mission comes a responsibility to make Discord a safe positive place for our users. For example, our policies clearly outline that hate speech, threats violent extremism have no place on our platform. When Discordas Trust Safety team learns of content that violates our rules, we act quickly to remove it. In this instance, we have banned users involved with original distribution of materials, deleted content deemed to be against our Terms, issued warnings to users who continue to share materials in question. Our Approach to Delivering a Positive User Experience This recent incident fundamentally represents a misuse of our platform a violation of our platform rules. Our Terms of Service Community Guidelines provide universal rules for what is acceptable activity content on Discord. When we become aware of violations to our policies, we take action. core of our mission is to give everyone power to find create belonging in their lives. Creating a safe environment on Discord is essential to achieve this, is one of ways we prevent misuse of our platform. Safety is at core of everything we do a primary area of investment as a business: fight against bad actors on communications platforms is unlikely to end soon, our approach to safety is guided by following principles: Underpinning all of this are two important considerations: our overall approach towards content moderation our investments in technology solutions to keep our users safe. Our Technology Solutions We believe that in long term, machine learning will be an essential component of safety solutions. In 2021, we acquired Sentropy, a leader in AI-powered moderation systems, to advance our work in this domain. We will continue to balance technology with judgment contextual assessment of highly trained employees, as well as continuing to maintain our strong stance on user privacy. Our Response to Tragedy in Buffalo Our Work With Lantern, First Child Safety Cross-Platform Signal Sharing Program Some of most recognizable names in tech such as Snap, Google, Twitch, Meta, Discord unveiled Lantern, a pioneering initiative aimed at thwarting child predators who exploit platform vulnerabilities to elude detection. This vital project marks a significant stride forward in safeguarding children who on average spend up to nine hours a day online. It underscores a critical truth: protecting our children in digital realm is a shared responsibility, necessitating a unified front from both tech behemoths emerging players. digital landscape must be inherently safe, embedding privacy security at its core, not merely as an afterthought. This philosophy propelled my journey to Discord, catalyzed by a profound personal reckoning. In 2017, harrowing discussions about children's online experiences triggered a series of panic attacks for me, leading to a restless quest for solutions. This path culminated, with a gentle nudge from my wife, in creation of a company that used AI to detect online abuse make internet safer for everyone, which was later acquired by Discord. This mission has been remains personal for me! Discord, now an eight-year-old messaging service with mobile, web, stand-alone apps over 150 million monthly users, transcends being just a platform. It's a sanctuary, a space where communities, from gamers to study groups, notably LGBTQ+ teens, find belonging safety. Our ethos is distinct: we don't sell user data clutter experiences with ads. Discord isnat place you go to get famous attract followers. We align our interests squarely with our users, fostering a safe authentic environment. However, our non-social media identity doesn't preclude collaboration with social media companies in safeguarding online spaces. Just as physical venues like airports, stadiums hospitals require tailored security measures, so too do digital platforms need safety solutions that meet their unique architecture. With all different ways that kids experience life online, a one-size-fits-all approach simply wonat work. This is not a solitary endeavor but a collective, industry-wide mandate. Innovating in safety is as crucial as in product features, requiring open-source sharing of advancements knowledge. For example, our team at Discord has independently developed new technologies to better detect child sexual abuse material (CSAM), have chosen to make them open-source so that other platforms can use this technology without paying a penny. tech industry must confront head-on most severe threats online, including sexual exploitation illegal content sharing. Parents rightfully expect digital products used by their children to embody these safety principles. Lantern is a pivotal advancement in this ongoing mission. Yet, as technology evolves, introducing AI, VR, other innovations, safety landscape continually shifts, presenting new challenges that no single entity can tackle alone. millions tech sector invests must be used to ensure users on our platforms are actually safe, not to persuade Washington that theyare safe. Our industry can lead by sharing with each other working collaboratively with legislators, advocacy groups, academics. Collaboration is keyaamong tech companies, legislators, advocacy groups, academicsa to ensure a universally safe online experience for our children. essence of online safety lies in an unprecedented collaborative effort globally. launch of Lantern is not just a step but a leap forward, signaling a new era of shared responsibility action in digital world. Itas time for us to focus on a safer tomorrow! Parents & Educators, Join Us on Discord! Safer Internet Day 2025 IntroducingA ROOST As technologies continue to evolve, so does dynamic safety landscape. This presents new challenges that no entity can tackle alone, so continued industry investment in safety features is imperative to make Internet a safer place for all. Today, Discord other founding partners a including OpenAI, Google, Roblox, Eric Schmidt, John S. James L. Knight Foundation, AI Collaborative, Patrick J. McGovern Foundation, Project Liberty Institute - unveiled a new cross-industry non-profit foundation called ROOST. ROOST - Robust Open Online Safety Tools - addresses a critical gap in child safety digital safety by providing free, open-source safety tools to organizations of all sizes. This will alleviate need for organizations to reinvent wheel in building tools that already exist, empowering them - especially smaller companies public interest organizations - to focus on growing their platforms services while promoting safety for online users. ROOST will offer free, open source easy-to-use tools to detect, review, report child sexual abuse material (CSAM), leverage large language models to power safety infrastructure, make core safety technologies more accessible more user friendly. With dedicated technical teams providing hands-on support, ROOST meets organizations where they are, helping them integrate robust safety measures while continuing to innovate. In addition to being a founding partner, Discordas Chief Legal Officer Clint Smith will serve as Board Chair of ROOST Discord is contributing funding, technology, employee expertise to foundation. This builds on progress momentum weave seen over past year in industry collaboration - signal sharing on bad actors via Tech Coalitions' Lantern initiative, codifying safety best practices via Digital Trust & Safety Partnership, training thousands of career professionals from around world through Trust & Safety Professional Association TrustCon. Discord is proud to be a part of this effort, helping to foster innovation, urgently bring new safety tools to market. Weare hopeful that together weall protect even more users, children, families to make internet an even better place. Helping users take space covertly: NEW Ignore feature launches! Safety Reporting Network: A Commitment to Safety Collaboration How Safety Reporting Network Works To further safeguard our users, Safety Reporting Network allows us to collaborate with various organizations around world to identify report violations of our Community Guidelines. This program helps our team apply a more global perspective to our enforcement activity, providing context for important cultural nuances that allows us to quickly effectively apply our policies to content activity across our service. Members of Discordas Safety Reporting Network have access to a prioritized reporting channel, and, once our Safety team is made aware of a policy violation, we may take a range of actions, including: removing content, banning users, shutting down servers, when appropriate, engaging with proper authorities. Our Ongoing Commitment Our Safety Reporting Network is just one component of our overall commitment to safety. We continually invest in technological advancements, like our recently launched Teen Safety Assist Family Center tools; regularly update our policies; continually invest in building our team; more. As we continue to improve evolve our safety efforts, you can visit our Safety Center to learn more about this ongoing work.
