Understanding Avoiding Common Scams Social Engineering Social engineering is a manipulation tactic used by bad actors to trick individuals into divulging sensitive personal information. bad actor often poses as a trustworthy entity, offering a seemingly beneficial exchange of information. In its most basic form on our platform, social engineering is manipulating people to give their login credentials to an attacker. Discord Staff Impersonation Sometimes attackers try to impersonate Discord staff to gather information. To use this tactic, they hack into Discord accounts, then convince an accountas friends list that they've aaccidentally reported them.a They encourage them to reach out to "Discord Employees" to resolve issue. These impersonators often copy social media profiles onto Discord accounts, produce fake resumes, may even claim their staff badges are hidden for safety reasons. end goal is to trick you into surrendering your account information, paying for their fraudulent services to aundo report,a acquiring your financial assets. Discord Staff will never directly message users on app for support account-related inquiries. If someone claiming to be staff asks for personal information, payment, changes to your login credentials, we recommend that you do not engage further. All Discord users can report policy violations in app by following instructions here. Discord Staff are one of many groups that may be impersonated. Similar actions may occur for other companies as well, so be wary of accounts that may impersonate Support Safety related questions in other companies too. In general, if you need support at any company, it is wise to go official source instead. You can always verify your account standing directly from Discord by going into User Settings > Privacy & Safety > Standing. Learn more about account standing here. Impersonated Discord DMs Attackers may also resort to impersonating official Discord responses through user accounts bots. Typically, these messages include threats to your account standing if you do not comply with their demands. An official Discord DM will never ask for your password account token, will always display a staff badge on profile, as well a system badge which says aOfficial.a a Malware Tricks Malware often finds its way onto a device through downloads of malicious files. These files may appear harmless even enticingalike a game from a friend. But once downloaded run, they can give bad actors access to your login credentials, email addresses, even your entire device. Malicious Links Fake Nitro Giveaways Always exercise caution when clicking on links that will take you off of Discord, even when they appear to come from friends promise rewards like free Nitro. When you click on a link given to you, a pop up will show that you are leaving Discord it will display website you are being redirected to. It is advised to check link to make sure you are going to place that is intended. a Reporting Scams Reporting safety violations is critically important to keeping you broader Discord community safe. All Discord users can report policy violations in app by following instructions here. Stay vigilant informed to protect yourself your digital assets. Scams go against Discordas Community Guidelines, when we see this kind of activity, we take action, which can include banning users, shutting down servers engaging with authorities. We are committed to reducing scams through technical interventions continuously invest in safety enhancements partner with third parties to accelerate our work. For more information you can read our Deceptive Practices Policy Explainer as well as our Identity Authenticity Policy Explainer. How teens find explore community on Discord Young people find community identity online Online connections are a fixture of modern life. One in three US adults report they are online aalmost constantly,a a similar share of teens say they use social media just as much, according to Surgeon Generalas advisory. Itas probably true that everyone spends too much time on their phones a but that doesnat mean there arenat important things happening there. For young people in particular, online spaces can be great for hanging out with friends, building social circles, forming identity at a key juncture in life. Technology also removes geographical limits placed on friendships allows people to find like-minded peers much more freely. Itas important to have opportunities to connect with people who are into same things, whether those are passions, causes, an identity. Coming together online can help people find community, help buildA genuine connections. On Discord, that may happen in servers focused on a favorite sports team, video game, TV show. Servers can be small intimate, with just your core friend group who might use it for hanging out chatting. They can also be larger spaces for more people to share ideas, organized around identities, including neurodivergence, disabilities, LGBTQ communities; as well as special interests like music, art, tech. For some people, spaces like these offer support social connection that might be hard to come by where they live. aEspecially as an LGBTQ young person, being able to find a space, be it online in person, can literally be life-saving if they come from an unsupportive community,a said Patricia Noel, Discordas mental health policy manager a licensed social worker. aJust being able to find people who accept you, who use your pronouns a all I can say is that it can be a life-saving experience for young people to be able to come on Discord to find community.a More people are talking about mental health Many young people use Discord servers to support each other as they navigate a difficult stage in life. In servers focused on peer support with mental health, members gather to discuss what theyare struggling with build community around helping one another. These spaces created managed by users arenat replacements for mental health professionals, but they offer an accessible reliable space to be heard, Noel said. Young people look to communities of friends for validation support, theyare at an age in life when that has a significant impact on their sense of self. aYoung people are really invested in their mental health. They want to be having these conversations,a Noel said. aThey're so open about what they're experiencing feeling, even way that they support each other is amazing. They're asking right questions, theyare so in tune with one another, theyare such an empathetic group.a In spaces dedicated to discussing mental health, people may feel more free to share things they arenat yet comfortable sharing elsewhere. They can show up in a space thatas designed to offer words of validation affirmation, offer that same kind of support back to others. aThereas a lot of research coming out around benefits of peer support just being able to talk to somebody who's gone through what youare going through, who's just within your same age bracket,a Noel said. aIt ends up being beneficial for person seeking support as well as person who is supporter.a Building positive spaces for online communities experience of hanging out with friends is central to Discord. Servers are all about conversation a text, voice, video a because thatas how people build genuine connections, in real world online. Conversations happen at both server level also one-on-one with smaller groups in Direct Messages, DMs. We think of this in contrast to social media apps that are built for broadcasting likes, driven by algorithms that monopolize usersa attention. When all your time is spent on shallow interactions endless feeds of other people seemingly living their best lives, itas hard to feel better more connected. Often, opposite is true: research published in Journal of Medical Internet Research found that social comparison on digital platforms, where people judge themselves against others they see online, is aa significant risk factor for depression anxiety.a Experiences of quality interactions social support online, on other hand, are related to lower levels of depression anxiety. good news is we know how online communities can bring people together. internet can still provide new solutions to peopleas need for social connection, Discord is committed to fostering safe, healthy, supportive spaces on our platform. aThe internet isnat going anywhere. It's a tool that young people use, it's going to continue to be a part of their lives,a Noel said. aThey want to be part of solutions. They want to be included when it comes to deciding what happens next.a Words Matter 1. Keep it simple. When designing safety alerts, Discord uses plain language, avoids idioms metaphors, keeps sentences words short when possible. This makes alerts easier to understand in moment, without overloading users with information. This can be particularly useful for users who may be in a heightened emotional state, for example, if they just got a notification that they violated Discordas anti-harassment policy they want to report someone else for harassing them. Our design team tries to put themselves in teensa shoes in those moments. To imagine what their emotional state might be at time. simpler we can make options for them, better. We try to make it easier for them to move through flow so they are clear about what's supposed to happen. Simple language is timeless. It isnat trendy metaphorical. it translates better across different languages cultures. Take for example when a teen receives a DM from a user for first time Discord may provide some helpful education about online safety. a 2. Guide, donat reprimand. With features like Discordas Teen Safety Alerts, Discord partnered with a leading child safety non-profit Thorn to design features with teensa online behavior in mind. goal is to empower teens to build their own online safety muscleanot make them feel like they've done something wrong. So Discord builds teachable moments guidance into our products, using language that aims to restore useras sense of control, without shaming them. aWith teens, because they can't opt out of some of these alerts, we want it to feel more like a guideaa guardrail versus a speed bump,a said Passmore, lead product designer for Safety team. aA speed bump is saying, aHey, you're doing something wrong, you need to check yourself.a But we built Teen Safety Alerts to feel more like guidance.a This alert will encourage them to double check if they want to reply, will provide links to block user view more tips for staying safe. goal is to empower teens by providing information that helps them make important decisions to protect themselves. a 3. Show that youare listening can help them regain control. When a teen encounters potentially harmful sensitive content has a run-in with another user who is acting hostile, they, too, may be in an activated emotional state. They may be angry at other person, even at themselves. This is common with cyber-bullying, which researchers say can lead to depression feelings of low self-esteem isolation. Our approach is to meet them in that mindset. This means offering them options reminding them that they have options like blocking a person reporting a message. We create a space to acknowledge what theyare experiencing. Itas also important not to dwell on upsetting incident. Instead, Discord uses language that aims to move teen out of that emotional state into a place of self-awareness. This can help them to calm down feel more in control. A usersa mindset matters to Discord. That is why we try choose our words so carefully to support in best possible way. How do you define troll-y? Defining terms One of main challenges for Platform Policy team is writing rules for content that isnat so clearly defined. Riggio notes that for most severe violations, such as posting illegal material making an imminent threat of physical harm, line between whatas allowed whatas prohibited is bright red. Discord has a strict policy for those types of violations clear processes in place for removing content banning user. But for content where there arenat legal definitions even clear societal ones, like for bullying harassment, line is more gray. Landing on a definition starts with posing a fundamental question, said Riggio: aWhat is problem that weare trying to solve here on Discord?a How team goes about answering that challenge becomes guiding force behind each policy. For bullying harassment, team looks at user experience. We donat want people to experience psychological emotional harm from other users.A aThe spirit of policy is focused on individual community experience building healthy interactions,a Riggio said. Because ultimately, Discord is a place where everyone can find belonging, experiencing these feelings hinder people from doing that. team did a rigorous amount of research including reviewing other platforms reviewing guidance from industry groups, including Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism Tech Coalition, which was formed so companies could share best intelligence resources when it comes to child safety online. They also read academic literature on what it looks like in society. They also brought in subject matter experts from different countries, such as academics who study harassment legal scholars who can offer additional context for how platforms should be thinking about policies enforcement. These experts provided feedback on early drafts of policies. They defined bullying as unwanted behavior purposefully conducted by an individual group of people to cause distress intimidate particular individuals, harassment as abusive behavior towards individuals groups of people that contributes to psychological reputational harm that continues over time. Policies like this one are only as useful if they are enforceable. So team identified two dimensions that must be taken into account when assessing content. First, intent of instigator. These are signals that user server is posting content deliberately is intending to cause harm. Intent isnat always easy to spot, but Riggio said just as in real life, there are signs. For example, a user is directly harassed by someone, there have been multiple instances of harassment in past. aWhat happens in society happens online. What happens in your high school can sometimes happen on Discord,a she said. second, is content targeted? Is it targeting a specific individual by name? Is it targeting a specific individual by group? Here, there could also be dimensions of targeting users groups because of certain protected characteristics, such as race gender, which would then be considered a violation of Discordas Hate Speech policy. How this policy covers trolling term trolling has many dimensions. Itas been used to normalize aedgy behavior,a Riggio said. aTrolling in of itself is a complicated term, because some communities that intend to cause harm downplay their behavior with, aWe're just trolling,aa Riggio said. Trolling on Discord takes on different dimensions. From "server raids", when a group of users joins a server at same time to cause chaos, to "grief trolling", when someone attempts to make jokes degrades deceased their next of kin, this type of negative behavior is rooted in disruption harassment, is not tolerated on our platform -- no matter how harmless instigators may think it is. aI hate saying asticks stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me,a because words hurt,a said Patricia Noel, Discordas mental health policy manager who is a licensed social worker has a background in youth mental health. She collaborates cross-functionally within Discord with external partners, such as Crisis Text Line, with goal of providing tools resources to teens who may be experiencing mental health challenges. Why education is as important as enforcement Part of enforcement strategy for bullying harassment is to include a series of warnings, with escalating enforcement actions aimed at educating users, namely teens, that certain behaviors are not OK on Discord. a aThis generation is really empathetic. But I also know that there are people who go online just for sake of going online being a troll,a Noel said. aThose might be very same folks who are having problems at home, who are dealing with their own mental health well being issues. They might not immediately recognize that they are doing harm to someone else.a Understanding that young people are going to make mistakes is reflected in how new warning system handles suspensions. For lower harm violations falling under Bullying Harassment policy, Discord will test suspensions rather than permanent bans. idea here is that some teens may need a long pause before coming back to platform, given how much growth development occurs during each year of adolescence. while there will always be a zero-tolerance policy for most serious violations, Discord will focus on remediation, when appropriate, for topics like bullying harassment. This is so teens can have an opportunity to pause, acknowledge that they did something wrong, hopefully change their behavior. challenge is that behavior is so wide-ranging, said Ben Shanken, Discordas Vice President of Product. He pointed to a recent analysis by Discord that looked at reports of bullying in large, discoverable servers. aIf you put these examples on an SAT test asked, aIs this bullying? Many people probably would answer questions incorrectly,a he said, noting how Discordas large teen user base is inclined to atroll-ya behavior. In one example, Shanken shared how teens were trolling each other by deceptively reporting their friends to Discord for supposedly being underage when in fact they were not. Itas trolling. While itas not nice, itas also part of how teens joke around. But, instead of simply banning offender, we build in an opportunity where they can learn from their mistake. aIf we ban a person, they don't know what they did wrong, they likely won't change their behavior,a said Shanken. aGiving them a warning saying, here's what you did wrong, flips script in a more constructive way. At its core, Discord is a place where people can come together to build genuine friendships. Educating users, especially young people, through our warning system is one part of Discordas holistic strategy to cultivate safe spaces where users can make meaningful connections. nature of being a teenager navigating relationships can be tricky. There are going to be situations where you hurt people's feelings. There may be moments where users lose their cool say something really mean even vaguely threatening,a Riggio said. aWe want to build in more of a runway for them to make mistakes online but also learn from them.a Remediation: Why you canat ban your way to a safe platform Discordas remediation philosophy Our approach to remediation is inspired by restorative justice, a concept from criminal justice that prioritizes repairing harm over punishment. Discordas Community Guidelines exist to keep people communities safe, itas important to make sure everyone knows how why to follow them. still, when people break rules, most of time they deserve a chance to correct themselves show that theyave learned. When users break an online platformas rules, they donat always do so intentionally. Consider how many different platforms someone might use in a day, each with their own rules expectations. Discord needs to enforce its own Community Guidelines, while understanding that a user who violates Guidelines might not even know they had broken a rule in first place. aA lot of users have their own aterms of servicea that may be different from ours,a said Jenna Passmore, Discordas senior staff product designer for safety. Admins moderators set rules, norms, expectations for their own servers on top of Discordas Community Guidelines Terms of Service, users may not know when theyare breaching rules of a server platform. aIf there's a mismatch there, itas not a severe violation, we don't want to kick them off platform.a Instead, Discord wants to teach people how to stay in bounds keep themselves, their friends, their communities safe fun for everyone. And, to be clear, when it comes to most severe violationsasuch as those involving violent extremism anything that endangers exploits childrenaDiscord will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy. Putting users in charge of outcomes In most cases, breaking Discordas Community Guidelines triggers a series of events that are aimed at returning user to their community with a better understanding of how they should behave. Education comes first. When Discord spots a violation, it lets a user know what specific thing they did wrong. Theyare prompted to learn more, in plain language, about that rule why it matters. Nobody expects someone to memorize full Community Guidelines Terms of Service, but this is best moment to help them learn what they need to know. Consequences come next. Any penalties we impose are transparent match severity of violation. A first-time, low-level violation, for example, could prompt a warning, removal of offending content, a cooling-off period with temporary restrictions on account activity. When action Discord takes to enforce its Community Guidelines takes proper measure of violation provides users a path back to good standing, users can often return to their community with a greater understanding of rules need to change their own behavior. If users stay on good terms, similar violations in future will play out roughly same way. If they continue to break rules frequently, violations stack up, so do consequences. idea is to provide users an opportunity to learn from their mistakes, change their behavior, therefore stay in communities they know trust on Discord, rather than pushing users who violate Discordas Community Guidelines off platform to other spaces that tolerate encourage bad behavior. aWe want users to feel like they have some agency over what's going to happen next,a Passmore said. aWe want an avenue for folks to see our line of thinking: You violated this policy, this is what we're doing to your account. Learn more about this policy, please don't do this again. If you do it again, here's what's going to happen to your account.a Banning is reserved for most extreme cases, highest-harm violations result in immediate bans. Otherwise, if someone repeatedly demonstrates that they wonat play by rules, consequences become more severe, from losing access to their account for a month, to a year, eventuallyaif they continue to violate Community Guidelinesafor good. Everyone knows where they stand Remediation depends on users who are able to learn change their behavior being able to return to good standing. Discordas account standing meter lets users see how their past activity affects what theyare able to do on platform. standing meter has five levels: good, limited, very limited, at risk, banned. aFor most folks, it will always be agooda,a Passmore said. When itas not, hope is that someone will act more thoughtfully so they can return to that good status stay there. She compared it to road signs that show risk level for wildfires. aIt changes your behavior when youare driving through a national park you see that thereas a moderate fire risk,a she said. Discordas internal policies outline severity of each type of violation, appropriate consequence, how one type of violation compares to others. These policies help ensure that employees who review violations of Discordas Community Guidelines enforce rules fairly consistently. That means when someone breaks rules, employees arenat deciding punishment on an ad hoc basis. Instead, outcome is determined by severity number of violations. aOur goal is to help people act better,a said Ben Shanken, Discordas vice president of product, who oversees teams that work on growth, safety, user experience. aPeople don't always know that they're doing bad things, giving them a warning can help them to improve.a Ultimately, we believe that guiding users toward better behavioraand giving them tools they need to learnaresults in a better experience for everyone. Bringing Policies to Life Discordas policy team invests time resources into understanding dynamics of type of behavior theyare writing policies about. aThe team does a significant amount of research to understand: What is phenomenon? What does this issue look like on other platforms? What does issue look like in society?a said Bri Riggio, senior platform policy manager who oversees this process. policy team reviews scholarly research, data, nonprofit industry guidance, among other resources. They bring in external subject matter experts from around globe, like academics who study online behavior legal scholars who focus on sexual harassment. They also do internal research. They interviewed Discordas Trust & Safety teamathe ones who review content for violationsato see examples of what they consider bullying harassment.A One thing policy team keeps in mind during this stage is how this research pertains to teens. aTeens are at forefront of my researchathinking about how we protect young people who are online making sure they feel safe comfortable using Discord,a said Edith Gonzalez, a platform policy specialist. She added that she looks for research that addresses parents' concerns when it comes to issues such as cyberbullying. At heart of each policy, Riggio her team start by asking question: What is problem that we are trying to solve on Discord? She calls this idea aspirita of policy. aIf we are trying to stop users from feeling psychological emotional harm from other users, if we want them to have a good experience, then we write policy to try drive towards that north star,a she said. aIt can be a guiding force for us, especially when we get escalations edge cases where policy may not be so clear cut.a For example, if Trust & Safety team gets a report of content that was flagged for bullying, but content falls somewhere in a gray area itas not clear if content was intentional, team discusses if taking action under policy is actually going to solve problem not. Another way of putting it: Does it go against spirit of policy? These discussions inform how policy team can sharpen better articulate policies over time. Policy specialists like Gonzalez begin listing all different behaviors that describe issue. For bullying harassment, examples might include: sexual harassment, server raids, sending shock content, mocking a person's death. aOnce I write down all criteria, I expand each behavior,a said Gonzalez. aHow do you define a violent tragedy? How do you define mocking? How do you define unwanted sexual harassment? Slowly, policy starts off as a list, then I keep expanding it.a For this policy, we define bullying as unwanted behavior purposefully conducted by an individual group of people to cause distress intimidate, harassment as abusive behavior towards an individual group of people that contributes to psychological reputational harm that continues over time. Riggio points out significance of sustained behavior. Itas an acknowledgment that context matters. For example, what may be friendly banter joking between individuals could be misconstrued as harassment, not taking into account that friends sometimes joke around with each other. aWe would be potentially over-enforcing policy with users who are just having fun with each other.a Research experience tell us that people donat always know rules, when appropriate, they need an opportunity to learn from their mistakes. Discord built a warning system that helps educate users, especially teens. (Important note: warning system does not apply to illegal more harmful violations, such as violent extremism endangering children. Discord has a zero-tolerance policy against those activities.) aThere's a perception that teens will roll their eyes at a rule, they don't like rules, but reality is, teens really like it when there are clear rules that resonate with them,a said Liz Hegarty, Discordas global teen safety policy manager. Once they learn rule, they might slip up again, so policy team built in several opportunities to educate teens that bullying isnat allowed. These show up in form of a series of time-outs, versus a flat-out ban after a few strikes, as is common on other platforms. aItas teen-centered,a said Hegarty. aIt's this idea of: how can you educate as opposed to just punishing teenagers when they're making mistakes?a This, too, reflects spirit of Bullying Harassment policy, because ultimately, Discord wants to empower people to build meaningful relationships on platform. aThe spirit is intended to get at various behaviors that we know make users feel uncomfortable,a said Riggio. aThatas behavior that impacts feelings of safety culture of a community.a Our Approach to Content Moderation Moderation across Discord All users have ability to report behavior to Discord. User reports are processed by our Safety team for violative behavior so we can take enforcement actions where appropriate. Discord also works hard to proactively identify harmful content conduct so we can remove it therefore expose fewer users to it. We work to prioritize highest harm issues such as child safety violent extremism. We use a variety of techniques technology to identify this behavior, including: In larger communities, we may use automated means to proactively identify harmful content on platform enforce our Terms of Service Community Guidelines.A If we identify a violation, we then determine appropriate intervention based on content conduct take action such as removing content suspending a user account. result of our actions are conveyed to users through our Warning System. Creating a safe teen experience In addition to all measures we've outlined above, we add layers of protection for teen users. Our proactive approach for teens has additional layers of safe keeping because we believe in protecting most vulnerable populations on Discord. For teens, we may monitor content activity associated with teen accounts to identify possible situations of unwanted messages through Teen Safety Assist. For example, if we detect potentially unwanted DM activity directed at a teen account, we may send a safety alert in chat to give teen account information about how they might handle situation. (For messages between adults, we do not proactively scan read content by default.) Together we are building a safer place for everyone to hang out. To stay up to date on our latest policies check out our Policy Hub. Culture of Safety What do we mean by safety? When we talk about protecting users, weare talking about preventing them from anything that could cause harm. That includes things like harassment, hateful conduct, unwanted interactions from others, inappropriate contact, violent abusive imagery, violent extremism, misinformation, spam, fraud, scams, other illegal behavior. Itas a broad set of experiences, but each of them can affect someoneas life negatively in real ways. They also degrade overall experience of community where they happen. In addition to keeping users safe, we also need them to feel safe. Thatas why we talk openly about our work, publish safety metrics each quarter, give everyone access to resources in our Safety Center. A culture of safety starts with people building technology Discordas commitment to safety is reflected in its staff way we build our products. Over 15% of our staff works directly on team that ensures our users have a safe experience. We invest time resources here because keeping users safe is a core responsibility: Itas central to our mission to create best place to hang out online talk to friends. Our safety work includes experts from all parts of company, with a wide range of backgrounds. These experts are engineers, product managers, designers, legal experts, policy experts, more. Some have worked in technology, but also social work, teen media, human rights, international law. Building a diverse team like this helps ensure we get a 360-degree view on threats risks, best ways to protect against them. We also invest in proactively detecting removing harmful content before it is viewed experienced by others. During fourth quarter of 2023, 94% of all servers that were removed were removed proactively. Weave built specialized teams, formed external partnerships with industry experts, integrated advanced technology machine learning to keep us at cutting edge of providing a safe experience for users. Getting users engaged in safety While rules technical capabilities lay foundation, users play a central part in making servers safe for themselves others. Our Community Guidelines clearly communicate what activities arenat allowed on Discord. We warn, restrict, even ban users servers if they violate those rules. But we donat want to spend our days chastising punishing people, we donat want people to worry that theyare always at risk of being reported. Thatas no way to have fun with friends. Instead, we help users understand when theyave done something wrong nudge them to change their behavior. When people internalize rules that way, they recognize when they, someone else, might be breaking them. They discuss rules organically, in process build a shared sense of what keeps their community safe in good standing. This has a multiplier effect on our work to build safer spaces: Users act with greater intention they more proactively moderate themselves their communities against unsafe actions. When communities have this shared commitment to rules, theyare also more likely to report harmful activity that could put an otherwise healthy community at risk. Changing safety narrative Itas sometimes said in technology that a platform canat really reduce harm block bad actors from doing bad things. Instead, those actions have to be addressed after they happen, when theyare reported detected. At Discord, we have loftier goals than that. We actually want to reduce harm. We want to make it so hard for bad actors to use our platform that they donat even try. For everyone else, we want to build products provide guidance that make safety not just a technical accomplishment, but a cultural value throughout our company communities we support. How Do aTeensa Rightsa Show Up in Discordas Enforcement Policies? What is a teensa rights approach? A teensa rights approach honors young peopleas experience, including areas where they could use a little helpasay, when they push boundaries just a little too far succumb to peer pressure engage in inappropriate behavior online. idea comes from United Nationsa guidance on impact of digital technologies on young peopleas lives. For report, committee members consulted with governments, child experts, other human rights organizations to formulate a set of principles designed to aprotect fulfill childrenas rightsa in online spaces. committee also engaged those at center of reportayoung people themselves. UNas guidance was not only rooted in research, it treated teens with respect. It listened to them. It's this kind of holistic human rights approach that makes this body of work so influential, especially for child rights advocates. But itas also become a guiding force for Discord. aTeens are going to try things out, figure out who they are, make mistakes online. Discord is focused on guiding them through that process without being overly punitive cutting them off from their support networks their friends,a said Laney Cloyd, a senior product policy specialist. Cloyd her colleagues set out to construct a new warning system for when a teen breaks Discordas rules. They started with idea that young people are going to do regrettable things, like send their friend a link that says, aFortnite cheats herea aCute kitten picsa itas really an IP grabber. They may think it's funny not harmful, but itas still against rules. aWe can't be super punitive on first violation, because they don't know. We have to teach them,a said Cloyd. Of course, when someone violates rules, there should be consequences. But a teensa rights approach considers a personas potential to changeacall it a teachable moment. Teens need extra opportunities to figure out what boundaries are. Itas true when theyare at home with their parents, when theyare at school with their teachers, when theyare on platforms like Discord with its own set of community guidelines. Parents, teachers, coaches are there to tell young people whatas what. Discord saw an opportunity to play that role online: We built interactive educational moments that explain to a person what they did wrong. aAs opposed to just saying, ayou're kicked off, go read our guidelines,a we offer more guidance so they can do better,a said Liz Hegarty, Discordas global teen policy manager. Hegarty pointed to research that shows teens really aren't given great advice about how to handle themselves online. Platforms have a role to play in helping teens build their digital citizenship skills. All of this is part of Discordas philosophy for designing policies that hangs on belief that people are capable of change if you give them a chance, especially when those people are young still learning. They need a chance at rehabilitation. (An important caveat is that some violations are more serious than others, Discord takes appropriate action depending on severity of violation. For example, we have will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy towards violent extremism content that sexualizes children.) It might sound odd that a tech company would borrow ideas from preeminent human rights organization. But consider most foundational tenet of human rights: right to live freely safely. Platforms like Discord are most successful when they enable people to be themselves, have fun, make meaningful connectionsaall without fear threats to their safety well-being. How do teensa rights actually show up on Discord? To illustrate how teensa rights are woven into our warning system, take for example Discordas updated approach to enforcing our Bullying Harassment policy. First, itas helpful to understand that bullying is broken down into a number of different dimensions. One of those includes imminent threats of physical harmafor example, extortion a death threat. For violations of that severity, there are no second chances. Users donat get to do that on Discord. But for non-imminent non-physical threats, Discord has built in more opportunities for teens to get message that bullying isnat allowed. These show up in form of a series of time-outs. Say a teen has been flagged for harassing a useramaybe theyare degrading mocking someone. For their first violation, they would get a notice Discord would remove content. Then second time, theyall get a notice, content will get removed, teen will be placed in aread onlya mode for a set number of hours. If it keeps happening, Discord will apply longer longer time outs. Ultimately if teen doesnat change their behavior continues to engage in harassment sustained bullying, they can receive a yearas suspension. This approach is in contrast to a traditional athree strikes youare outa rule, where most violations, no matter how severe, would count against you, then after three dings, youare banned for good. Discordas more rehabilitative approach takes into account too-real probability that teens are going to make mistakes. aImagine a 14-year-old who falls in with a bad crowd engages in a bunch of bullying gets suspended for a year,a said Cloyd. aIf they return, a 15 year old is going to be a different person in a lot of fundamental ways.a new warning system is also geared toward addressing specific thing a teen did wrong. For example, letas say a teen posts an image that violates Discordas rules. An appropriate measure would be to turn off their ability to post images for a while, but they can still talk to their friends, join voice chats, play games. aWe're taking very targeted interventions not just slamming a big ban hammer down,a said Cloyd. aBecause you posted one wrong image you didn't know was wrong, wead block you out of app forever? That's not fair. That's not a learning experience.a Why do teens need special rights in digital spaces? aWe intuitively recognize that as children get a little bit older, they are autonomous humans. They have agency,a said Hegarty. aThey have right to access online spaces safely.a This goes back to UN document, which Hegarty first encountered before she came to Discord when she worked for a childrenas digital advocacy organization. aThe whole world is fairly new to thinking about how we handle teens in online spaces, especially when more more of their lives are taking place online. It has an impact across everything from telemedicine to education,a said Hegarty. Teens are at a transformative exciting stage of life. They get to explore world in new ways. They use platforms like Discord to find themselves make meaningful connections, but that can't be separated from potential that they'll make mistakes along way. Recognizing thataand helping them grow from itahelps keep everyone safer. Teachable Moments Hidden in Plain Sight Using research to help teens build their 'safety muscle' To do that, Discord works with organizations like Digital Wellness Lab at Boston Childrenas Hospital National PTA to understand needs of one of our largest user bases. aWe are experts in technology, not experts in teenagers. So we need to make sure we are pulling in expert research when we're thinking about what it means to be a safe, healthy ultimately, empowering place for young people,a said Liz Hegarty, Discordas global teen safety policy manager.A A Hegarty her colleagues are guided by research, which is empathetic to teens' lived experiences cautions against being overly paternalistic. For example, Digital Wellness Lab advises parents to resist urge to step in solve every problem for their teen, online off. Instead, they recommend asking probing questions talking through decision-making process. This can clear way to have more conversations about digital boundaries. aThese conversations can help teens build their safety musclea, said Hegarty. We built our Family Center with this idea in mind. Launched in 2023, Family Center is an opt-in tool that enables guardians, trusted adults, teens to alinka their accounts. While it allows parents to know who their teen is connected with, tool does not allow adults to see contents of their teenas conversations with friends. aThe key is to find balance between respecting teen autonomy agency while also giving parents ways to check in with their teensa, said Savannah Badalich, Discordas senior director of policy. aParents trusted adults in a teen's life are here to coach them,a said Badalich, who leads team responsible for key safety areas, such as teen safety mental health. aLet them explore themselves, let them find who they are. But give them parameters in which to do so.a There is a risk that a teen may choose not to talk at all if they feel they are being constantly monitored. This is why it's important to follow research. aLeading experts say that sort of parental surveillance does not always help generate safety create a trustworthy environment for teens to talk to their caregivers,a Hegarty said. Hegarty notes that when building Family Center tool, Discord decided to add an additional layer of support. As a teen connects with their parents, Discord surfaces information for Crisis Text Line (note that this is for users in U.S. only). This is a support line that provides free, 24/7 mental health support via text, WhatsApp, web chat. idea is to provide available resources to teens to encourage them to seek help if they need it. Itas another way we embed subtle lessons throughout experience. Weaving in teachable moments Discordas Teen Safety Assist includes two recently released safety features: one for when a teen receives a direct message (DM) from a user for first time, another that blurs potentially sensitive content in DMs group DMs with friends. When an alert is triggered, teen might see a pop-up that says, Unwanted message? If you donat want to chat with this person, you can block mute them.A They can then click to alearn more,a see a message that prompts aUnwanted message?a, as well as provides a set of tips for handling situation.a a aIt's this idea of educating as opposed to just punishing teenagers when they make mistakes,a said Hegarty. aIn moment, itas important to give teens resources, autonomy, agency, help.a Hegarty points to research about how teens are nervous to block other people. They're worried if person finds out they're blocked, teen is going to look uncool. Meanwhile, if they report, they arenat sure what will happen next. They are anxious about getting somebody in trouble. Research from Thorn, a leading child welfare nonprofit, also suggests that when teens encounter a potentially harmful experience online, they are less likely to seek support offline, such as talking to a trusted adult. So Discord is trying to meet teens where they are. aIt's not a paternalistic approach that protects teens from everything. Being overly restrictive risks them lacking necessary skills to move within world once they turn 18,a said Badalich. aInstead, let's educate them throughout their experience. Let's give them tools to control their experience.a Giving teens opportunities to learn Risk-taking is part of growing up. Itas part of being a teenager. aBecause their brain is still developing, they need options, time education,a said Badalich, whose team is also working to sharpen Discordas enforcement system with teens in mind. When it comes to developing policies rules that govern platform, Badalich her team are rethinking what that looks like, with understanding that teens need extra opportunities to learn. aKeep up, take down, ban have been main levers. we're continuing to explore even more ways to take necessary action,a said Badalich. For example, aWhen you think about someone talking about self-harm, do we really want to penalize them? do we want to figure out some other form of intervention?a To be clear, when it comes to most severe violationsasuch as those involving violent extremism content that sexualizes childrenaDiscord will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy. But when it comes to building out more nuanced, research-driven policies, policy team looks to lessons from restorative justice, a concept that recognizes that people are capable of change. aInstead of just being purely punitive all of time,a said Badalich, aDiscord wants to move in direction of where we are giving people opportunities to change, grow, learn.a Building a Safer Place for Teens to Hang Out Choose what you see who you want to hang with Introducing our new Teen Safety Assist initiative: Teen Safety Assist is focused on further protecting teens by introducing a new series of features, including multiple safety alerts sensitive content filters that will be default enabled for teen users. Starting next week, weare excited to release first two features of Teen Safety Assist initiative. Teens have shared that they like tools that help them avoid unwanted direct messages (DMs) media. To support this, weare rolling out safety alerts on senders sensitive content filters that automatically blur media that may be sensitive a even if sender doesnat initially blur it with a spoiler tag.A a Weave partnered with technology non-profit Thorn to design these features together based on their guidance on teen online safety behaviors what works best to help protect teens. Our partnership has focused on empowering teens to take control over safety how best to guide teens to helpful tips resources. Weare grateful for support of Thorn to ensure we build right protections empower teens with tools resources they need to have a safer online experience. first two features of Teen Safety initiative will start rolling out globally in November 2023 will be turned on by default for teen users. Stay tuned for many more features from this initiative as we look ahead to next year. Work together to keep each other safe We know mistakes happen rules are accidentally broken. Our new Warning System includes multiple touchpoints so users can easily understand rule violations consequences. These touchpoints provide more transparency into Discord interventions, letting users know how their violation may impact their overall account standing gives information for them to do better in future. We built this system so users can learn how to do better in future help keep all hangouts safe.A Some violations are more serious than others, weall take appropriate action depending on severity of violation. For example, we have will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy towards violent extremism content that sexualizes children. Warning System is built based on our teen-centric policies. This is a multi-year, focused effort to invest more deeply holistically into our teen safety efforts. We incorporate teen-centric philosophies in how we enforce our policies, assess risks of new products with Safety by Design, communicate our policies in an age-appropriate manner. For Warning System, this means that we consider how teens are growing, learning, taking age-appropriate risks as they mature, we give them more opportunities to learn from mistakes rather than punish them harshly. Warning System starts rolling out today in select regions. Stay tuned for many more updates to our Warning System in future. a For our server moderators admins, weave recently expanded their safety toolkit with new features that allow them to proactively identify potentially unsafe activity, such as server raids DM spam, take swift actions as needed.A We began rolling these tools in September to Community Servers, now weare rolling them out to all servers. You choose what stays private While you might be an open book with your friends, having your personal business out there for everyone to see can feel a bit weird. Thatas why you get to decide, from server to server, how much you want to share how easy it is to contact you. With Server Profiles, you can adjust to how you present yourself in different spaces, allowing you to be as much of real ayoua as you feel comfortable being in any particular group.A You can also always try turning on Message Requests: a feature that sends any DM from someone new into a separate inbox requires your approval before that user can DM you again. Or, go extra mile turn off DMs entirely from server members unless youave explicitly added them to your friends list. Weave got you PHEW, okaya that was a lot. Thanks for stickina around jamming through our most recent updates with us. Navigating Online Boundaries With Your Teen Weare committed to making Discord a safe place for teens to hang out with their friends online. While theyare doing their thing weare doing our part to keep them safe, sometimes itas hard for parents to know whatas actually going on in their teensa online lives. Teens navigate online world with a level of expertise that is often underestimated by adults in their lives. For parents, it may be a hard lesson to fathomathat their teens know best. But why wouldnat they? Every teen is their own leading expert in their life experiences (as we all are!). But growing up online, this generation is particularly adept at what it means to make new friends, find community, express their authentic selves, test boundariesaall online. But that doesnat mean teens donat need adultsa help when it comes to setting healthy digital boundaries. it doesnat mean parents canat be a guide for cultivating safe, age-appropriate spaces. Itas about finding right balance between giving teens agency while creating right moments to check in with them. One of best ways to do that is to encourage more regular, open honest conversations with your teen about staying safe online. Here at Discord, weave developed tools to help that process, like our Family Center: an opt-in program that makes it easy for parents guardians to be informed about their teenas Discord activity while respecting their autonomy. Here are a few more ways to kick off online safety discussions. If a teen feels like they could get in trouble for something, they wonat be honest with you. So go into these conversations from a place of curiosity first, rather than judgment. Here are a few conversation-starters: Teens will be less likely to share if they feel like parents just donat get it, so asking open questions like these will foster more conversation. Questions rooted in blame can also backfire: teen may not be as forthcoming because they feel like adult is already gearing up to punish them. Read more helpful prompts for talking with your teen about online safety in our Discord Safety Center. Our goal at Discord is to make it a place where teens can talk hang out with their friends in a safe, fun way. Itas a place where teens have power agency, where they get to feel like they own something. Just because your teen is having fun online doesn't mean you have to give up your parental role. Parents trusted adults in a teenas life are here to coach guide them, enabling them to explore themselves find out who they areawhile giving them parameters by which to do so. On Discord, some of those boundaries could include: Using Discordas Family Center feature so you can be more informed involved in your teensa online life without prying. At Discord, weave created several tools to help parents stay informed in touch with their teens online, including this Parentas Guide to Discord Family Center. In spirit of meeting teens where they are, weave also introduced a lighthearted way to spur conversations through a set of digital safety tarot cards. Popular with Gen Z, tarot cards are a fun way for teens to self-reflect find meaning in a world that can feel out of control. messages shown in cards encourage teens to be kind to use their intuition trust their instincts. They remind teens to fire up their empathy, while also reminding them itas OK to block those who bring you down. no, these cards will (unfortunately) not tell you your future! But theyare a fun way to initiate discussions about online safety establish a neutral, welcoming space for your teen to share their concerns. They encourage teens to share real-life experiences stories of online encounters, both positive negative. idea is to get young people talking, parents listening. Sometimes, even as adults, it's easy to get in over your head online. Through our research with parents teens, we found that while 30% of parents said their Gen Zeras emotional mental health had taken a turn for worse in past few years, 55% of Gen Z said it. while some teens acknowledged that being extremely online can contribute to that, more reported that online communications platforms, including social media, play a positive role in their life through providing meaningful community connection. Understanding healthy digital boundaries how they can impact mental wellbeing is important, no matter if youare a teen, parent, any age in-between. When it comes to addressing unique safety needs of each individual, there are resources, such as Crisis Text Line. Trained volunteer Crisis Counselors are available to support anyone in their time of need 24/7. Just text DISCORD to 741741 to receive free confidential mental health support in English Spanish. How To Report Content To Discord Submitting a Report to Discord a next screen will allow you to further specify specific abuse thatas occurring. You can always click back change your first answer, so you can select most relevant category. Alternatively, you may select aDelete Message,a which, as a mod will enable you to report message to our Safety team as well, while removing content from your server. What to do if you receive a violent threat, someone is at risk of Self-harm If a credible threat of violence has been made you someone else are in immediate danger, if someone is considering self-harm is in immediate danger, please contact your local law enforcement agency. Additionally, if you are in United States, you can contact Crisis Text Line to speak with a volunteer crisis counselor to help you a friend through any mental health crisis by texting DISCORD to 741741. A You can learn more about Discordas partnership with Crisis Text line here. You can find more resources about mental health here. What Happens After I Submit a Report? When we become aware of content that violates our Community Guidelines Terms of Service, our Safety team reviews takes necessary enforcement actions, including: disabling accounts, removing servers, when appropriate, engaging with proper authorities. We may not review your report manually respond to you directly, but weall use your report to improve Discord. You can read more about reports we receive actions we take on violations of our Community Guidelines Terms of Service in our quarterly Transparency Report. a Developing Moderator Guidelines Lead by Example moderators are people that your community members look to, not just for enforcement of server rules maintaining peace, but also as role models for what behavior is appropriate for server. If your users see moderators ignoring bending certain rules, they will learn that that is ok for them to do so also, they will call you out if you attempt to hypocritically enforce rules against them. As such, moderators should hold themselves to a higher standard than other users, especially in regards to civility more subjective rules such as what is considered NSFW content. This also applies also for private interactions among mod team. For example, if a moderator is talking in chat shares a suggestive picture, users will understand that other pictures that are equally as suggestive are ok to post. Not only will this encourage borderline rule-breaking behavior, it makes it more difficult for moderators to peacefully moderate NSFW content because users will say aWell, you posted this picture picture I posted is basically same.a same holds true in way moderators respond to questions. If someone asks for help on something moderators respond to them rudely condescendingly others will treat new users same way create a hostile environment. Thatas not to say that moderators canat have fun, of course. Moderators can should participate in chat regularly engage with members as normal users. If a moderator entering chat is disruptive in of itself, it usually means that moderators are not active enough in server. Ultimately, moderators should strive to be seen fondly by server members, yet respected in their positions of authority. Moderators that fail to enforce rules will be seen as unprofessional apushoversa by server members, while moderators that enforce rules too strictly and/or do not participate in chat will be seen as aloof, aggressive, out of touch. Spirit of Rules One of things you may often hear is that aspirit of rulesa is more important than aletter.a In other words, it is more important that people follow intent of rules, rather than adhering to a literal technical definition. As a result, moderators should focus on managing problems of chat, including addressing unhealthy behavior that may not directly break a rule. It is appropriate to moderate people that are deliberately toeing line to see what they can get away with (i.e., trolling), but what many moderator teams also forget is that rules are not infallible, moderators should use their judgment to enforce rules only when it makes sense, not blindly following letter of law. There may be instances where wording specifics of rules end up disallowing behavior that, in practice, does not go against main principle of moderation. In these cases, moderators should refrain from warning user without consulting rest of their mod team also seriously consider modifying rules to more accurately reflect expectations of mod team in regards to server conduct. For example: letas say you have a rule that prevents users from cropping images to focus on sexual body parts in order to prevent NSFW conversations from occurring in chat. However, someone ends up cropping an image of an in game character to focus on her skirt from behind, discussing outfit. In this case, it may not be appropriate to warn user since they are using this image to start an appropriate conversation, even if it technically breaks rule about cropping pictures. So, mod team should discuss ways that rule can be rewritten to cover scenarios like these, rather than resign themselves to warning user abecause rules say so.a Remember: rules exist to serve community, not other way around. Moderators should conduct themselves in accordance with rules, potentially even better, but they ultimately have power to change them for better of server if need be. Treat your rules as a living document remember that they are there to improve your community, not stunt it. When to Forgo Progressive Discipline While certain rules readily offer an ainstant bana option (such as doxxing) in some cases, a useras conduct may reveal that they are only in chat to troll otherwise cause trouble in a way that does not break one of instant ban rules. Just as rules exist to serve community, so too does progressive discipline system. purpose of progressive discipline system is to allow your members to understand their bad behavior rectify it in future without unduly punishing them for occasional small mistakes. Conversely, this means that users that are clearly acting in bad faith on server may not be afforded same leniency should be muted banned depending on circumstances especially if user in question does not have any previously normal chat history. While users that instantly break rules without message history could all be potentially banned, some behavior you may want to consider in particular includes: Itas important that disruptive users be addressed quickly before they sour mood of other server members (which could lead to additional infractions from users that were incited by original bad behavior in first place). Just as moderators should not use rules to punish users that donat practically deserve it, moderators should also be sure not to allow disruptive users to remain on principle of following policy. Other Considerations While principles above are most generally important moderation principles, there may be other things you want to include in your moderator guidelines channel as well such as Always keep in mind any peculiarities of your server questions your moderators might have so that you can proactively address them before they become issues. Summary A moderation guidelines channel is an important channel for helping your moderators get acquainted with both procedural aspects of moderation more subjective aspects. Moderators should be aware that they are leading by example hold themselves to a higher standard so that other users will be encouraged to follow their example. This will help them perform their duties smoothly as well as allow them to readily de-escalate conflicts before they become an issue, encouraging a positive server culture. Finally, by encouraging your moderators to evaluate situations critically, you have mods that can understand both when users should be swiftly punished as well as when rules may need to be adjusted clarified to allow greater flexibility. If youare interested in seeing example moderation guidelines, you can check out link here. Hopefully these help you in developing your own moderation guidelines. Happy moderating! Using XP Systems What Are XP Systems How Do They Work? One of most important factors of keeping a community alive healthy is activity. To maintain activity, moderators can use a few different methods which generally can be separated into two groups: active passive. Active methods are those which require presence active participation of a moderator. Passive methods, on other hand, do not require a constant presence from an individual are often automated by using bots. Keep in mind that even passive methods will require occasional maintenance from a moderator. One of more popular passive methods are XP systems. XP systems, otherwise known as experience leveling systems, grant users experience points (XP) levels based on their activity in a server. Their main purpose is to reward member activity in community. These systems exist in form of bots. Usually they are just one function of multi-purpose bots, but there are cases where sole function of bot is leveling system. basic way these systems work is: These four steps are only a simplification of process, there are many options to consider while using these systems. Depending on bot you choose to use, you can get various options for configuration but there are several that are commonly available on most bots. Some of these options are: Usage of XP Systems main function of XP systems is to reward user activity. Their ability to passively lead users towards being active allows moderators to occasionally take a moment to step back from their usual activities of engaging with their community. existence of a leaderboard appeals to competitive nature of humans pulls them to be more active. Rewards additionally add to this appeal. This is applicable in small, medium some large communities. Alternatively, XP systems can be used as a measure of security. By locking certain permissions behind levels, you can make sure that inactive malicious users are prevented from committing certain offenses. This is mostly applicable in very large servers. Both of these routes will require utilization of roles. There are two main reasons for this: Regulation of Activity As goal of XP systems is to boost activity, it is important to note that they will also lure in users who believe any type of activity is acceptable. This is not case. While problem of spam is already resolved by cooldown ability of most XP systems, there are still behavioral issues that need to be addressed. Members need to be aware that rules still exist in community they cannot simply do as they please. It is important to moderate those who blatantly misbehave in order to level up. Other contributions to community, which are not measured with activity in text voice chat, should also be rewarded, such as artworks, stories, etc. Furthermore, activity that comes from channels which encourage spam-like behavior, such as bot channels, should not count towards total. For that reason, XP gain should be disabled in channels of that sort. Types of XP Systems Knowing that we have ability to reset XP in server, we can use this option to create different types of XP systems. We can divide XP systems into three different types: cyclical, permanent combined. Cyclical systems reset XP points in a regular cycle. Cycle duration should be set based on activity, though it is not advisable to use this system in communities with very low activity. constant resets in leaderboard allow new members to climb charts quickly, but this only lets system be used for rewards. It is common to give out special rewards to most active users at end of cycle, such as custom roles for duration of following cycle, which encourages continued activity to retain their rewards. This also gives moderators opportunity to post announcements regularly at ends of cycles. biggest downside of this system is that not all bots have ability to also remove leveling roles when cycle ends. Permanent systems do not reset at any point in time. Occasionally, users that are banned have left are removed from leaderboards. They give a good look into who most active dedicated users in community are. Permanent systems can be used both for rewards security. Their biggest downside is that they are not very friendly towards new members, especially in older communities. Combined systems are a combination of cyclical permanent systems. They usually require usage of 2 separate bots to keep track of rankings on both leaderboards. They take best aspects of both systems, meaning they can be used both for rewards, which would be connected to cyclical system, security, which would be connected to permanent one. This also allows for cyclical leaderboard to help involve new users more, while still giving good insight of who most active members of all time are with permanent one. only big downside that remains is issue of removing roles from a large number of members. Negative Aspects As with any system, there are several negative aspects to consider when it comes to using XP systems. All of these should be taken into consideration before you make a decision on whether you want to use one. Some of most commonly voiced concerns would be following: fact that these systems encourage sending a larger number of messages automatically leads to idea of spam. Since spam is considered a violation of rules, as well as a ToS violation, this would become a huge problem. issue is easily resolvable, thanks to built in anti-spam measures XP systems have, primarily message cooldown. This, in combination with good moderation would make it certain that no spam is generated by presence of system. Since most XP systems require utilization of roles for truly fulfilling their usage, issue of role bloating comes to mind. It is important to manage space leveled roles properly in order to avoid creating an excessive number of roles with no real use in your server. It is believed that when it comes to rewarding members, rewards should be granted manually through qualitative judgement of content, rather than quantitative. Itas a fact that bots cannot themselves tell quality of messages sent. fact that all types of conversations allow users to gain XP means that there is no meter on what quality of conversation is. Granting privileges as a result of such conversations sends wrong idea of what sort of activity is encouraged. Only humans can truly judge content subjectively to determine quality. By combining proper moderation, for handling judgement of quality, built-in preventive mechanisms of XP systems for quantity control, this issue can be held down to a minimal level. This would be one of most difficult problems of system to resolve. Many members, with intent of increasing their XP count level, will attempt to hold conversation in community. This part of it is perfectly fine. problem arises when they start forcing conversation at any point in time solely to increase their message count. result would be communication that is completely unnatural unhealthy. This type of abuse of system canat really be stopped with cooldown system since most of time it is not spam. only real way to prevent this is to use No XP role, but difficulty of telling organic inorganic communication apart raises question: Was there really any violation of system? Not in every case is an XP system useful for a community. In many cases moderators canat figure out how they can add this sort of system make it seem like a natural part of server, how it can fit theme of community. Considering theme purpose of your server is an important part of making decision of adding a leveling system to your server. Before you make decision, ask yourself: How can I make this system a natural part of my community? Which Bot Do I Use? In following section, several publicly available bots will be presented as options for what you can use for an XP System in your server. following bots have been chosen based on data collected from a survey of various moderators, administrators owners in Discord communities. This list is not exhaustive. There are plenty of alternatives available online. All of listed bots are free public. Some features may be limited to paid additions private versions of bots. content of this article is not endorsed by any bot company related to bots. Gaius Play is an entertainment bot that also hosts an XP system. It takes both text voice chat activity into account. basic version comes with a preset configuration for XP gain leveling, as well as commands for adding rewards up to 6 roles, fully customizing toggling level-up messages, manually controlling XP, ignoring activity in certain channels ability to boost XP gain within certain parameters (roles, channels, time periods). It also has ability to remove leveled roles from all users, making it ideal for use in a cyclical system. Additionally, there are several premium features, such as unlimited reward roles a tree leveling system. Users can also reset their own reward roles in order to change paths on tree leveling system. Amari is a bot that is solely focused on leveling systems. It only looks at activity in text channels. This is a very simple bot, containing commands for setting rewards, manually controlling XP, customizing toggling level-up messages, as well as ignoring activity in some channels. It has ability to have 2 leaderboards active at same time, both of which can be reset at any point. Donor features allow for modification of cooldown between messages, as well as modification of XP gain per message. Nadeko is a multi-purpose bot with a leveling system module. It detects activity exclusively from text chat has a preset configuration for XP gain. It contains commands for setting up reward roles, toggling level-up messages, ignoring activity in channels manually controlling XP. A big upside of this bot is that you have option to host it yourself. This also adds ability to set up in-bot currency rewards, as well as better overall control of bot. Tatsu is another multi-purpose bot with an XP system module. It has several basic commands, allowing creation of reward roles, toggling level-up announcements, modifying XP gain per message cooldown, manual XP control ignoring channel activity. It also features a dashboard a global leaderboard alongside local one. Summary With available selection of bots documentation explaining setup of XP systems, using leveling modules is simpler than ever. configuration options that exist on these modules allow for creative usage of leveling systems with goal of passively increasing activity within community. Naturally, you have to consider several factors prior to deciding on using XP systems. If you are considering using one, think of how you can best integrate it into your community. In which way will you use it? Which type of system would suit your community best? Which bot would be best for task? Of course, there are negative aspects to consider as well, meaning youad have to figure out how to control minimize them. Carefully weigh all pros cons prior to making a final decision. Creating Moderation Team Channels Moderation Channel Setup Once confident in channel permissions that lock access to your private moderation channels, itas important to think about what you want your moderation channels to look like. larger server more channels you may need to accommodate everything. An important rule of thumb is to make sure that your moderation channels are an exception to any auto-moderated actions your moderation bot may be taking, that automoderator is configured not to act on messages from moderators. No blacklists should be in effect in these channels to ensure proper discussion of punishments happenings in server can be discussed truthfully respectfully. Itas also important to ensure that any message logging is configured to ignore channels that not all moderators have access to. For example, if all of your moderators can see a general action log channel, but you have a separate channel for a lead chat, deleted edited messages from that channel should not be logged for privacy reasons. More about this can be found below. Structurally, it is recommended to have informational channels at top of your moderation channel category to make sure everyone sees them. Anything that should be easily viewable by team follows, such as an update channel moderation/action logging based channels. Channels restricted to smaller groups of moderators should be closer to bottom as less people have access to these, partnership channels meant to maintain relations as opposed to direct moderation connections can be on bottom. A sample of a large staff channelset can be found below. a a Weall now begin to outline a variety of channels that are often useful for moderation purposes. below list is for your consideration when building your own moderation channel category, but by no means should you feel obligated to add every channel discussed below to your server. This is all about recognizing your needs making sure they are met! Every moderation team should have a developed moderation handbook that is easily accessible to all team members updated regularly. However, some moderation teams like to have an overview channel for rule enforcement for quick referencing. This channel can contain information such as how you categorize punishments, an overview of popular commands for easy referencing after returning from a moderation break, links to all guidelines moderation forms for easy coordination. We recommend that this channel is viewable to all moderators, but Send Message permissions for informational channels like this should be limited to server owner administrators to ensure only important select information is fed into channel. Additionally, denying Manage Message permissions to everyone but administrators is also recommended to ensure that these informational messages arenat deleted. Action logs are most important moderation channels out there, but also busiest. Moderation action logs exist for a variety of purposes, you can configure them however you see fit. Some recommended actioning channels include, but are not limited to: Like your server, your moderation team can have a general channel. While it is important for your moderators to moderate, itas also important for your team to bond. This is best achieved by having a space that is not dedicated to moderation. It exists to talk to each other, get to know each other, build rapport in your team environment. Moderation can be stressful, this is where you can go to take a break with your teammates. However, it is important to maintain same set of moderation expectations here as you would in public channels. An occasional vent is understood acceptable, but you should avoid speaking negatively of server members that can taint a moderation experience. While itas important to bond with your teammates, it is also important to bond with your server members as well. Chatting in server itself is just as encouraged as getting to know your fellow moderators. If you enable community server option for your server, youall have updates fed to a chosen channel. As these will be major community-based updates for moderation purposes, it is often recommended to have them feed to a moderation update memo based channel for ease of viewing. Channels that serve this purpose can be used for a variety of reasons including announcing extended absences from team for vacations mental health purposes to avoid burnout, taking team-wide votes, making announcements for moderator removals, departures, promotions, initiatives team is pursuing. Many servers use a single channel as a catch-all update arena as it serves a very specific purpose will not be used daily. Although there are a variety of ways to organize your team hierarchy, in addition to regular moderators most mod teams also have administrators who are responsible for overseeing regular moderators. Some mod teams also make a distinction between regular moderators moderators-in-training, who may have different permissions compared to regular moderators otherwise be subject to additional scrutiny during their training period.
