If these distinctions exist within your own mod team, it may be wise to create separate administrator channels training channels. Administrator Channels - An administrator chat is necessary to speak about private matters on team. This is to judge general moderation performance, handle punishments for problematic actions internally, it also serves as a place to handle any reports against moderators to ensure privacy. Please remember, it is important that these messages are not caught up in bot logging so moderators are not made aware of fact that they are being discussed privately before leads connect with them. Training Channels - General permissions granted to all moderators will not yet be accessible to moderator trainees, thus some teams consider locking their access to select channels. There will need to be a space for all moderators leads to privately discuss growth of trainees without them gaining access even after promotion. Some teams may go as far as to establish a unique action log channel used during training periods before giving them access to full history of moderation team once they prove their ability to be unbiased moderators. Again, it is important to ensure that discussion channels for trainees are exceptions to basic bot logging to avoid awkward occurrences with trainees seeing commentary about them that they should not see yet. There are a plethora of moderation channels that can benefit a team in unique circumstances that donat fit into above categories. Consider following when thinking about what fits best for how your community is run: If your community is linked to an external community such as Reddit Twitch, it would be useful to have separate moderation channels dedicated to this external community in addition to your Discord moderation channels. Reddit moderation channels specifically can be created by utilizing webhooks. Reddit moderation spaces housed on Discord often have r/modnews updates feeding into a special update area channel sets unique to their external community needs. You can also have new posts comments logged into a designated Reddit action log for easy reference without opening Reddit. Teams that have a separate Reddit Twitch moderation team in addition to their Discord moderation team may have designated hangout spaces for all teams to get to know each other casually. But, most importantly, they may have shared moderation spaces to discuss troublemakers that can span multiple platforms to flag problematic users for other team. Easy specialized communication across teams will help to keep all facets of your community safe! Conclusion There is no right wrong way to set up a moderation channel category outside of ensuring you utilize correct permissions. Itas important to consider needs of your community how their needs translate to needs of your team when creating your moderation space. Having flexibility a willingness to grow as your server grows requires change is imperative. While action logs are most useful kind of moderation channels from a punishment perspective, hangout spaces are important to establishing team cohesion rapport. Identifying needs of your team making sure they are adequately met will help you create strongest moderation environment as possible. Schools X Discord Benefits of Using Discord in Classrooms Lots of new opportunities are created for schools who make use of a private Discord server. One of biggest opportunities is presented in a cultural shift away from formality closer to general bonding. Gone are days of formal communications over e-mail instead we have open chat discussions with teachers, fellow classmates, group project members, even private one-on-oneas (similar to office hours!) when necessary. In this section we seek to discuss many ways that Discord can help virtual learning. Discord can function as a virtual classroom setting in ways that can generate new opportunities for continued reliable teamwork while enabling new exciting ways for students to connect with each other. Utilizing Discord as a Virtual Classroom While certain permissions are essential to creating an environment that separates teachers student private chats subjects, a classroom environment acts as overall hub for everything necessary from a full school, to a specific classroom, to separate groups working on projects, even a variation of subjects being taught. Simultaneously, a server can be set up to serve a variety of school-related functions including, but not limited to: Discord naturally lends itself to communication in ways that allow students to help each other. If one student is stuck on an assignment, any student can answer their question perhaps join them in a study session to work out problem together. Schoolwork can feel less solitary, there is less of a reliance on teachers aids, students who may be taking same subject in different classes can meet each other help each other out. This also allows teachers to monitor such a space to gain insight as to where their students are struggling so they can adjust their lesson plans accordingly. Interaction with each other doesnat have to be limited to just typing in designated channels. Students can interact with each other teachers while using subject specific audio and/or video channels as well, allowing them to have more personal interactions cater to different learning styles. However, if you are using these channels to broadcast a lesson not promote group work, make sure that you disable voice activity for students to avoid accidental noise from being broadcasted throughout your online classroom. This helps create a controlled environment for all involved in virtual classroom space. An example about how to do this is below. Discordas Easy to Use Interface Will Make Students Feel at Home Discord was created for housing online communities which sets it apart from other routes taken for e-learning platforms. Your students staff will feel at home in Discord user interface because it is easy to use made for quick adaptation. natural familiarity that many students may bring from their personal usage of platform even other similar platforms will reduce friction of adopting into new virtual learning atmospheres more easily help transition Discord into their daily educational routines. A common complaint in larger classroom settings, both in person virtually, is that environment is impersonal. In a sea of many faces, it is understandable that a student may feel like just another number on attendance roster. However, Discordas premise of providing an easily built space meant for easy informal communication can reduce this lack of personal connection instead help students feel welcome, including, easily engaged. a There is Always Fun to be Had in a Healthy Community When creating your virtual classroom it is important to keep in mind what you want purpose of your server to be. A server for a specific math classroom taught by Mr. Wumpus at noon everyday is going to be geared entirely towards education, whereas a more open-concept Algebra server that welcomes all students currently enrolled in course under various teachers to have a more common meeting space while also being split into their respective virtual classrooms via permissions allows for antics in addition to education. Educational settings can also be fun if you choose to build them that way. There is always fun to be had in a healthy community when school day finishes, providing this hang out space for students will allow them to not only bond but associate positive feelings with school. There can be spaces designated to help students study together in after school hours perhaps come together to take a study break to play one of their favorite games. A music bot can be used to listen to music in an essay-writing sprint, a leveling system can be used to reward students for participation. Community feelings lead to happiness, which can impact mental health grading. Discord is an Extension of your Physical Campus Discord also brings many advantages to educational arenas outside of classroom. A server can be viewed as an extension of your physical campus to Internet in an e-learning environment. Similar to a real-life campus, Discord is a meeting place for students staff to chat, get to know each other, build a stronger community in places they feel safe. Shy students may even find it easier to bond better in an online environment than a physical one which can lead to generating new friendships while also improving pre-existing ones. Students who perceive a welcoming environment have positive feelings about their school community will often get better grades because of higher motivations levels. Interestingly, a further extension of a physical campus would be to an alumni association. While school related Discord servers are often for study tools virtual classrooms, they can also serve as special places for alumni to connect after graduation. They can not only catch up with their old classmates, but they can mentor current students as well. Such a situation can be brought about via unique ideas like career fairs oriented towards advising current students about future career options by making use of a schoolsa alumni network. Disadvantages of Using Discord as a School Platform As mentioned above, Discordas widespread usage for personal gaming easy to use interface means that a lot of students could already use Discord in their free time begin to adopt it into their lives after being introduced to it in a classroom setting. person someone may present themselves as online can differ from who they are in real life. When given opportunity to use a profile picture, set usernames nicknames, even statuses, things can get out of hand quickly. It may even be difficult for some teachers to identify which student is behind certain accounts if these expectations arenat established immediately upon server creation. With likely change that a student might not want to use a picture of themself as their profile picture, it is important to establish server guidelines about what is appropriate to be in that photo. While some users may not be comfortable using their full name even their first name in their username, set expectation that everyone has to change their nickname in your private school-related Discord servers to their real name. On a related note, if a user is subscribed to Discord Nitro, they may also change their profile picture on an individual server basis. However, it's not required in order to use Discord on whole. Our recommendation if a student is uncomfortable with using their real picture for their platform-wide account is to tell them to make a secondary account specifically for school where they can use a photo of themselves. With Discord's account switcher feature having a second account for this purpose is less of hassle. Finally, when students first enter server, we recommend enabling Developer Mode to privately connect each individual User ID to a student should someone alter change their identity/account information in future. This could be done through schools information management system, just by using a spreadsheet. It is also imperative to reiterate boundary that you expect everything present in virtual school ecosystem to be school appropriate. Features like profile pictures, username, status are platform-wide features that appear in all servers a user is in. What is appropriate in some spaces may not be appropriate in school. Consider this ahead of time to establish rules around this also punishments should this not be respected. It is important to keep in mind that Discord does have strict Terms of Service Community Guidelines that state users arenat allowed to use NSFW content other forms of illegal content as their username, profile picture, and/or status. This will partly make sure content on their profiles is acceptable to a degree. However, you may not be comfortable if a student is cursing in your virtual classroom that can be dealt with accordingly by you. Conclusion Discordas very purpose is to foster communication by bringing users an easy to understand interface that is adaptable to a variety of needs, thus making it a really useful modern tool for e-learning virtual classrooms. With right permissions, students can be brought into environments where they can not only learn, but also have fun in a virtual extension of their physical campus. Through utilization of a variety of ways to teach classrooms communicate amongst groups, Discord naturally fosters teamwork open forum discussions between students teachers alike. However, Discord is still a platform with millions of users exploring a variety of interests. Itas important to enter Discord prepared to handle students who may be using inappropriate media for school via platform-wide features like profile pictures, statues, usernames because they are appropriate elsewhere. If you consider logistics of creating a safe, school-appropriate environment set expectations guidelines upon entry, Discord is a great tool for your future educational needs! Confidentiality in Moderation Considerations Regarding Leadership Whichever moderation roles a server may have, there should always be an authority role that can make calls at their discretion if they believe it is best thing for community. A good example on how to do just that can be found here. Moderation administrators, leaders, managers, etc. should always be prepared ready to make judgment calls on information provided to them, whether by mods users. A very common misconception among moderation teams is that they should share all information amongst team for transparency. This can be a double-edged sword in sense that disclosing private information that is not essential for a moderator can open more routes for that information to have unauthorized distribution. If this occurs, it will compromise privacy trust of users that information applies to. In sensitive situations containing very volatile information, consider if it may be beneficial to have it handled directly by a team leader even owner of community. Personally identifiable information (or PII) is any information that can identify a user, such as an email address, full name, phone number, IP address, exact location, even their Discord user ID username. People should never disclose someoneas personal information except their own in an appropriate environment, as disclosing othersa info can be treated as doxxing, which is a disclosure of personal info by a third party (for example, someone posting another useras address), can, in some instances, be actioned on by Trust Safety as it may violate Discordas Terms of Service/Community Guidelines. User IDs usernames are acceptable as long as there is a justifiable need to disclose it, but make sure to always consider if there may be repercussions to that user if disclosed in any instance. PII is very sensitive as it removes a useras privacy can result in them being targeted online even in real life. Thus, this information should always be protected with utmost discretion. Moderators may come in contact with this in ways such as a message they have to delete, someone maliciously doxxing another person, a user accidentally sharing it without realizing harm they are putting themselves in even from information included in a report. This information typically should not be disclosed to anyone community leaders should consider removing it from bot logging channels to protect a useras identity. Also consider encouraging members of your community to learn how to safeguard their own information. You can include rules within your communities that discourage sharing of even oneas own personal information. As important as it is to protect other users, it is just as important to help them protect themselves. Users may sometimes share their information out of good will as a way of attempting to bond with others, but bad actors can use that information maliciously. Personal matters can refer to a huge range of information, but some common examples can include relationships, interpersonal conflicts, previous history, things as simple as a DM private conversation. As a moderator you may very likely come across information involving this as part of reports, concerns, even someone breaching trust by screenshotting sharing private messages. This information is extremely important to protect as people may trust you to keep it private use it only to take care of issue at hand. Exposures of this information can be very harmful to people can result in targeted harassment, bullying, even further negative consequences. Stories of this can cause people to be concerned even worried about reporting something for fear of it happening to them. In end, this makes things very difficult for moderators to not only reassure, but to rectify. Most public communities have ways of protecting their server with moderation tools, actions, procedures. This includes moderator actions such as warnings, kicks, mutes, bans, etc. Moderation actions may be especially important when it involves a specific user. A Moderation info can even include internal details such as protocol, procedure, censor lists, even bot details. Moderation information is something that can vary from server to server, thus it is relatively up to discretion of each moderation team to instill their own server rules to enforce. Some may have full transparency with an open log channel, some may take a more confidential approach only speak with those involved. Both have their pros cons, but be sure to weigh what could happen if people know who receives what penalties. For protocol, always remember to carefully decide what to share publicly, as disclosing a procedure can lead to someone using that information to evade moderators even exploit server. This also stands true with bots, as disclosing bot details such as configuration censor list can result in users evading protections put in place by your team. a There are many different forms of information that must be considered heavily before disclosing to different people, whether they be users other mods. Information can range from sensitive personal information such as emails, names, phone numbers, location, IP address, etc. to community-related information such as mod actions, previous incidents, user history. Regarding users, very little should be shared to people who are not involved. When it comes to fellow mods, it is always best to share as much information as is reasonable aside from personal information to ensure everyone has a well-informed mindset. Some questions to consider when speaking with users include: Now for mods members of more internal team on servers, mods should of course be ain loopa to know story of a situation, itas never recommended to keep mod teams in dark. That being said, even with other moderators, be careful about sharing unnecessary information, especially personally-identifying information, not only because there is often little benefit to it, but primarily because it compromises a useras privacy even if behind closed doors. A While there are fewer factors to consider, they are still just as important as ones you would ask for another user. Some things to consider when disclosing to moderators include: Remember that if you arenat sure if you should disclose something related to moderation, always ask an administrator/leader on your server for guidance, always dispose of private information if it is not needed. Benefits of Confidentiality It may be easier to be fully transparent not have to check every sentence before it is said sent. That being said, there are many benefits to upholding a consistent, confidential environment where staff act with discretion when assisting with a variety of matters. There are many consequences if confidentiality is not upheld properly. Below are some examples of benefits of protecting information as well as consequences that can come with being overly transparent. Keeping Pseudonymous. As stated by Discordas Safety Principles, Discord is pseudonymous, which means that your account on Discord doesnat need to be tied back to your identity. A Protecting users who may provide information as evidence otherwise may sometimes expose who they are, protecting this information reassures that their personal life wonat be compromised by socializing confiding in a serveras staff. Trust. Users will know of hold high trust within a staff team if they are confident that high expectations of privacy will be respected by team they confide in. If not upheld, users will find it difficult to trust team, may heavily contemplate even refrain contacting a moderation team again in future. User Safety. Diligent protection of user data information helps protect users as it prevents unwanted data from getting into wrong hands. If information is not guarded, information that gets into wrong hands can result in targeted harassment bullying, as many private details can reveal information to malicious individuals. Moderator Safety. Keeping moderation actions confidential only disclosing information to people who need to know helps to keep moderator anonymity reinforces idea of a team decision. Disclosing moderation actions who performed them can put a target on mod, as people may treat them personally responsible for an action may result in harassment disrespect from users who may not understand decision. Personally identifiable information being shared outside of need to know groups can result in compromising users making them feel as if they may need to sacrifice their Discord to retain personal privacy. This leads to a loss of trust from member, perhaps even loss of them as a member of your community. Designing Server for Privacy There are multiple things to be mindful of when considering privacy confidentiality, it extends well beyond standard moderation. Often, privacy will fall down to way that server is configured. Some things to consider include: Server Discoverability. If an LGBTQ+ server is in Server Discovery, a user may use an emote from that server in another one, if someone clicks on emote, it may accidentally expose user as they may identify as LGBTQ+ privately but not publicly. Public Join Messages. Some servers may have awelcome botsa even Discordas welcome feature that greets new users publicly upon joining. Server staff should take into account type of community that they stand for, consider if users may perhaps feel uncomfortable exposed by being mentioned immediately upon joining. Security. Automated security agatekeeper botsa may be used to prevent malicious users from joining a server on alt accounts as part of malicious groups. While this seems perfectly normal, part that has to be considered is what data you are requesting. Some of these bots may collect IP addresses, browser data, various other forms of information. Users may not be comfortable in supplying information that could compromise who they are. Always make sure to read through privacy statement of any bot that you add to ensure that you are not asking for too much information from regular members. Bot Logging. Many servers have private log channels maintained by one more bots. This tracks joins, leaves, deleted edited messages, even more. There are two main points to be wary of with these: if personal information is posted for any reason, be it accidentally by misclick maliciously to dox a user, it will usually appear in a moderator logging channel when deleted. After situation has been dealt with, owners admins should consider deleting log message to prevent personal information from persisting within that channel. Keeping Balance There are pros cons to any level of disclosure that is offered by a server to its community its staff. It is not black white there are gray areas in both transparency revealing select information with moderator discretion. There must always be a balance of both that may shift depending on situation at hand type of community that is present. Just as complete confidentiality will lead to distrust, total transparency will lead to users feeling unprotected due to a lack of privacy. Ban Evasion Advanced Harassment Understanding High Conflict Persons (HCPs) vast majority of community members are interested willing to participate according to platform rules, even if they might not agree with every one of them. Sometimes people break rules disagree, but their behavior can be quickly corrected they can learn from their mistakes. If users continue to break rules, they may be given longer-term even permanent bans from community platform. Most users will accept their ban, but a small fraction will not. A 2018 study by Stanford University estimated that 1% of subreddit communities on Reddit initiate 74% of all conflict on platform. This incredibly small percentage of users rank extremely low in agreeableness personality trait, have no interest in getting along with others. Only a trained clinical psychologist can diagnose a patient with a disorder, but a term commonly used prior to diagnosis is HCP (high-conflict people). There are four primary characteristics of high conflict personalities, which is not a diagnosis but their description of specific conflict behavior: If you fail to use tact in your moderation technique communication approaches, you may find that you your community become target of a high-conflict person. They may spam your community you may delete their posts ban their accounts, but more accounts can be created. Discord uses IP bans to prevent users from creating new accounts, but VPNs can be used to circumvent these bans. If truly motivated, armies of bot accounts can be created used for mass-spamming, members of your community can be doxed, ISPs platforms can be DDoSad to create fear in your community. If a high-conflict person gains access to money, they can pay somebody else to do work for them. Most moderators choose to simply wait out harassment. Advanced harassment like this may go on for several days, even weeks, but then stop abruptly as individual turns their attention to something new in their life. In some cases harassment can go on for months, continuing to escalate in new ways that may put lives of your team community members in danger. What can you do to protect your community from High Conflict Persons? What motivates a person to behave like this? This article will help to explain motivations behind this persistent, destructive behavior, provide actionable steps to reduce resolve their harassment. Virtue of Battling a Nemesis A anemesisa is an enemy rival that pursues you relentlessly in search for vengeance. A nemesis typically holds some degree of fascination for a protagonist, vice versa. Theyare an antagonist whoas bent on revenge, who doesnat go away, who seems to haunt mind of protagonist. Theyave moved past being an enemy to become something much more personal. You might assume that a high-conflict person harassing your community is your nemesis, but this would be incorrect. Youare not going out of your way to obstruct their behavior, your primary focus is to engage moderate your community. If harassment stopped, you would move on forget about their behavior. You resist their behavior only as long as it falls under your realm of influence. In their mind, you have become their nemesis, you must be punished for your insolence. To them, you are Architect of an oppressive Matrix, President Snow of an authoritarian Hunger Games, tyrannical Norsefire government in V for Vendetta. You your community represent opposite of what they believe. In one way another, either by your direct actions through your association with your community, you have wronged them deserve to suffer for your behavior. Itas clear that you will never learn understand what they see. You not only participate in creating corrupt unjust system that they are oppressed by fight against, but as a moderator, you are very lynchpin that maintains corrupt system. You may believe this sounds outlandish, you would be correct. Most people donat believe that world is out to get them, that theyall be hunted down persecuted for what they believe. These individuals have an overactive threat detection system that makes them believe that you your community are actively plotting their downfall. They take your opposing stance as a direct challenge to their competence, authority autonomy. They harass you your community because they believe that youare out to get them, want to replace them their way of life. truth is, all you really want them to do is follow rules maintain a civil conversation. Understanding Tactical Empathy Now that you have a better understanding of how somebody like this thinks, weall discuss strategies that you can employ to solve this problem. goal is NOT to get them to seek help change their mind- we arenat attempting to solve people. Instead, our goal is to prevent stop certain negative behaviors that keep happening so that you can protect your community focus your energy elsewhere. key to getting an individual like this to change their behavior is through utilizing atactical empathya. Tactical empathy is use of emotional intelligence empathy to influence anotheras behavior establish a deal relationship. It is not agreeing with them, but just grasping recognizing their emotions positions. This recognition allows us to act appropriately in order to respond to our counterpartas position in a proactive deliberate manner. premise behind tactical empathy is that no meaningful dialogue takes place when we are not trusted we are perceived as a threat. In order to get someone to stop harassing your community, you need to shift yourself from being villain of their story to being just another random person in their lives. You must work to shatter persona that they have projected onto you show that you are not enemy working to destroy them. Youare just a mod trying to keep your community safe. By demonstrating that you understand respect them as an individual, this will disarm them allow them to focus their energy elsewhere. It will not change their opinion, but at least their behavior will change. A Modas Guide to Situation Diffusal When somebody continues to harass disrupt your community, theyare essentially holding your community hostage. If someone truly is holding your community ahostagea, theyare often doing so because theyare looking to open a dialogue for negotiation. Frequently, people take hostages because they need somebody to listen. They arenat getting attention that they believe they deserve, attempt to cause as much disruption as possible in order to make their case. You are a community moderator negotiating peace of your community, not their lives, but these tactics can still apply. Situation diffusal can generally be defined by three primary processes, each designed to collect information use it to disarm high-conflict person from believing that youare an enemy threat. These processes are called Accusations Audit, Mirroring to Understand Getting to aThatas Righta. An accusations audit is where you focus not on just things that they believe, but things that they believe you did wrong. An accusation Audit is not based on logic - itas based on unfiltered emotions of other person. Itas important that you go through their early comments messages to understand what prompted this behavior in first place. This might have been banning them for breaking a rule not properly punishing another community member that they got into an argument with. They might believe aI feel like you didnat give me a chance to explain myselfa aI feel like youare discriminating against mea. Your understanding of their beliefs will be flawed inaccurate, but you must do your best to piece it together into a coherent argument on their behalf. If possible, learn more about other communities theyare a part of. Identify if theyare harassing any other communities, reasons for doing so. Are there any commonalities of note? Once you believe youave figured out why theyare upset with you your community, mirror their language to verify it. At this point, opening a dialogue might be incredibly difficult if theyare using throwaway accounts regularly. Chances are they do have a primary account they continue to use in other communities, which can help greatly with starting your dialogue. At this stage, youare still working to collect information about what they believe, directly from source. Examples of questions you can use to verify their opinions include, aIt seems like you believe that Iam being unfair because I didnat give you a chance to explain yourself.a aIf I understand correctly, you believe Iave been discriminating against you instead of taking your opinion seriously, is that right?a Chances are, responses you receive will be filled with aggression, profanity insults. You must ignore all of this, continue working to understand their position events that resulted in them targeting your community. Negotiations like this are difficult in voice-to-voice communication, nearly impossible via instant private messaging. They will be incredibly resistant at first, perhaps thinking that youare attempting to trick them into a perjury trap for them to admit their guilt ignorance. When you get them talking to you, mirror that language to get them to elaborate further on their beliefs. An example of dialogue might go something like following: Spammer: aItas bullshit that mods ban strawberry jam lovers because blueberry jam lovers are afraid of being exposed for who they really are.a Mod: aAfraid of being exposed?a Spammer: aYeah, blueberry jam lovers are secretly running world plotting against anyone who doesnat believe in same jam flavor preferences as they do.a Realistically, blueberry jam lovers are not actually running world plotting anything nefarious, but in mind of spammer this is undeniably true. while this example was intentionally mild, you can infer more severe types of conversations that would follow a similar format. Regardless, as you dig further into what they believe, youall notice that rabbit hole will go very deep be filled with logical fallacies obviously disprovable biases that make no sense. Remember that truth reality behind what they believe is completely irrelevant, attempts to correct them will undermine your goals. Your job is to help them explain their beliefs to you to best of their ability, for you to understand their position to best of your ability. Once you believe youave collected enough information, you can move to final step, getting to aThatas Right.a Once you believe youave completely understood their position what they believe, you can repeat their entire position back to them. Demonstrate your understanding by effectively summarizing it concisely accurately, regardless of how much you disagree with position. Donat focus on their behavior actions that resulted in them getting banned. Instead, focus exclusively on ideology that drove their behavior. Do this until youare able to get them to say aYes, thatas righta at least 3 times, by asking if thereas anything else that you forgot in your summary. If you did miss anything, repeat entire position again while including extra information. When reiterating their points, be very careful about restating things that are not true. Do your best to remove personal bias from statements to focus them back to aabsolute truths.a Their actions are about trying to make a point- but what youare doing is getting them to make their point without taking action, because you have heard what they are trying to say. If you do this well enough, if you put enough effort into doing this correctly (and it doesnat need to be perfect), they will know that you finally understand where theyare coming from that theyave been heard by you, their opinion has been validated. By demonstrating you understand their position, you go from being part of problem to being a real person. They might not like you, but they will at least (if begrudgingly so) respect you. When you successfully reach this state of your discussion, itas essential that you be careful with your choice of words. Thereas a good chance that spammer will leave your community alone now that they know that their opinion has been recognized. At very least, you should see an immediate reduction in number of times they attempt to cause harm. If they do continue to harass you your community, itas possible that you failed to address primary reason that theyare upset. Open dialogue with them again follow steps above from beginning, check to see that you havenat fallen into a common pitfall mistake. Common Pitfalls Mistakes Below is a list of common examples of mistakes people make during negotiations: When using tactical empathy, remember that purpose of exercise is to bring their beliefs to conscious mind demonstrate agreement. If you attempt to tell them what they should believe, you may instead get a ayouare righta fail to see any change. difference is subtle, but important. Make sure that other side actually feels heard, that youave fully understood their position. Donat Try to Correct their Opinion As a reminder: do not attempt to correct modify their opinion. Remember purpose of this process. It is not to modify their position opinion, itas only to mirror their opinion to stop identifying you your community as a threat. methodology outlined in this article is designed for conversations in real-life, especially over phone. Itas unlikely that youall be able to get spammer on an audio call, so itas essential to be patient with process careful with your wording. Formal grammar like punctuation can make a sentence feel more serious threatening. Use casual phrasing make an occasional spelling mistake to show youare human. If youare uncertain about tone, read sentence out loud while sounding as angry as you can, adjust accordingly. process outlined here can be easily undermined by others who arenat involved in process. If youare working to negotiate with a spammer but another moderator is threatening them in a different conversation, you wonat see any changes in their behavior. Communicate with your team on strategy you plan to use, remember to ask for emotional support step away if it becomes too taxing. Can High-Conflict People be Helped? There will be some of you who believe that after getting this far, you may be on path to rehabilitating a person like this. mistake is believing that you are further along than you really are, that youare qualified to help someone struggling to control their emotions. truth is, getting to athatas righta is only 1% of process. Even if youare a clinical psychologist, you wouldnat be getting paid for your work, at least not this work. Attempting to provide support via text chat will have diminishing returns. Attempting to show somebody like this aerror of their waysa may result in all of work you have done being reversed. Instead, you must focus on people who want your help who need it- this being people in your community. Empower people who are truly deserving of your time energy. At end of day, youare a human a moderator. Your primary focus in this realm is to make sure your community is safe stays safe- if youave managed to get persistent spammer to stop then youave accomplished what it is youave aimed to do. Facilitating Positive Environments Introduction core foundation of a server on Discord is community that populates it. Your community is what you engage with, protect, grow over time. Engagement is important to focus on, but itas just as important to make sure you are facilitating positive welcoming engagement. Why Positive Environments are Important Positive engagement can mean a lot of things, but in this article, we will be referring to way in which moderation can affect culture of server you are moderating. As moderators your policies, knowledge of your community, deductive skills influence way in which your community engages with each other with your team. When you establish nurture your community, you are growing a collective group of people who all enjoy at least some of same things. Regardless of your server topic, you are undoubtedly going to have members across different a variety of ethnicities, sexual orientations, identities from across world. Ensuring that your space on Discord is a space for them to belong necessitates making it safe for them to feel like they can be themselves, wholly, without reservation. Your members are all humans, all community members, all people that deserve respect deserve to be welcomed. Establishing Community Boundaries in Moderation When you are establishing your community, itas important to have a basic understanding of what kind of environment you would like your server to be. Itas good to break down general moderation philosophy on what content discussion youad like your community to engage in what content would be inappropriate given space. Depending on topic of your server these goals may be different, but some common questions you can ask to establish general boundaries are: Moderating Hateful Content When it comes to content you allow moderate in your server, itas important to, again, reflect on what type of community you are. Itas also important that you act quickly precisely on this type of harmful behavior. Some users will slowly push boundaries on what type of language they can aget away witha before being moderated. When discussing moderation, a popular theory that circulates is called broken windows theory. This theory expresses that if there are signs of antisocial behavior, civil unrest disorder, as well as visible signs of crimes in area, that it encourages further anti-social behavior crime. Similarly, if you create an environment in which toxic hateful behavior is common, cycle will perpetuate into further toxicity hatefulness. What is Bad-Faith Content vs. Good-Faith Content? aBad-faitha content is a term that describes behavior done intentionally to cause mischief, drama, A toxicity to a community. They are also commonly referred to as bad actors, are type of people that should be swiftly dealt with addressed directly. aGood-faitha content is a term that describes user behavior with good intentions. When users are a positive foundation in your community, members that join interact with established community will grow to adapt speak in a way that continues positive environment that has been fostered established. Itas important to note that while agood-faitha users are generally positive people, it is possible for them to state wrong sometimes even harmful words. importance of this distinction is that these users can be educated from their mistakes adapt to behavior you expect of them. When users toe line, they are not acting within good faith. As moderators, you should be directly involved enough to determine what is bad-faith content remove it. On other hand, education is important in community sphere for long term growth. While you can focus on removing bad behavior from bad-faith users, reform in good-faith community members who are uneducated in harmful rhetoric should also be a primary goal when crafting your community. When interacting in your community, if you see harmful rhetoric a harmful stereotype, step back meaningfully think about implications of leaving content up in channels that use this kind of language. Does it: Ideas to Help Prioritize Inclusivity A core way to handle all de-escalation stands in your approach. Users, when heated up during a frustrating toxic discussion, are easy to set off to accidentally escalate to more toxicity. key is to type calmly, to make sure with whatever manner you approach someone to de-escalate, you do it in a way that is understood to be for benefit of everyone involved. Closing Creating a healthy community that leaves a lasting, positive impact in its members is difficult. Moderators have to be aware, educated, always on lookout for things they can improve on. By taking initiative on this front, your community can grow into a positive, welcoming place for all people, regardless of their race, gender, gender identity, sexual orientation. Fundamentals of Family-Friendly Servers How Family-Friendly Servers Differ From Other Servers Because you are dealing with young people, family-friendly servers may become what many refer to as Home Servers. These are online communities that are perceived to be safe spaces that people come back to time again, like a home. Thus, such servers may attract users for different purposes than a community meant for college students might, for example. moderators of family-friendly servers can be viewed as both authoritative figures but also older siblings friends that may be looked up to by their community in unique parasocial relationships. They will also have unique experience of seeing many of their young users mature grow along with server. When forming this kind of environment, itas important to make sure your moderators are naturally empathetic to unique situations that will arise within member reports as a result of interpersonal relationships amongst younger users. During foundational stages of server building make sure to keep ideas such as privacy concerns, text filters, appropriate topics of discussions, rule continuity at forefront of your mind. Consider how you will handle users who are above traditional age range of family-friendly servers who may not wish to abide by these rules. While privacy concerns exist on any platform, they are something to be especially aware of when moderating family-friendly spaces. Rules that cover privacy internet safety may be more strictly enforced to protect younger server members from any harmful actors looking to take advantage of less experienced internet users. Oftentimes, these concerns can culminate in a blanket rule stating that sharing any personally identifying information in server is not allowed. This goes beyond exact locations can include full names, ages, even face reveals. Revealing exact locations full names are generally frowned upon in most online communities because they can be used to find more information about a potential doxxing target. Forbidding users to share their age is an added level of privacy to protect younger members seeking community on Internet from being taken advantage of by those with malicious intentions. Younger users may not understand how risky age differences can be to navigate. Face reveals can be reverse-image searched to further learn information about users who arenat protecting their online privacy, even be stolen used in various forms of bullying. As a result, many family-friendly servers find it best to limit all personally identifying information outside of first name country if users arenat choosing to utilize an online persona to protect themselves. As moderators itas important to help educate young users about how to maintain confidentiality use discretion when revealing personal information. This starts with recognizing not clicking malicious links steers into conversations about reporting things that make them uncomfortable in any way protecting their private information. Keep an eye out on how others interact with younger users act accordingly, as a victim may not realize they are a victim in some situations. Text filter implementation determining which topics of discussion are appropriate for server may be more strict than average community as a result of building a safe space for younger users. There is generally no room for crudeness in any form. A This goes beyond using text filters to monitor hate speech, which is against Discordas Community Guidelines, going further to include curse words, innuendo, illegal substances activities, gore, dark humor making light of serious situations, any negative harmful rhetoric from within fandom your community supports, more. Be sure to adapt your text filters as new situations filter evasions arise within your community. It is often recommended to keep your blacklist private to avoid exposing harmful terminology to users. Additionally, make sure your text filters mirror topics of discussion you arenat allowing in your server clearly outline those preferences in your server rules by noting that your environment is strictly SFW any NSFW content is not allowed. Automoderation can be utilized to mute ban users who are engaging in problematic discussion around hate speech, moderators can use their judgment on other blacklisted words as long as your moderation bot is set to log filtered words in moderation channels. As mentioned in previous section, rule continuity is a big deal in spaces meant for young people to ensure equal enforcement across everything. If youare looking to filter certain content, it should also not be allowed to discuss that topic in your server. This goes for both general chatting for various other forms of server usage, any place where there can be user generated content. One such example is meme art channels. While itas a great idea to foster encourage a healthy positive artistic environment, content that is NSFW, hate speech politically motivated, creations that may lean into age-restricted content like alcohol consumption gore should be monitored discouraged. If you have an active music channel setup, it might be worth keeping an eye on playlists to make sure content being monitored elsewhere doesnat slip by here. With release of server avatars, it is less likely that rule-breaking content can find its way into your server via this route, but consider moderating statuses of active users, user profiles, profile pictures if it does. It also helps to have your moderators lead by example follow same rules in their profiles that you are looking to enforce elsewhere. Continuity is key for equal unbiased rule enforcement. Considerations for Users Above Your Target Age Range While family-friendly environments exist to be safe spaces for young people you may find yourself also having users who are above your target age range. Their presence should not be discouraged, but itas important to ensure that your rules welcome messaging clearly defines your space as family-friendly so that they are aware of expectations for ANY user who joins server. Most will likely be accepting of rules youave put in place space you are trying to cultivate. However, others may naturally challenge certain restrictions that they find childish assume donat apply to them. Establishing language around why your community is meant to be family-friendly importance of keeping it safe for everyone as a result, will be helpful if these conversations arise. Users who may rebel against rules that they do not agree with should be actioned accordingly. If you notice a large portion of your userbase seeking out your community but growing frustrated with its family-friendly restrictions, you can consider opening locked channels for mature users that can either opt-in to their existence show proof of their age. If you decide to do this, make sure you have a separate set of rules in place for these channels, as well as an identification vetting process to make sure that younger users do not get exposed to content you donat want them to be exposed to. This would require moderation that is different from rest of your server, so itas important to consider whether not your moderation team can handle this locked channel if you feel it aligns with your serversa purpose. To Recap Family-friendly communities exist to welcome Discordas youngest users into safe spaces with protection of moderation teams. Home Servers are SFW communities that limit topics of discussion more than a generalized server would in order to cultivate that safe environment. As a result, thereas special consideration to be taken around user privacy educating users about their privacy, expanded text filters, appropriate topics of discussion, rule continuity when building out rules structure of such an environment. Make sure your team is prepared to handle older users who may find these rules constricting by explaining their importance to your communityas purpose. Understanding Avoiding Moderator Burnout Moderator Burnout: What is it? Starting a new job position activity will always be exciting. Most moderators are eager to help a community that they love that they are an active part of to grow prosper. You spend a lot of time there already, so why would you not want to do your part in helping that community be successful? However as time passes, interests can change initial enthusiasm can wane. As a moderator, you might find yourself spending time in other communities you realize your real world schooling work is a priority over moderating, so there is potential for anxiety to build as you try to juggle all of your responsibilities. Maybe your mental health is being affected by spending many hours a day on internet, dealing with trolls people who simply just want to cause trouble. This can mentally drain you, having to deal with negativity conflict day in day out. When moderating begins to feel like a chore, as opposed to a hobby, thatas when you might feel like moderator burnout has set in. Burnout is emotional, mental, physical exhaustion you feel after a prolonged period of stress brought on by certain activities. Spending too much time in a stressful environment can easily lead to feelings of exhaustion, feeling distant from activity task at hand, simply just having negative feelings when thinking about doing activity task. These negative effects on your body mind eat away at you until you feel like you are at your limit just do not have enough energy motivation in you anymore to continue moderating. Sometimes burnout makes it feel like only thing that can make you happy is to stop being a moderator completely. Signs of Moderator Burnout One of most common signs of moderator burnout is when you have been noticing yourself being less less active when it comes to moderating, as well as being less active in server itself. As a moderator, you have begun to feel like it is a chore for you to be moderating server; something you feel forced to do, knowing it needs to be done with no joy attached to task at hand. Time seems to move so slowly when you are moderating as you are constantly checking clock, just hoping that an hour of your time is enough on server. Your time spent on your server becomes less less as days go by until you have either stepped down completely withdrawn from any activity in server, moderation otherwise. A burgeoning lack of participation is another sign. If you know yourself well enough, you can probably tell when something is bothering you. Perhaps on any normal given day, you are social engage with your other team members as well as with regular server members, but recently youare only chatting in public channels, giving out occasional public warning. You notice that you only really check staff channels when there is a ping. Your account may be in server your name on member list, but youare no longer an active community member. At this point burnout has set in. There may be urge to come in every day give 100% but then you run risk of giving too much, too quickly. You start to dread amount of work necessary to do your part eventually start to taper off. You might notice yourself making more mistakes than normal. Frustration is another part of burnout that can affect mental aspects of moderating. Feeling like you are making too many mistakes are not doing as much as another moderator is a hard thing to put a reason to. Feelings of inadequacy may lead to reprimanding yourself internally, being your own worst critic, finding yourself in a rut, thinking everyone in server is being difficult. You know you are making mistakes, others on your team see it, thinking they are helping by giving you constructive criticism. There is a lack of accomplishment that makes you frustrated, especially in moderating. Nothing you do feels like it is being done right, adding that to difficulties of members of server, frustration kicks in. When telling members of server to do something they continue to post against rules, you begin to wonder if you matter are even making a difference. A Burnout can easily affect your attitude. Moderating tests your patience as some members of server will purposefully push line, seeing what they can get away with. As a new moderator, you might not be as strict, as you are wanting community to not only respect you but to like you. As time passes, your patience may begin to run thin you put up with a lot less while you get more irritated. You have a shift in your attitude can become bitter at what you have to deal with when moderating a server. Avoiding Moderator Burnout After taking time to look at signs of moderator burnout, it is important to know how to avoid it so you your team can find your groove again remember what it feels like to enjoy being not only a moderator but a community member. Everything is healthy with moderation, including, well, moderation. Knowing when you need breaks encouraging yourself, as well as other moderators, to take these breaks can really help with mounting stress levels. Moderating takes a toll on your mental health, so being able to step away catch your breath can really help reset your focus. Reach out to other members on your team that can help with moderator duties shoulder workload so those that are experiencing burnout can feel that it is okay to step away. A big part of working on a team is being honest with each other when things are good when things are not so good. You may be surprised at how eager your team members are to help prop you up when youare feeling low. Remember- you're not alone in this, so feel free to take those breaks be assured that server is not on fire that there are eyes other than yours that are there to share workload. Offline life your overall health should always come before any aspect of online life. Make sure you are not taking on too much, but also have enough to do. This can be a tricky balance. Depending on your moderation experience skills, it can be hard to determine what your work load capabilities are, especially as offline life changes. Be upfront honest with what your team expects from you, but also let them know that if you are feeling overwhelmed, that they can talk to you. Always have an open line of communication so you can find ways to help yourself, as well as others you moderate with. Something that has worked on larger servers that you might be able to incorporate to your server is having a summary of channels. With summary, you can have moderators on your team sign up for which channels they enjoy moderating, as well as others, not feel like you have to be in too many channels at one time. Delegating work makes it seem more manageable less daunting. Encourage yourself your fellow moderators to try new channels after a couple weeks to change everyoneas scenery, as well allowing various team members chance to interact with certain server members that might only hang out in channels that they donat normally moderate. As a moderator, you might feel yourself wanting to do more seek to add to your responsibilities. Suggesting community events helping out organizing running these events makes for a great change of pace to contrast normal moderating duties of watching chat. Events are great for bringing regular members together with moderators. It is a fun task that can bring activity levels up spread some excitement. Create an environment that is fun to moderate in. Having suggesting a staff channel where you your fellow moderators can be yourselves vent is a great way to relieve some stress have your team get to know one another. Ask them questions every day to encourage discussion communication between your entire team. Building a team that works well with one another helps with communication between fellow moderators, so they can express how everyone is feeling, seek advice on stresses in community. A You can get to know each otheras personal lives what other things in life might be causing outside stress. Getting to know each otheras personalities can help determine if someone might easily burn out if they are just more introverted than other moderators on your team. Holding events, such as game nights, where you all play a game online together can really help you other moderators feel at ease, bring enjoyment to everyone, help everyone reset for next day of moderating. One of biggest, perhaps simplest, things you can do to help with moderator burnout is just being thankful. Typing two little words of athank youa can go a long way. As a moderator, you spend your free time helping server, so let your fellow moderators know you appreciate that they chose this as their hobby. To that end, positive specific feedback is one of best ways to let someone know that they did a good job what exactly it was that they did well. By being specific about what youare thanking your moderator for, youare letting them know that their hard work is recognized valued seen. Recognize when they put in a lot of hours on server are here on a day-to-day basis. Finding ways to reward them, whether through gifting Nitro a special recognition in server, can be really fulfilling to them. It reassures them that they are an important part of server are making a difference when helping. Be gracious with your words remind them that they are here with you. It starts a chain reaction you will see moderators thanking other moderators for their hard work. Summary Moderator burnout can happen to anyone at any time. It is important to understand what it is how you can help. Whether you are an owner, administrator, another moderator, it is important to support your team look for signs of burnout so you can suggest ways that might help them in how they are feeling. Always have an open line of communication with your team that fosters honesty. Encourage them yourself to step away when feeling stressed overwhelmed, thank each other for helping in server. Servers are a lot harder to run when doing it alone; moderators that are excited to be there are an important part of making sure things operate smoothly. Patreon X Discord What, Exactly, is Patreon? Letas start with obvious question: what is Patreon? In case you are unfamiliar with Patreon, it is a subscription service for content creators similar to YouTube Memberships Twitch Subscriptions. Supporters ( hereby referred to as apatronsa) can pay a monthly fee to access content from creators they are supporting. This private content can cover a wide range of content including text posts, polls, videos, images, merchandise, more. possibilities are truly endless you, as a content creator, have control over how much value you place on content you produce distribute over Patreon. Patreon also uses tiered platforms based upon monetary commitment. For example, letas say you are a comic book creator that can generate an entire comic in a monthas time. You could charge patrons $5 to access works in progress, maybe snippets of story youare writing, behind scenes streams of you working on an anticipated page panel. At next $10 tier, patrons can gain access to whole comic as a reward, maybe even access polls to help you decide what to do next. Further, a $25 reward could be that patrons have complete access to your entire library, get a physical edition of your comic book sent to them! ideas are endless when it comes to what kind of rewards you can offer your patrons. In fact, one of new ways to explore rewards systems for patrons is via Discord. Why Create Discord Rewards? For content creators that use platforms like Patreon, providing rewards to patrons is an absolute necessity because it directly benefits those who choose to support you. One of simpler rewards creators can provide patrons is a Discord reward system automatically managed by Patreon Bot. An example of such an award allows you to assign one more roles to patrons in your Discord server based upon their subscription tier on Patreon. Once they have their designated roles, you can utilize channel permissions to provide your supporters with exclusive access to aspects of your server like hidden channels perhaps even hoist them in sidebar of your Discord server as an added bonus. This gives them closer access to you as a creator as well as your content your community. This, in turn, can make them feel appreciated as support perhaps allow them to see a direct impact of their support on your content. Installing a Discord Rewards System on Patreon first step to setting up Discord Rewards on Patreon is to have a Patreon account. Once youave started building your Patreon page (or have one completed), youall need to head into your aTiersa section of your page. Once in aTiersa section, pick tier youad like to grant access to your rewards in your Discord server. We recommend that this should be lowest tier youad allow patrons to subscribe at in order to receive a special role in a Discord server that we are presuming is public. Once youave selected your chosen tier, youall need to connect your Patreon to Discord. Now, letas make this reward a reality with following steps: Please note, if you created your server that you plan on adding to your Patreon, youall have no trouble finding it in server list mentioned in Step 4. If youave had a friend, moderator, maybe even a community manager create your server, you might not see it in this list. Make sure you have Manage Server permission in order to see it. If you donat, double check with server owner have them add it to one of your roles in order to successfully connect to Patreon. Customizing Your Discord Rewards With your Patreon page successfully linked with your Discord server, you may notice this message in Patreon: To finalize reward set-up, you need to create actual roles. We recommend creating a different role for each of Patreon tiers you have distinguishing roles by naming them after tiersa name amount of money pledged by patrons of each tier. For example, if you have a $50 per month Patreon tier named Top Contributor, you could name corresponding reward role either a$50a aTop Contributor.a This usually works out most suitably for future rewards, because you can easily distinguish your followers who send $5 a month, versus those sending $50 a month, change role permissions accordingly if you are offering them different levels of Discord access. Remember that it is important to keep Patreon Botas role above all other roles we make for this purpose so it can help manage them. Now that your tier roles are in server, there should be no more red warning text on Patreon Tier Creation page. If there is, give it a quick refresh. disappearance of this text means that you can now check box aGives patrons access to selected Discord roles.a If you are using multiple roles for each tier of your Patreon for organization in your server, make sure theyare all added. After setting your channels permissions spoken about in next step, double check that correct role in your Discord server is associated with proper tier on your Patreon page. Success! Youave completed Patreon Discord integration! Now lets establish accessibility levels. At this point, youall want to build a structure to your server for these new tier roles. Head back to channel list decide how youad like to reward your different tiers. Do you want each tier to have their own channel category, do you want one channel category with different channels designated to different tiers? Make sure to give each category and/or channel permissions associated with each role that you want to have access to that area. We have an based upon channel list image below to see some of our recommendations in action. This example utilizes one channel category for all patrons, but gives certain patron tiers different levels of access. A Youall notice Patreon allows you to assign users multiple roles when they subscribe to a tier. This makes it handy to ensure your private channels categories are easier to manage across different role tiers. In our provided example youall see that all patrons have access to an exclusive general text voice channel to talk to each other regardless of tiers. However, different tier levels are given access to different additional perks such as sharing social media links for creator to follow back, polls for future content, a VIP text voice chat to better talk to creator theyare supporting. Conclusion Congratulations on launching your new and/or updated Patreon page! beauty of this system is that you can continue to create new roles channel permissions to best serve your community as you continue to grow. Now that youare done with basic steps outlined in this guide, all you have to do is edit/add/drop/shift roles around as needed to ensure you are making most of your Discord Rewards patron program. Patreon rewards give your fans supporters exclusives in exchange for supporting your work. Having this automated system to handle manage your supporters means you can spend more time making new content, less time worrying about a bot, a function in Discord whenever new patrons sign up. It also makes managing permissions much more simpler because you have a lot more control over which roles a patron is assigned to based on their subscription tier. Best Practices for Moderating Content Creation Creating an Area for Content Creators Content creation is one of coolest aspects of a community! Even those that do not create themselves can celebrate passion excitement that comes with sharing art. Artists shouldnat be regulated to just a generalized #media channel where all users are posting photos, you should consider instead giving them their own designated area in server. This shows these users that moderators see their contributions to community appreciate what they are doing. This area can be a channel dedicated to sharing art content, even an entire channel category depending on how your moderation team wishes to interact with your communityas creators how active this part of your community may be. Listen to their needs expand modify this category as necessary. Unique Rules of Road When building out a content creation realm in a server, it is important to keep in mind that your moderation team may encounter some new situations that don't apply to rest of server. Of course, content creators are subject to same laws of land in place for entire community, but there may need to be some of these unique rules of road to consider including: Plagiarism. This is practice of taking someone elseas work claiming that it is your own. Plagiarizing another content creator should not be tolerated within any creative space. It should be highly discouraged acted upon with moderator intervention if your community brings an accusation of plagiarism to your moderation team. As moderators, it is important to understand difference between plagiarism finding inspiration in someone elseas work. Tracing another creatorsa artwork is most common form of plagiarism, whereas being inspired by an original character to try out a new pose, color scheme, scene featuring them is inspiration. While creators are often looking out for each other willing to bring concerns about plagiarism to moderation teams, it is important to be able to look for it yourself by familiarizing yourself with your artistsa styles reverse image searching images of concern to your team. Be sure to be able to explain to your community why plagiarizing is harmful when these situations arise. Managing Constructive Criticism vs. Hate. Your content creation channels are going to be accessible to your entire server. This is so that entire fandom can celebrate together, but also to drive interest from users to support your content creators. This means that average user can come in comment on content. There is a line between constructive criticism hate. Watch out for it as moderators be prepared to intervene should anything cross line into attacks hate-filled commentary that would give content creation an unwelcoming atmosphere. Oftentimes in creative communities it is an unspoken rule that you should not give constructive criticism unless it is specifically asked for. average user may not realize this could accidentally offend an artist if theyare not aware of this. As a moderator, itas important to help artists understand constructive criticism when they ask for it while shielding them from trolls baseless hate. Sharing content can be intimidating, so it is especially important to ensure that content creation channels remain positive respectful environments. One way you can mitigate this issue is by making it clear in your rules that unless artist specifically asks for constructive criticism, that feedback of that nature is not allowed. Bumping. Art bumping may occur in an art channel where artists feel their content isnat easily viewed by enough people. This is essentially act of media getting bumped up in chat from other people sharing their media at same time from chatter about other works. An accusation of bumping usually comes up when a creator feels their art isnat being noticed, if they believe someone they do not have a good relationship with is intentionally bumping their work. In this case, itas important to defuse situation not allow any forms of bullying by de-escalating conflict. Maintaining an environment where users respect everyone's work is necessary for peace of mind of creators consumers alike. You can also consider building out a channel category instead of a single channel which would allow for a channel dedicated to posting art a separate one for discussion. You may contemplate a rule of not posting art within a certain time frame of another creator posting, but be cautioned that this can lead to over-moderation by your community. NSFW content. If your server allows Not Safe for Work content, it is important that you create a specific channel for it that can be marked as an NSFW channel separate from your regular content creation channels. In line with Discordas policies, this will not allow users under age of 18 to see this channel without agreeing to a prompt that says they are not a minor. It is also important to consider that implementation of an NSFW channel disqualifies you from being a A Partnered Verified Discord server. Make sure to keep expectations around SFW NSFW content creation in line with that of your entire server, offer to answer any questions in DMs if a creator thinks a piece may toe boundaries you enforce. Advertising Commissions. If you have a blanket ban on advertisement in your community, you may not want to make an exception to rule here. However, if you decide to allow advertising commissions in your server, you are allowing more commissions to flow to your creators. Do not allow other users to beg for free art try to guilt creators with open commissions into providing free content to them. It may be case that your moderation team will have to enforce boundaries if someone who commissions a creator within your community doesnat pay them revokes payment. Conversely, if a creator requires payment up front then does not deliver work doesnat refund commissioner, moderator intervention should occur to no longer allow them to accept commissions from other members. To be clear, you are not responsible for their financial disputes business transactions. Ultimately, creators should look into their specific payment provider website for policy information on fraud filing disputes, both of which are out of your control. Your job as a moderation team is protecting creators from scammers who make themselves known within your community. Youave created this space to cater to creators need them to know that users who take advantage of them creators who take advantage of users are not welcome here. Low Quality/Low Effort Art. Something your moderation team should consider is whether not you will be moderating low quality low effort art. Lower quality art has ability to potentially create a divide with more experienced artists diminish overall quality of your artistic channels. Expectedly, this is a very subjective divisive topic. Moderating alow qualitya alow efforta art can run risk of upsetting younger users creators that are at very beginning of learning how to create. When considering moderating low quality art, be sure to display empathy compassion to avoid coming off as inconsiderate rude. Be honest realistic in your descriptions requirements for these art spaces so that users may have a better idea as to what is isnat acceptable both content quality wise. Other ways to healthily promote higher quality artists is via potential role systems, automatic pins, weekly artist highlights, which will be discussed in further detail below. Off Topic Art. As a team, think about whether you want your artist channels to be dedicated to purpose of your server if you want to also allow off topic content. Once this rule is decided, check that your moderation team is on same page for enforcement nudging should you decide not to allow off topic art. Engaging Content Creators There are several ways to keep your communityas content creators engaged, which helps to showcase how much your moderation team values their contributions to server. Discord has several native features that can showcase your communityas talent in emojis, stickers, banners, server icons. While a banner a server icon are important to be branded thus rarely changed, generating emojis stickers (especially from within your community) is a good way to bond, celebrate inside jokes with your community, show some love for your creators. Oftentimes communities will employ certain yearly opportunities like emoji elections where creators can submit emojis for consideration allow your community to vote as a whole. Continued engagement with your content creators is also important. If you are engaging your community with generalized game server events, examine whether you can engage your content creators in same way with art events monthly prompts as this promotes community bonding. If your community has a system to reward winners for their work participation in events, work to instill same kind of system for art adjacent events prompts. Finally, some communities may want to install a special role for content creators, especially those that are active constantly contributing quality work. This will showcase artists in server to rest of server. Do keep in mind however, that unique role colors can lead to inadvertent exclusivity a social hierarchy within server. This can also have effect of alienating artists that do not yet have role, which is why you should be careful when thinking about if you want to introduce this role to your community. If you decide to bring a specialized role into your server, take step to have clear criteria for users to qualify for it as well as easy rules for moderators to grant it to users. This ensures that your moderation team can avoid accidentally leaving someone out hurting someoneas feelings. Avoid bringing a role into your server if your server has had problems with role related hierarchies in past. Listen to your communityas needs anticipate potential problems! Conclusion Content creators are an exciting subset of fandom that should be welcomed to your community! Ensure that they have their own area to share all forms of content in, whether it be a channel an entire channel category. Be aware that content creation arenas often come with unique rule considerations that you may not have encountered previously in daily moderation of your server.
