Talk to your moderation team about everything before launching this channel category so that you are all on same wavelength with enforcement before jumping in. Continuously engage your creators involve them in artistic aspects of server, such as emoji sticker creation. Art can bring people together, having a healthy artistic space within your community will provide a new way for your community to bond celebrate your fandom! Managing Interpersonal Relationships Degrees of Interpersonal Relationships Any relationship between two members of a community can be described as an interpersonal relationship. These relationships exist on a wide spectrum. As you participate in a community, you are most likely going to develop connections to varying degrees with other members of community. As a moderator, this may even be expected as part of your duties to promote community engagement healthy conversations. Thatas perfectly normal, as itas very natural for people who spend a lot of time communicating to develop closer ties to one another. Every kind of relationship, from mere acquaintances to romantic partners, can occur in a Discord community, every relationship you form as a moderator will carry its own unique challenges responsibilities in order to ensure you are performing your duties to best of your ability. Any kind of interpersonal relationship can create difficulty in moderation, but as nature of relationship changes, so too does unconscious bias you may experience. A friendship between a moderator a member of community is least problematic type of intersocial relationship, but as these friendships form it is still important to take notice be aware of them. As a moderator it is your duty to be available to everyone in community, even people who you may not ever see as a friend, so you must resist temptation to devote more time attention to people you more easily connect with. If your biases toward your friends begin to show up in your moderation efforts, many more serious harder to diagnose problems can arise. Feelings of "elitism" afavoritisma can start to take hold disgruntled members may take advantage of your friendships to excuse justify their own behavior, so take care to make sure that you are remaining impartial. A friendship between a moderator a member of community that persists for a long period can evolve into a closer more open relationship. These relationships are built on trust shared experience, can be more difficult to impartially manage than regular friendships acquaintances. This kind of relationship could come from fact that this person is someone you know from another server, in real life, possibly even a family member. No matter what scenario, closeness of this kind of relationship makes it very difficult, sometimes impossible, to remove your own partiality from equation. Special care must be taken to ensure you engage listen to other moderators on your team when someone you are closely involved with is in question. When in doubt, it may be best to remove yourself from situation entirely, which we will discuss in more detail later in article. A romantic relationship between a moderator a member of community can (and does!) happen. As is natural, if you meet someone who shares common interests has an attractive personality, over time your relationship may progress into something more profound. Romantic relationships are certainly most difficult to manage as a moderator. saying holds true, especially in new romantic relationships, that you will see your significant other through arose-tinted glassesa which tend to blind you from their potential flaws wrongdoings. Additionally, other members can very quickly see a budding relationship as an opportunity for a fellow member to grab power through moderator they are romantically involved with. As a best practice, you should remove yourself from any moderation decisions involving a user that you are in a romantic relationship with. Failing to do so can has directly caused death of some communities, especially when romantic partners are both on same moderator team. This type of one-sided interpersonal relationship is rare among moderators because of connection a moderation team usually has to content creator personality that they moderate for. More commonly, a user witnessing a friendly moderator carrying out their daily duties to interact with their server can develop such a relationship. However, this type of relationship requires an extra level of care awareness, as they can quickly become toxic if not managed appropriately. Always be aware of them, consider their existence when making certain moderation decisions. DMA has an article exclusively dedicated to parasocial relationships for further reading. On Visibility One thing to keep in mind when evaluating your relationships in your communities- regardless of nature of thema is that your relationships connections if played out in server are most likely visible to other members of community. When interacting with your friends, close friends, even your partner in a space with other people such as your server, members of community may pick up on fact that you do have these relationships. As with any kind of community, there may be feelings of exclusion perception of ain-groupsa that can arise in, especially when it comes to relationships between a aregulara server member a highly public visible one like a moderator. A responsibility you have as a moderator is to take this dynamic into account effects it can have on your members how they view you your friendships. Making sure that your friendships relationships are not creating an exclusionary atmosphere for other community members, where they feel like itas unwanted difficult for them to contribute. On subject of avisibilitya, a moderator a whether they are consistently conscious of it not - is someone in server who has power over other users in that space. It is not always easiest task balancing dynamic between being part of a community cultivating relationships friendships with being conscious of your role within that community as a moderator what that imbalance may influence. This difference in responsibility position can make relationships connections with other users in server more complicated. You may not be directly aware of it when youare chatting with fellow server members, but there will be users in your community who are keenly aware of your status as a moderator. This scrutiny can affect how they approach becoming friends with you as well as affect how they view your own relationships with other server members. Always keep this dynamic in mind be aware of how your position may affect not just how users interact with you but also how they interpret your relationships conversations with other members. A Higher Standard Just as it is natural for these relationships to form, it is also human nature to unconsciously develop act on a bias toward people closest to you. As a moderator, that natural bias is something you must actively resist, take conscious steps to avoid. What happens when friend of a moderator has a bad day doesnat act in spirit of rules of community? In an ideal scenario, moderatoras response would be same reasonable response that would be expected if offending member were anyone else. Your response to these situations will have a profound impact on your communityas attitude toward you as a moderator, as showing favoritism will quickly evaporate communityas trust in your ability to be impartial. Moderators are human, for inexperienced seasoned moderators alike, this kind of scenario can prove to be one of most significant tests of their ability to manage conflict. In preparing for this scenario, most important tool in a moderatoras arsenal is self-awareness. It is burden of a moderator that this commitment comes above any interpersonal relationships that may form during time spent engaging with a community. Being ever-mindful of your responsibility role in a community can help temper depth of relationships that you build. As a recommended best practice, moderators should be careful about building interpersonal relationships of depth (close romantic relationships) in communities they moderate, including with other moderators. only guaranteed way for a moderator to remain impartial in upholding rules for all members is to exclusively maintain friendships within their community, but this isnat always reasonable for communities that you are closely involved in. Should you find yourself in a difficult scenario involving a member with whom you have a close interpersonal relationship, here are some best practices for managing situation: first step in successfully managing a scenario that involves someone you have an interpersonal relationship with is to take stock of your own investment. How are you feeling? Are you calm capable of making rational judgment? Is your gut reaction to jump to defense of member? is opposite true - do you feel need to be overly harsh in order to compensate for potential bias? Carefully self-evaluate before proceeding with any action. wrong type of moderator response in a scenario like this can often exacerbate distract from actual issue at hand, potentially weaken your communityas trust in your capabilities as a moderator. If in course of your self-evaluation you realize that you cannot positively answer any all of these questions, it may be necessary for you to more seriously evaluate whether not you need to make difficult decisions regarding your position as a moderator. If your interpersonal relationship is preventing you from fulfilling your duties as a moderator, you may need to consider either abdicating your role as a moderator ending relationship until circumstances improve. Neither option is easy ideal, but making tough decisions for health of community is your primary responsibility as a moderator. Once youave determined that youare capable of proceeding with moderation, evaluate scenario to identify what problem is whether it immediately needs to be addressed. If there is no immediate need to step in, as a best practice it is usually better to defer to another moderator whenever your personal relationships are involved. Contact another member of your moderation team to get a second opinion some backup if necessary. If immediate action is required, a concise direct reference to rules is usually sufficient to defuse situation. Use your best judgment, but be aware that likelihood of arules lawyeringa is higher with someone who trusts you sees you as a friend in these scenarios because moderation action can be seen as a violation of that trust relationship. Clearly fairly indicating grounds for you speaking up is crucial to prevent further issues from arising. Additionally, be careful about what is discussed in private with person involved in this scenario following any action. There is a higher likelihood of them contacting you via DM to talk about your decisions because of level of trust that exists between you. As a best practice, it is usually best to avoid litigating rules of server with any member, especially a member with which you have an interpersonal relationship. Politely excuse yourself, if prudent, redirect conversation by giving member a place to productively resolve their own issue. As with any moderation action, once taken it is best practice to leave a note for your team about what action was taken why. Another period of self-evaluation is a good idea after any action is taken. Ask yourself, was action taken in alignment with rules of your community? Was it fair to both offending member, as well as other members of your community? Was your decision affected by your bias towards offending member? If necessary unclear, ask your teammates for their outside perspective. Summary Taking moderation action when offending member is one with whom a moderator has an interpersonal relationship can be one of most difficult scenarios that a moderator can find themselves in. Set yourself up for success as a moderator by tempering type of relationships you build within your community cultivating ability to self-evaluate. best tool available to a moderator in these scenarios is self-awareness ability to recognize when their own biases prevent them from acting fairly. Remember that moderation is a team sport, that team is your most valuable resource in impartially upholding rules values of your community. Considering Mental Health in Your Community Importance of Mental Health Awareness Before we discuss what to consider when introducing mental health channels to a community, it is important to understand difference between mental health a mental illness, to be aware of realities of what these terms entail. Mental health mental illness are strongly intertwined, but very different. People with good mental health can develop a mental illness, while those with no mental illness can have poor mental health. Mental health reflects our emotional, physiological, social well-being. Though topic of mental health is still quite taboo to talk about in certain circles, there is help available for those who wish to seek it. Mental health is a crucial aspect of a personas existence as it affects our actions, emotions, thoughts. A healthy mental state enhances effectiveness productivity in work, education, interpersonal relationships. A mental illness is a disorder of mind that affects not just our thinking but also our energy, mood, occasionally our conduct behavior. Such a diagnosis may make it difficult to cope with many obligations of life. Common mental illness diagnoses are anxiety disorders, such as panic attacks, post-traumatic stress disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, specific types of fears. There are also mood disorders like depression, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia. An excellent guide for identifying mental health challenges pathways to care can be found here. Being informed aware about mental health issues is a great start when youare considering how it may affect apply to your community team. As an illness can manifest in a variety of different ways, it is vital to be ready have clear guidelines on these complex topics when dealing with online communities both for your staff internally for your community externally. An often overlooked result of community moderation is how it can affect mental health of your team. Moderator burnout stems from situations that harm your teamas mental health, understanding signs how to deal with it are essential in building a strong online community led by a moderation team that can act as a strong support system not only to your community, but to each other. Adding a Mental Health Channel in Your Server There is a lot to consider when discussing if you want to add a channel that addresses is dedicated to talking about topics that deal with mental health within your Discord server. Firstly, you have to determine whether not your community needs a mental health discussion channel thread. Consider whether not your team has seen much talk about mental health-related content in your community whether such conversations have remained respectful even without your teamas active intervention. If these conversations have devolved into arguments negativity in your community, maybe re-evaluate if you feel this type of channel will benefit those in your server really think about if you can find a way have enough resources to guarantee that it remains a safe space for all users. easy way to contemplate whether not a mental health channel would fit into your server is by looking at general topic of your server. If your Discord server is more focused on gaming, it may not make sense to allow something that drastically differs from your serveras purpose. Contrarily, a server focusing on community building might be a safer space for a mental health channel. Ultimately, itas very subjective all about listening to not just needs of your community but tone of your server. A lot goes into developing an excellent community introducing a mental health channel is not easy as you have to consider how to best moderate it. This includes how youall be utilizing auto moderation text filters in channel as accidental flags in highly emotional situations can be more harmful than helpful. If you do decide to create a mental health channel thread, it is important to be aware of all possible situations to be flexible prepared for unexpected scenarios. Understanding that some moderators arenat comfortable in these situations is important if you decide to allow such a channel on your server, you need to be able to vet your moderators future helpers. As moderators arenat mental health professionals, they shouldnat be treated as such should also be presented with option to opt out of spaces such as this. Therefore, it is vitally important that you establish clear internal guidelines procedures to set expectations for channel at a manageable level. Facilitating Healthy Discussions about Mental Health Discussing mental health in a positive way can be challenging as it is a sensitive topic with a variety of experiences attached to it. However, there are some ways to make this an easier experience from a moderation standpoint, most important of which is having clear server rules moderator guidelines for how to act when these discussions are taking place having clear escalation protocols for if things go south. Talking with your moderators about mental health challenging times in life as well as facilitating breaks for them demonstrates that you care about their well-being. This is an integral part of establishing a healthy environment for your moderators solid internal relationships. creation of specific mental health-related guidelines ensure that users remain respectful of each other that conversations are within designated guidelines of your community. Some suggestions for creating these guidelines include: Escalation protocols are another important foundation for when mental health discussions take place. Some ideas to consider when implementing them: a Moderation of mental health channels can be a touchy subject. On one hand, moderators should be firm in removing harassers users who are disrespecting others. On other hand, moderators should try their best not to over-moderate. There must be a balance to ensure that these channels that have very sensitive subject matters within them are moderated with care. Some ways to do this are: a There are an incredible amount of resources available for mental health supportaeverything from emergency phone numbers to suicide hotlines LGBTQ+ helplines. Find a Helpline resource consists of a list of global helplines hotlines. We also recommend looking at TWLOHA resource, which is a non-profit movement dedicated to presenting hope finding help for people struggling with their mental health. Discord has also partnered with Crisis Text Line, a non-profit that provides text-based volunteer support for people in crisis. You can learn more about our integration partnership how to use it on Discord here. Some more examples of support sites include: Not all communities are prepared to host a mental health channel thread, there is a lot to consider before adding one to your server. While allowing talk about mental health can be incredibly beneficial, it is just as important to realize that moderators arenat professionals should not be put in those positions if they arenat comfortable with it. Thatas why we advise that you carefully consider your current environment, your communityas purpose, implications that might occur if you choose to add one. Whatever you decide is best for your community, we believe that education is key. It may be helpful to think about adding a channel post that gives people access to professional support lines, such as FindaHelpline TWLOHA resource, as well as other resources laid out in this article. Generally, facilitating a healthy discussion around important topics of any kind is essential in helping to develop stronger communities online. Make sure that your community is a safe space for everyone that chooses to call it home! Twitch X Discord Is Discord for Twitch Necessary? At some point during their Twitch careers, most streamers will ask question, aIs having a Discord for my community necessary?a. Most streamers are already struggling enough with configuring their overlays, cultivating relationships with other streamers, taking time to edit design future content. Will working with yet-another platform really help move my streaming career forward, is it just another item on endless list of distractions? Most of streamers who ask this question fail to understand how Discord fits into their high-level plan for scaling their brand community. One of biggest misconceptions is that Twitch can be used for every step of growing your channel, brand, community. Twitch is only one of many platforms required for success. While Twitch is well-known for engaging monetizing your active community base, it struggles with content discovery, data collection, long term retention. Twitch should instead be viewed as a tool to engage connect with an already-existing community. image above categorizes content platforms into 3 primary groups; Discovery, Engagement, Activation. Content platforms that focus on Discovery are specifically designed to spread new, persistent content that can be viewed later. These platforms are ideal for finding new community members fans to engage with by inviting them to join another more personalized platform, such as a fansite, email list, Discord community. It is through this persistent community that you can advertise ways to support engage directly with primary content creators by supporting through Patreon viewing/subscribing on Twitch. platforms above can obviously be used for different purposes, but theyare segmented as such because of how their primary business models work. Discovery platforms run on ads focus on getting you to consume more content. Engagement platforms are more personalized, with content not designed for larger audiences frequently encourage users to take action. Activation platforms are designed to have monthly direct recurring payment models that provide an enhanced personalized version of Engagement content. Going Live Back Again With a better understanding of primary purposes of each platform, you can begin to design your user experience in a way that provides new community members an easy direct way to participate in show dedication to community. Regardless of how your Twitch viewers discover your channel content, directing them to a centralized community hub will allow them to share their appreciation with others, go from being an individual fan to being part of a community. To get most out of Discord encourage members to join your stream, spend time with your community before after each livestream. Before each stream, spend 15 minutes chatting with your active Discord members to ask them about their day receive feedback about your content. As you begin your stream, post announcements on your social media platforms use a bot to alert your Discord community that youave gone live. Moderators should continue to oversee discussions in your Discord, but encourage members to watch livestream as it occurs. Bots scripts can also be used to remind users to join Discord community if they havenat already, as well as following on social media for updates alerts. Finally, as your stream is ending, remind community that youall be available in Discord for a short time to discuss stream answer any questions. Some streamers will also include special events for high-ranking members subscribers, which can help encourage collaboration active use of server. Playing with Viewers via Discord One of most effective ways to engage directly with your community is to create content with them. This can either be done while livestreaming, else as a scheduled event that community can participate in. Events need not necessarily be games, but can also include Q&A sessions discussions about a topic of interest. Special precautions must be made while playing with viewers as youare live to prevent astream snipinga, where community members will attempt to disrupt your stream game while youare live. Moderators should take note be ready to handle disruptions while engaging directly with community, but most situations can be prevented by assigning restrictions requirements to be on stream with host. For example, being a subscriber to community requiring participants to apply for a spot if game has a limited number of participants can help ensure everybody understands follows rules. Discord for Twitch Checklist As you grow your Discord community, members will have different expectations of what your server offers, how itas managed what server is used for. For example, a community with 500 members may not be expected to have a full events calendar, but they would definitely expect that roles have been properly configured so that subscribers appear as a different username color with more permissions access to restricted channels. Below is a simple checklist for functionality your server should have: Conclusion We hope these guidelines have helped you to determine if creating a Discord server for your Twitch audience is right fit for you. most essential thing to keep in mind is that your Discord server is not just an appendix to your Twitch presence. It serves as its own entity community that needs to be fostered with same, if not more, personal attention care in order for it to blossom. With right mindset efforts, your Discord community can bolster your Twitch presence bring your community closer together, for longer Application of Metaphors in Moderation Five Types of Community Moderation Approaches An academic study interviewed dozens of moderators across multiple platforms grouped moderation approaches into five different categories: a Being able to understand perspective behind each of these approaches then applying them to your own community as needed is a powerful ability as a community manager. This article will discuss in more detail what these five categories mean how you can apply them within your own communities. Nurturing Supporting Communities Moderators that nurture support communities (nurturing-type moderators) focus on shaping community conversations that occur in server among members to match their vision. foundation for their moderation actions stem from their desire to keep community positive welcoming for everyone, not just long-time members. They seek to create a community with a good understanding of rules that can then develop itself in a positive way over time. These types of moderators may implement pre-screening of members content in their communities by implementing a verification gate using an automoderator to filter out low quality members content curate conversations of server to be better suited to their vision. Although this passive behind-the-scenes guidance is one type of nurturing moderator, these types of moderators also often actively engage with community as a aregular member.a For nurturing-type moderators, this engagement isnat meant specifically to provide an example of rule-following behavior, but rather to encourage high-quality conversations on server where members will naturally enjoy engaging with each other moderators as equals. They are leading by example. Overseeing Facilitating Communities While nurturing- supporting-type moderators operate based upon their long-term vision for a community, moderators that are focused on overseeing facilitating communities focus on short-term needs day-to-day interactions of community members. They are often involved in handling difficult scenarios fostering a healthy community. For example, these types of moderators will step in when there is conflict within community attempt to mediate between parties to resolve any misunderstandings restore A friendliness to server. Depending on issue, they may also refer to specific rules community knowledge to assign validity to one viewpoint to respectfully discredit behavior of another. In both situations, moderators will attempt to elicit agreement from those involved about their judgment resolve conflict to earn respect of their community members restore order to server. Those in overseeing facilitating communities category may also take less involved approaches towards maintaining healthy day-to-day interaction among members, such as quickly making decisions to mute, kick, ban someone that is causing an excessive amount of trouble rather than attempting to talk them down. They may also watch for bad behavior report it to other moderators to step in handle, allow community to self-regulate when possible rather than attempting to directly influence conversation. Fighting for Communities Where overseeing facilitating community moderators emphasize interactive communicative approaches to solving situations with community members, moderators who see themselves as fighting for communities heavily emphasize taking action content removal rather than moderating via a two-way interaction. They may see advocating for their community members as part of their job A want to defend community from those who would try to harm it. Oftentimes, moderators themselves may have been on receiving end of problematic behavior in past desire to keep others in their community from having to deal with same thing. This attitude is often driver behind their A no-nonsense approach to moderation while strictly enforcing communityas rules values, quickly working to remove hateful content users acting in bad faith. Moderators in this category are similar to subset of moderators that view moderation from overseeing facilitating communities, specifically ones that quickly remove those who are causing trouble. However, compared to perspective that misbehavior stems from immaturity, moderators that fight for communities have a stronger focus on content being posted in community, rather than intent behind it. In contrast to moderators in overseeing facilitating communities category, these moderators take a firmer stance in their moderation style do not worry about complaints from users who have broken rules. Instead they accept that pushback on difficult decisions they make is part of moderation process. Governing Regulating Communities Those that see themselves as governing regulating communities see moderation team as a form of governance place great emphasis on appropriate desirable application of community rules, often seeing process for making moderation decisions as similar to a court system making decisions based on a set of community alaws.a They may also see themselves as representatives of community moderation team emphasize need to create policies enforce rules that benefit community as a whole Moderators in this category may consciously run community according to specific government principles, such as having a vote on community changes. However, they may also achieve consensus within team about changes to server without involving community at large even have one moderator make final determination about community changes. This afinal decisiona power is usually exercised in terms of vetoing a proposed policy issuing a ruling on an issue that is particularly contentious within mod team community. Very rarely would a form of decision-making be exercised, it would be granted to very specific members of a team hierarchy such as server owner administrative lead. Even so, moderators in this category find following procedure to be important tend to involve others to some extent in making decisions about community rather than acting on their own. This tendency is also seen in way that they approach rule enforcement. Moderators that see themselves as governing regulating communities view rules as if they were laws of a country. They meticulously review situations that involve moderator intervention to determine which rule was broken how it was broken while referring to similar past cases to see how those were handled. These moderators also tend to interpret rules more strictly, according to aletter of law,a attempt to leave no room for argument while building their acasea against potential offending users. Managing Communities Moderators that see themselves as managing communities view moderation as a second job to be approached in a professional way. They pay particular attention to way they interact with other members of community moderation team as well as moderation teams of other communities, strive to represent team positively to their community members. This type of moderator may appear more often as communities become very large as there becomes a need for clearer, standard processes division of responsibility between moderators in order to handle workload. Though this metaphor focuses more on moderator team dynamics than relationships between moderators users, it can also shape way moderators approach interactions with users. Managing-type moderators are more likely to be able to point users toward written rules, guidelines, processes when they have questions. Managing-type moderators are also much less likely to make aon-the-flya decisions about new issues that come up. Instead, they will document issue post about it in proper place, such as a private moderator channel, so it can be discussed a new process can be created if needed. This approach also makes it easier to be transparent with users about decision making. When there are established, consistent processes in place for handling issues, users are less likely to feel that decisions are random arbitrary. Another strength of this approach is evident in efficient on-boarding processes. When a community has clear processes for documenting, discussing, handling different situations, adding new moderators to team is much easier because there is already a set of written instructions for how they should do their job. This professional approach to moderation can also help moderators when they are attempting to form partnerships make connections with other servers. An organized moderation team is much more likely to make a good impression with potential partners. If you want to learn more about managing moderation teams, click here. Conclusion As you read through this article, you may have found that some moderation category descriptions resonated with you more than others. more experience you have moderating, wider variety of moderation approaches youall implement. Rather than trying to find a single abesta approach from among these categories, itas better to consider your overall balance in using them how often you consider moderation issues from each perspective. For example, you can nurture support a community by controlling how members arrive at your server curating content of your informational channels to guide conversation, while also managing overseeing interactions of honest, well-intentioned community members quickly banning those who seek to actively harm your community. Itas perfectly natural that each person on your moderation team will have an approach that comes easier to them than others no category is superior to another. Making sure all moderation categories are represented in your moderation team helps to ensure a well-rounded staff that values differing opinions. Even just understanding each of these frameworks is an important component of maintaining a successful community. Now that you understand these different approaches, you can consciously apply them as needed so that your community can continue to thrive! Internationalization of a Community Expanding from one Language Which languages to choose entirely depend on type of server you run. For a community server, it is recommended to adjust it to communityas needs. Usually, most commonly featured languages outside of English are German, French, Spanish, Turkish Russian. You can determine your featured language by community analysis, server insights (if your server has them), demand. What nationalities are represented most in your server? Which users struggle most with English upon joining server if theyare struggling, what language do they usually communicate in? In addition to that, you can consider starting a survey every time you your staff feel ready to expand into a new language. On other hand, if you make a server for a brand company, it is recommended to go by your target audience. Introducing features like internationalization needs carefully planned, but steady steps. If your server was originally English only, itas not recommended to expand into too many languages at once for a variety of reasons. Agree on one language (preferably most popular one in your server) slowly add on from there, if need presents itself. Once you figure out a pattern a stable structure on how to approach expansion, you can add more sections for different languages. Server Design As your server grows, so does Discord. It is vital to keep in mind that your server can get a lot of incoming users who have never really used Discord before- so make sure your serveras design is user-friendly, easily accessible, has a clear structure. Also, remember that more languages you feature on your server, more text-and voice channels will appear for your staff. It is recommended to hoist most important text-channels at top of your server. That may include announcements, server-info, rules, optionally giveaways more. To ensure global accessibility, translate important parts like rules server information in every language you feature alongside your main language. Additionally, you can add a server guide for easier coordination. Both new users your staff will benefit from that. It should cover a list of accessible text voice channels as well as a short but detailed description of each. Furthermore, try to integrate every additional language in a way that utilizes it to its utmost potential. You can do so in form of a feedback suggestion channel in each languageas category. This lets you hear directly from users that would benefit from that additional language chat most. Consider having staff that are dedicated to interacting with each section instead of focusing all their attention on global chat. Having these additional language chats makes it so that your international users donat feel less validated only because they donat want to canat communicate in global chat. You can implement that same line of thinking when organizing server events. Consider alternating between server-wide international events as demand allows. For latter, analyze your serveras activity for each region host it at time with most community engagement for those users for best results. You can apply same system to voice channels by creating a few global voice chats then adding language specific channels. Your staff should only allow one common language to be spoken in global chats redirect every other language into their appropriate voice channels. Creating a Server with One More Languages From Scratch If you want to feature multiple languages with equal amounts, you can effectively combine multiple Discord servers in one. For first half, it will be same as before: Have at least one international general-chat before you split server into each language. That way every user is able to communicate with entirety of server instead of just their language-specific section. Let users choose their language via a reaction verification with option to opt-out change regions. You can summarise most important aspects in a common text-channel, text being translated into every featured language. simplest way to manage split server is by having same channels categories, but in different languages. This will heavily depend on type of server you moderate, but recommended channels for every section are ones you would usually include in a monolingual server. These channels should include things like rules, announcements, general-chat, bot-commands, media, optionally a looking-for-game channel, more. Take care to ensure you have appropriate translation for each channel. Moreover, community events can be a lot more diverse. You can host a variety of events for each language as well as let all of them participate in shared events. Take time to analyze each nationas activity also take holidays national days into account. Staff Arrangement Internationalizing your server may mean that your moderation team grows to be larger than expected, so to make it easy for users to contact appropriate staff you can separate moderators by nicknames, colors, role hoist. Nicknames: If you want to have moderation team equally displayed throughout server, you can arrange moderators by nicknames. Simply add language they moderate at beginning of their nickname so they are alphabetically sorted below each other. Users will have an easier time recognizing appropriate moderators, but with a large staff, this might end up looking a little busy. Some moderators tend to change their nicknames frequently may not be big fans of having tag in front of their name, either. Colors: It is advised to have colors of each moderator role in same shade with a slight but still visible difference. This helps to differentiate moderators regular users will be able to tell difference immediately. Remember that newer users might not check each role just contact first seemingly online moderator they see. Role hoist: If you display only accompanying moderator role for each language, ensure that you have a common, not displayed role for all moderators so one team is not less validated than other. Users should definitely be able to contact appropriate staff ping correct moderators to help them out with issues in chat. but, when displaying a lot of teams with many members each, some of them might be pushed off screen. You run risk that some moderators that are displayed below other teams seem less aimportant validateda to community, but shared staff role should fix that problem easily. Moderation While moderating a multilingual server it is crucial to have moderators that are native speakers at least fluent in each language that you decide to expand to. Having moderators that are native speakers makes it so that they not only understand textbook definitions of what is being said but understand cultural contexts that may come with international chats. However, these moderators should also be accomplished capable with other responsibilities of being a mod that lie outside of just being fluent. While community moderators should follow basic tasks (moderate chat, be accessible for questions, guide users), things in multilingual servers can be a bit more advanced. Moderators need to identify address inappropriate behavior towards other cultures in an authoritative, but instructive way. Furthermore, they need to free chat from toxic behavior control discussions about sensitive topics. In addition to that, they have to be open for cultural questions of users who chose a language they are not fluent in yet. Both user staff need to work their way around language barriers together. Theyall be required to help users, as well as resolve disputes, often at same time. For that, theyall have to rely on their communication skills in order to succeed in resolving both situations any other issue that may require it. Without good communication skills, users won't understand what you're trying to convey to them, which should be assertive but tolerant. Moderators can under no circumstances be discriminating towards users of other cultures beliefs. It is their responsibility to create a civil, welcoming comfortable environment for all users. While you are always entitled to your own opinion, make sure to keep a neutral output in public part of server try not to let it cloud your judgement. Managing several moderators from all around world can turn out to be quite tricky. Organizing meetings waiting for everyoneas approval for one date may be a real challenge to deal with. Getting majority of team on board could take days, especially with difference in time zones. One simple solution is to delegate some captains representative moderators for each team. They will gather feedback, opinions suggestions from rest of staff team discuss them with rest of staff during meeting. That way itas easier to organize staff meetings, but they can also directly inform rest of their team who could not make it due to time conflicts. Depending on size of staff teams, you can appoint more than one moderator for that position. When creating more than one staff role, make sure that everyone is comfortable with their position their responsibilities. Misalignment can lead to misunderstanding later on, it might create needless tension amongst staff. Consider appointing one representative in each region that your server is branching out to. That will open possibility to have regional staff meetings where language culture specific issues suggestions can be discussed without need for an international meeting with whole team. While not every moderator will get chance to get to know every other moderator from different regions in these larger moderation rosters, it is important that team feels united regardless. Donat leave it up to one team to tackle an issue- let them know that they can always ask for help from rest of staff. Global Accessibility: Make sure that you have bots available for every part of your server. That could either mean that you include them in global section of your server, you translate commands definitions in every language featured. Moderation: Since not all moderators will be able to understand every single language, using bots turn out to be very helpful for auto-moderation. Inform your fellow moderators about inappropriate words phrases ensure that you added them into bot filter for easier moderation. Banned filtered words should contain common slurs in not only English, but also in commonly banned words for every language that you offer. Language Barriers: It may occur that users message ModMail in poor English in their native language. Find out user's nationality reply with a message in their native language that lets them know their request is being routed to appropriately fluent mod. To save these messages, simply create an extra text-channel in ModMail server let moderators translate important phrases that might come in handy. Cultural Awareness It's easy for people to underestimate impact cultural differences can have. Culture influences values, rules, thought patterns, perception. That means that events happening in other countries may be viewed differently in each nation. News social media don't always portray truth which lets misinformation spread easily. Make sure to have your staff updated about current situations so they have it easier to deal with discussions about sensitive topics trolls. Communication is key users of server will massively benefit from it. While people are entitled to have their own opinion ask for further information, make sure to let it happen in a calm civil atmosphere under a moderatoras watch. If you as a moderator find that youare ill equipped to talk about topic, you should refrain from publicly voicing your opinion until youare better informed. Conversely, you may want to refrain from allowing contentious topics like current events politics to occur in your server at all, which is something you should decide with your moderation team as a whole. Final Words Making a server internationally available is a great idea can be a boon to your communityas retention. It can be utilized for both communities companies alike. But you have to be careful with your approach- Internationalization is a deliberate complicated process it should be treated as such. If itas gone about in wrong way, left uncompleted rushed, these international spaces could backfire. It may result in negative feedback, a disappointed community staff deserted channels. Make sure to inform your staff community about every step youare about to take, give them a chance to voice their input. Feedback suggestions from both your mods your community will be essential to making sure this is right fit for your server. Internationalization requires a lot of effort prioritization in order to properly take care of many factors simultaneously, but if done right, itas an unparalleled way to enrich your community. Training Onboarding New Moderators Training Methods Each server has to decide for themselves what most effective training method looks like. This article will present explain some recommended methods that can simplify moderation training. aBuddy Systema approach describes working in pairs groups, in which two more abuddiesa work together on one task. Requiring newer moderators to work with each other even an assigned team member allows you to better monitor progress for aid to come when required. It promotes active communication trust between moderators also allows them to keep an objective view on everything. Having multiple opinions about certain matters receiving assistance from a reliable source prevents moderators from feeling pressured with moderation tasks can even open your eyes to new viewpoints. Additionally, it allows its members to effectively share their moderation skills with each other. It also aids in terms of personal safety: if a moderator feels personally attacked by a user, they get immediate support from their abuddiesa without feeling need to tackle issue alone. A Using this system allows less experienced moderators to quickly effectively catch up to moderation standards as they learn how to deal with specific matters first hand. It is important to remind more experienced moderators on your team to allow new moderators to learn instead of wanting to quickly handle every task themselves. With time, certain actions will also become second nature for newer moderators, too! This approach is most commonly used when onboarding new moderators. Here experienced moderators head of staff introduce each new member of team personally guide them through most important aspects. difference between this system aBuddy Systema is that each new moderator will be acquainted with moderation tasks responsibilities by a higher up, usually only once. After walkthrough most recruits are expected to manage certain moderation duties on their own while being supervised. It is crucial to support reassure them so they are able to grow confident in their actions. Recruits can display appropriately train their soft skills be informed about moderation standards in a controlled environment without fear causing too much irreparable damage. Another method of efficiently training both experienced inexperienced moderators is by letting them regularly test their knowledge. This involves designing exemplary situations of some everyday issues happening within your Discord server to let trial moderators explain how they would handle them. Such instances can include how to handle issues in audio channels, user disputes, DM Discord invitations, off topic discussion in incorrect channel, potential issues that may be encountered with bots. At end you should provide some sort of amodela aexamplea answer to let recruits know where they need to improve. One negative effect of this system could be fear of failure that some inexperienced moderators might be exposed to. Reassure them that making mistakes is okay as long as you take responsibility for your actions are willing to learn from them. Moderation is an ever-shifting learned art, mistakes are not to be punished when they happen every once in a while.It may be tempting to conduct these regular exercises incognito (aka acting up on an alt to see how they do) test them without warning- while this may yield more aeverydaya unbiased results, it has a high probability of backfiring. Blindsiding your moderation team with tests exercises has potential to do more harm than good, especially in terms of team trust morale. Itas recommended that you donat do this instead, practice transparency when conducting regular exercises in order to avoid a potentially inequitable situation. Another form of training is to demonstrate how situations scenarios are handled in your community via presentation an actual demonstrative walk-through with moderation alt accounts. This is very useful for training where moderators have to use a wide range of commands, such as explaining moderation Modmail bots. Ideally, this should take place in an audio channel group call where you can share your screen. Not everyone is able comfortable joining a voice chat unmuting themselves, which is something to be considered beforehand. Training Program Content An essential part of onboarding new moderators is to have an easily accessible document outlining basic responsibilities details on moderator tasks different moderation teams. Such documents need to be designed for each server individually, but they usually contain general rules for staff, conduct expectations, a punishment outline to set a standard unity for moderation actions. Recommended additions to such a moderation handbook are: Be sure to recognize anything that is prevalent in your moderation culture community that is also worth mentioning here! more thorough guidelines, easier document is to refer back to for any questions. For example, gaming servers should have a brief description of featured gaming companyas Terms of Service discussion about how to handle cheaters users mentioning account sharing/selling in accordance with those rules. Another example would be for bot support servers where a brief description of commonly encountered issues how to solve them as well as an FAQ section to help users with simpler answers. Another important topic new moderators should have easy access to are commands for moderation bots. Having a simple guide in a separate text channel with a quick guide of botsa prefix format (command, user-id, [time], reason) will aid moderators in quickly responding to ongoing issues on server. It lets them react fast without having to pause to look up necessary command. Try to use same prefix for mainly used moderation bot to not cause unnecessary confusion, particularly for users who are new to moderating. Each server uses a differently designed service to assist moderators with helping out users. Bigger servers tend to rely on a ticket Modmail system, so properly introducing them with sample conversations problematic matters is essential for both recruit future user. Confident moderators are more willing to aid users in need than those who are still unsure of how system works. This kind of training should include commonly used commands procedures. There should be conversation about how to redirect users to higher staff closing tickets appropriately so they donat stack up cause confusion. As long as a ticket system remains organization those guidelines organizations are established across full team this will prove to be an easy to use communication system that is much less daunting than it may seem! Staff Safety No user should ever feel unsafe threatened on a Discord server. Staff members are often exposed to harmful disrespectful messages, some of them targeted at some moderators directly. An important aspect of onboarding moderators therefore is to make them aware of how to react in such situations. They need to be able to create an environment in which it is comfortable for them to work in not be afraid to ask for help if they feel threatened by users or, in extreme cases, other staff members. Staff members supporting each other being able to communicate in such moments is crucial for an effectively working team. Creating Managing a Training Program Effective management promotes a feeling of professionalism simplifies process of training new moderators by a lot. Important aspects that should always be covered when creating a training program are time management, deciding on which staff are involved in training why, effective communication, detailed content, flexibility. Choosing an appropriate approach. How do you want to introduce new members? What system did you conclude will work best for your server staff team? Never be afraid to evolve an already existing plan into something that suits better for your current situation. Deciding what topics to cover. What topics do you prioritize over others think require more time investment than others? How are you moderators handling learning process? Might there be anything in need of adjustment? Selecting voluntary participants. Having a reliable team behind you to assist you in training is of most importance. Everyone involved should be aware of what exactly they need to teach how to approach training within a reasonable time frame. Developing a timetable. Find common ground between everyone involved, including both mentors trainees, settle on when to teach what topic. Recommend tools to easily manage bigger teams are Google Docs similar, but bots self made timetables will suffice, too. Try to keep it simple easily accessible for everyone involved. Communication. Who responds to whom? Decide on how when mentors report to head of staff other higher ups. Documenting helps with ensuring everyone is aware of their part planning how to proceed further. Flexibility. No matter how carefully you plan everything out, it can always happen that something doesnat work according to plan. In such situations you need to be able to react spontaneously be flexible, such as pitching in for someone who is unable to attend due to a last minute shift in schedule. How to Deliver Effective Training Before conducting training, you should evaluate what can make your training most effective. Below you will find some best practices to set up a training program be able to atrain trainersa. Planning When you are giving a training, it is important to properly plan your training. What are most important topics to cover? What do you want new moderators to know after conducting training? How much time are you planning to spend on training? Some people struggle to focus for a longer period of time, so if your training takes over two hours, you should consider breaking your training up into multiple sessions of shorter duration. Make sure to accommodate for any accessibility issues notes for those who were unable to be present. Goals Each training should have objectives. You can create an outline of your training where you write down topics you will cover objective of that topic. For example, if you are training moderators to use Modmail, your objective is that new moderators are able to handle Modmail tickets use commands available to them. For each topic, also write down how you want to give this training: are you going to give a demonstration? Will you use illustrations? Will you offer new moderators to practice during your training get hands-on experience? Publicly sharing this with trainees can help keep you on topic allow them to come prepared with questions Practice After creating your training, make sure to practice it at least once. First, go through entire training yourself to see if everything is covered that you think is important. You can then give your training to someone on your team, in case you missed something important to check whether not your estimated time is accurate. If it is possible, go through material with someone who is unfamiliar with moderation. Adjust your training appropriately you are good to go! Interaction For every training session, it is very important to have interaction with your trainees. People lose their attention after 15-30 minutes, so your training should include a discussion, practice, some sort of interaction. Some of these interactive sessions are covered down below. Interaction with your trainees is also important because it acts as a way for you to verify whether not your objectives are properly conveyed. Make sure there is a break once every one to two hours so trainees can focus on your training without feeling overwhelmed. Methods Every training can consist of a combination of different training methods. These include, but are not limited to, lectures, quick exercises, group discussions, practice runs, quizzes, videos, demonstrations, more. When planning your training, you can write down what method would work best to convey objectives to your trainees. A group discussion will be better applicable to discuss moderation cases, where a demonstration practice would work better to demonstrate how Modmail bots work. Try mixing up multiple methods within a training to keep it fresh keep people from losing their attention. Preparation Preparation is key when you are giving any sort of training. Have quick notes ready with keywords that you are going to use during your training, so you do not lose track of where you are what objective you are trying to convey. If you need any material such as a presentation, paper pencil, example cases such, prepare them beforehand so you do not lose time during your training setting these up. If you use any material, test them beforehand. Donat forget to clear your schedule beforehand have some water ready if your training is mostly conducted over a voice chat call. It is important to sleep well night before feel confident. This will let you remain focused have an uninterrupted training session. Make sure you are ready at least five minutes before training starts to welcome arriving trainees as a final check whether not everything is ready good to go. If your training takes place in a voice chat call, test your microphone if you have a wireless headset, make sure it is charged up beforehand! Wrapping up your training When your training is done, finish with an exercise, group discussion, something else that is interactive fun to do. Ideally, this should summarize entire training. Have some room at end to answer any questions your trainees might have. Donat forget to thank everyone who participated for their active contributions! Evaluation After each training, write down what went well what could be improved. You can ask your trainees after they have had some experience as a moderator, what they missed during training that they think should be covered next time, as well as asking what information they did not find useful. You can then adjust your training for next time! Summary Having a training onboarding process in place is very important to have new moderators get accustomed with moderation culture, using bot commands, server rules, your moderation guidelines. There are several training methods that include buddy mentor systems as well as exercises demonstrations. A training document should outline most important information new moderators need, but prevent them from being overwhelmed with information they are unable to comprehend. To have efficient training in place, there are some very important aspects to consider, such as your preparation, goals, how you will carry out training of your new moderators, planning. Considering all of these things when creating your training process will make onboarding as informational effective as possible for you your new recruits! Reddit X Discord Does Your Subreddit Need a Discord? Discord communities are distinct from subreddits attract different audiences. While there are often overlaps between those audiences, it will not always be case, itas important to determine whether your community will benefit from having a Discord before you attempt to start one. Successful Discord communities revolve around human connections conversations not just content. For a Reddit community to translate well into a Discord community, it should be centered around a topic its members are passionate about are highly engaged with. To start, ask yourself following questions: If you believe answers to those questions would be negative about your community, it might be helpful to take a step back reconsider whether a Discord server would benefit it. Moderation Teams Typically, itas best to keep Reddit Discord moderation teams separate. Your Discord is a separate ecosystem with its own needs - itas important to find users from within it that will help you develop maintain it, make it flourish. When starting off, adding your existing subreddit moderator team usually works. However, itas important to note that those mods might not always be as dedicated to this new platform as they are to one that they came from. Looking into future for your Discord server, things might change subreddit mods that helped it in early days might end up having to take a backseat in favor of users who are brought in from within server. owner of server should be a dedicated mod from subreddit who knows both community inner-workings of Discord. Decisions made by owner will be critical to development of your server, so take a moment to review all of potential candidates within your team to choose best one for task. Make sure to bring in at least one user subreddit mod who is also as knowledgeable with Discord ecosystem familiar with your existing community to help with setup administration of server early on. You now have a bunch of mods! Mods on your subreddit, mods dedicated to your Discord server, mods that are both. But what do you do with all these mods, how do you tell them apart, what perms should they have? Communication between your different teams is key to success of both of your communities. Outside of owner, you should ideally have at least two other moderators that are present on both teams. These shared mods will be able to efficiently relay information between teams, coordinate collaborations between Reddit Discord communities, be able to take action in emergency situations, mediate conflicts if they occur. A Here are a few best practices: Itas important to be upfront to your community about fact that your subreddit Discord server are run moderated by completely separate mod teams after server starts taking shape. Set up escalation paths for both of your teams to direct issues related to your subreddit to Reddit modmail, vice-versa, direct users experiencing issues within server to its team. A All staff positions (except owner lead admins) should be independent of useras status on different moderation teams, you should remind your staff team that it is not a given to be modded elsewhere if you become a mod on either platform. Mods that participate in multiple teams must still uphold your activity requirements, meet all of your expectations similarly to rest of your team. Hosting Events Cross Promotions While your communities are linked together, theyare separate entities with different groups of regular visitors contributors. When considering cross platform promotions, assess their relevance to each of your audiences, determine whether they will find it helpful. A few best practices around this topic are: Closing notes Creating a Discord server can be a great way to broaden your subreddit-based community's horizons, giving your users a whole new way to interact with each other. However, it's important to remember that maintaining a Discord community can be a whole lot of work that some of your existing team members might not be interested in taking. Finding right person to lead your Discord ensuring your community's new outpost is in good hands early on will ensure a lasting smooth relationship between your subreddit Discord, to everyoneas benefit. Securing Your Discord Account Account Security first step towards securing server you moderate is securing your own Discord account. Your first line of defense is a strong unique password. Some characteristics of strong passwords include: You can also use a random password generator a password manager to create a completely random password that will be nearly impossible to guess, but difficult to remember. Another option is to combine several random words together. key, though, is that words need to be completely random. Using a tool to help select words at random from dictionary is a good way to help ensure their randomness. Once you have a strong password, you should also enable two-factor authentication, also known as 2FA. 2FA ensures that even if someone manages to guess your password, they wonat be able to get into your account without access to device where 2FA app is. You can also enable 2FA via SMS receive your authentication code via text message. However, SMS 2FA is less secure than application-based 2FA because text messages can be intercepted your phone number could be stolen. Although chance of this is still low, you should still avoid enabling SMS backup for this reason if possible. You also need to make sure devices where your Discord account is logged in device that has your 2FA app are physically secure. Make sure your computer is password protected locked when you are physically away from it. If you use a public computer, make sure that you use incognito mode on web browser to ensure that your Discord information is removed when you close browser. For a phone tablet, require a PIN code to unlock it so that it canat be used by strangers. Now that your account is nice secure, there is one more thing you must closely monitor to ensure it doesnat fall into wrong hands: yourself. Avoiding Social Engineering Attacks weakest link in any cybersecurity system is usually a human, security of your Discord account is no exception. Social engineering is use of deception to manipulate individuals into divulging confidential personal information that may be used for fraudulent purposes. People attempting to gain access to your Discord account may attempt to get you to log into a fake site, download a malicious file, click on a suspicious link. Being able to identify these actions avoiding potential pitfalls is an important part of keeping your account (and servers you moderate) safe. One of most common dangerous scams on Discord is a user a bot sending out a direct message with a QR code saying that you should scan QR code with Discordas QR code scanner for free nitro. This will generally be combined with instructions on how to access use Discordas QR code scanner. However, it is important to remember that Discord's QR code scanner is only used to log in to Discord. Scanning given QR code will allow that attacker to directly log into your account, bypassing your password any 2FA you may have configured. If you accidentally scan a suspicious QR code, you should immediately change your password as this will invalidate your current account token log you out of all devices.You can also report any such scams directly to Discord Trust Safety for further action. For more information on making reports, check out this article. Another common attack is to encourage you to click on a link that redirects to a fake Discord website. Before clicking on any links from a user, ask yourself following questions: If you find that answer to many of above questions is ayesa, you should avoid performing whatever action they are requesting. You can also check any suspicious-looking URLs with various URL checkers, such as this one. If user is specifically asking you to click on a link that prompts you to log in to Discord, another option you have is to navigate directly to https://discord.com in your web browser log in from there. If clicking on useras link still takes you to a login page, double check URL of website. One thing youall want to check is if website starts with https:// instead of http:, that there is a lock next to beginning of URL. Although some fake sites may still have an https:// designation, many of them will not. Other signs may be slight misspellings of URL visual tricks such as diiscrd.com dlscord.com with a lowercase ala instead of an aia. If you notice any of these signs, it is highly likely that it is not actually Discordas website instead a fake website intended to trick you into entering your login credentials so that it can steal your account. a Conclusion Creating a strong password, enabling 2FA, following best practices for physical device security are first steps towards keeping your Discord account secure. However, there may be people that try to trick you into giving access to your Discord account through various scams other social engineering attacks. Being able to spot suspicious messages users being cautious when encountering strange links files is another important part of keeping your account safe. Of course, anyone that is able to illicitly gain access to a moderator account on your server still has potential to do great harm, such as banning users deleting messages, channels, roles. Be sure to share this information with other moderators on your server so that you can each do your part to keep your community safe by keeping your accounts secure. Parasocial Relationships Definition A parasocial relationship describes a one-sided relationship between a spectator who develops a personal attachment through various influences to a performer who is not aware of existence of spectator. It is strengthened by continuous positive exposure to its source, which mainly happens on social platforms. Process In this section weall take a look at how parasocial relationships are developed how to establish severity of level of parasocial relationships you are encountering from a moderation standpoint. Development of Parasocial Relationships establishment of parasocial relationships can be portrayed as such: User A, in this example a popular content creator, uploads regular content on a big platform. User B, who takes position as a member of User Aas audience, takes an interest in their content. User B reacts to User Aas content observes them. While User A may know that people are enjoying their content, they are unlikely to be aware of every viewersa existence. This total awareness becomes more unlikely bigger audience gets. User B on other hand is regularly exposed to User Aas content takes a liking to them. interest is usually defined by User Aas online persona: content, visual appeal, likeability, even their voice can all be influencing aspects. User B perceives User A as very relatable through common interests behaviors starts to develop a feeling of loyalty, even responsibility, during that phase of one-sided bonding. This behavior can be attributed to personal reflection in User A, as well as psychological facts like loneliness, empathy, even low self-esteem. As a consequence, User B can easily be influenced by User A. At this point User B might feel like they understand User A in a way nobody else does may even begin to view them on a personal level as some sort of friend close relative. They see this individual every day, hear their voice on a regular basis, believe that they are connecting to them on a deep level. They develop an emotional attachment, stronger parasocial relationship gets, more attention User B pays to User Aas behavior mannerisms. While User A most likely doesnat know User B personally, User B will seek out interaction with recognition from User A. That behavior is typically represented through donations on stream, where User A either reads out their personal message name publishes a athank youa message on certain websites. Additionally, User B tries to follow engage with their idol on as many platforms as possible aside from their main source of content creation. These social media platforms are usually Instagram Twitter, but can also include User Aas Discord server. Levels of Parasocial Relationships While that type of relationship is natural sometimes even desired, it is important to define level of parasocial relationships differ between its intensity for safety of community, staff members, performer. In their article in Psychology focused academic journal aThe Psychologista, researchers Giles Maltby designed three levels of severity of parasocial relationships based on Celebrity Attitude Scale. aFans are attracted to a favourite celebrity because of their perceived ability to entertain to become a source of social interaction gossip. Items include aMy friends I like to discuss what my favourite celebrity has donea aLearning life story of my favourite celebrity is a lot of funa.a least harmful level is general public social presence. targeted celebrity is subjected to gossip mostly provides a source of entertainment. Their presence is mostly found in talks with friends, talk shows, on magazine covers, similar public-facing media. Discord users on this level usually interact with community in a relaxed, harmless way. next level is parasocial interaction. characteristics of this level are development of an emotional attachment of a spectator with a performer, resulting in intense feelings. This behavior is characterized by spectator wanting to get to know performer, followed by desire to be part of their life as well as considering them as part of their own life. A result of that can be addictive even obsessive behavior, which can be noticed in Discord servers, too. aThe intense-personal aspect of celebrity worship reflects intensive compulsive feelings about celebrity, akin to obsessional tendencies of fans often referred to in literature. Items include aMy favourite celebrity is practically perfect in every waya aI consider my favourite celebrity to be my soulmatea.a Spectators of that level usually ping performer message them privately in an attempt to be recognized. While that behavior is natural, anything that endangers safe interactions between themselves, community, performer needs to be supervised carefully. Unrestrained abusive behavior, which can be found in unwanted intimate, borderline NSFW questions comments, needs to be addressed corrected accordingly. final level is considered most intense level also most dangerous. It contains severe, harmful obsessions that can extend all way to stalking real-world consequences. Parasocial relationships to this degree will rarely be found on Discord, but have to immediately be reported if present. aThis dimension is typified by uncontrollable behaviours fantasies about their celebrities. Items include aI would gladly die in order to save life of my favourite celebritya aIf I walked through door of my favourite celebrityas house she he would be happy to see mea.a vast majority of users wonat reach level past seeing performer as a source of entertainment, but moderators should be aware of potential consequences of anything beyond that as they can be harmful to both spectator, performer, safe environment you are working to upkeep for all. Parasocial Relationships on Discord Parasocial relationships on Discord can pertain to anyone who is perceived as being popular influential, making them acelebritiesa of Discord. Some examples of parasocial relationships on Discord can be found between a user a moderator, a user a content creator you are moderating for, even a member of your moderation team content creator you are working for. But what does all that mean for you, mod? While Discord moderators are not nearly as popular influential as big content creators celebrities, they are still observed by Discord users. While being a moderator puts you into a position of power responsibility over wellbeing of server, some users perceive it as you climbing social ladder in Discord server. In their eyes, becoming a moderator changes your overall social status within your Discord community. Being hoisted higher in serversa hierarchy results in members quickly recognizing you potentially treating you differently due to your influence, even becoming afansa of you as a person.
