Some users will soak up any information they can get about you, especially if they realize that you have common interests. This may lead to development of a parasocial relationship between users you. Users you have never interacted with before might see you as a person they would get along with seek out your attention, leading to a one-sided relationship on their part. Having such an audience can be overwhelming at first. People will start to look up to you, younger users especially can easily be influenced by online personas. They might adapt to your behavior even copy your mannerisms. Knowing that, you should always be self-aware of your actions etiquette in public to promote a healthy, sustainable relationship with users. Receiving special attention from users can quickly influence spiral into developing an arrogant, entitled attitude. There is nothing wrong with being proud of your position accomplishments, but being overtly arrogant will influence a membersa behavior towards you. mindset of one user deciding a moderator is not being responsible can spread through community in negative ways. They might belittle you in front of new members give them feeling that you wonat be there to help them might not inform you of ongoing problems on server during a temporary absence of moderators in chat. A healthy user-moderator relationship is important to prevent stop ongoing raids as well as make moderators aware of a user misbehaving in chat. Additionally, itas important to be mindful that your perceived fame does not start to negatively influence your judgment. For example, you may find yourself giving special attention to those who seem to appreciate you while treating users that are indifferent towards your position as a moderator more harshly. It also causes dynamics within staff team to change as fellow moderators might start to perceive you differently if you begin to allow bias to seep into moderation. They may start to second guess your decisions, feel need to check up on your moderator actions, even lose trust in your capabilities. If you ever notice that you experience said effect, notice one of your fellow moderators is experiencing it letting it consume them, be supportive sort out negative changes. When confronting another moderator about it, make sure to do it through constructive criticism that doesnat seem like a personal attack. In spite of that, effects of parasocial relationships donat always have to be negative in nature. If users manage to build such a connection to a moderation team, general server atmosphere can grow positively. Users know what moderators like donat enjoy, which will lead them to behave in a way that appeals to staff usually abides by server rules. They will also be able to predict a moderatorsa reaction to certain behavior messages new people might use. As a result, they will attempt to correct users that are mildly misbehaving themselves without getting staff involved immediately in hopes of receiving positive feedback from staff. Naturally, moderators wonat be able to know of every single person that tries to appeal to them through those actions, but once they are aware that such things happen in certain text channels, it will give them opportunity to focus on other channels provide their assistance there. As mentioned before: In case of content creators who frequently upload videos, streams, other forms of media for their followers, chance of a parasocial phenomenon being developed can be even greater. This will only intensify by joining a creatorsa Discord server. This can be done under false assumption that there will be a higher chance of their messages being read noticed. Your responsibility as a moderator is to neither weaken that bond nor encourage it while providing security for users, staff, content creator. Let users interact in a controlled environment while maintaining privacy of content creator. Some users might even feel like content creator owes them some sort of recognition after long-term support, both through engagement donations. Such a demand can be intensified when theyare shown as ahighera in hierarchy through dedicated Discord roles, such as Patreon/Donator simple activity roles. In case of multiple people building a parasocial relationship with same content creator experiencing that phenomenon, they may see other active users even moderators as arivals.a They see content creator as a close friend in their eyes feel threatened that others, especially those that financially support content creator, perceive them same think they are even closer to them. During such moments, it is recommended to keep peace between users let them know that content creator appreciates every fan they have. While ones providing financial support are appreciated, every viewer is what makes creator as big as they are played a part in getting them to where they are today. Maybe it wonat only be user that feels closer to them by joining server. Many beginner moderators may also find themselves feeling as though they are above rest of community because their idol has entrusted them with power on their server. Being closer to them than most of users can easily fog your judgement; it is essential to prioritize being friendly respectful to users over these personal convictions. When adding moderators to your moderation team, it is important to keep an eye out for this kind of behavior to combat it, to hold your teammates accountable should you see this behavior begin to exhibit in one of your teammates. Making sure your entire team is on same page regarding your duties standing in community is essential to maintaining a healthy moderation environment. As a moderator for a Content Creator, this individual you may admire deeply has put their trust in you to keep their community safe. Falling into machinations of developing an unhealthy parasocial relationship with them directly interferes with your ability to do that, failing not only community but creator. In Conclusion Despite potential dangers from parasocial relationships, fact that they develop at all may indicate that you are doing a good job as a moderator. While positive attention appreciation are key factors to a healthy development, not everyone may like that sort of attention it is completely acceptable to tell your fellow moderators even users themselves about it. At one point you might feel like you reached your limit need a break from moderation managing parasocial relationships aimed at you those around you. Moderator burnout is very real, you should not hesitate to take a break when you need it. Users will view you, as a moderator, as a leader that helps guide your designated Discord server in right direction. As such, you will be a target for rude comments by users that have personal issues with server while simultaneously getting showered with affection by other users who are thankful for what you do for server. Never be afraid to ask for help rely on moderation team if things go too far for your personal boundaries comfort level, even if you are an experienced moderator. Establishing a healthy relationship with community is important, but being able to trust your fellow staff members is even more so. Nobody expects you to build an intimate relationship with every member, but knowing you can count on them their support is essential for team to function correctly. Transparency in Moderation Pros Cons of Transparency While there are certain abest practicesa when it comes to moderation transparency, there is no single system that is right for everyone. amount of transparency you need for your moderation system ultimately depends on your server rules, culture, vision. This article will explain pros cons of transparency ways that you can apply transparency to your moderation system. Though idea of moderation transparency is generally considered to be a good thing, it is important to understand that there are both pros cons to transparency in moderation. Some of these pros cons are described below. To help you understand how pros cons apply to transparency, consider an example in which a moderator publicly warns another user not to call someone a aretarda because it violates an existing aNo Slurs Alloweda rule. Moderation System Now that you are aware of some of pros cons of transparency in moderation, you must next understand components of moderation system so that you can consider ways in which these components can be made more less transparent. Broadly speaking, a moderation system can be split into following components: Transparency communication go hand-in-hand. more you communicate these components to relevant users server as a whole, more transparent your moderation system is. Implementing Transparency There are several ways to implement transparency in each of these components, each with their own pros cons. Each section here will establish ways in which a component can be made more less transparent a recommendation of appropriate level of transparency for each. However, please keep in mind that every serveras needs are different some of pros cons discussed may not apply to your server. It is always important to consider your specific community when it comes to implementing transparency. Your server rules are backbone of your moderation system. They describe how your members should conduct themselves what happens if they donat meet those expectations. In general though, your rules should be specific enough to ensure comprehension compliance without being overly wordy attempting to provide an exhaustive description of prohibited behaviors. For example, giving a couple of examples of NSFW content for a ano NSFW content rulea may help people understand what you interpret as being NSFW, compared to other servers Discord itself. However, too many examples may make list seem fully comprehensive, people will assume that items not on list are fair game. Disclaiming that examples of rule-breaking content are non-exhaustive that moderators have final say in interpreting if someone is breaking rules can help to address users that are interested in testing limits of rules being rules lawyers to escape punishment on a technicality. Developing moderator guidelines is another important part of your moderation system. Similar to your rules guiding conduct of your server members, your moderator guidelines help guide conduct of your moderators. Keeping your moderator guidelines visible to rest of server will encourage compliance from members, enable them to defuse incidents without moderator intervention. Furthermore, providing basic standards of moderator conduct will help users know when itas appropriate to report moderators to server owner for misconduct hold them accountable. However, you should avoid putting too much of your moderator guidelines out in public in order to avoid rules lawyers deliberately misinterpreting spirit of guidelines to their advantage. After developing your moderator guidelines, balancing these pros cons will help you determine how much of your guidelines you should present to public. Logging user infractions is key to ensuring that entire moderation team has same understanding of how often a user has broken rules. Transparency between mod team user in question is important for user to understand when they have received a warning that brings them closer to being banned from server. Informing user of which moderator warned them is important for holding moderators accountable to warnings they issue, but may leave moderators open to harassment by warned users. Having a procedure to deal with harassment that stems from this, is one way to achieve accountability while still protecting your moderators from bad actors in your server. Although communication of infractions is vital to ensure understanding among your server members, it may be prudent to withhold information about exactly how close a user is to being banned so that they do not attempt to toe line by staying just under threshold for being banned. Furthermore, even though a public infraction log may be a good way to promote cohesion transparency by showing examples of unacceptable behavior to rest of server fostering discussion between mod team community, others may think that such a log infringes on user privacy that these logs may constitute a awitch hunt.a It may also leave mods users open to harassment over warnings given received. If you want to encourage a sense of community understanding without taking away user privacy inadvertently encouraging harassment, a better option may be to encourage users to bring up criticisms of rules enforcement in a feedback channel if they wish to. Provided that mod team ensures these conversations remain constructive civil, creating a public medium for these conversations will help others understand how mod team operates allow them to provide feedback on how server is run. Everyone makes mistakes, moderators are no exception. It is important to have a process for users to appeal their warnings punishments if they feel that they were issued unfairly. If you decide to have a public infractions log, you may receive appeals on behalf of warned users from people who were uninvolved in situation if they feel warning was issued unfairly. While this can help with accountability if a user is too nervous to try to appeal their warning, it can also waste time of your mod team by involving someone that does not have a complete understanding of situation. In general, it is better to keep appeal process private between moderation team punished user, primarily via mediums such as direct messages with an administrator through a mod mail bot. During appeal process, it is best to ensure that you clearly calmly walk through situation with appealing user to help them better understand rules while maintaining moderator accountability. Summary In end, there is not a single acorrecta way to manage transparency in your moderation system. appropriate level of transparency will vary based on size of server rules that you implement. However, walking through steps of your moderation system one by one considering various pros cons of transparency will help you determine for yourself how to incorporate transparency into your moderation system. This will help you build trust between moderators non-moderators while preventing abuse on both ends of system. Auto Moderation in Discord Why is Auto Moderation important? Auto Moderation is integral to many communities on Discord, especially those of any notable size. There are many valid reasons for this, some of which you may find apply to your community as well. security that auto moderation can provide can give your users a much better experience in your community, make lives of your moderators easier prevent malicious users from doing damage to your community even joining your community. If youare a well established community, youall likely have a moderation team in place. You may wonder, why should I use auto moderation? I already have moderators! Auto moderation isnat a replacement for manual moderation, rather, it serves to enrich it. Your moderation team can continue to make informed decisions within your community while auto moderation serves to make that process easier for them by responding to common issues at any time more quickly than a real-life moderator can. Different communities will warrant varying levels of auto moderation. Itas important to be able to classify your community consider what level of auto moderation is most suitable to your communityas needs. Keep in mind that Discord does impose some additional guidelines depending on how you designate your community. Below are different kinds of communities their recommended auto moderation systems: If you run a Discord community with limited invites where every new member is known, auto moderation wonat be a critical function unless you have a significantly larger member count. Itas recommended to have at least some auto moderation however, namely text filters, anti-spam, Discordas AutoMod keyword filters. If you run a Discord community that is Discoverable has public invites where new members can come from just about anywhere, itas strongly recommended to have anti-spam text filters Discordas AutoMod keyword filters in place. Additionally, you should be implementing some level of member verification to facilitate server onboarding process. If your community is large, with several thousand members, anti-raid functionality may become necessary. Remember, auto moderation is configurable to your rules, as strict loose as they may be, so keep this principle in mind when deciding what level of automation works best for you. If your Discord community is Verified Partnered, you will need to adhere to additional guidelines to maintain that status. Auto moderation is recommended for these communities in order to feel confident that you can succinctly effectively enforce these guidelines at all times so consider using anti-spam text filters Discordas AutoMod keyword filters. If you have a Vanity URL your community is Discoverable, anti-raid is a must-have in order to protect your community from malicious actors. Built-in moderation features Some of most powerful tools in auto moderation come with your community are built directly into Discord. Located under Server Settings tab, you will find Moderation settings. This page houses some of strongest safety features that Discord has to natively offer. These settings can help secure your Discord community without elaborate setup of a third party bot involved. individual settings will be detailed below. AutoMod AutoMod is a new content moderation feature as of 2022, allowing those with aManage Servera aAdministratora permissions to set up keyword spam filters that can automatically trigger moderation actions such as blocking messages that contain specific keywords spam from being posted, logging flagged messages as alerts for you to review. This feature has a wide variety of uses within realm of auto moderation, allowing mods to automatically log malicious messages protect community members from harm exposure to undesirable spam words like slurs severe profanity. AutoModas abilities also extend to messages within threads, text-in-voice channels, Forum channels giving moderation teams peace of mind that they have AutoModas coverage across these message surfaces without having to worry about adding more manual moderation work by enabling these valuable features. Setting up AutoMod is very straightforward. First, make sure your server has Communities enabled. Then, navigate to your serveras settings click AutoMod tab. From there, youall find AutoMod can start setting up keyword spam filters.a Keyword Filtersa Keyword filters allow you to flag block messages containing specific words, characters, symbols from being posted. You can set up one aCommonly Flagged Wordsa filter, along with up to 3 custom keyword filters that allow you to enter a maximum of 1,000 keywords each, for a total of four keyword filters. When inserting keywords, you should separate each word with a comma like so: Bad, words, go, here. Matches for keywords are exact aware of whitespace. For example, keyword aTest Filtera will be triggered by atest filtera but not atestfiltera atesta. Do note that keywords also ignore capitalisation. To have AutoMod filter messages containing words that partially match your keywords, which is helpful for preventing users from circumventing your filters, you can modify your keywords with asterisk (*) wildcard character. This works as follows: Be careful with wildcards so as to not have AutoMod incorrectly flag words that are acceptable commonly used! AutoModas Commonly Flagged Words keyword filter comes equipped with three predefined wordlists that provide communities with convenient protection against commonly flagged words. There are three predefined categories of words available: Insults Slurs, Sexual Content, Severe Profanity. These wordlists will all share one rule, meaning theyall all have same response configured. These lists are maintained by Discord can help keep conversations in your Community consistent with Discord's Community Guidelines. This can be particularly helpful for Partnered Verified communities. a Both AutoModas commonly flagged word filters custom filters allow for exemptions in form of roles channels, with commonly flagged word filter also allowing for exemption of words from Discordas predefined wordlists. Anyone with these defined roles, sending messages within defined channels containing keywords from Discordas wordlists, will not trigger responses from AutoMod.This is notably useful for allowing moderators to bypass filters, allowing higher trusted users to send more unrestricted messages, tailoring commonly flagged wordlists to your communityas needs. As an example, you could prevent new users from sending Discord invites with a keyword filter of: *discord.gg/*, *discord.com/invites/* then give an exemption to moderators users who have a certain role, allowing them to send Discord invites. This could also be used to only allow sharing Discord invites in a specific channel. Thereas a lot of potential use cases for exemptions! Members with Manage Server Administrator permissions will always be exempt from all AutoMod filters. Bots webhooks are also exempt. Spam, by definition, is irrelevant unsolicited messages. AutoMod comes equipped with two spam filters that allow you to flag messages containing mention spam content spam. Mention spam is when users post messages containing excessive mentions for purpose of disrupting your server unnecessarily pinging others. AutoModas mention spam filter lets you flag block messages containing an excessive number of unique @role @user mentions. You define what is aexcessivea by setting a limit on number of unique mentions that a message may contain, up to 50. It is recommended to select "Block message" as an AutoMod response when it detects a message containing excessive mentions as this prevents notifications from being sent out to tagged users roles. This helps prevent your channels from being clogged up by disruptive messages containing mention spam during mass mention attempts mention raids, saves your members from annoyance of getting unnecessary notifications ghost pings. a This filter identifies spam at large by using a model that has been trained by messages that users have reported as spam to Discord. Enabling this filter is an effective way to block out a variety of messages that resemble spammy content reported by Discord users, identify spammers in your community that should be weeded out. However, this filter isnat perfect might not catch all forms of spam, such as DM spam, copy/pasta repeat messages. You can configure AutoModas keyword spam filters with following automatic responses when a message is flagged: This response will prevent a message containing a keyword spam from being sent entirely. Users will be notified with an ephemeral message when this happens, informing them community has blocked message from being sent. Discord will seamlessly block all messages containing matching keywords, spam content, excessive mentions from your filters from being sent entirely regardless of volume of messages, making this response especially effective for preventing de-escalating raids where raiders try to spam your channels with repeated messages excessive mentions. This response will send an alert containing who-what-where information of a flagged message to a logging channel of your choice. This message will preview what full caught message wouldave looked like, including full content. It also shows a pair of buttons at bottom of message, a Actions Report Issues. Thes action buttons will bring up a user context menu, allowing you to use any permissions you have to kick, ban time out member. message also displays channel message was attempted to be sent in filter that was triggered by message. In future, some auto-moderation bots may be able to detect these messages action users accordingly. a This response will automatically apply a time out penalty to a user, preventing them from interacting in server for duration of penalty. Affected users are unable to send messages, react to messages, join voice channels video calls during their timeout period. Keep in mind that they are able to see messages being sent during this period. To remove a timeout penalty, Moderators Admins can right-click on any offending useras name to bring up their Profile Context Menu select aRemove Timeout.a AutoMod is a very powerful tool that you can set up easily to reduce moderation work keep your community's channels conversations clean welcoming during all hours of day. For example, you may want to use three keyword filters; one to just block messages, one to just send alerts for messages, one to do both. Overall, it's recommended to have AutoMod block messages you wouldn't want community members to see. For example, high harm keywords such as slurs other extreme language should have AutoModas ablock messagea asend alertsa responses enabled. This will allow your moderation team to take action against undesirable messages users behind them while preventing rest of your community from exposure. Low harm keywords commonly spammed phrases can also have AutoModas aBlock messagea response enabled without need to set up alerts. This will still prevent undesirable messages from being sent without spamming your logs with alerts. You can also quickly configure AutoModas keyword spam filters in real-time to prevent de-escalate raids by adding spammed keywords - adjusting your mention limit in event of a mention raid - to prevent raids from causing lasting damage. It's also recommended to have AutoMod send you alerts for more subjective content that requires a closer look from your moderation team, rather than having them being blocked entirely. This will allow your moderation team to investigate flagged messages with additional context to ensure thereas nothing malicious going on. This is useful for keywords that can be commonly misrepresented, sent in a non-malicious context. a Verification Level None - This turns off verification for your community, meaning anyone can join immediately interact with your community. This is typically not recommended for public communities as anyone with malicious intent can immediately join wreak havoc. Low - This requires people joining your community to have a verified email which can help protect your community from laziest of malicious users while keeping everything simple for well-meaning users. This would be a good setting for a small, private community. Medium - This requires user to have a verified email address for their account to be at least 5 minutes old. This further protects your community by introducing a blocker for people creating accounts solely to cause problems. This would be a good setting for a moderately sized community small public community. High - This includes same protections as both medium low verification levels but also adds a 10 minute barrier between someone joining your community being able to interact. This can give you anyone else responsible for keeping things clean in your community time to respond to araidsa, large numbers of malicious users joining at once. For legitimate users, you can encourage them to do something with this 10 minute time period such as read rules familiarize themselves with informational channels to pass time until waiting period is over. This would be a good setting for a large public community. Highest - This requires a joining user to have a verified phone number in addition to above requirements. This setting can be bypassed by robust araidersa, but it takes additional effort. This would be a good setting for a private community where security is tantamount, a public community with custom verification. This requirement is one many normal Discord users wonat fill, by choice inability. Itas worth noting that Discordas phone verification disallows VoIP numbers to be abused. Explicit media content filter Not everyone on internet is sharing content with best intentions in mind. Discord provides a robust system to scan images embeds to make sure inappropriate images donat end up in your community. There are varying levels of scrutiny to explicit media content filter which are: Donat scan any media content - Nothing sent in your community will go through Discordas automagical image filter. This would be a good setting for a small, private community where only people you trust can post images, videos etc. Scan media content from users without a role - Self explanatory, this works well to stop new users from filling your community with unsavoury imagery. When combined with proper verification methods, this would be a good setting for a moderately sized private public community. Scan media content from all members - This setting makes sure everyone, regardless of their roles, isnat posting unsavoury things in your community. In general, we recommend this setting for ALL public facing communities. Once youave decided on base level of auto moderation you want for your community, itas time to look at extra levels of auto moderation bots can bring to table! next few sections are going to detail ways in which a bot can moderate. Bot-controlled Auto Moderation If you want to keep your chats clean clear of certain words, phrases, spam, mentions everything else that can be misused by malicious users youare going to need a little help from a robotic friend two. Examples of bots that are freely available are referenced below. If you decide to use several bots, you may need to juggle several moderation systems. When choosing a bot for auto moderation, you should also consider their capabilities for manual moderation (things like managing mutes, warns etc.). Find a bot with an infraction/punishment system you rest of your moderator team find to be most appropriate. All of bots listed in this article have a manual moderation system. main most pivotal forms of auto moderation are: Each of these subsets of auto moderation will be detailed below along with recommended configurations depending on your community. Itas important your auto moderation bot(s) of choice are adopting cutting edge of Discord API features, as this will allow them to provide better capabilities integrate more powerfully with Discord. Slash commands are especially important as youare able to configure which commands are usable on which bot on a case by case basis for each slash command. This will allow you to maintain very detailed moderation permissions for your moderation team. Bots that support more recent API features are generally also considered to be more actively developed, thus more reliable in regards to reacting to new threat vectors as well as able to adapt to new features on Discord. A severely outdated bot could react insufficiently to a high-harm situation. a As mentioned above, one of more recent features is Slash Commands. Slash commands are configurable per-command, per-role, per-channel. This allows you to designate moderation commands solely to your moderation team without relying on permissions on botas side to work perfectly. This is relevant because there have been documented examples in past of permissions being bypassed on a moderation botas permission checking, allowing normal users to execute moderation commands. a One of most common forms of auto moderation is anti-spam, a type of filter that can detect prevent various kinds of spam. Depending on what bot(s) youare using, this comes with various levels of configurability. One of most common forms of auto moderation is anti-spam, a type of filter that can detect prevent various kinds of spam. Depending on what bot(s) youare using, this comes with various levels of configurability. Anti-spam is integral to running a large private community, a public community. There are multiple types of spam a user can engage in, with some of most common forms listed in table above. These types of spam messages are also very typical of raids, especially Fast Messages Repeated Text. While spam can largely be defined as irrelevant unsolicited messages, nature of spam can vary greatly. However, vast majority of instances involve a user users sending lots of messages with same content with intent of disrupting your community. There are subsets of this spam that many anti-spam filters will be able to catch. For example, if any of following: Mentions, Links, Invites, Emoji Newline Text are spammed repeatedly in one message, spammed repeatedly across several messages, they will provoke most Repeated Text Fast Messages filters appropriately. Subset filters are still a good thing for your anti-spam filter to have as you may wish to punish more less harshly depending on spam. Notably, Emoji Links may warrant separate punishments. Spamming 10 links in a single message is inherently worse than having 10 emoji in a message. Anti-spam will only act on these things contextually, usually in an X in Y fashion where if a user sends, for example, ten links in five seconds, they will be punished to some degree. This could be ten links in one message, one link in ten messages. In this respect, some anti-spam filters can act simultaneously as Fast Messages Repeated Text filters. Sometimes, spam may happen too quickly a bot can fall behind. There are rate limits in place to stop bots from harming communities that can prevent deletion of individual messages if those messages are being sent too quickly. This can often happen in raids. As such, Fast Messages filters should prevent offenders from sending messages; this can be done via a mute, kick ban. If you want to protect your community from raids, please read on to Anti-Raid section of this article. Text filters allow you to control types of words and/or links that people are allowed to put in your community. Different bots will provide various ways to filter these things, keeping your chat nice clean. A text filter is a must for a well moderated community. Itas strongly recommended you use a bot that can filter text based on a banlist. A Banned words filter can catch links invites provided http:// https:// are added to word banlist (for all links) specific full site URLs to block individual websites. In addition, discord.gg can be added to a banlist to block ALL Discord invites. A Banned Words filter is integral to running a public community, especially for Partnered, Community, Verified servers who have additional content guidelines they must meet that a Banned Words filter can help with. Before configuring a filter, itas a good idea to work out what is isnat ok to say in your community, regardless of context. For example, racial slurs are generally unacceptable in almost all communities, regardless of context. Banned word filters often wonat account for context with an explicit banlist. For this reason, itas also important that a robust filter contains allowlisting options. For example, if you add acata to your filter someone says acatcha, they could get in trouble for using an otherwise acceptable word. Filter immunity may also be important to your community as there may be individuals who need to discuss use of banned words, namely members of a moderation team. There may also be channels that allow usage of otherwise banned words. For example, a serious channel dedicated to discussion of real world issues may require discussions about slurs other demeaning language, in this exception channel based Immunity is integral to allowing those conversations. Link filtering is important to communities where sharing links in agenerala chats isnat allowed, where there are specific channels dedicated to sharing that content. This can allow a community to remove links with an appropriate reprimand without treating that misstep with same gravity one would someone who used a slur. Allow/ban-listing templates for links are also a good idea to have. While many communities will use catch-all filters to make sure links stay in specific channels, some links will always be inherently unsavory. Being able to filter specific links is a good feature- with preset filters (like google filter provided by YAGPDB) coming in very handy for protecting your user base without requiring intricate setup on your behalf. However, it is recommended you configure a custom filter as a supplement, to ensure specific slurs, words, etc. that break rules of your community, arenat being said. Invite filtering is equally important in large public communities where users will attempt to raid, scam otherwise assault your community with links with intention of manipulating your user base where unsolicited self-promotion is potentially fruitful. Filtering allows these invites to be recognized instantly dealt with more harshly. Some bots may also allow by-community white/banlisting allowing you to control which communities are approved to share invites to which arenat. A good example of invite filtering usage would be something like a partners channel, where invites to other, closely linked, communities are shared. These communities should be added to an invite allowlist to prevent their deletion. Discord also implements a native filter on links files, though this filter is entirely client-side doesnat prevent malicious links files being sent. It does, however, warn users who attempt to click suspicious links download suspicious files (executables, archives etc.) prevents known malicious links from being clicked at all. While this doesnat remove offending content, shouldnat be relied on as auto moderation, it does prevent some cracks in your auto moderation from harming users. Raids, as defined earlier in this article, are mass-joins of users (often selfbots) with intent of damaging your community. Protecting your community from these raids can come in various forms. One method involves gating your server using a method detailed elsewhere in DMA. Raid detection means a bot can detect large number of users joining thatas typical of a raid, usually in an X in Y format. This feature is usually chained with Raid Prevention Damage Prevention to prevent detected raid from being effective, wherein raiding users will typically spam channels with unsavory messages. Raid-user detection is a system designed to detect users who are likely to be participating in a raid independently of quantity of frequency of new user joins. These systems typically look for users that were created recently have no profile picture, among other triggers depending on how elaborate system is. Raid prevention stops a raid from happening, either by Raid detection Raid-user detection. These countermeasures stop participants of a raid specifically from harming your community by preventing raiding users from accessing your community in first place, such as through kicks, bans, mutes of users that triggered detection. Damage prevention stops raiding users from causing any disruption via spam to your community by closing off certain aspects of it either from all new users, from everyone. These functions usually prevent messages from being sent read in public channels that new users will have access to. This differs from Raid Prevention as it doesnat specifically target remove new users in community. Raid anti-spam is an anti-spam system robust enough to prevent raiding usersa messages from disrupting channels via typical spam found in a raid. For an anti-spam system to fit this dynamic, it should be able to prevent Fast Messages Repeated Text. This is a subset of Damage Prevention. Raid cleanup commands are typically mass-message removal commands to clean up channels affected by spam as part of a raid, often aliased to aPurgea aPrunea.Built-in anti-raid It should be noted that Discord features built-in raid user bot detection, which is rather effective at preventing raids as before they happen. If you are logging member joins leaves, you can infer that Discord has taken action against shady accounts if time difference between join leave times is extremely small (such as between 0-5 seconds). However, you shouldnat rely solely on these systems if you run a large public community. Messages arenat only way potential evildoers can introduce unwanted content to your community. They can also manipulate their Discord username Nickname to be abusive. There are a few different ways a username can be abusive different bots offer different filters to prevent this. Username filtering is less important than other forms of auto moderation. When choosing which bot(s) to use for your auto moderation needs, this should typically be a later priority, since users with malicious usernames can just be nicknamed in order to hide their actual username. Specialized Auto Moderation Bots So far, weave covered general auto moderation bots with a wide toolset. However, there are some specialized bots that only cover one specific facet of auto moderation execute it especially well. A few examples descriptions are below: This bot detects raids as they happen globally, banning raiders from your community. This is especially notable as itall ban detected raiders from raids in other communities itas in as they join your community, making it significantly more effective than other anti-raid solutions that only pay attention to your community. Fish is designed to counter scamming links accounts, targeting patterns in joining users to prevent DM raids (Like normal raids, but members are directly messaged instead). These DM raids are typically phishing scams, which Fish also filters, deleting known phishing sites. Both of these bots are highly specialized link file moderation bots, effectively filtering adult sites, scamming sites other categories of sites as defined by your moderation team. Which bot do I use? When choosing a bot for auto moderation you should ensure it has an infraction/punishment system you your mod team are comfortable with as well as its features being whatas best suited for your community. Consider testing out several bots their compatibility with Discordas built-in auto moderation features to find what works best for your serveras needs. You should also keep in mind that list of bots in this article is not comprehensive - you can consider bots not listed here. world of Discord moderation bots is vast fascinating, we encourage you to do your own research! For largest of communities, itas recommended you employ everything Discord has to offer. You should use High Highest Verification level, all of Discordas AutoMod keyword filters a robust moderation bot like Gearbot Gaius. You should seriously consider additional bots like Fish, Beemo Safelink/Crosslink to aid in keeping your users safe have detailed Content Moderation filters. At this scale, you should seriously consider premium, self hosted, custom moderation bots to meet unique demands of your community. You should use High Verification level to aid in preventing raids. If raiding isnat a large concern for your community, Gearbot Giselle are viable options. Your largest concerns in a community of this size is going to be anti-spam text filters meaning robust keyword filters are also highly recommended, with user filters as a good bonus. Beemo is generally recommended for any servers of this size. At this scale a self hosted, custom, premium bot may also be a viable option, but such bots arenat covered in this article. Itas recommended you use Fire, Gearbot, Bulbbot, AutoModerator Giselle. Mee6 Dyno are also viable options, however as theyare very large bots have been known to experience outages, leaving your community unprotected for large amounts of time. At this community size, youare likely not going to be largely concerned about anti-raid with anti-spam text filters being your main focus. Youall likely be able to get by just using AutoModas keyword filters commonly flagged words lists provided by Discord. User filters, at this size, are largely unneeded your Verification Level shouldnat need to be any higher than Medium. If your community is small private, likelihood of malicious users joining to wreak havoc is rather low. As such, you can choose a bot with general moderation features you like most use that for auto moderation. Any of bots listed in this article should serve this purpose. At this scale, you should be able to rely solely on AutoModas keyword filters. Your Verification Level is largely up to you at this scale depending on where you anticipate member growth coming from, with Medium being default recommended. Configuring Auto Moderation for listed bots Mee6 First, make sure Mee6 is in communities you wish to configure it for. Then, look at its documentation (https://gearbot.rocks/docs) for full details on how to configure auto moderation for your community. Using Webhooks Embeds What is a Webhook? A webhook is sort of a areverse APIa: rather than an application you own (like a bot) calling another application to receive data when it wants it, a webhook is something you can give to someone else's application to send data to you directly as soon as thereas something to share. This makes process very convenient efficient for both providers users. Now letas apply this definition to a more tangible example. Letas say you arenat around to reply to new e-mails for a while. Through power of webhooks you could have a setup that replies automatically! When an event happens on a service (like receiving an email), that service activates your webhook sends you data relevant to event that happened. That way, you have exactly information you need to automatically reply to each new e-mail you receive. So what does this mean for your server? Basically, Discord provides you with ability to have a webhook that sends a message to your server when itas activated, with option to send message to any channel along with having a cool name avatar of your choice.For example, letas say youare waiting for latest chapter of your favorite webcomic series to release. You can set up a webhook thatas connected with an RSS feed. feed will activate webhook when chapter is released a message will be posted on your server to notify you about it. This can be applied to many different things - potential is limitless! If service is capable of sending JSON Webhooks, Discord can often use these to create visually appealing embeds when it sends a message out. However, it can also accept raw text messages to pass along as well. Usage of Webhooks Webhooks are a great tool for services that have events that youare interested in latching onto. This can be incredibly useful for Content Creator communities where their latest YouTube videos Twitter posts can be funneled into channels for followers to have easy viewing access in your Discord community. You could also use this for a community thatas oriented towards an open-source technology by having events from GitHub be submitted directly to your server for people to keep track of. There are a lot of platforms out there that provide you with ability to handle everything by yourself- from creating Webhook through your Discord Server Settings to plugging it into platform you want updates from. However, this often requires you to be more familiar with at least some level of programming as many of these platforms require developer accounts. There can be a few hoops to jump through to get everything set up just right. This can often turn people off from using these types of webhooks. However, times are changing barrier to entry when dabbling into world of webhooks is much lower. These days, multiple third-party services exist that have handled all hard techy stuff for you. They can interface with platforms that would normally require you to do extra work to get data you want. IFTTT Zapier are two such services that lets you plug-and-play several useful platforms directly into your Discord server through a clean web interface that allows you to customize type of data your webhook receives, thus what messages are sent to your server. Just keep in mind that some services have restrictions on how many events can be sent to one webhook, so you may have to create multiple distinct webhooks for multiple functionalities. Note that these options restrictions are entirely platform-dependent. Discord has no problems handling whatever data is thrown at its webhooks when activated, even if itas from different sources. Thereas another use-case for Webhooks that is more unique. While theyare very useful for automated messages, theyare also great for one-off embed messages that have a very polished look! You have ability to customize name avatar of webhook, but if youare technologically-inclined you can create your own JSON data to activate webhook with. This allows you to fully define aesthetics of an embed in your message, giving a clean look to whatever information youare sending. One possible application is nice formatting for your server rules information, rather than just sending multiple plain text messages.Of course, there are other possible uses, only limit is your creativity! If youare not too keen on developing JSON data by hand, have no idea what a aJSONa is, services like Discohook also make it easy for anyone to take advantage of this use case. As a note, websites linked here are not endorsed by Discord are only a suggestion from authors of article. How do I set up a webhook? process of setting up webhooks can be roughly explained in five simple steps! Step 1: In your Discord server, you will need to create a webhook copy webhook URL. This URL is path for your webhook to receive an HTTP POST request from a service when an event occurs. Step 2: From this menu, you have ability to style your webhook with a name avatar. We recommend at least a name to distinguish its purpose. Step 3: If youare using a third-party service to handle events send messages, plug your webhook URL into service configure type of events that service should trigger for. Step 4: If your third-party service allows you to, configure additional options that will change look content of your message to way you like. Step 5: Now that youave created connection, when event happens, data will be sent directly to Discord your webhook will post a message in your preferred channel! What is an Embed? Weave been talking about embeds a lot, but we havenat quite explained what they are yet! In simple terms, embedding refers to integration of links, images, GIFs, videos other forms of content into messages on social media. An embed itself is a part of message that visually represents content in order to increase engagement. As a user of Discord, you have probably seen embeds more than a few times. They often are created automatically by Discord when a user sends a link, such as allowing you to view a YouTube video within Discord when a YouTube URL is shared. But did you know that Discord Bots Webhooks can create their own embeds with all kinds of data? Theyare pretty flexible! They can have colored borders, images, text fields, other kinds of fancy properties. If you're a developer, options available to you to create a good-looking embed are powerful versatile. For non-developers, platforms may give you visualizations that help you plug-and-play data into a website for customization purposes. There are also online tools to help you do this too! Here are several of those properties that can be modified in an embed in order to style it, to give you an idea of whatas possible when you have ability to style your messages: Markdown is also supported in an embed. Here is an image to showcase an example of these properties: Example image to showcase elements of an embedAn important thing to note is that embeds also have their limitations, which are set by API. Here are some of most important ones you need to know:An important thing to note is that embeds also have their limitations, which are set by API. Here are some of most important ones you need to know: If you feel like experimenting even further you should take a look at full list of limitations provided by Discord here.Itas very important to keep in mind that when you are writing an embed, it should be in JSON format. Some bots even provide an embed visualizer within their dashboards. You can also use this embed visualizer tool which provides visualization for bot webhook embeds. a Benefits of using Webhooks There are several benefits to using webhooks in your community including simplicity, versatility, automation, customization, accessibility. Simplicity. Webhooks are straightforward lacking in complexity. They have a single function, which is to send a designated message when they are activated. Versatility. Webhooks have many different use cases, all stemming from being able to send a message upon activation. This allows for many types of automation powered by other services, allows you to send clean looking messages manually. Both of these setups have their own various uses ranging from posting updates logging to posting custom messages for an aesthetic purpose. Automation. With webhooks, there isnat a need to constantly look for updates post them yourself. Once set up, a webhook will automatically post any updates you need. Customization. Each webhook can have a unique name avatar, each message it sends can be unique as well. You can have multiple webhooks with different looks in different channels use each of them however you like. Accessibility. Once you create a webhook, all you need is its URL a website that will push messages. Since these webhooks are hosted on Discord, they donat need to be hosted like a normal bot, often saving moderation teams from encountering a financial investment to use them, making them more easily available to all users. Webhooks vs. Bots Webhooks bots, while having slight similarities, are actually very different from each other. There are several aspects we have to look at when comparing two: a Even though this comparison is important for better understanding of both bots webhooks, it does not mean you should limit yourself to only picking one other. Sometimes, bots webhooks work their best when working together. Itas not uncommon for bots to use webhooks for logging purposes to distinguish notable messages with a custom avatar name for that message. Both tools are essential for a server to function properly make for a powerful combination. a Even though this comparison is important for better understanding of both bots webhooks, it does not mean you should limit yourself to only picking one other. Sometimes, bots webhooks work their best when working together. Itas not uncommon for bots to use webhooks for logging purposes to distinguish notable messages with a custom avatar name for that message. Both tools are essential for a server to function properly make for a powerful combination. Summary Thanks to their simplicity accessibility, webhooks have become a staple in many communities. Despite their limitations lack of functions compared to bots, theyare still very useful A play an important role in automation decoration of your server. Overall, webhooks are a great tool for pushing various messages, with limitless customization opportunities. Ultimately, choice of using them depends solely on your needs preferences. Internal Conflict Resolution Causes of Internal Conflicts There can be many causes for conflicts between your moderators, some of which occur more often than others. Some of these can easily be prevented, while others might need a more intentful thought process to stop them from escalating to a conflict. Personality Clashes Differences main reason for conflicts to arise is a difference in personalities amongst your team. Everyone perceives, analyzes responds differently to certain situations. While this should be a learning opportunity for everyone involved, it can lead to arguments when moderators can not get along. While emphasizing there are different approaches to same issue, you should teach moderators to learn from each other instead of disagreements ending in a conflict. When a moderator constantly disagrees with someone else, ends up in a personal argument, try taking them aside let them know that they should be working on their personal issues. You can help them as an objective observer - it can be very valuable to let members of your team know that you understand their individual perspectives are working to balance them. Try to avoid aHalo/Horns effecta as much as possible. This is a type of cognitive bias where your view of someoneas actions can influence how you think feel about that person in general, both positively as well as negatively. Poor Communication Misunderstandings between your moderators can lead to a conflict as well, especially when there is a different understanding of how a situation should be handled. Having transparent, consistent communication where everyone is on same page is very important in an online setting such as Discord. Text is often perceived differently than talking over voice even in person. Oftentimes a language barrier can lead to misinterpreting a message as well. Try to prevent misunderstandings from happening with clear communication when misunderstandings happen, step in where possible explain how situation should be handled. Foster a culture where it is not only allowed but encouraged to ask for clarification on someoneas statement if you have any doubts about what their intent was. Bullying Harassment Making jokes is beneficial for maintaining a healthy welcoming environment even a way to deal with tough situations moderators may face. However, it is important to make sure that jokes donat push boundaries of what is appropriate lead to perceived bullying of server members behind closed doors, even other members of your own team.What is perceived to be a harmless in-joke in context could out of context seem like a malicious unwarranted comment. When it is clear someone is not comfortable with certain jokes feels targeted, you need to step in clear situation by telling moderators involved that you want a positive atmosphere where everyone feels welcomed comfortable while clearly identifying what line was crossed so it does not happen again. Thatas not to say that all close knit groups trend towards exclusionary jokes, but it is something that can happen without a team even being cognizant that itas a problem. Hence why itas pertinent to keep inclusivity good faith intent in mind with situations like this. Unfair Treatment A main cause for conflicts is unfair treatment amongst members of your team. This might be because there is a lack of equal opportunities, because there are unrealistic expectations. Make sure that everyone on your team is treated equally as everyone deserves same treatment, regardless of your personal relationships. This also means you other moderators should have reasonable expectations of each other. Moderators often volunteer to help out in your community, so donat expect them to be available at all times; they might have other responsibilities as well. Any mod teamas north star should be that areal life comes firsta, to be lenient amongst themselves in face of that. Unclear Responsibilities Sometimes it is not clear what responsibilities everyone has on team. This can lead to misunderstandings eventually to conflicts. Make sure everyone on team receives adequate training information on what different roles positions should be doing. You might want to divide different responsibilities amongst members of your team between different roles, such as moderators administrators. Be as transparent clear as possible on what everyone should be doing. Competition Sometimes moderators feel that they are competing against each other, especially if there are statistics promotions available. You should always be clear that moderation is not about competition, it is about helping your community in best way possible. Not every moderator has same time available to help, so naturally there are going to be differences amongst your team. Moderation is not about quantity but quality - if this negatively skewed competitive atmosphere is a frequent issue, it may be worth looking at whether there are mechanisms within your community that encourage competition conflicts that could be removed revised, such as quotas, public moderation statistics, leaderboards. Different Values Standards Moderators usually come from all over world might have different values. Sometimes, these might result in a conflict. Remind your moderators that they should always respect each other's values, regardless of their own opinion. Moderators should be able to explain why they feel a certain way in order for others to be more understanding of situation. When someone has values that do not align with serveras moderation philosophy, you might need to remove them from your team. Unresolved Underlying Issues It is not always possible to immediately see a reason for a conflict, this might be due to unresolved underlying issues. It is very hard to know these without having a conversation with everyone involved. There can be many more causes for a dispute to arise, but it is always important to find underlying issue which causes a conflict, only then are you able to resolve it. Preventing Internal Conflicts To minimize prevent conflicts from happening, try as best as you can to get a comprehensive view of why how conflicts occur in your server. It is very important to develop interpersonal relationships with all of your moderators value their contributions to server. Encourage moderators to take initiative in projects they are enthusiastic about, especially in collaboration with other moderators. Just as moderators set a positive example in your community, you as leader of your moderation team should set a positive example within your team. When you propose major changes to server, listen to your teamas viewpoints before deploying explain why a decision was made. Good communication is very important within a team, not only to prevent conflicts, but also to keep all moderators on same page. All moderators should feel involved informed when you are making major changes. You can give your moderators regular feedback on how they are doing what they can improve. Make sure moderators always feel welcome to provide feedback constructively positively to each other that they can always contact you someone in charge in case a conflict does arise. Try to discourage gossip within your team, both internal external. When moderators start to talk about each other behind their backs, it becomes personal can distort relationship your moderators have how they see themselves within server. Instead, encourage moderators to form friendships with each other by organizing social events for your staff. During those events, you can learn about different personalities in your team. Last, but not least; you shouldnat lash out over mistakes.Give feedback where it is appropriate move on. Be quick to forgive forget. You should always prevent belittling your moderators while also creating a culture of de-escalating situations in private. Resolving an Internal Conflict There are many ways to resolve conflict internally most of these will depend on what cause is for conflict. A good way of resolving conflicts is using Thomas-Kilmann model. It should be stated that conflicts are not necessarily bad shouldnat be avoided at all costs. When you are working in a team, it is important to be able to challenge status quo question each other, to keep everyone on aligned up to date. In Thomas-Kilmann model, there are two dimensions when you are choosing a course of action: assertiveness cooperativeness. Assertiveness is degree to which you try to satisfy your own needs where cooperativeness is degree to which you try satisfy other person's concerns. Based on these dimensions, there are five ways to handle a conflict: All these different ways to handle a conflict are your intention to solve them: Sometimes situations occur differently than you expect at first. Donat jump to conclusions when you are dealing with a conflict, as reasons for conflicts are often more complex than they first appear. A Everyone tends to resolve conflicts in a certain way, so try to balance them so you donat end up overwhelmed overwhelm others. first step is to identify cause for conflict. You might already know this based on previously sent messages, but sometimes you need to contact everyone involved separately in private to determine cause of conflict. It is your responsibility to determine how to handle a situation. While collaborating together to resolve a conflict might look most appealing, this will not always be possible. Try not to completely avoid a conflict: if you feel uneasy dealing with conflicts donat want to give moderators feedback, you might not want to be in a leading position. If you need to resolve a conflict, choose a neutral place to work it out. This might be a separate server a private group. None of people involved in conflict should have power over others, so you someone else should act as an objective observer. If conflict is between other moderators, you should offer guidance, but donat offer solutions: ultimately it is up to others to resolve their conflicts, you are not taking sides. Remember that not all conflicts require consequences. Most conflicts are sparked by passion of your moderators who are simply in disagreement on how to deal with situations. Try to turn a conflict into a learning opportunity for everyone involved. Let them explain how they view situation how they would have handled it behaved differently. Afterwards, you should be able to identify specific disagreements that you can solve. Listen to everyone involved give everyone an equal opportunity to express themselves. Remind everyone to stay respectful at all times, even if they disagree with each other. Giving Receiving Feedback As said before, you should discourage gossip within your team encourage each other to give constructive feedback. It is important that everyone knows how to give receive feedback to prevent a conflict from happening in future situations. Giving Feedback When you notice a moderator that displays behavior takes action that can be improved, you should give them feedback on how to improve this in future. Donat rush in giving your feedback, everyone needs time to process. When a situation becomes heated, it will not be best time to give feedback. Remember to always give feedback in private! If you are in doubt as to whether not you should give feedback, see if you can recognize a pattern in their behavior actions. Everyone makes mistakes that is perfectly fine as mistakes serve as a learning opportunity you should only give them feedback if it becomes a pattern. Additionally, itas recommended that you ask for consent to give feedback. While this may seem a little counterintuitive to helping moderator improve change, blindsiding someone when theyare not ready can result in backlash rather than progress. When you do decide to give someone feedback, donat focus on person who made a mistake: focus on their behavior action instead.By making feedback personal equating it to an issue with individual rather than their choices, you can come off as argumentative unconstructive biased. Never exaggerate their behavior, be sure that you are clear specific . When you make generalized vague comments about someone, they will not be able to improve their behavior. Feedback should be actionable- there should be a suggestion a change that individual can work on as a result of feedback. Otherwise itas just airing your grievances, which is unproductive for all parties involved. next time you see someone doing something good when you have given them feedback in past, give them a compliment! Positive, specific feedback is especially effective in encouraging repeating said good actions. Giving each other positive feedback is just as important as giving each other constructive corrective feedback. Remember to always treat others as you would like to be treated yourself. It is proven that negative feedback is given mostly when people are experiencing negative emotions like hunger, anger, loneliness, tiredness. This negative feedback method is referred to as HALT-mode, it is important to try to avoid situations where you are giving feedback when you find yourself in one of these states. Receiving Feedback When someone is giving you feedback, it is very important to listen to what they have to say. Donat jump to conclusions, react defensively, disagree immediately. Take a moment to summarize feedback as you understand it to make sure you have understood their feedback correctly. You should always thank someone for giving them feedback, even if you disagree. It has to be clear you are welcoming feedback to improve. If you do not thank them, they might not give you valuable feedback in future. Ideally feedback is very clear specific, in which case you can end conversation by thanking them for their feedback reflect back what you are going to do with feedback in future. Other times it might not be understandable to you as a result, it is unclear what you should do differently in future. In this case you should ask questions to understand their feedback better. To have a better understanding of what they want to achieve with their feedback, it is a good idea to ask other person how they would have handled situation how they would have behaved. After this you should thank them reflect back on what you are going to do with their feedback. It is okay to let someone know why you disagree with their feedback, but remember to stay respectful at all times explain clearly why you disagree. Everyone should feel heard, even if you are not acting on their feedback. Handling Demotions There are many reasons why you might want to remove a moderator from your team, including internal conflicts you are unable to resolve. Removing demoting a moderator is not easy to do, but can be a necessary evil. Removing someone from your team should be in best interest of your community team can often be in best interest of that person as well. Be sure to give someone an opportunity to learn from their mistakes before removing them. Give a warning first have a conversation in private with them, following principles of giving receiving feedback outlined above. While it is not easy to deliver bad news, here are some tips to keep in mind when you do want to remove someone from your team. Donat delay conversation Once you have made decision to remove someone from your team, donat hesitate wait for conversation to take place. When someone is causing more issues than they are solving, they will need to be removed sooner than later, but make sure that someone has had enough opportunities to fix their mistakes resolve their issues. Please make sure you have this conversation in private, for example in direct messages a voice call. Keep it short clear When you are talking to someone you are removing, it is important to keep your message short clear. Tell them they are being removed from team, why you have made this decision, when this will take effect. Be transparent in what reasons you have for removing them, but do not go into too much detail with specific examples. This may result in a conversation where you are arguing about these examples rather than informing them of their removal. A Youare aiming for polite dismissal, not a lambasting of their character. Stick to your decision Despite your message being short, clear, transparent, you might still receive counter arguments as to why they should not be removed to give them another chance. It is important they can express themselves, but it should be clear at all times that decision to remove them has already been made is not up for debate. Always listen carefully to what someone has to say appreciate their feedback, but unless someone has substantial evidence a mistake was made, repeat your decision make it clear that your decision is final. Be helpful compassionate Even though you are delivering bad news, you should take a supportive approach in conversation. Remember that while it might be difficult for you to deliver bad news, it most definitely is difficult to be on receiving end. Show empathy for them especially when they have done a good job in past. In some cases, moderator youare removing may wish to receive feedback on what they can improve - giving this feedback in a constructive fashion is important, will help them to avoid future problems. This feedback should include reflecting on positive contributions they made to team, helping them understand what causes of conflict might have been while they were on your team, simply trying to give them something positive to take forward work on as a result of your conversation. This conversation shouldnat reflect a reversal of your decision, but can be a useful point of reference if they want to join other servers work on improving their skills down line, perhaps even re-apply to join team in future. Inform your team When someone has been removed from your team, make sure to inform team of this decision. It is up to you whether not you want to share reason for their removal, but refrain from sharing details as these are confidential, especially when these could be potentially harmful to someone. You also want to prevent anyone, including yourself, from talking bad about them, as this sets a wrong precedent for your team. As with your decision, you should be straightforward clear to your team, an example of this could be: aToday we have decided to remove Sarah from our team. I will not go into too much detail why this decision was made, but we believe it is best decision for community entire team.a In case someone was removed because of misbehavior, you might want to include that in message, as this gives team assurance you are not removing someone because of a personal conflict, it shows a strong message about how you want moderators to conduct themselves. Wrapping Up In every group, eventually a conflict dispute will arise which needs to be resolved. There are common causes, such as personality clashes differences, poor communication, unclear responsibilities, harassment. To minimize prevent conflicts from happening, try understand as much as possible why conflicts occur in your server. It is very important to develop interpersonal relationships with all of your moderators value their contributions to server. Try to discourage gossip within your team. When moderators start to talk about each other behind their backs, it becomes personal can distort relationship your moderators have how they see themselves within server. You can resolve conflicts using Thomas-Kilmann model. It is important to know conflicts are not necessarily bad shouldnat be avoided at all costs. When you are working in a team, it is important to be able to challenge status quo question each other, to keep everyone on same page sharp. When you want to give feedback to someone, talk to them in private be clear specific. Prevent giving feedback when you feel hungry, angry, lonely, tired. Focus on their behavior action instead never exaggerate their behavior. Oppositely, when someone is giving you feedback, it is very important to listen to what they have to say to avoid jumping to conclusions, reacting defensively, disagreeing immediately. Take a moment to summarize feedback to make sure you have understood their feedback correctly. Sometimes you need to remove someone from your staff team. Donat delay this conversation, keep it short clear, stick to your decision. When conversation is taking place, be helpful compassionate do not forget to inform your team as well, but make it clear that certain things remain private for safety privacy of those involved. Keeping all of those points in mind when managing a team environment will be integral to maintaining a healthy atmosphere full of various viewpoints that are united in shared desire to keep your community safe. Using Modmail Bots What are Modmail Bots? Before we discuss how to use a modmail bot, we should explore what they are what purpose they serve. Simply put, modmail bots are bots that allow users to contact moderators of a server via a direct message with bot. bot then relays these messages to entire moderation team by creating a private channel on server visible only to server moderators (also referred to as a aticketa). Moderators can then use this private channel to have bot relay their own messages back to original user, all while keeping a record of entire conversation within server. Moderators can even discuss ticket together in that channel without user seeing since it requires usage of a specific command to send a message to user. There are numerous modmail bots online, each with their own styles features. Some modmail bots can be self-hosted, while others are hosted publicly online! Here are some examples of modmail bots you can use: a It is important to do research into readily available bots to understand what your server needs to choose whichever one best meets those needs. Please note, content of this article is not endorsed by any developer company related to bots. What Can Modmail Contribute to my Server? Before adding a modmail bot into your server, you should determine if you need one by considering benefits drawbacks of modmail bots. Letas review pros cons of modmail bots to help with this decision. One of biggest benefits of having a modmail bot is better organization. Anytime a user opens a ticket, be it a question concern about server, instead of trying to figure out which moderator is online available, a user can quickly DM modmail bot get in contact with entire moderation team while also notifying active moderators online. This also eliminates over usage of pinging entire moderation team in public channels. a next benefit of modmail bots is team discussions. In above example, weare using ModMail bot by CHamburr. As you can see, a user has opened up a ticket that can be viewed by entire moderation team. team can then decide who wants to respond to ticket, as well as discuss ticket in question among themselves more efficiently handle issue. Team discussions are great for trickier questions that not everyone on team might know answer to. In image below, you can see an example of what moderators see from their side. team can split their focus knock out tickets depending on their priority, urgency, even work together to pick up a ticket if another mod has signed off. ability to read through moderator discussions work together is a great team building exercise for moderator teams! a a next benefit of modmail bots are information logs. Most modmail bots have a modmail log that shows all of modmail tickets that have been opened closed along with useful receipts of conversations that happened in channels. This is great for administrators/lead moderators who want to see how cases were handled want to catch up on what theyave missed while offline. This also helps moderators look back on reporting history if an old report is continued at a different period of time if they suspect someone is abusing modmail. Another benefit of having a modmail bot is anonymity. Some modmail bots allow you to reply to user anonymously which can decrease chances of someone harassing a moderator, other unpleasant situations that may come from having to action someone. Users can sometimes get upset want to seek revenge after being banned, muted, kicked from a server, so being able to communicate with someone action them without revealing your identity is extremely valuable.
