Defending Your Online Spaces Editor's Note: On July 1 2024, Supreme Court reaffirmed that moderation decisions are protected by First Amendment of U.S. Constitution. You can read our response to this ruling here. Today, Discord filed an amicus brief with Supreme Court in support of our ongoing efforts to create online communities of shared interests that are safe, welcoming, inclusive. cases at issue (Moody v. NetChoice, et al. NetChoice et al. v. Paxton) challenge constitutionality of two new laws in Texas Florida. You may have heard of them: these laws would significantly restrict ability of online services to remove content that is objectionableA to their users force them to keep a wide range of alawful but awfula content on their sites. Discord is not a traditional social media service, but whether intended not, laws are broad enough to likely impact services like ours. Itas hard to overstate potential impact if these laws are allowed to go into effect: they would fundamentally change how services like Discord operate, with that, experiences we deliver to you. Thereas no doubt that outcome here is hugely important to us as a company, but that alone is not why we are taking a stand. Ultimately, we filed this brief because important context was missing from official record: you all vibrant communities youave built on Discord. Taking a step back, Discord has invested heavily in creating safe fun online spaces. Our Community Guidelines set rules for how we all engage on Discord, we put a lot of effort into enforcing them: around 15% of company works on safety, including content moderation. This includes Trust Safety agents who enforce Discordas rules, engineers who develop moderation tools for both Discord its users, many more dedicated individuals across our company. We do this work so that you can create those online spaces where you can find foster genuine connection. But in order to bring this world to life, Discord needs to be able to prevent, detect, remove harmful speech conduct. Barring companies like Discord from moderating content is a little like barring garbage collection in a city: every individual block would have to devote its own resources to hauling its own garbage, diverting those limited resources from more productive activities individualized curation that makes each neighborhood unique. So, while our rules content moderation efforts certainly reflect our own values speech about kind of services we want to offer, we really do it for you allawe work to take care of hard stuff so you all can focus on creating communities you want. Thatas why we decided to take such a strong position in these cases: we want to make sure Supreme Court understands how these laws would impact your speech your communities. Fortunately, First Amendment has a lot to say about thisait protects your association rights, which make it possible for you to come together around your shared interests see content that is relevant helpful, not harmful.A Keeping your communities fun safe by not allowing harmful content is a top priority for us. We wouldnat be doing what we do without all of you, we will keep working to make sure you can create online spaces you want.A A Discordas Commitment to Teen Child Safety Our Policies You can read an overview of following policies here. Teen Self-Endangerment Policy Teen self-endangerment is a nuanced issue that we do not take lightly. We want our teen users to be able to express themselves freely on Discord while also taking steps to ensure these users donat engage in risky behaviors that might endanger their safety well-being. In order to help our teenage users stay safe, our policies state that users under age of 18 are not allowed to send access any sexually explicit content. Even when this kind of content is shared consensually between teens, there is a risk that self-generated sexual media can be saved shared outside of their private conversations. We want to help our users avoid finding themselves in these situations. In this context, we also believe that dating online can result in self-endangerment. Under this policy, teen dating servers are prohibited on Discord we will take action against users who are engaging in this behavior. Additionally, older teens engaging in grooming of a younger teen will be reviewed actioned under our Inappropriate Sexual Conduct with Children Grooming Policy. Through our thorough work partnership with a prominent child safety organization, we determined that we will, when possible, warn teens who have engaged in sexually explicit behavior before moving to a full ban. An example of this includes teens sharing explicit content with each other that is not their own content. Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM) Child Sexualization Policy Discord has a zero-tolerance policy for child sexual abuse, which does not have a place on ourA platform a anywhere in society. We do not allow CSAM on Discord, including AI-generated photorealistic CSAM. When such imagery is found, imagery is reported to National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC). This ensures that sexualization of children in any context is not normalized by bad actors. Inappropriate Sexual Conduct with Teens Grooming Policy Discord has a zero-tolerance policy for inappropriate sexual conduct with children grooming. Grooming is inappropriate sexual contact between adults teens on platform, with special attention given to predatory behaviors such as online enticement sexual extortion of children, commonly referred to as asextortion.a When we become aware of these types of incidents, we take appropriate action, including banning accounts of offending adult users reporting them to NCMEC, which subsequently works with local law enforcement.A How We Work to Keep Our Younger Users Safe Our Safety team works hard to find remove abhorrent, harmful content, take action including banning users responsible engaging with proper authorities. Discordas Safety by Design practice includes a risk assessment process during product development cycle that helps identify mitigate potential risks to user safety. We recognize that teens have unique vulnerabilities in online settings this process allows us to better safeguard their experience. Through this process, we think carefully about how product features might disproportionately impact teens consider whether product facilitates more teen-to-adult interactions and/or any unintended harm. Our teams identify strategize ways to mitigate safety risks with internal safety technology solutions during this process through getting insight recommendations from external partners. Discord uses a mix of proactive reactive tools to remove content that violates our policies, from use of advanced technology like machine learning models PhotoDNA image hashing to partnering with community moderators to uphold our policies providing in-platform reporting mechanisms to surface violations. Our Terms of Service require people to be over a minimum age (13, unless local legislation mandates an older age) to access our website. We use an age gate that asks users to provide their date of birth upon creating an account. If a user is reported as being under 13, we delete their account. Users can only appeal to restore their account by providing an official ID document to verify their age.A Additionally, we require that all age-restricted content is placed in a channel clearly labeled as age-restricted, which triggers an age gate, preventing users under 18 from accessing that content. newest launches of safety products are focused on helping to safeguard teen experience with our safety alerts on senders that educate teens on ways they can control their experience limit unwanted contact. Additionally, sensitive content filters provide additional controls for teens to blur block unwanted content. Rather than assigning prescriptive solutions for teens, we aim to empower teens with respect for their agency, privacy, decision-making power. Additionally, we are expanding our own Trusted Reporter Network in collaboration with INHOPE for direct communication with expert third parties, including researchers, industry peers, journalists for intelligence sharing. Our Technology Solutions Machine learning has proven to be an essential component of safety solutions at Discord. Since our acquisition of Sentropy, a leader in AI-powered moderation systems, we have continued to balance technology with judgment contextual assessment of highly trained employees, along with continuing to maintain our strong stance on user privacy. Below is an overview of some of our key investments in technology: Teen Safety Assist: Teen Safety Assist is focused on further protecting teens by introducing a new series of features, including multiple safety alerts sensitive content filters that will be default-enabled for teen users. Safety Rules Engine: Safety Rules Engine allows our teams to evaluate user activities on platform, including registrations, server joins, other metadata. We then analyze patterns of problematic behavior to make informed decisions take uniform actions like user challenges bans. AutoMod: Automod is a powerful tool for community moderators to automatically filter unwanted messages with certain keywords, block profiles that may be impersonating a server admin appear harmful to their server, detect harmful messages using machine learning. This technology empowers community moderators to keep their communities safe without having to spend long hours manually reviewing removing unwanted content on their servers. Visual safety platform: Discord has continued to invest in improving image classifiers for content such as sexual, gore, violent media. With these, our machine learning models are being improved to reach higher precision detection rates with lower error rates decrease teen exposure to potentially inappropriate mature content. We proactively scan images uploaded to our platform using PhotoDNA to detect child sexual abuse material (CSAM) report any CSAM content perpetrators to NCMEC, who subsequently work with local law enforcement to take appropriate action. Investing in technological advancements tools to proactively detect CSAM grooming is a key priority for us, we have a dedicated team to handle related content. In Q2 2023, we proactively removed 99% of servers found to be hosting CSAM. You can find more information in Discordas latest Transparency Report. There is constant innovation taking place within beyond Discord to improve how companies can effectively scale deliver content moderation. Our approach will continue to evolve as time goes on, as weare constantly finding new ways to do better for our users. Evolving our Policies to Keep You Safe Threats, Hate Speech, Violent Extremism Hate harm targeted at individuals communities is not tolerated on Discord in any way, combating this behavior content is a top priority for us. We evolved our Threats Policy to address threats of harm to others. Under this policy, we will take action against direct indirect threats, veiled threats, those who encourage this behavior, conditional statements to cause harm. We also refined our Hate Speech Policy with input from a group of experts who study identity intersectionality came from a variety of different identities backgrounds themselves. Under this policy, we define ahate speecha as any form of expression that denigrates, vilifies, dehumanizes; promotes intense, irrational feelings of enmity hatred; incites harm against people based on protected characteristics. In addition, weave expanded our list of protected characteristics to go beyond what most hate speech laws cover to include following: age; caste; color; disability; ethnicity; family responsibilities; gender; gender identity; housing status; national origin; race; refugee immigration status; religious affiliation; serious illness; sex; sexual orientation; socioeconomic class status; source of income; status as a victim of domestic violence, sexual violence, stalking; and, weight size. A Last year, we wrote about how we address Violent Extremism on Discord. We are deeply committed to our work in this space have updated our Violent Extremism Policy to prohibit any kind of support, promotion, organization of violent extremist groups ideologies. We worked closely with a violent extremism subject-matter expert to update this policy will continue to work with third-party organizations like Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism European Union Internet Forum to ensure it is enforced properly. Financial Scams, Fraud Services, Malicious Conduct During 2022, we invested significantly in how we combat criminal activity on Discord. In February, we released two blogs to help users identify protect themselves against scams on Discord. We will take action against users who engage in reselling stolen ill-gotten digital goods are involved in coordinated efforts to defraud businesses engage in price gouging, forgery, money laundering. We also do not allow any kind of activity that could damage compromise security of an account, computer network, system under our updated Malicious Conduct Policy. We will take action against users who use Discord to host distribute malware, carry out phishing attempts denial-of-service attacks against others. How Discord Prevents Removes Spam We invested a substantial amount of time resources into combating spam in 2022, disabling 141,087,602 accounts for spam spam-related offenses, with a proactive removal rate of 99%, before we receive a user report. We observed a significant increase in number of accounts disabled during third quarter of 2022, leading to an elevated but lower fourth quarter, then to a substantial decrease in first quarter of 2023. These trends can be attributed to both increased ongoing investments in our anti-spam team a shift in our approach to reducing number of disabled accounts by placing greater confidence in our proactive spam mitigations avoiding false positives. As a result, only .004% of accounts disabled submitted an appeal during past quarter. Spammers are constantly evolving adapting to new technologies methods of detection, moving to use new parts of platform to target users. Combating spam requires a multi-faceted approach that employs new tools technologies, while also remaining vigilant adaptable to changing trends. We're constantly updating our approach to remove spam, as our proactive efforts have increased, we've observed a steady decline in number of reports we receive for spam. a above trends were made possible over past year due to a number of technological advances in both back-end front-end features, products, tools to help prevent remove spam from Discord. Discord is committed to combating spam building a safer environment for people to find belonging. We've grown our teams, shipped new features, products, tools, continue to listen closely to users about how spam impacts their experience on Discord. We're constantly updating our approach to remove spam remain vigilant adaptable to changing trends. We will continue to prioritize safety work hard to combat spam in order to help make Discord best place for people communities to hang out online. How We Leverage Machine Learning to Fight Child Sexual Abuse Material Weare bridging a key gap in CSAM detection To understand how tech industry is working to solve these challenges, itas helpful to understand technology itself. industry standard for CSAM detection is a tool called PhotoDNA, which was developed by Microsoft donated to National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC)athe nationally recognized hub for reporting suspected online child sexual exploitation in US. When imagery depicting child sexual abuse is reported to NCMEC, PhotoDNA is used to create a unique digital signature (or ahasha) of that image. That hashaand not illegal imagery itselfais stored in a database that serves as a reference point for online detection efforts. At Discord, we proactively scan images using hashing algorithms (including PhotoDNA) to detect known CSAM. For example, if someone uploads an image that matches against known CSAM that has been previously reported, we automatically detect it, remove it, flag it for internal review. When we confirm that someone attempted to share illegal imagery, we remove content, permanently ban them from our platform, report them to NCMEC, who subsequently works with law enforcement.A There are more than 6.3 million hashes of CSAM in NCMECas hash database more than 29 million hashes of CSAM contained in databases from around world. That gives tech industry a strong foundation for stopping spread of this harmful material on our platforms. But thereas one key limitation: it only detects exact similar copies of images that are already logged in database. This means that predatory actors will try to exploit this weakness with unknown CSAM that has yet to be seen logged, indicating that there is either a likelihood of active abuse, images were synthetically generated using AI. Machine learning helps us stop CSAM at scale Unknown CSAM has continually plagued our industry our team felt it was important to advance our own detection capabilities. We started with an open-source model that can analyze images to understand what they are depicting. Our engineers experimented found that we could use this model to not only determine how similar one image is to another, but due to semantic understanding of model, it also demonstrated promising results for novel CSAM detection. When we find a match, we follow same process that we use for PhotoDNA matches: A human reviews it to verify if it is an instance of CSAM. If it is, itas reported to NCMEC added to PhotoDNA database. From that point, newly verified image can be detected automatically across platforms. This speeds up review process, expands database of known CSAM, makes everyone better faster at blocking CSAM over time. This is a major advancement in effort to detect, report, stop spread of CSAM. At a recent Tech Coalition hackathon, engineers from Discord other tech companies collaborated on ways we can work together to identify new forms of CSAM that evade existing detection methods. During this collaboration, we were able to work to make AI-powered detection mechanism we built open-source. At Discord, we believe safety shouldnat be proprietary a competitive advantage. Our hope is that by making this technology open source, we can bring new capabilities protections to all tech platforms, especially newer companies that donat yet have established trust safety teams. This is part of our work alongside Lantern program, which is committed to stopping people from evading CSAM detection across platforms. Together, weare working to increase prevention detection methods, accelerate identification processes, share information on predatory tactics, strengthen our collective reporting to authorities. Ultimately, this is an ideal use of machine learning technology. Itas important to note, though, that human expertise judgment is still involved. Our expert staff continues to review anything thatas not an exact match with PhotoDNA, because stakes are high we need to get it right. What matters most is that combined efforts of machine learning human expertise are making it harder than ever for predatory actors to evade detection. Weare working to build a safer internet. Itas in our DNA. Safety is a top priority at Discord. Itas reflected in our personnel: roughly 15% of our staff is dedicated to safety. These teams work to ensure our platform, features, policies result in a positive safe place for our users to hang out build community. Weare stronger together safety landscape is continually shifting. There are always new challenges emerging, no single entity can tackle them alone. Our industry can lead by sharing tools, intelligence, best practices. We also need to work collaboratively with policymakers, advocacy groups, academics to fully understand emerging threats respond to them. Initiatives like Lantern organizations like Tech Coalition represent kind of collaborative efforts that make it possible for us all to better stay ahead of bad actors work together towards a universally safe online experience for everyone. How We Put Safety at Center of Everything We Build What it means to start with safety As soon as we start building something new, we assess risks that might come from it. By starting at concept phase, we can factor safety into everything we do as we design, build, launch, manage a new product. Throughout process, our teams weigh in with specialized knowledge in their domains, including teen safety, counter-extremism, cybercrime, security, privacy, spam. Functionally, this is how we pinpoint any gaps that may exist as we build products features that make Discord a fun, safe place to hang out with friends. Four key questions for building safer products Any time we build something, we prioritize four key questions to determine our approach to building safer products: There are some things we consider with each product. Weall look, for instance, at our data to learn more about most common kinds of violations that are related to what weare building. That can help us understand most harmful most abundant violations we know about today. But our products donat all have same behaviors content, so we canat just copy-paste our work from one tool to another. Think of Family Center voice messages, for example. They have unique purposes functions, so we needed different answers to each of questions above as we built them. By starting with these questions on day one, we were able to make right decisions for each tool at each step of process maximize our approach to safety in end. By following this approach, everyone involved in making our products has a clear-eyed honest understanding of risks that could potentially arise from our work. We make intentional decisions to minimize those risks commit to only releasing something if it meets our high standard of safety. What starting with safety looks like in practice Letas look a little deeper at voice messages, feature that lets you record audio on your phone easily send it to your friends. Hereas a brief rundown of how we incorporated safety conversations into every aspect of bringing this fun tool to life. At earliest stage, product team drew up preliminary specifications consulted with trust safety subject matter experts on staff. product manager shared specs with individuals from policy legal teams, with a focus on flagging any concerns discrepancies regarding Discordas own policies. Once initial feedback was incorporated, product manager created an action plan, bringing on engineers who began building feature. Even during this stage, safety experts were part of process. In fact, it was here that members of safety team called for an additional requirementaa way for us to handle large amounts of audio messages. Just as users can report written messages, they also can report audio messages for content that violates our policies. Our safety teams needed to ensure we had a way to review those reports effectively as they flow in. In this instance, team had to figure out how audio review process would even work. Would reviewers have to sit listen to hours of reported messages each day? That didnat seem viable, so core team decided to use existing text tools that could transcribe reported messages. Now reviewers can evaluate text quickly, review audio for additional context. Once again, product manager engineers worked closely with safety team to include building in this additional layer of safety. Just because our voice messages feature is live doesnat mean our safety job is complete. We need to understand how effective our methods are, so weave developed metrics that track safety give us insight into impacts of decisions weave made. We track, for instance, if we have unusual rates of flagged content appeals on decisions, as well as breakdown of various violations on our platform. We summarize these metrics in our quarterly Transparency Reports. What it doesnat look like To better understand our safety-centric approach, consider alternative. A different platform could start with an innovative idea best intentions. It could build product it thinks would be most exciting for users, review risk safety implications when itas ready to go live. If company identifies risks at a late stage, it has to decide what to address before releasing product to world. This can happen is flawed. If youare already at finish line when you notice risks youave created, you might realize you have to start over to do it right. Building a product this way is risky, users are ones most exposed to those risks. How Discord starts with safety At Discord, we understand that we have to think about safety growth holistically. Discord is built differently from other platforms. We don't chase virality impressions. Discord makes money by providing users a great experience through premium subscriptions. Under this model, we can focus on our users have more freedom to prioritize safety. Put simply, weare only interested in growing a platform thatas safe. Weare here to help people forge genuine friendships, we know that can only happen when people feel safe connecting with one another. Weave gathered these resources to help give you a head start: Making your hangouts on Discord more private secure Weare excited to announce that starting today, weare rolling out passwordless login with biometric passkeys to streamline safeguard your sign-in experience as well as default end-to-end encryption for audio video (E2EE A/V) calls. Read on to see how these two features will help make your time on Discord safer, for both you your friends on call! Passwordless Login Passwords are annoying to remember are not most secure (yes, that includes awumpu2-1s-c00la). We provide various forms of multi-factor authentication (MFA) to protect your account, but we wanted to continue to prioritize security with a more seamless experience. Now, you can register a passkey to your Discord account, secured by on-device biometric features such as Face ID Touch ID, to sign in with just one easy step. Discord canat access your biometric data, helps ensure that nobody but you can use your passkey to sign into your account. Your passkey lives on your device, allowing you to seamlessly sign into Discord on any device that has access to that passkey. Thatas a win-win-win for privacy, security, a seamless user experience. Passwordless login with a passkey keeps your account as protected as possible. You can learn more about setting up a biometric passkey how to then log in with that passkey here. End-to-End Encryption for Audio & Video (E2EE A/V) Last summer we began experimenting with encryption protocols technologies for audio video calls, we are excited to announce roll out of our E2EE A/V protocol. Today, weall start automatically migrating audio video calls in DMs, Group DMs, voice channels, Go Live streams to a new system that utilizes E2EE A/V. Youall also be able to verify your end-to-end encrypted call identity of other members in it, giving you peace of mind no one else can listen in. When we consider adding new privacy features like E2EE A/V, we do not do so in isolation from safety. That is why safety is integrated across our product policies, why messages on Discord are unencrypted. Messages will still be subject to our content moderation approach, allowing us to continue offering additional safety protections.A Privacy is an essential part of feeling secure, we want to be transparent about security technology we use. Thatas why weave also published a technical blog to provide more insight into work, how we got here, our design implementation goals, technical overview of how we built our E2EE A/V protocol. You can also see how weave worked closely with external experts to assess risks develop robust safeguards to build our protocol. Discord is a place where you can be authentic should feel safe when talking with your friends - this includes maintaining account security protecting your privacy. Passwordless login makes sure no baddies can worm their way into your Discord account, end-to-end encryption has arrived to help keep audio video calls between you your friends private. To enable passwordless login, just head into User Settings > Account find section called aSecurity Keysa to get started! E2EE A/V is on by default for up-to-date Discord clients on desktop mobile, support for other clients such as web consoles will roll out next year. You can head here to learn how to verify your E2EE A/V calls are truly end-to-end encrypted.A Obsessed with security privacy? So are we aweall continue to prioritize build products that respect both. Navigating Online Boundaries With Your Teen Weare committed to making Discord a safe place for teens to hang out with their friends online. While theyare doing their thing weare doing our part to keep them safe, sometimes itas hard for parents to know whatas actually going on in their teensa online lives. Teens navigate online world with a level of expertise that is often underestimated by adults in their lives. For parents, it may be a hard lesson to fathomathat their teens know best. But why wouldnat they? Every teen is their own leading expert in their life experiences (as we all are!). But growing up online, this generation is particularly adept at what it means to make new friends, find community, express their authentic selves, test boundariesaall online. But that doesnat mean teens donat need adultsa help when it comes to setting healthy digital boundaries. it doesnat mean parents canat be a guide for cultivating safe, age-appropriate spaces. Itas about finding right balance between giving teens agency while creating right moments to check in with them. One of best ways to do that is to encourage more regular, open honest conversations with your teen about staying safe online. Here at Discord, weave developed tools to help that process, like our Family Center: an opt-in program that makes it easy for parents guardians to be informed about their teenas Discord activity while respecting their autonomy. Here are a few more ways to kick off online safety discussions. If a teen feels like they could get in trouble for something, they wonat be honest with you. So go into these conversations from a place of curiosity first, rather than judgment. Here are a few conversation-starters: Teens will be less likely to share if they feel like parents just donat get it, so asking open questions like these will foster more conversation. Questions rooted in blame can also backfire: teen may not be as forthcoming because they feel like adult is already gearing up to punish them. Read more helpful prompts for talking with your teen about online safety in our Discord Safety Center. Our goal at Discord is to make it a place where teens can talk hang out with their friends in a safe, fun way. Itas a place where teens have power agency, where they get to feel like they own something. Just because your teen is having fun online doesn't mean you have to give up your parental role. Parents trusted adults in a teenas life are here to coach guide them, enabling them to explore themselves find out who they areawhile giving them parameters by which to do so. On Discord, some of those boundaries could include: Using Discordas Family Center feature so you can be more informed involved in your teensa online life without prying. Our Response to Pentagon Leaks Summary of Current Situation Because investigations are ongoing, we can only share limited details. Our Terms of Service expressly prohibit using Discord for illegal criminal purposes. This includes sharing of documents that may be verifiably classified. Unlike overwhelming majority of people who find community on Discord, this group departed from norms, broke our rules, did so in apparent violation of law. Our mission is for Discord to be place to hang out with friends online. With that mission comes a responsibility to make Discord a safe positive place for our users. For example, our policies clearly outline that hate speech, threats violent extremism have no place on our platform. When Discordas Trust Safety team learns of content that violates our rules, we act quickly to remove it. In this instance, we have banned users involved with original distribution of materials, deleted content deemed to be against our Terms, issued warnings to users who continue to share materials in question. Our Approach to Delivering a Positive User Experience This recent incident fundamentally represents a misuse of our platform a violation of our platform rules. Our Terms of Service Community Guidelines provide universal rules for what is acceptable activity content on Discord. When we become aware of violations to our policies, we take action. core of our mission is to give everyone power to find create belonging in their lives. Creating a safe environment on Discord is essential to achieve this, is one of ways we prevent misuse of our platform. Safety is at core of everything we do a primary area of investment as a business: fight against bad actors on communications platforms is unlikely to end soon, our approach to safety is guided by following principles: Underpinning all of this are two important considerations: our overall approach towards content moderation our investments in technology solutions to keep our users safe. Our Response to Tragedy in Buffalo Our Work With Lantern, First Child Safety Cross-Platform Signal Sharing Program Some of most recognizable names in tech such as Snap, Google, Twitch, Meta, Discord unveiled Lantern, a pioneering initiative aimed at thwarting child predators who exploit platform vulnerabilities to elude detection. This vital project marks a significant stride forward in safeguarding children who on average spend up to nine hours a day online. It underscores a critical truth: protecting our children in digital realm is a shared responsibility, necessitating a unified front from both tech behemoths emerging players. digital landscape must be inherently safe, embedding privacy security at its core, not merely as an afterthought. This philosophy propelled my journey to Discord, catalyzed by a profound personal reckoning. In 2017, harrowing discussions about children's online experiences triggered a series of panic attacks for me, leading to a restless quest for solutions. This path culminated, with a gentle nudge from my wife, in creation of a company that used AI to detect online abuse make internet safer for everyone, which was later acquired by Discord. This mission has been remains personal for me! Discord, now an eight-year-old messaging service with mobile, web, stand-alone apps over 150 million monthly users, transcends being just a platform. It's a sanctuary, a space where communities, from gamers to study groups, notably LGBTQ+ teens, find belonging safety. Our ethos is distinct: we don't sell user data clutter experiences with ads. Discord isnat place you go to get famous attract followers. We align our interests squarely with our users, fostering a safe authentic environment. However, our non-social media identity doesn't preclude collaboration with social media companies in safeguarding online spaces. Just as physical venues like airports, stadiums hospitals require tailored security measures, so too do digital platforms need safety solutions that meet their unique architecture. With all different ways that kids experience life online, a one-size-fits-all approach simply wonat work. This is not a solitary endeavor but a collective, industry-wide mandate. Innovating in safety is as crucial as in product features, requiring open-source sharing of advancements knowledge. For example, our team at Discord has independently developed new technologies to better detect child sexual abuse material (CSAM), have chosen to make them open-source so that other platforms can use this technology without paying a penny. tech industry must confront head-on most severe threats online, including sexual exploitation illegal content sharing. Parents rightfully expect digital products used by their children to embody these safety principles. Lantern is a pivotal advancement in this ongoing mission. Yet, as technology evolves, introducing AI, VR, other innovations, safety landscape continually shifts, presenting new challenges that no single entity can tackle alone. millions tech sector invests must be used to ensure users on our platforms are actually safe, not to persuade Washington that theyare safe. Our industry can lead by sharing with each other working collaboratively with legislators, advocacy groups, academics. Collaboration is keyaamong tech companies, legislators, advocacy groups, academicsa to ensure a universally safe online experience for our children. essence of online safety lies in an unprecedented collaborative effort globally. launch of Lantern is not just a step but a leap forward, signaling a new era of shared responsibility action in digital world. Itas time for us to focus on a safer tomorrow! Parents & Educators, Join Us on Discord! Safer Internet Day 2025 IntroducingA ROOST As technologies continue to evolve, so does dynamic safety landscape. This presents new challenges that no entity can tackle alone, so continued industry investment in safety features is imperative to make Internet a safer place for all. Today, Discord other founding partners a including OpenAI, Google, Roblox, Eric Schmidt, John S. James L. Knight Foundation, AI Collaborative, Patrick J. McGovern Foundation, Project Liberty Institute - unveiled a new cross-industry non-profit foundation called ROOST. ROOST - Robust Open Online Safety Tools - addresses a critical gap in child safety digital safety by providing free, open-source safety tools to organizations of all sizes. This will alleviate need for organizations to reinvent wheel in building tools that already exist, empowering them - especially smaller companies public interest organizations - to focus on growing their platforms services while promoting safety for online users. ROOST will offer free, open source easy-to-use tools to detect, review, report child sexual abuse material (CSAM), leverage large language models to power safety infrastructure, make core safety technologies more accessible more user friendly. With dedicated technical teams providing hands-on support, ROOST meets organizations where they are, helping them integrate robust safety measures while continuing to innovate. In addition to being a founding partner, Discordas Chief Legal Officer Clint Smith will serve as Board Chair of ROOST Discord is contributing funding, technology, employee expertise to foundation. This builds on progress momentum weave seen over past year in industry collaboration - signal sharing on bad actors via Tech Coalitions' Lantern initiative, codifying safety best practices via Digital Trust & Safety Partnership, training thousands of career professionals from around world through Trust & Safety Professional Association TrustCon. Discord is proud to be a part of this effort, helping to foster innovation, urgently bring new safety tools to market. Members of Discordas Safety Reporting Network have access to a prioritized reporting channel, and, once our Safety team is made aware of a policy violation, we may take a range of actions, including: removing content, banning users, shutting down servers, when appropriate, engaging with proper authorities. Supreme Court Decision Reaffirms Discordas Right to Keep Your Online Spaces Safe Terms of Service Feedback Changes Context What changed? On October 16th, 2018, we added an arbitration class action waiver clause. To summarize, this clause states that when thereas a disagreement between Discord you, weall use an alternative dispute resolution process known as arbitration. Why did we change it? current legal landscape in United States is such that class action lawsuits can be abused. This clause was added because we are now operating a game store subscription service for profit. Like many other companies, we are now a target for entities who wish to abuse class action lawsuit. If youad like to learn more about legal landscape, arbitration, potential abuse of class action lawsuits, weave included a handful of links in Resources section at bottom of this post. What does that mean for you? We think that people can disagree on whether not arbitration is good in general whether not class action system is one that is beneficial; we donat think itas completely black white. In fact, weare very interested in how Europe is approaching implementing class action lawsuits, as their approach may mitigate issues that United States faces with them. Because we donat think itas black white, one of things that weave implemented (which some of our competitors do not), is to allow you to opt out of this clause completely. We encourage you to opt out if you wish. You wonat be penalized in any way if you do so. At no point will we ever gate any features take any action on users because theyave opted out of arbitration. Changes following changes will be live sometime before October 20th, 2018. United States Exclusivity As we stated above in aWhy did we change it,a our motivation for this change is because of legal climate in United States. To protect our users outside United States, weave decided to modify this clause so that it only affects users in United States. If you are outside of United States, this clause does not apply to you. This means users outside United States do not need to opt out if they were wanting to. Opt Out Extension Furthermore, every user was (or will be if they havenat logged in yet) notified of changes to our Terms of Service on date they were updated by a blue notification bar at top of Discord client. In hindsight, we should have provided notice of these changes much further in advance, so we apologize for that. That said, much of feedback weave received is that our community was not aware of these changes. To provide more opportunity for those who wish to opt out for those who may have overlooked notification bar, weave extended our opt out period from initial 30 days to 90 days. How do I opt out? Stated in our Terms of Service under DISPUTE RESOLUTION: Your opt out doesnat need any specific template form. It just needs request to opt out it must come from email associated with your Discord account. We want to reiterateaaayou will not be penalized in any way for opting out of arbitration. Again, we encourage you to do so if you wish to. a Wrapping Up Thanks again for your feedbackaaaitas important to us as a company that we hear from our community. We really appreciate that you all care so much to voice your opinions. If you have any further questions, please send an email to privacy@discordapp.com weall be happy to answer! a Resources a Teachable Moments Hidden in Plain Sight Using research to help teens build their 'safety muscle' To do that, Discord works with organizations like Digital Wellness Lab at Boston Childrenas Hospital National PTA to understand needs of one of our largest user bases. aWe are experts in technology, not experts in teenagers. So we need to make sure we are pulling in expert research when we're thinking about what it means to be a safe, healthy ultimately, empowering place for young people,a said Liz Hegarty, Discordas global teen safety policy manager.A A Hegarty her colleagues are guided by research, which is empathetic to teens' lived experiences cautions against being overly paternalistic. For example, Digital Wellness Lab advises parents to resist urge to step in solve every problem for their teen, online off. Instead, they recommend asking probing questions talking through decision-making process. This can clear way to have more conversations about digital boundaries. aThese conversations can help teens build their safety musclea, said Hegarty. We built our Family Center with this idea in mind. Launched in 2023, Family Center is an opt-in tool that enables guardians, trusted adults, teens to alinka their accounts. While it allows parents to know who their teen is connected with, tool does not allow adults to see contents of their teenas conversations with friends. aThe key is to find balance between respecting teen autonomy agency while also giving parents ways to check in with their teensa, said Savannah Badalich, Discordas senior director of policy. aParents trusted adults in a teen's life are here to coach them,a said Badalich, who leads team responsible for key safety areas, such as teen safety mental health. aLet them explore themselves, let them find who they are. But give them parameters in which to do so.a There is a risk that a teen may choose not to talk at all if they feel they are being constantly monitored. This is why it's important to follow research. aLeading experts say that sort of parental surveillance does not always help generate safety create a trustworthy environment for teens to talk to their caregivers,a Hegarty said. Hegarty notes that when building Family Center tool, Discord decided to add an additional layer of support. As a teen connects with their parents, Discord surfaces information for Crisis Text Line (note that this is for users in U.S. only). This is a support line that provides free, 24/7 mental health support via text, WhatsApp, web chat. idea is to provide available resources to teens to encourage them to seek help if they need it. Itas another way we embed subtle lessons throughout experience. Weaving in teachable moments Discordas Teen Safety Assist includes two recently released safety features: one for when a teen receives a direct message (DM) from a user for first time, another that blurs potentially sensitive content in DMs group DMs with friends. When an alert is triggered, teen might see a pop-up that says, Unwanted message? If you donat want to chat with this person, you can block mute them.A They can then click to alearn more,a see a message that prompts aUnwanted message?a, as well as provides a set of tips for handling situation.a a aIt's this idea of educating as opposed to just punishing teenagers when they make mistakes,a said Hegarty. aIn moment, itas important to give teens resources, autonomy, agency, help.a Hegarty points to research about how teens are nervous to block other people. They're worried if person finds out they're blocked, teen is going to look uncool. Meanwhile, if they report, they arenat sure what will happen next. They are anxious about getting somebody in trouble. Research from Thorn, a leading child welfare nonprofit, also suggests that when teens encounter a potentially harmful experience online, they are less likely to seek support offline, such as talking to a trusted adult. So Discord is trying to meet teens where they are. aIt's not a paternalistic approach that protects teens from everything. Being overly restrictive risks them lacking necessary skills to move within world once they turn 18,a said Badalich. aInstead, let's educate them throughout their experience. Let's give them tools to control their experience.a Giving teens opportunities to learn Risk-taking is part of growing up. Itas part of being a teenager. aBecause their brain is still developing, they need options, time education,a said Badalich, whose team is also working to sharpen Discordas enforcement system with teens in mind. When it comes to developing policies rules that govern platform, Badalich her team are rethinking what that looks like, with understanding that teens need extra opportunities to learn. aKeep up, take down, ban have been main levers. we're continuing to explore even more ways to take necessary action,a said Badalich. For example, aWhen you think about someone talking about self-harm, do we really want to penalize them? do we want to figure out some other form of intervention?a To be clear, when it comes to most severe violationsasuch as those involving violent extremism content that sexualizes childrenaDiscord will continue to have a zero-tolerance policy. But when it comes to building out more nuanced, research-driven policies, policy team looks to lessons from restorative justice, a concept that recognizes that people are capable of change. aInstead of just being purely punitive all of time,a said Badalich, aDiscord wants to move in direction of where we are giving people opportunities to change, grow, learn.a Upholding Our Commitment to Safety in 2023 Beyond Product Developments Discordas ground-up approach to safety starts with our product features. Not only do we intentionally build products that help to keep our users safer, but we also implement a Safety by Design practice, which includes a risk assessment process during product development cycle that helps identify mitigate potential risks to user safety. This year, we made key investments that help teens, parents, all of our users have a positive Discord experience: Partnerships We believe that everyone in industry should share solutions, intelligence, technology, which is why we continued to invest in furthering our partnerships with a number of safety organizations this year. These organizations help us to keep our platform internet safer by supplementing our expertise insights helping us to continue to advance cutting edge safety efforts. As part of our extensive fight against child sexual abuse material (CSAM), we continued to deepen our partnership with Tech Coalition. I joined Tech Coalitionas Board of Directors am excited to help shape organizationas future continue to collaborate with industry leaders to combat online sexual abuse exploitation. One of most exciting parts of our partnership with Tech Coalition this year was launch of Lantern, a first-of-its-kind signal sharing program for companies to enhance strengthen how we detect attempts to sexually exploit abuse children teens online. Discord joined other industry partners like Google, Mega, Meta, Quora, Roblox, Snap, Twitch to share signals about activity we detect that violates our policies utilize signals shared by other companies to surface violating activity on their platforms. We also expanded our partnership with INHOPE, a global network combatting CSAM online. Through this partnership, we are better able to collaborate with hotlines globally working to address this important issue. We joined Internet Watch Foundation (IWF), UKas frontline defense against spread of online child sexual abuse imagery. By becoming a member, Discord will be able to deploy IWFas world-leading services to keep platform safer, including IWFas URL List Keywords List, as well as its Non-Photographic URL Hash Lists. Discord also joined Christchurch Call, a community of over 120 members worldwide with a shared goal of eliminating violent extremism online. Partnership transparency are cornerstones of our effort to counter extremism we are committed to working collectively with this global community to make internet world a safer place. Discord is partnering with European Center for Not-for-Profit Law to lead a pilot project to implement their Framework for Meaningful Engagement (FME). ECNLas expertise FME will help us build deploy AI systems in support of our safety work. We continued our important partnership with National PTA around family engagement efforts. Through their Build Up Belong program, we supported local PTAs as they hosted events to help families build healthy digital habits foster productive conversations about navigating online interactions.A Additionally, we are proud board members of Digital Trust & Safety Partnership, which gathers tech platforms to collaborate on publish online safety best practices. This includes conducting audits of our policies processes to ensure safety is built into our systems by design. We also are active members of Trust & Safety Professional Association, an organization that gathers Trust & Safety professionals from around world for training to share best practices across industry. Looking to 2024 beyond As technologies continue to evolve, so does dynamic safety landscape, presenting new challenges that no company government can tackle alone. Continued industry investment in safety features must be made to ensure users on our platforms are safer. We can do this by evolving our features policies to ensure they are up to date, holistic, meet needs of our users; regularly sharing knowledge progress; working collaboratively with each other legislators, advocacy groups, academics, to ensure a safer online experience for everyone. While weave made a lot of progress over last year, we know there is still much more we can must do a on our own in collaboration with others a to combat known new threats. work here never stops. As we look to New Year, my team I are as committed as ever to building on important safety work weave done over past twelve months, we are confident that Discord will continue to be best place for people to have fun online. Welcome to Policy at Discord Working with CARU to protect users on Discord Protecting privacy safety of our users is of utmost importance to Discord. Discord is a communications service for teens adults who are looking to talk with their communities friends online. We do not allow those under age of 13 on our service, we encourage our users to report accounts that may belong to underage individuals. Weare pleased to share that Better Business Bureauas Childrenas Advertising Review Unit (aCARUa) issued a report endorsing our practices relating to childrenas privacy. CARU regularly monitors websites online services for compliance with laws best practices relating to childrenas privacy engaged with Discord as part of its routine monitoring work. CARU finished its review of Discord in October 2020 issued following statement in connection with release of its report: a[T]he outcome we hope for is proactive corporate accountability on childrenas privacy, that is exactly what Discord delivered.a a Dona Fraser, Senior Vice President Privacy Initiatives, Director of Childrenas Advertising Review Unit (CARU). Discord appreciates CARU's thorough evaluation of our service our practices. We look forward to continuing our work to improve online privacy safety. a a
